1.content:
Warily, you closed your eyes, trying to relax. You'd a tough day at school, unsurprising considering that the new school year had began several days earlier. Already, you was wishing for some escape, but a quiet house and time away from your rather girly sisters was the closest thing to it that you could hope for.

Least that what it would normally be like. Your eldest sister, Hayley had disappeared about a year ago, sent to some private school which name you didn't even know, and you hadn't heard anything from her since. That was strange, as you were close, Mainly because she definitely was the tomboy of the family. It was the opposite, least in hobbies, compared of your other two sisters. Your youngest sister, Hannah was the stereotypical girly, princess obsessed brat. At seven, she was either doing ballet, or at a friend's house doing dress up or something like that. As for Melanie, she was your twin sister. Ditzy, blond, and vain, she was at least tolerable towards you. It was strange that she wasn't around; you expected that she would be least in her room, pouting about something but you quickly realized she would be either giving moral support to one of your friends (and crush) Megan Thompson, whom just joined the school's cheerleading squad, or pining over your best friend, Harry Rich.

Smiling slightly, you headed to the fridge and got yourself a snack. Even mom wasn't around, which was unusual. Normally, she was upstairs in her study, but today, there was no sign of her. As you placed your sandwich on a side table, you felt something hard by the side of your chair. Surprised, you leaned over to see what it was. Much to your surprise, it was an old-looking leather bound book. Opening it, you saw on the first page the words Magic Book

"Magic book, huh?" you muttered, wondering what it was doing in your home. Normally, you would had tossed it aside, but there was something compelling about the book. Almost like it called out to you, wanting you to read more of it.

Warning! This book is a magic book and is not meant for male eyes! Do not read anymore of this book unless you're prepared to accept the full consequences of magic.

You take the book to your room, thinking it was a practical joke from one of your sisters. Only you placed a shirt over it to hide it as something in the back of your mind was warning you not to let anyone see you with it. You were so preoccupied with the book that you did not notice the strange little girl sitting on your bed until you turned around. You jumped upon taking notice, causing her to let out a low scream of fright.

"Who are you?" Unnerved, you demanded. "How did you get into my room?"

The girl looked at you as if she were stunned but looked down at herself and sighed. "I- I'm Christina." Timidly, she said. "I'm Harry's cousin from out of town. Please, John... I- I need your help."

"Harry didn't tell me he had a cousin coming for a visit." Raising an eyebrow, you said.

"It's sort of a surprise visit." Wincing, Christina said. "Harry was always telling me how he got into your room so I did it myself."

Seeing the scrapes on Christina's legs and arms, you knew she was telling the truth. Still, you were annoyed she had sneaked into your house and into your room. You sighed. "It's not safe for a girl as small as you to climb that tree." Scolding, you said. "Also, its very strange for a boy like me to have a little girl in his bedroom."

Christina began to tear up so you called for Hayley. When she entered your room, she looked at the little girl in surprise. "Who..."

"She says she's Harry's cousin." Annoyed, you said. "She climbed the tree to get in here. She said she needed my help but I don't know for what."

Hayley sighed, a bemused look on her face. "Come with me... Christina." Kindly, she said. "You should not be in a boy's room; we will talk, girl to girl."

Reluctantly, Christina nodded and slid off your bed. She allowed Hayley to take her hand and was led out of the room. After they were gone, you closed the door but paused as you turned around. You had spotted something lying on your bed. Upon closer inspection, you found it to be a pair of antique glasses.

"Harry's cousin must have dropped it when she slid off my bed." Muttering, you said.

You were going to give them back to her but something compelled you to try them on. Upon doing so, you saw the book you had found glowing slightly. Surprised, you took off the glasses and saw that the glow had vanished. Curious, you put the glasses back on and saw the book glowing again.

"That's weird." Curious, you said. "I wonder..."

There are no shortcuts to magic."

The rest of day wasn't so bad. You got to hang out more with your new friends and they helped you keep away from Tim when you walked down the halls and during lunch. Hanging with the girls made you feel better about your own problems. You even found yourself thinking that staying a six year old girl wouldn't be the worst thing in the world at one point, though you quickly tried to banish that thought from your mind. You managed to get a message to Mom through Hayley that you wanted to sleepover at Liz's house. Mom thought it was a great idea and made arraignments for Haley to bring you a bag of sleepover supplies, toothbrush and night clothes and such.

Pretty soon the day was over, and you found yourself sitting with Liz on the school steps waiting for her mom to pick you two up. She was running a bit late, so you were the only to left. Liz looked apologetic. "Sorry, I should have mentioned my mom's usually late."

"It's fine," you assured her, but you were honestly a little worried Tim was hanging around waiting to jump out at you.

"What do you want to do when we get to my house anyway? We could watch TV, play board games, or I have legos..." That all sounded pretty normal and not super girly. You could use a night like that. Getting away from Tim and your sisters. You could just relax with your new friend. Of course, the next thing she said floored you. "Or we could talk about witch stuff..." Liz said this very casually, as if it were the most normal thing in the world.

You head whipped toward her and your mouth went wide open in surprise. "Wait, what?"

Liz looked at you confused, but then, something occurred to her. "You...didn't know I'm from a witch family? But my last name is Belacourt. Haven't you heard of the Belacourt witch family?"

You shook your head. "No, I didn't and I haven't. I don't really know any of the witch families." Of course, you couldn't escape it. You had about a million questions for her, but didn't know where to start. "Are the other girls from Witch families too?" Ellen had led the charge against Timmy earlier that day. You suddenly wondered if she had an ulterior motive for standing up for you. However, Liz's answer reassured you.

"No, just me. I'm actually really excited to have a friend I can talk to about that stuff with."

You nodded, but fired off another bunch of questions. "Do you know about me? Have you always been a little girl? Your family isn't evil like the some witches, right? Do you have powers yet? Can you turn me back into a boy?" You noticed her face looked overwhelmed. "Sorry. That was a lot of questions."

She nodded, but answered as best she could. "It's okay. I thought you knew all this and just weren't talking about it in front of the others. Well...ummm...yeah, I know about you having been a teenage boy before, and I've always been this age. Or at least, I have been ever since my birthday. You know what I mean. You couldn't change me with magic if you wanted to anyway. My dad's side of the family is super immune to magic, so I got that too." You nodded and she continued. "My family isn't bad or anything like the Banes. My mom is a witch librarian. She collect magic books and stuff and researches spells. She helps other witches find stuff in books. We're witches too, but we don't have very strong magic. We can't turn people into boys and stuff. The most my mom can do is move objects around and change people's hair color and I haven't started learning or anything." She paused before turning a question back at you. "Do you really hate being a little girl that much?"

You knew you had to tread carefully, not wanting to hurt Liz's feeling. You made sure to answer honestly though. "I miss my old friends and the stuff I used to be able to do. This is all so different." You smiled. "But I like hanging out with you and the other girls. You girls are really fun."

Liz smiled back. "I like being with you too." She paused for a minute. "How come Tim is mad at you anyway?"

You sighed. "You know how Stephanie and Rachel used to be Steve and Rick?" Liz nodded. "I'm the one who turned them into girls."

Liz started giggling. "That was you? That was so funny. They've been chasing Tim around and he's so scared of them."

You smiled and then started giggling too. "I guess it was kind of funny. And it did serve all them right. It was a karma spell or something. But I didn't mean to do it, and I don't want them trapped like that, and I've been trying to find a way to turn them back."

Liz nodded. "Maybe my mom can help you. She helps all sorts of witches find spells they need."

"Yeah, maybe..." You don't feel super excited by the idea. Yes, you wanted to turn Steve and Rick back, but you had actually been looking forward to just having a normal, non-magic, sister-free sleepover, even if it involved little girls. Witch stuff always got so complicated. As Liz's mom's car pulled around the corner, you made a decision.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: you're invited over to one of the girl'...

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Liz's mom looked surprised to see you standing with her daughter. "Oh.." she said, surprised. You didn't know whether become she knew who you was, or whether Liz had a friend she wanted to take home.

"Hi, mommy. This is Lucy, we're going to have a sleepover. I've told her about you."

Liz's mom's face darkened almost immediately. "Elizabeth Marie Belacourt! You know you shouldn't talk about such things! Not even to miss Harrison. Yes, I know you're Natalie's daughter. Before you ask, no, I cannot and will not even attempt to change you back. It simply cannot be done."

"I just want a normal afternoon. Well, as normal as possible. No annoying sisters, outraged cousins, and definitely no witch stuff. Its already done enough damage." Liz looked slightly surprised, but not displeased. You knew she would prefer a normal day, too.

Liz's mom stared at you, as if she was evaluating you. After a minute, she said, "I'll give your mother a call. I'm sure she'll send some clothes for you."


After a fifteen minute trip, you arrived at the Belacourt house, and surprisingly, a suitcase was waiting for you. It was girl, super girly, and you knew it was yours. Blushing slightly at the sight, you picked up the case and followed your new friend. Liz lead you to her room, which was as girly as you imagined, and closed the door. "We should get out our school clothes, Lucy. Then we can play" Liz said.

You nodded, though you didn't touch your suitcase. You knew Liz was finding an outfit, and your heart sank when she pulled out two pairs of pink tights and two pink leotards....
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Just have a normal playdate and sleepover

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"We're doing ballet?" you asked, trying not to sound so displeased by the idea you insulted her.

Liz looked at you confused and then looked back at the leotards, and then giggled. "No, you didn't seem excited about ballet at recess, so I wouldn't make you do it. I just thought we could play in the back yard while the sun is still up. I like playing in leotards cause it's easy to practice cartwheels and stuff."

"Oh..." You felt embarrassed that you immediately assumed she was trying to dress you up. "So the second one...?"

"I was trying to decide whether to wear the plain leotard or the one with writing." She held up the two leotards. Indeed one leotard was plain pink, while the other had 'Ballet Princess' written across it in sparkly writing and frilly shoulders poofs. The tights also had subtle differences. "The ballet princess one I just wear for fun. They want you to wear plain-color ones in my ballet class."

You sighed. "Sorry. My sisters and mom keep trying to get me to dress up. Seems like everyone is trying to tell me who to be." Your mind flashed to Elena and Tim, both of whom had different designs of what your fate in life should be.

Liz nodded. "I won't do that. That's not what friends do." You smiled. "I mean if you do want to borrow one of my leotards you can, but I figured you'd rather wear shorts or something."

You took a look at your suitcase, sitting in a corner of her room. A pessimistic part of you guessed that within there lay no shorts. "Do you have shorts I could borrow?" Liz nodded and went into her closet to find some, but you quickly changed your mind. If Liz wasn't trying to force anything upon you, that meant her house was a safe space where you could feel free to experiment a bit, and you were admittedly curious about how being in a leotard would affect your range of movement. "Actually, maybe I will borrow a leotard. But do you have a different color?" A leotard was an experiment enough. You didn't need to add the pink in too.

"Not really. I wore my black one to ballet yesterday, so it needs to be washed, and my blue one has a rip in it." She looked apologetic. "I have a purple one," she added helpfully.

Pink or purple didn't seem like much off a choice. "I'll take the pink one." Liz handed you the plainer of the two pink leotards, correctly assuming you didn't want to be identified as a ballet princess.

"You can use my bathroom to change if you want," Liz offered as she got ready to get changed. She stopped when she noticed you weren't moving. "Ummm...is something wrong?"

You blushed. "I...um...don't actually know how to put all this stuff on. I've worn this kind of stuff before, but only because my sister put it on me with magic."

Liz giggled. "Sorry. Let me get my mom."

---------------------------------------------

Twenty minutes later, you and Liz were dressed in your leotards in the backyard, ready to play. Mrs. Belacourt had helped dress you, showing you along the way how to do it yourself. She was very kind about the whole ordeal, recognizing that learning how to put on a leotard and tights was a little overwhelming for a first-timer. She didn't even get upset when you realized you had to use the bathroom after putting it on, and she had to take the whole ensemble off, then on again. Despite the way, you two met, she seemed like a really sweet lady, who was only worried before that you were using her daughter as a way to get out of your predicament. Now, you appreciated her kindness and she seemed to think you were very polite and sweet.

"How's it feel?" Liz asked as she cartwheeled past you.

You blushed as you plucked the side of your leotard. "I actually kind of like it. Feels smooth and it's easy to move around in." You never would have admitted that to Mel or Hannah or your Mom. Maybe not even Hayley. You didn't really get to enjoy the leotard last time, because you were mad Mel forced you into it, but here you were free to just let go of that frustration and enjoy yourself. "It was a real pain getting it on, but now that's it's on it's really comfy."

Liz grinned as she came back next to you. "I'm glad you like it." She then practiced doing a split on the ground.

"You do gymnastics?" you asked as you poked at the ballet bun Mrs. Belacourt had tied on the back of your head to keep your hair out of your face as you played. It felt strange, but not bad.

Liz nodded. "Yeah, gymnastics and flute once a week. Ballet twice a week." She smiled up at you. "So what do you want to play? I've got a frisbee."

You didn't answer at first, as you watched Liz doing the split. Megan used to take gymnastics as well and she had tried to teach you how to do a split like that when you were a boy. You were never able to do it. You weren't great at cartwheels either. Maybe you could learn to do them now. Or maybe this was a chance to see what ballet was like without your sisters or Tim there to give you grief about it. You liked the leotard, maybe you could see what else you liked.

"Actually," you blushed deep red as you talked. "Maybe you could teach me some...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: wearing the outfit

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Gymnastics"

"Why?" Liz asked, slightly surprised.

You paused, but after a pause of ten seconds, you said, "I could never do it before my transformation, and I want to see if I can now. Besides..."

"Lucy, you're looking secretive" Liz said, interupting as she saw a slight smile forming on your face.

"..I can use it to fight. Nobody would see it coming" you said as you stared at your pink clas body

"You want to fight?" Liz said, slightly appalled.

"Not if I not have to. I don't want the whole 'its not ladylike' talk. I wanna be able to fight off Tim if he does something stupid" you admitted.

"I can see why" Liz admitted, "But why did you blush?"

"I don't want mommy to get any ideas" you said, staring at Liz's 'ballet princess' leotard. "Plus, you like it"

Liz's slight frown quickly turned into a smile. "What do you want to learn first? Handstands, or cartwheels?"

"Cartwheels" you said, as Liz did a flip. It was't perfect, but it was decent enough. You paused, tried one.. and overbalanced. Falling onto your shoulder, you gave Liz an annoyed look.

"I fall all the time. Try again" Liz urged. You nodded, and tried again. After thirty minutes, you had improved slightly, but was still mostly falling. Still, it was enjoyable. "Liking it, Lucy?" You nodded.

"We better get inside. Wanna watch a movie?"

choices: Mrs. Belacourt calls Natalie to let her know how things went
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
The rest of the evening went well. You and Liz watched Aladdin, and the two of you ended up singing and dancing around to the songs. You met Mr. Belacourt when he came home from work. He was a quiet, but sweet man, who was happy to see that his daughter had made a new friend who seemed so comfortable with. It turned out Mr. Belacourt was a great cook too, making you some the most delicious mac and cheese you had ever had. After dinner, the two of you finally got changed out of your leotards and into your nightclothes. Mom had packed your a powder blue nightgown with lace trim, which wasn't the worst thing you could have worn, you supposed. After that you and Liz stayed up for another hour just talking about anything you could thing of: friends at school, favorite movies, witchcraft, whatever. Eventually, it was time for sleep.

Before you fell asleep, Liz turned toward and said with a smile and a yawn, "I'm really glad you came tonight Lucy."

You nodded and smiled. "Me too. If I'm going to be a girl, I'm glad I have a friend like you." You paused. "Please never tell my sisters I wore the leotard." You looked at Liz only to see she was already asleep. You weren't sure how much of what you said she heard. You smiled and stared up at the ceiling, thinking about what a good day it had been.

----------------------------------

Around eleven, just before she went to bed, Mrs. Belacourt peeked into Liz's room to check on the two of you. She found Liz fast asleep in her bed, but you were in a nearby armchair, producing a green flame in your hand. You stared at the flame transfixed, watching the fire dance. Mrs. Belacourt frowned and approached you. You noticed her and blushed, but didn't put the flame out.

"What are you doing, Lucy?" You had expected her to annoyed at you for being awake or for using magic unsupervised, but her voice was kind. She seemed concerned, not mad, and you felt like you could confide in her.

"Sorry, I couldn't sleep, so I was just practicing making a flame."

Mrs. Belacourt smiled. "Well, that much I can see, but why?" She noticed you glance over at Liz. "Don't worry about waking her. She can sleep through anything."

You nodded in understanding and shared what was on your mind. "Well, I really had fun today, you know? Liz is so nice and I really like being with her. I could just have fun without worrying about what my sisters or stupid Tim might say about me or tell me who to be. Turning into a girl has been really hard."

Mrs. Belacourt nodded. "I would certainly think so."

You continued. "But since I had so much fun today, I thought maybe it would be easier if I just enjoyed being a girl and wasn't thinking all the time about the fact that I used to be a stupid boy." You looked back at the flame. "And my mom said, the more I use magic, the more I'll start to think like a girl, so I thought..." You stopped there.

"You thought you'd get rid of all those boy feelings that are making you frustrated." You nodded, feeling embarrassed. Mrs. Belacourt stroked your hair. "Oh, sweetie. It's okay." She collected her thoughts, deciding how to approach this. "Feel any girlier?"

You shook your head. "Not really." You sighed and let the flame go out, giving up.

Mrs. Belacourt smiled. "I wouldn't think so. Lucy, I've done a lot of research on witch boys who become girls, and while a lot of people do think that simply using any kind of magic will make a more...feminine frame of mind take hold, I don't believe that is the case."

"You don't?" You were sure how you felt about that.

"No. Magic responds to the wishes we have. So I believe a lot of witch boys unknowingly used magic to change their minds into something more suited to their new form. It was a subconscious wish, and if a transformed boy wished to be more like a girl, their magic would make it so."

You took the information in. "So why's it not working for me?"

"Because you don't really want that. You seem like a very free-thinking and thoughtful kid, Lucy. I don't think you want to just magically think like a girl. I think you want to discover who you are as a girl, without the help of magic."

"I...guess that makes sense," you decided.

She smiled. "So tell me...what have you found out about yourself today?"

You thought about it and began to make a list. "Well, I like wearing leotards. There are girls at school I like talking to. Liz is really fun and a good friend. And I want to get good at gymnastics."

Mrs. Belacourt ruffled your hair. "Now that sounds like a lot of great stuff you learned about yourself, don't you think? And that will help you going forward."

You smiled at this realization. "I guess that is pretty sweet. And I can always learn more about myself tomorrow." You felt so much better. "Now if I could just get my sisters to stop bothering me."

Mrs. Belacourt chuckled at that last comment. "Believe me, Lucy. I had 4 sisters myself. They never stop bothering you, especially when you're the youngest. But you love them anyway."

"I guess that's true." You yawned, finally starting to feel sleepy. "Thanks, Mrs. Belacourt. That really helped. Liz is really lucky to have a mom like you."

Mrs. Belacourt picked you up and placed you in the bed. "That's sweet of you, dear. And your mother is very lucky to have a kind, thoughtful daughter like you." She pulled the covers over you, tucking you in. Almost immediately, you fell asleep.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: during the night

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
As soon as you fell asleep, Mrs Belacourt snuck out of the room, and headed for her study. Quickly, she called mom.

"Natalie, I'm sorry for calling you so late, but I knew you'd be up anyway. Lucy has just gone to sleep."

"A bit late, Clara. Has she had her usual nightmares?" mom said, frowning slightly.

"In a way as her boy side is conflicting poorly with her growing girlish side, but she seems to be coping better than most" Clara Belacourt said.

"Tell me about it. I wish the sleepover here was going better" mom said crossly,

"What happened? Oh, I see. The one that transformed with your daughter, but remained a teen. You've got her over? Still, you have one advantage over me; you call magically put them to sleep if you wished" Clara said. Clara knew her magical abilities were more suited to theory than any practical magic, which lead to many dismissing her as a glorified libarian.

"Yes. With Lucy having a sleepover, her former twin decided to have one of her own, and with eight teen girls in the house, eventually they decided that 'Mel's and Megan's tomboy friend' needed an urgent makeover. The poor girl has it bad with talk about boys as it is, but the dress the girls but her in really makes Christina look like a princess" mom said, as she stared at Christina's sleeping form. Christina's rosewood colored hair was slightly curled and loose, flowing to the back of her pink gown. Despite having slightly puffed sleeves, Christina's shoulders were bare, though her arms were covered by pink gloves that perfectly matched the dress. A green and silver pendant that matched Christina's eyes dangled from her neck, along with matching earrings. "I did what I could, but with so many non witches and non awaresin the house, I couldn't really act. Melanie is the problem. Her method of 'helping' is not doing Christina or her sister any favors.

"I can guess. I'm not surprised Lucy was initially embarrassed to be dressed in a pink leotard, though both girls enjoyed themselves" Clara said
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Mrs. Belacourt calls Natalie to let her know ho...

choices: Mom has a serious talk with Mel about her ways of "helping" you and Christina
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom smiled hearing that you had enjoyed yourself. "I'm so glad to here that, Clara. Thank you so much for calling." At least one transformed boy had a good time tonight. She was going to have to have a serious conversation with Mel.

"Of course. I know Liz and Hannah have another ballet lesson tomorrow afternoon. Should I hand back Lucy, then?"

"That sounds like a good idea. I would come over tomorrow morning otherwise, but I'm stuck in parent-teacher conferences all day. The result of having four children." Mom laughed.

"It's a plan then. I will see you tomorrow. Have a good night, Natalie." And with that, the two hung up the phones.

-------------------------------------------

The next morning, you woke up a bit late. Mrs. Belacourt had let you sleep since you were up so late. It was nice, but it felt a little weird waking up in Liz's room without Liz there. It looked like she had gotten up already. You stretched and gave a quick good morning squeeze to Mr. Fuzz, who Mom had known to send alone in your suitcase of overnight things. You were glad, as sleeping with him did make you feel better.

Hungry and curious to see where Liz had gotten to, you jumped out of bed and took a look in your suitcase for new clothes. "Okay, experiment time," you said to yourself. "Let's see if I like anything." Mom had only packed dresses, but that was alright. You settled on a green floral print dress, girly, but casual, and paired it with a red hoodie Mom had packed in case you got cold. Checking yourself out in the mirror, you smiled. You looked okay. You were getting better at this. Maybe you could get Mom to take you shopping. Then, you'd at least get some say in the clothes you wore.

As you descended the stairs, the smell of waffles caught your nose, making you hurry a little quicker to the kitchen area. Mr. Belacourt was there making waffles as Liz watched eagerly. Liz, also dressed, smiled when she saw you. "Hey, Lucy. I'm glad you are up. I was worried you were going to sleep all morning. But Mom said not to bother you cause you got to sleep so late."

You blushed and noticed Mrs. Belacourt reading a book at a nearby table. "Thanks, Mrs. Belacourt." She smiled at you.

"Were you nervous about being in a different house?" Liz asked. "I bet that's scary. Becky tried to sleep over a couple weeks ago, but she had to have her mom pick her up, and I've never tried sleeping at someone else's house before. It must be weird."

You nodded as you climbed up on the stoop next to her. "I guess so. I used to sleep at other people's houses all the time when I was a boy, but I used to be able to sleep without Mr. Fuzz when I was a boy too, so I guess I feel more nervous than I used to. But your mom was really nice and helped me get to sleep."

Mr. Belacourt plopped two plates full of waffles covered in powdered sugar and maple syrup in front of you and LIz. It look delicious. "That sounds like my wife. She helps me sleep all the time too." He smiled over at his wife, who returned the smile.

"So what is the plan for the day?" you asked Liz's parents as you took a bite of the delicious waffles. "Is my Mom coming to pick me up soon or do Liz and I have more time to play?" Hanging with Liz was your main desire at the moment, and you weren't ready to face your sisters again quite yet.

"She's going to take you home after Liz and Hannah's ballet class," Mrs. Belacourt informed you. You heart skipped a beat.

"Ballet? You two have ballet today?" You remembered it was Friday and that was indeed one of the days Hannah had ballet, and since Liz was in the same class, it made sense, but you still didn't feel like you wanted to suffer through a ballet class.

"Don't worry. You don't have to join in," Mrs. Belacourt reassured you. "It was just the most convenient time for both of us to hand you back over and we figured it would give you and Liz plenty of time to play."

"Oh, I guess that's okay then," you responded hesitantly. It still meant sitting through ballet, but it sounded unavoidable, plus more time with Liz felt like a pretty good trade-off.

Liz suddenly got excited and pushed her waffles aside for a moment. "Guess what?" she asked with a smile. "I made you something this morning."

You looked at her curiously. "What did you make?"

With a huge grin, she held out a small bracelet decorated in rainbow colors. "I made you a friendship bracelet. I know we haven't been friends long, but I really had fun yesterday. I just wanted to you to have a reminder of all the fun we had together."

You took the bracelet from her and looked at it closely. "Thanks, Liz. I wish I could make one for you too."

"Well, I have all the materials you need. I could teach you how after breakfast," she offered.

You put the bracelet on and smiled at your newfound friend. "Sounds like fun. I'll try to make you a good one. But first, more waffles." You continued to happily consume your waffles.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: the next morning

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
After breakfast, Liz gathered the materials needed to make the friendship bracelets while you watched curiously. Only as she was about to explain the first step, you felt a cold chill just before you found yourself somewhere dark. You jumped, frightened as a teenage girl appeared in front of you with seven other girls behind her. The girl in front was fairly attractive with an average build, shoulder length red hair and hazel eyes. The girls behind her were too out of focus for you to see clearly and you guessed there was a reason for that.

"Relax, you were not teleported anywhere." Smiling, the girl said. "I am Cassy Bane, leader of this small coven and we would like to extend an offer to join us."

"You want me to be a part of your coven?" Worried, you asked. "I... I think I should ask my mom first before agreeing to anything."

"Your mother can't hold your hand forever, Lucy." Still smiling, Cassy said. "there are some decisions you have to make on your own." She giggled before adding, "We heard you made a little mess with your magic; we can help you clean it up."

"How?" Curious, you demanded.

"By teaching you magic, of course." Now grinning, Cassy replied. "Think about it. We need to go before our link is traced. See you around, Lucy."

With that, you jumped again finding yourself lying on the floor of the sitting room with Liz and Mrs Belacourt looking over her, worried. "Lucy, what happened?!" Fearful, Liz demanded. "You just passed out on us out of the blue!"

"I- I'm not sure." Feeling dizzy, you replied.

Cassie's coven moves to recruit Christina
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You told the whole story to Mrs. Belacourt and Liz, sparing no detail. Though maybe you should have. Liz looked a little freaked.

Mrs. Belacourt nodded. "They've noticed your power. This isn't going to start to happen I'm afraid. As you grow stronger, witches are going to want you to be part of their coven to grow they're own power."

Liz looked at her mother. "Didn't you say to stay away from Cassie Bane though?"

"Cassie Bane is not someone you want to associate with. She enjoys using her magic to tease and embarrass others. You can't really what she says either. It's a well-known secret that she likes to keep her non-magic brother trapped as a little girl. If she heard about what you did to Steve and Rick, I would wager that she is more interested in teaching you how to keep their forms locked as girls." Mrs. Belacourt sighed. She had been hoping her daughter's weak magic potential would keep her save from this world, but she didn't regret letting you be her friend. It would just cause complications.

You looked surprised. "Wait, locked? You mean Steve and Rick aren't trapped as girls?"

Mrs. Belacourt hadn't realized you weren't aware of that part. "Karma spells are only temporary. They'll probably turn back in the next day or two. I guess you're mother wanted you to work on fixing it yourself though."

You shook your head. Your mother had to stop keeping things from you. Though, she was right. Even if the spell was temporary, you needed to take responsibility. "Yeah, I still want to change them back myself."

Mrs. Belacourt smiled. "I'm glad to hear you say that. You're really are turning into a responsible little witch." You blushed, enjoying hearing yourself described as a witch. "Liz had told me this morning about Rick and Steve and I've actually been doing a little research to find a spell that should help you fix them."

Your eyes brightened. "Really? That's great. Though Mom sort of wanted me to find the answer myself."

"Part of finding the answer is making use of your resources. Since I'm a witch librarian, asking me for help is perfectly fair. This is what I do." Mrs. Belacourt stood up. "Give me a few minutes. I need to gather a few supplies and call your Mom to let her know about Cassie. Why don't you two work on your bracelets in the meantime." With that she left the room.

You and Liz set to work, though she looked a little worried. Eventually, you asked her how she was. "You okay?"

"Just worried. Cassie Bane scares me."

You put the final touches on the friendship bracelet you were making for her. "Don't worry. I'm not going to join up with her and I won't let her hurt you either." You felt sure of that. You had met way scarier witches after all, but you didn't tell Liz that part. No sense in scaring her more. Either way, you felt sure that your friendship with girls like Liz would keep you walking the path of good magic. You smiled as you handed her the completed bracelet. "This bracelet is my promise to you, okay?"

She smiled and admired the bracelet. "You're pretty good at this. How about we make some for Ellen and the others too? I'm sure they'd love these."

You grinned, happy to see your friend in better spirits. "Sounds like fun. Let's do it."

-------------------------------------------

Back in her house, Cassie Bane frowned as she thought about her encounter with you. A blonde hair girl, about her age, sat on her bed, waiting for Cassie to say something. Finally, the blonde girl spoke instead. "How do you think it went? Think she'll go for it."

Cassie sighed and shook her head. "I think we got to her too late. She's making friends on her own and after her encounter with Elena Kruse, I doubt she'll be so easy to trust strange witches. 1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mel was lying in her bed and staring at the ceiling, feeling annoyed that her mother felt the need to humiliate her at Hannah's ballet studio. She had just been joking around with Christina. There had been no need for everyone to freak. The girl was definitely becoming a teenager, and her defiant, rebellious streak was kicking in. She didn't like being cut down by her mom. Suddenly, she heard a noise, a tapping at her window. She looked over to see the face of Cassie Bane at the window, looking to be let in. Mel bit the bottom of her lip and considered getting Mom, but she decided against it. No harm in seeing what she had to say.

Mel locked the door to her room, then went to open the window, allowing Cassie to hop in. "How'd you get up here anyway?" she asked.

Cassie smirked. "I'm not just a skilled witch, but an excellent tree climber. Easy enough to get to your bedroom window. I figured your mom would be on the look out for magic, so the low-tech way seemed the best way to talk to you."

Mel nodded, unsure about letting Cassie in, but curious about what she had to say. "Well, my mom is doing the dishes downstairs, but she's coming up soon to help Lucy with a project. So let's keep this quiet. Anyone of my sisters could be walking by too."

"Well, I'll make this simple then. I'm recruiting for my coven and I think you'd be a good fit."

"Yeah, right. It's not like you've ever said two words to me before," Mel pointed out. "You don't want me. You want Lucy."

Cassie shook her head. "I thought I did. That girl's power is really something, but she doesn't seem fun at all. Not like you. And you have just as much potential. I really admired what you did to Ms. Rich last night. Reminded me of games I play with my brother."

Mel looked shocked. "How'd you know about that?"

"I've got friends everywhere. You could to. We could show you how much fun magic can be."

Mel considered this for a second. It was really tempting. She was sick of being told what to do with her magic all the time. She was a blossoming witch, and she wanted to explore and experiment with her magic. "My mom would kill me if she found out."

"First thing I'll teach you is how to cover your tracks. Mom never needs to know. And if she does, so what? No law against joining a coven."

Mel nodded. "What do I have to do?"

Cassie grinned. "Swing by my house tomorrow. I'll introduce you to some of the girls." And with that she slipped out the window again. Mel watched her sneak back to the street and disappear into the night. Mel smiled, eager to have the opportunity to practice magic without Mom looking over her shoulder. She shut the window and returned to her bed, thinking happily about what tomorrow would bring.

-----------------------------------------------------

You sat in the middle of your room, dressed in a nightgown, magic book open before you. You nervously made sure you had all the proper ingredients you needed for the spell. You looked up at your mom who was staring at the wall. "Everything okay, Mom?"

Mom turned her attention back to you and smiled. "Just thought I heard something, but I think it was just Mel closing a window." She sat down next to you. "I'm excited to see you cast your first real spell. Thank you for waiting to do this until I could be with you."

You blushed as your mom got all mushy. She had asked you to wait to try the spell Mrs. Belacourt found to turn Tim's friends back into boys again and now was your first chance to actually try it. "I've done magic before, Mom," you reminded her.

"That was impulsive magic, responding to your strong emotions. This is something different. My daughter's first spell." She beamed proudly, embarrassing what remaining teenage pride you had left.

You began to chant, summoning flame and focusing it in a small bowl you had placed before you. You then picked up pictures of Rachel and Stephanie taken from a school yearbook and tossed them in the flame. "The punishment done. Return daughter to son." The flame glowed purple and then went out. You tilted your head and looked at your mother. "Is that it? Did it work?"

Mom nodded. "I think so." She pulled out the pictures, which had not been burnt. They now showed Rick and Steve instead of the girls. "I can have Hannah call them tomorrow to make sure. She can pretend to be asking about homework since she's in their class."

You took the pictures of the two boys from her and marveled at them. "That is sooooooo cool. Magic is awesome."

Mom smiled at you. "Sounds like you are beginning to enjoy yourself, Lucy"

You shrugged. "I've been having more fun, I guess."

"It shows. Your teacher was very pleased that you were making more friends yesterday." You blushed suddenly remembering the parent-teacher conference, but Mom quickly reassured you. "Don't worry. She said only nice things." You sighed in relief. "Come on. Let's get you to bed."

You nodded and stood. In a minute, Mom was tucking you in. You went deep into thought for a moment and looked at her. "Hey, Mom. Can you take me shopping tomorrow? I want to get some of my own clothes." You had been mostly using hand-me-downs from your sister since you had transformed.

Mom looked surprised. "Six-year olds usually let their mothers handle to clothes buying. Plus, there's the no tomboy rule."

"I know. But hanging with Liz and the others got me wanting to experiment a bit. I'm learning there are many ways to be a girl. If I'm going to be a girl, I want to find my own way to be one."

Mom nodded and brushed your hair. "I understand. I'm so proud of you, sweetie. I'll take you to the mall tomorrow. Just you and me."

You smiled. "Sounds great, Mom."

She stood to turn out the light. "Let me know if you get any more offers to join covens."

You giggled. "I'm not joining any coven. I'm going to start my own someday. And it will be way better than Cassie's coven. Just you watch." And with that, Mom turned out the lights and you fell asleep, Mr. Fuzz cradled in your arms.

The next day was Saturday. Mel got dressed in something nice but casual. She wanted to impress Cassie and whoever else was in the coven. She nervously got a bag together and head down stairs. As she reached the bottom floor, she could hear giggling and the television. It sounded like you and Hannah were were watching something. She poked her head into the living room. Indeed some cartoon show with pastel ponies was on the screen, with you and Hannah sitting in your nightgowns, watching transfixed. Neither of you seemed to notice Mel. Mel couldn't remember the name of the show you two were watching, something with Ponies in the title, but she had always been a girl who liked to feel older than she was. Cartoons hadn't been her thing since she was 4. She recognized it as one of Hannah's favorites though.

After another fit of giggles, you turned to Hannah and smiled. "You were right, Hannah. This show is hilarious."

"See," Hannah said triumphantly. "Just cause a show is for girls doesn't mean it's bad. I bet you would have even liked it as a boy, if you hadn't been so afraid to do anything I liked."

You blushed, realizing you had been pretty gender stereotypical back then. You felt a bit of guilt. "Yeah, I guess you are right." You paused. "I still think ballet is kind of boring though." Watching Hannah and Liz's class yesterday hadn't changed your mind on that one.

Hannah smirked, and started tickling you, causing you to burst out laughing. "Oh yeah, little sis. I bet you'll be joining us soon enough. You'll be such a pretty ballerina."

You begged Hannah to stop between laughter. She was enjoying the big sister role a bit too much for your taste, but the two of you had been getting on better than you ever had, and that was nice for both of you. "Hannah...come on...we're missing the show."

Mel frowned at the sweetness of the scene before her. It was starting to annoy her that you were adjusting okay. Mom, Hayley, and Hannah seemed to completely adore the new you and Mom, in particular, was very proud of how responsible you were starting to be with your magic. Mel, on the other hand, felt like she could do no right. She also just started with her magic studies. Why wasn't anyone as proud of her? She felt a strong desire to knock you down a couple pegs.

"Morning, Mel. Where are you off to?" Mel almost jumped. She hadn't realized Mom had come up behind you.

"Oh, library. Got a history paper on the French Revolution due Monday." Mel wasn't lying. The paper was real, and she'd swing by the library before going to Cassie's. Mom was supposed to be a the mall most of the day with her new favorite daughter, so Mel would be able to come and go as she pleased.

"An interesting topic," Mom said. "I look forward to talking to you about it later." She then turned to you and Hannah. "Girls, eggs are ready. Come and get them while they are warm."

"Awww Mom. Do we have to now? Can't we wait until the shows over?" It didn't matter if you were a 6-year-old girl or a 13-year-old boy. You always asked this, even with a DVD player and a DVR.

Mom rolled her eyes. "No, you can record it. Come on. And I expect a little more appreciation for cooking you breakfast."

You blushed as you hit the record button on the remote and got up, following your Mom and Hannah to the kitchen. "Sorry, Mom. Thanks for making breakfast."

Mom smiled and tussled your hair lovingly, which gave Mel a queazy feeling. To Mel, it felt like Mom was letting you off the hook. It wasn't fair how much easier she was on you.

Mom turned to Hannah. "Oh, Hannah, were you able to call Rick and Steve?"

Hannah nodded. "Yeah, I called both their houses and asked what the homework was, and both of asked me why stupid girls couldn't keep the homework straight. It's like they share a brain." She turned to you. "You should of left them as girls. I liked them way better that way."

You shrugged. "Yeah, but that wouldn't have been the right thing to do. Not like they are witches or anything."

Mom tussled your hair again. "Well, I'm so proud of you, my responsible little witch." Though embarrassing, you couldn't help but smile.

Mel rolled her eyes, annoyed at you being Mom's goodie-two-shoes little daughter and the praise you was getting. This morning had only made her more convinced she needed to take Cassie up on her offer. She needed to join Cassie's coven. With that, Mel left without saying goodbye, which she was sure Mom would scold her about later.

You tilted your head in confusion. "What do you mean? They have ones for boys too. Look over there." You pointed down the aisle toward the boys section of the clothing store you were in.

Mom followed your eyes and, sure enough, there were shirts for boys with sequin flip designs, including Star Wars, Lego Ninjago, and Pokemon characters. Mom made a puzzled expression. "Boy's styles have changed since I was a kid. Boys you know actually wear those?"

"Yeah, Pi has a couple. So do a few boys in my class and I think I've even seen Rick wear one. They're pretty popular." You handed a couple of the girls sequin flip shirts to Mom, including the unicorn one and one with a cat with heart shaped eyes.

Mom looked them over. Even if boys were wearing similar ones at school, she was surprised you were so willing to accept the ones with feminine designs on them. She considered asking you about it, but was worried it would cause a negative reaction. Of course, your next choice surprised her even more.

"What do you think of this dress, Mom?" You held up a cream-colored dress that was a knit sweater on top, then turned into a layered tulle shirt on the bottom. It looked like it might work for both casual and formal occasions.

"It's very pretty." That was all she could think to say.

"Well, should I get some matching tights to go with this? Or would it look better in red? And are you scanning me to see if I'm under a spell?" You had noticed Mom's hand glowing purple as you talked.

This was a rare occasion you saw your Mom get fluster. "Well, yes, honey. This is just...more than I expected from you today. I mean, you told me you wanted to go shopping, but I didn't expect this." Her hand glowed again for a second. "But you don't seem to be under any magical influence. So I'm just confused. Confused and surprised."

You grinned. "I thought I told you last night, Mom. Hanging with Liz just got me thinking. Rather than being so negative about my change, I should experiment and see what I like. If I'm going to be Lucy, I want to know who Lucy is. What I like. Mrs. Belacourt helped me realize that too."

Mom nodded dumbfounded. Both you and Mrs. Belacourt had indicated this all before, but seeing it in action was a completely different matter. "It's just the first time I'm really seeing it firsthand, I guess." She reached down and hugged you. "I'm so proud of you." She paused and looked at the dress. "I say get the red one and pair it with cream colored tights." You smiled and swapped the cream dress for the red one. "You do seem much happier."

"I feel happier. And there is tons of stuff I want to try today."

"Oh, such as?"

You smiled, ready to blow Mom's mind again.

After a bit more shopping, including clothes, both causal and dressy, a swimsuit for the summer, and a couple of leotards, you and Mom found yourself at a kids salon in the mall, where you made a request you almost immediately regretted. You wanted to get your ears pierced.

"Well, I didn't realize girls her age knew that kind of language," Sally finally said in surprise. You blushed deeper.

Mom shook her head. "She's spent a little too much time around 13-year old boys." Sally nodded in understanding.

"Sorry, Ma'am," you apologized. "I didn't realize it was going to hurt that much."

"You still want the other one done?" Mom asked.

You thought for a second, then nodded. "Yes, please. The girls at school will think I'm a chicken if I show up with just one earring." Mom chuckled as the reason you wanted your ears pierced became apparent. All your new friends had them. "I'll try not to curse this time," you promised Sally, but it was a promise you would fail to live up too.

-------------------------------------------------

Fifteen minutes later, you and Mom walked out of the salon. Your ears still hurt, but not as badly as they did initially. And you had some ear studs to show for your endurance. Still, you were a little disappointed. "We're not going to get my nails painted?" You asked Mom, feeling a little disappointed. You did find yourself curious about what it was like to have sparkly nails. In fact, coupled with your new sequin interest and your choice of leotards, sparkles seemed to be a recurring theme with the new you. It felt nice to know you liked sparkly things in a way.

Mom shook her head. "Sorry, sweetie. Hannah has a lot of sparkly nail polish at home. I can do your nails myself there. I just had to get out of that salon. I felt like people kept judging me as the awful parent who lets her six-year-old daughter curse. It was a little embarrassing."

You nodded. "Yeah, sorry about that. I guess it was out of habit."

Mom patted your head. "I understand, sweetie. Just promise you won't do that in front of your friends. The last thing I need is other mothers getting on my case. And some mothers get very picky about who they let they're daughters play with. You don't want them to get the wrong impression of you."

You understood what she was saying. You were sure Liz's mom would understand, but you didn't know the moms of Ellen, Keira, or the other girls yet. You voiced your agreement, then braced yourself to ask Mom your final mall day request. It wasn't something you were sure she'd agree to. "So you know how I've been studying the magic book?"

"Well, yes. You seem quite interested. It's very exciting, isn't it?"

"It's great, Mom, but there was a spell I found there that I wanted to try. A simple protection spell." You looked the friendship bracelet around your wrist. You wanted to enchant to ones you made for your friends, so they'd be safe if Cassie or Elena or anyone like that tried to get at you through them. Your friends didn't have to know about it either, well, except Liz, of course.

Mom nodded. "That's a nice and easy one. Good beginner's spell."

"But I checked at home and we don't have the ingredients I would need, so..." You eyes drifted across the mall toward Samantha Forrester's store. Mom followed your eyes and you could tell she recognized what you were requesting. "I know you don't like Samantha, but I don't know of any other store that has magic stuff, and I figured you'd be with me to whole time we're in there, so you can make sure I'm safe. I won't even talk to her if that helps. Please, Mom..."

Mom sighed. You made a few good points, but she really wanted to avoid you being exposed to Samantha as much as possible. After a second, she made her decision.

Sarah giggled. "You both dropped the ball." Calmly, she said. "The question is, who will be the first to pick it back up?"

Christina looked at her mom, thoughtful then asked, "Do you think..."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Christina after the fight

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Christina paused before finishing the rest of the question. "Do you think Mrs. Harrison would make me six too?"

Sarah raised an eyebrow in surprise. "Really? When you were turned into a six-year-old girl originally you hated it. You seemed so relieved to be thirteen again."

Christina nodded. "Yeah, that's true, but I didn't realize how hard it was going to be. Lucy's adjusted much better than I have. Maybe she went about this the smarter way."

Sarah looked at her new daughter, thinking about what she had just said. Was this really the right call? "I understand you feeling that way, but it is a big decision. Why don't you take a day or two to think about it, and, then, if you still want to be six like Lucy, we can talk to Natalie." Christina thought about this, then nodded again. That seemed fair.

"Thanks, Mom." Christina knew though that her mind was already made. She was miserable like this. Maybe by following in Lucy's footsteps, she could find a new way forward.

---------------------------------------------

"I feared this moment would come," Mom sighed as she faced her next great opponent. Well, two opponents technically. You and Hannah stood before her in your respective nightgowns arms crossed, faces full of a pouting expression. It was the next morning, Sunday, but any further work dealing with Samantha and Cassie had to be put on hold by the two stubborn girls in front of her. "It was only a matter of time until you two teamed up."

"You lied to me," you accused Mom quickly. "You said girls only started gymnastics when they turned seven."

"I started when I was much younger than that," Hannah interjected.

"And Liz takes gymnastics and she's six," you added. You couldn't believe you hadn't thought of that when Mom first rejected the gymnastics idea.

"My gymnastics class has six-year-old beginners in it too," Hannah continued.

"And I looked it up online. Most girls start gymnastics at five or six. So why won't you let me take it? I could be in the same class as Hannah and Liz. It would be so much fun." You didn't get what Mom was thinking, but you didn't like her not letting you do this.

Mom couldn't help but chuckle. The two of you were adorable when you worked together. "I should have known you two would start start talking and that my six-year-old daughter still had the internet research savvy of a thirteen-year-old. I've got to lie a bit better next time." She sighed. It was time to come clean. "Okay, you got me. I had a completely different reason for saying no to gymnastics."

"What is it?" you and Hannah demanded.

"Most six-year-old girls have had their whole lives to get used to their bodies. They know their limits and their weaknesses. Lucy, you've only had that body for about two weeks. You're still not used to it yet. Gymnastics is great, but I was worried that it might be a bit to...active for you so soon after your transformation. I didn't want you to hurt yourself."

You shook your head in protest. "Mom, I can handle it. I promise. Please let me do gymnastics. It looks like so much fun."

"Please, Mom. It would be great to have Lucy in class with me."

Mom sat back in her chair and thought for a moment. "Tell you what. I'll make you a deal. You can join Hannah's gymnastics class, if you join her ballet class too."

That was a surprise. Hannah couldn't have been happier with the idea. She loved the idea of you joining ballet too, but you weren't nearly as enthusiastic. "What? Why? Ballet is boring. Why do I need to do that too?" Come to think of it, Mom had been trying to nudge you in the direction of ballet at the mall to. Why ballet over gymnastics?

"Hey, ballet's not boring. You'll love it."

Mom shushed you both before you turned on each other in an argument about ballet. "Ballet is a bit slower and more subdued. It's the perfect way for you to learn how to handle that new body of yours. If you take ballet as well, I will trust you to handle yourself in gymnastics."

You frowned. Mom's counteroffer had put you and Hannah on different pages. You felt alone in your position, which was annoying. "But Hannah takes ballet twice a week and gymnastics once a week. I'd be doing more ballet than gymnastics. That's not a fair deal."

Mom held firm. "That's the deal. Take it or leave it. Though if ballet is completely unbearable after a month, we can try to think up a different way to go."

You considered your options for a moment. You looked over at Hannah, who clearly was hoping you'd agree. You had been so bored when visiting Hannah and Liz's ballet class on Friday, but maybe actually doing it would be a little less awful. Still, you had always seen ballet as one of the most girly activities known to man. It might be a point of no return. Not that you had much intention of being a boy again. And hanging with Liz and Hannah would be fun. Finally, after a minute deep in thought, you made your decision. "Fine," you uttered very begrudgingly.

Hannah cheered and hugged you, while Mom smiled. "Thank you, Lucy. That puts my mind at ease. I'll sign you up for both first thing tomorrow morning."

You sighed. This confrontation had not gone as you had expected, but whatever. At least, you could take gymnastics with Liz now.

Your train of thought was interrupted when...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Ms H can make me six too?

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
… the phone rang. Mom immediately answered it, and said, "She did WHAT?!"

You turned to Hannah, believing Mel had done something and gotten herself caught. Apparently, so did she as Hannah turned to you and said, "Do you think Mel has done something stupid? What do you think it is?"

"Probably tried to turn some boys into girls and got caught" you said thoughtfully.

"Do you think its Stephanie and Rachel?" Hannah asked.

You scowled. "Thats not a good thing, Hannah..."

Mom could hear Hannah and your speculations and said, "Girls. could you both go up to your rooms? I need to talk in private.And no, its nothing to do with Melanie's rebelious poor attitude."

You and Hannah exchanged looks, but ultimatey follwed mom's order. Once you was gone, mom said, "Sorry, I had to get rid of two spying little girls. Why did you say that, Sarah? You know there are two things I cannot change about either Christina or Lucy. Their gender, and their age. Other physical attributes fine. i can do hair color, bust, height. Hell, I could even stick them both into seashell bras and make them both into mermaids, but I can't do their ages. What transformed them both initially saw that part of them lock.

"Any way to undo that lock?" Sarah asked. "Christina is freaking out."

"So you made that promise to pacify her? Pray that she says 'no', since the only witch that could attempt to undo the lock is Elvira. And she won't do it. Trust me, I know. She'll say 'too dangerous and can cause unpredictable, unintended changes, and likely to end in disaster'".
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Humoring a witch

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Despite Mom's insistence that you and Hannah go up to your rooms, the two of you hung around at the top of the stairs, listening in to Mom's phone conversation. You couldn't hear it all, but you could hear enough.

"So, Christina wants to be six like you. I guess she misses being with you all the time. That's good, isn't it?" Hannah asked. She knew from talking with you the night before that Christina was still a sore subject after the big fight.

You shrugged. "Maybe. Though I don't get why Mom can't make her six again. Samantha's glasses made her six originally. She only became thirteen again because of Mom's magic."

Now it was Hannah's turn to shrug. "Maybe it's like a time limit thing. Mom could only change her age for a bit after the glasses changed you two." Suddenly, an idea occurred to her. "Hey, maybe if Mom can't make her six, you can. You changed Rick and Steve into girls."

You shook your head. "I didn't change their ages though. And I wouldn't want to hurt Christina by accident." You sighed. You were still mad at Christina, but you didn't want anything bad to happen to her. "I just hope Christina doesn't do anything stupid." She had a tendency to make bad decisions when she didn't get what she wanted.

"You girls better not still be listening to me!" Mom called from downstairs.

You and Hannah looked at each other with wide eyes. "What do we do?" you asked.

"Run!" Hannah said and the two of you dashed off to her room.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"You need to get that idea out of your daughter's head before she does something rash." Serious, mom said. "A distraction would help. Perhaps Witchbloom."

If you are not comfortable with sending Christina away to witch school, at least consider allowing Hayley to tutor her. She is certified to teach magic and perhaps the two of them will find a sisterly bond."

After ending the call, mom waved her hand and a startled Melanie appeared in front of her. "Hey, I was still visiting Cassie!" Annoyed, she protested.

"It's past your curfew, young lady." Firmly, mom said. "I've been more than patient with you."

Melanie whipped around to find...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: The phone call continues

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Melanie's grandmother, Elvira Strange was a tall and slender woman with long black hair and piercing green eyes. She wore an elegant black dress that accented her curves well only her expression was that of deep disappointment. "I expected better from you, Melanie Harrison." Scolding, she said. "You have a lot of potential."

Melanie, quite foolishly, summoned a flame to her hand. "I follow my own path!" Defiant, she snapped. "You are not the boss of me..."

Elvira summoned a flame to her own hand which literally engulfed the room and threw Melanie off her feet! She tumbled twice before hitting the wall and looked up at Elvira with a sense of terror; this was a side of her grandmother she had never seen. "I am the head witch." Irritated, Elvira snapped back. "As such, I command all witches, including you." She frowned down at Mel, who was now literally shivering in fright at the sight of her power. "Do not ever challenge me again."

Melanie turned to mom for help only to see her gulp. "I had hoped you would not repeat my own mistake." Her voice quivering, she said.

Elvira sighed then closed her hand, causing the flame to vanish with a low thunderous boom. "Eva Morgana and her sister, Helena young have been spotted in the area." More calmly, she explained. "They prefer to work under the cover of darkness so, unless you wish to forever disappear or never see your sisters again, be home before six PM without fail."

Melanie quickly nodded but said nothing as Elvira then turned to mom who sighed. "I am trying to help her see what she is doing is wrong but..."

Elvira hushed mom silent. "All witches fall into their rebellious stage." Smiling, she said. "Even Hayley had challenged me once only it was under stress of a witch test." She looked at Melanie and added, "Your mother joined a coven to spite me as you are doing to her."

"What- What happened?" Nervous, Melanie asked.

Elvira shook her head. "Your mother came very close to losing her magic forever." Sadly, Elvira replied. "It was not from breaking the law but from the coven wanting to steal her magic."

"A witch can do that?!" Startled, Melanie asked.

Elvira grabbed Melanie's hand and pointed to the mark on her arm. "This mark is not just a fashion statement." Gravely, she said. "It will grow and, once it is all over your body, your magic will be gone." She then sighed. "Don't believe me... chapter seven, lesson eight."

With that, Elvira vanished from the room, leaving Melanie more than a little shaken...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: The head witch brings dire warnings.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Cassie snorted dismissively over the phone. "Mel, I promise I'm not trying to steal your magic. It wouldn't serve me to. I want to change the way the magic community thinks about magic. I don't want it all for myself. Stealing another witch's magic goes against my philosophy and would just piss off the Witch's council. Even with my mother's allies there. Elvira and your mother are just trying to divide us. Why are you calling me anyway? We can just communicate mentally." She sounded sincere, but Mel felt unsure who she could believe.

Mel sighed. "I don't know...I feel like Mom picked up on that somehow. At least with my cell I don't send out any magical trace. Just normal hiding things from my Mom."

"Makes sense. You can be crafty when you want to be, though I wouldn't put it past Natalie to have picked up on this too." Cassie paused as she collected her thoughts, then jumped back to Mel's concerns. "But, if your worried, you can take a look at chapter seven, lesson eight. It clearly states that the rune mark can have that effect, but it requires a lot of dark magic, that frankly I'm not capable of yet. Besides, you would have weeks in that scenario to counter the effects."

"Then, why was it such a close call for my mom?" Mel asked.

Cassie shrugged even though Mel couldn't see it. "Maybe she got wrapped up in a witch cult when she was younger. It was pretty common 25 years ago. Powerful witches with strong personalities would prey on the young to cultivate their own power. Many of them tried to steal magic. My mom hated them. She called them a complete perversion of the coven system, but you'd be surprised how many witches of our parent's generation belonged to one at one point or another. Elena Kruse ran one, but I don't think she was one of the power suckers."

Mel flipped through the pages of her witch book as she listened. "Mom's never mentioned any of that."

"She's probably ashamed. It was a rough period in our history."

Mel came to part of the book she was looking for. "Okay, found chapter seven, lesson eight." She took a moment to read it over. "Yeah, seems to be pretty much what you said. Witch cults, power sucking, some totally dark stuff."

"Yeah, it's a betrayal of witch practice in my mind. Covens are supposed to be beautiful havens of sisterhood. Those were betrayals of that trust. Frankly, if your Mom was part of one I don't blame her for freaking out about you joining a coven. She's probably pretty scarred and a little concerned about my motivations." Cassie actually felt a bit of sympathy for Natalie, not that she would ever tell her that.

"Sooooooooo...what are your motivations then?"

Cassie chuckled. "Fair question, I guess. I'm honestly pretty simple. I think women are better than men and witches are better than humans, and think witches should live their lives according to that philosophy. Cause frankly, men and humans suck. They hunt us and try to control us. I refuse to live that way." She paused, then spoke again. "Plus, I'm a rude bitch and I don't have patience for people that cross me." Mel giggled. "Listen, power is great and all, but I'm more powerful with other witches who share my worldview around me. Witches like you. Believe me, there are much more dangerous people than me out there in the dark."

Mel nodded, remembering Elvira's warning. "Like Eva Morgana and Helena Young."

Cassie felt a chill hearing those names. Her mom had taught her when she was little about witches to watch out for. Those two were mentioned a number of times, but knowledge of them was scarce. "Yeah...I don't know much about those two, but I do know even my Mom is wary of them. Take Elvira's warning seriously. If I had know they were spotted in the area, I wouldn't have kept you at my place this late."

Mel was silent for a moment as she considered this. "Anything we can do to protect ourselves?"

Cassie paused, which Mel found chilling. Finally, Cassie spoke. "Stay inside at night. Don't go out for any reason. That's really all I can think of." She paused again. "Listen, can we talk about something else? Talking about those two unsettles me, and we've got enough to think about, especially with Samantha coming after me."

Cassie's fear definitely was making Mel anxious about these two women, but Mel obliged. "Yeah, sure. Why is Samantha so mad at you anyway? You both like turning boys to witch girls. Shouldn't you two get along great?"

"You'd think so, wouldn't you? But my stunt with the glasses that turned Harry and your brother into Christina and your sister put the scrutiny of the witch council on her. Even though I sold it all, they figure why was that stuff even if her store to begin with. So she's in the doghouse and she's taking it out on me."

Mel giggled. "As much as Lucy annoys me, she annoyed me more when she was John, so I'm glad you pulled that stunt."

"Thanks." Then, Cassie remembered something. "Oh, by the way I heard from Magenta. She took care of the boys. Tim and Lucy are in for a rude surprise when they go back to school tomorrow. Should be fun." Magenta was another girl in the coven, a blonde, who Mel had been introduced to at Cassie's during the afternoon.

"Is her name really Magenta?" Mel asked. She hadn't wanted to ask earlier.

Now, it was Cassie's turn to giggle. "No, it's Bess, but she thinks being called Magenta makes her sound more elegant and mysterious. I think it's silly, but she's a good friend, and very good at leaving no magical trace. It won't come back to us."

"Awesome," Mel said. Suddenly, she heard her name called from downstairs. "Crap, I got to go. Mom's calling me."

"Kay, see you at school tomorrow. I hope I put your mind at ease."

"You did." At least about the coven stuff, but now Mel felt like she was going to have nightmares about the witch sisters. She didn't want Cassie to know she was freaked about it though. "Later." Mel hung up the phone and rushed downstair to see what Mom wanted.
