1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
The entire family gathered around the dining room table. You were dressed in purple leggings and a grey tee with a picture of a cat on front, one of your purchases at the mall yesterday as you like cats. Hannah sat next to you and you looked at each other nervously. Mom sounded really serious when she called you all down and you felt you had a feeling you need what was coming.

"Mom, did something happen to Christina?" Hannah had just asked the question you were afraid to.

Mom looked confused and then shook her head. "No, Christina should be okay. And she just became the least of our worries." Mom then proceeded to tell you all about Elvira's warning, including the two names, Eva Morgana and Helena Young. The nervousness in her voice told you it was something serious.

"So...these sisters...are they worse than Elena Kruse?" You asked with trepidation.

Mom bit her lip than nodded. "Yes...I'm sorry I have to tell you all this, I know it's scary. But you have to understand why we're going to be taking certain precautions. I don't want them getting anywhere near you four."

"How come I've never heard about these two?" Hayley asked. "I heard a lot about bad witches both from you and at Witchbloom, but these two are completely new to me."

Mom sighed, then spoke. "We had hoped they were dead, honestly. We thought they were after our last encounter with them 20 years ago, but we never found the bodies and some suspected that they were still out there somewhere. Still, they weren't the sorts of women we wanted recorded in our history, so the stories were swept under the rug."

"Grandmother said they hunt in darkness," Mel added. She wasn't particularly happy with her mother or her grandmother, but she did recognize that this wasn't a time to fight with them.

Mom nodded. "Exactly, so until these two are dealt with you all are to be home by six." That sounded okay to you, your new after school activities would be done by then and you and Hannah were in bed by eight anyway. Hayley seemed less pleased.

"Mom, that's crazy. The days are getting shorter this time of year. That curfew is going to start getting earlier and earlier. We turn the clocks back in early November and that's less than a month away. and then we'll lose a whole nother hour. I often stay at school until about six. That's just not sustainable."

Mom raised a hand to stop Hayley. "Hayley, believe me, I understand. This curfew will last only until Eva and Helena are dealt with. The full force of the Witch Council is looking into this. I hope this will only last a week or so."

Hayley reached her hand up to her face and pinched her nose as she thought. "I guess. This still sucks."

"It does, but now I need you all to promise me, you'll follow my instructions in this matter." Mom looked at Mel. "My bet is even Cassie would tell you to fear these two. Her mother certainly does."

Mel nodded and quickly promised she'd followed the curfew. Mom could tell she was sincere too. Mel wasn't a great liar, as the past few days had demonstrated. You, Hannah, and Hayley quickly followed suit.

Your curiosity compelled you to ask though. "Mom, who are these two? Why is everyone so scared of them?"

"It's better that you don't know. I don't want to give you girls nightmares."

"Mom, we're already scared. And personally, I'd feel, like, a lot better knowing what we're dealing with." Mel made a convincing point. Hayley and Hannah nodded in agreement.

Mom sighed and decided to share despite her better judgment. "Fine. But this story may change the way you see me...I haven't always been as responsible as I am now." With that she began her story.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: A family meeting

choices: A strange woman enters your bedroom.
A strnage woman enters Mel's bedroom.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
There was once a powerful coven of young witches." Darkly, mom began. "Eva and Helena Kruse, Samantha Forester, Lilly Sweetie, and myself. We all took pleasure in throwing mischief at our brothers and friends with our magic."

Mel raised a hand to her mouth in shock. Her mom was friends with them?! It was certainly a scary thought if the two were now the most feared witches around. "Why were you friends with them?!" Shocked, she demanded. "It, like makes no sense!"

"Like you, I was offered to join their group during a time I was trying to get a foot hold in controlling my own life." Sadly, mom explained. "I did not suspect how dark Eva and Helena were until it was almost too late." She shook her head, a pained expression on her face. "The two had hatched a plan to permanently turn all of the boys within their families into girls and witches."

"What happened?" Worried, you asked.

"I opposed the plan as it would have made my brother, Jack the next head witch ahead of myself." Hurt, mom replied. "Call it vanity, call it what you like but I did not want to give up all the power that came with that position. Eva and Helena used a dark side to the loyalty mark to strip me of my powers for breaking the loyalty bond and take it for themselves."

"So the loyalty mark is like a contract?" Worried, Mel asked. "I did not read that anywhere.

Mom nodded, shedding a few tears. "If it was not for my brother's insane resistance to magic and colossal strength, they would have succeeded." Sadly, she said. "He stormed the Kruse house and busted all of their heads before he carried me home to mom where the mark was removed... I was lucky he still cared so much for me."

"Uncle Jack is that strong?!" Stunned, Mel asked. "What happened to him?"

"He married Samantha Forester's little sister, Sara." Softly, mom said. "Shortly after, they went into hiding to live a normal life."

"Why is the contract not mentioned in the magic book?" Wincing, Mel demanded.

"The contract curse connected to the mark is now a forbidden technique." Serious, mom replied. "Anything deemed forbidden is not taught in the magic books of today but they do warn of them." She sighed. "I am not denying you membership in this coven, Melanie. I am simply trying to protect you from the mistakes I have made growing up; they cost me dearly."

"What happened to Samantha Forester and this Lilly Sweetie?" Curious, Hayley asked.

"Samantha Forester quit the coven the same time I did only she had blocked the mark contract from holding her." Frowning, mom said. "She never warned me about it and it sort of divided us ever since." She sighed. "As for Lilly Sweetie, she simply vanished. No one has seen or heard from her since that night my brother came to the rescue. I can only assume she lost her magic and became normal."

"There is more to this... isn't there?" Wincing, you said.

Mom nodded. "Yes but it was dark times; an era of my life I would rather forever bury in the past." Softly, she said. "I came close to throwing everything away for my pride and power and I will not allow any of you to stumble down that same path." She frowned deeply. "Know this; Eva and Helena target people close to those they hate to make them suffer."

The meeting ended with everyone feeling rather shaken. You and Hannah were the most shaken, due to your ages and mom offered you both a cup of tea to help you sleep. Hayley remained behind to question mom further while Mel went to her room with a lot to think about. "So mom nearly went rogue due to a bad coven." Shaken, she thought. "That explains a lot. She doesn't want me to make the same mistakes." She sighed, shaking her head. "She's just being over protective; I'm more careful than that."

Later that night...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Knowing a little is scary enough.

choices: Your magic flares up again by mistake
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Neither Hannah nor you slept in your rooms that night. The story had been a little terrifying and both of you ended up sleeping with your mother, which she found some amusement in. Before you fell asleep you found yourself asking Mom one last question.

"So, are Eva and Helena just after us? Or are other people in danger?"

Mom considered this question, not sure how to answer. "They might want revenge on me, Lucy, but more than anything, they want to cause chaos and fear in the witch community that cast them out. There is not a witch who shouldn't watch her back. But don't worry, we're save in this house. Elvira and I put up enough protective charms around this place to keep an army out." She patted you as you fell asleep with that reassuring thought. The house would be safe. It was the rest of the world that scared her.

-------------------------------------------------

The night passed without incident and the next morning, you and your sisters went back to school. It was nice to return to normalcy. You gave Ellen and the others their friendship bracelets with the protective charms, which they were excited about (though they didn't know about the protection spells). Classes also seemed more enjoyable than they had last week. You figured your mind was readjusting to being six, which made the classes less boring. Plus, you're friends made everything better. You wanted to talk to Liz at some point about Eva and Helena, but it was hard to find a moment when the two of you were alone. You did get to tell her you would joining gymnastics and ballet, which made her super excited.

One troubling thing you observed was Cassie and Mel hanging out together. The two looked like they had bonded over the weekend, and could be seen laughing and talking through the halls, sometimes with other girls as well. Other members of Cassie's coven, you guessed. Still, you had bigger problems than Cassie and Mel becoming friends.

Finally, at recess, you and Liz found a moment you could be alone together.

"How much did your mom tell you?" you asked Liz after you told her your story.

"Not that much. She said she wasn't part of any cults like other witches were. She wasn't strong enough to get their attention. But she told me enough to scare me." Liz yawned. "I barely slept."

You nodded. It had been the same way with you. Suddenly, you noticed someone coming toward you and he didn't look happy. Your cousin, Tim. You groaned.

"Look out, Liz. A dumb-headed boy is approaching," you called loud enough to hear.

"I don't want to hear it, cootie-brain," Tim yelled. "Rick and Steve turned back to normal over the weekend, but now they're back to being silly girls with heads full of fairy dust or whatever. What did you do?"

You winced. Rachel and Stephanie were back? What had happened? Had your magic gone wrong or was someone else responsible? "What makes you think I did something?" you asked, trying to defend yourself.

"Because it was you last time. You clearly love being a girl now, so of course, you're trying to find ways to torture me just cause you want me to join your club of pretty prissy princess."

Liz rolled her eyes at that. "We don't want you playing with us, Tim. We're not going to do that to you."

"Who asked you?" Tim shouted at Liz, which annoyed you to no end. What gave him the right to yell at your friend? You stepped between them annoyance in your eyes.

"Back off, Tim. Or else you won't like what happens next."

Before he could respond, something happened that indeed Tim did not like.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: your choice.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Just then, two young girls walked up behind Tim with bemused looks on their faces. At first, you thought they were Rachel and Stephanie and felt a twinge of guilt. Only you remembered mom telling you that all witches had a unique signature. You had no way of telling if the magic was your own or not but still, something did not feel right. You sensed strong magic; something neither Rachel or Stephanie should have had.

"Are you picking on little girls again, Tim?" Grinning, Rachel asked. "Why not pick on someone your own size for a change?"

Tim rolled his eyes then turned to the two girls. "You know why I pick on girls, you two!" Annoyed, he snapped. "Or has cooties messed up your brain?"

The two girls giggled, their expressions turning more sinister and that was when you spotted Rick and Steve approaching from behind! It was then mom's words echoed in your head. "So far, she really has not broken any laws. However, she will be watched more closely now and I doubt her mother will be pleased with that."

You gasped, realizing who the two imposters likely were and immediately panicked. "Tim, Liz; run!" Screaming, you ordered.

You grabbed Tim's hand as you ran, pushing Liz forward with the other. Tim had no time to react and the panic in your voice moved him to obey as the three of you ran for the nearest teacher with a magical signature. Mel and Cassie heard your scream and turned your way, curious. You do not know what they saw but seeing their faces turn pale gave you an indication that it was not good at all and you changed direction just as you felt magic just barely miss hitting you!

Only when you reached the teacher did you realize that it was her who had fired the magical shot, likely to counter a spell meant for you. "Stay behind me, children." Whispering, she commanded. "Those two were never a match for Miss Sweets."

You turned back to where you ran from the two imposters only to find that they were gone as Rick and Steve ran up to you, looking slightly concerned. "Why did you scream like that?" Smiling, Rick demanded. "We don't bite."

"You two are such drama queens." Grinning, Steve added. "We're not like those real jerks, Greg Waters and Karl Dusty. We just mess with you, that's all."

"You mess around too much." Strictly, Miss Sweets scolded. "These two have been through a lot so I suggest you back off before you cause their parents to take action."

Albeit reluctantly, Rick and Steve walked away as you turned to Miss Sweets. "You are Miss Sweetie, aren't you?" Fearful, you asked.

The teacher nodded. "I take it your mother told you about me and the others of our little coven twenty years ago." Softly, she said. You nodded and she sighed. "It took me years to reestablish my reputation so I would be grateful if you did not tell anyone." She smiled. "As far as anyone else is concerned, I am Miss Sweets, a humble grade school teacher."

She then walked away as Mel and Cassie ran up to you while Tim hurried off with Rick and Steve. "Are you, like okay, Lucy?" Worry in her voice, Mel asked.

"That was Eva and Helena!" Panicked, you whispered. "They were here! Here at the school!"

Mel and Cassie turned to each other then turned to you and Liz. "There is always safety in numbers, Lucy." Sounding sincere, Mel said. "You may not want to be a part of Cassie's coven right now because you are, like scared or something but there is no harm in you both tagging along with us for protection."

"I will not do anything to make my mom look bad; the law is on her case as it is." Calmly, Cassie added. "This coven is legit; hang out with us for a while and then decide for yourselves." She smiled. "You might like it."

You turned to Liz who merely shrugged, not knowing what to do. Finally, you replied...

"What did you do?" Tim wailed.

"Shut up. Do you want to whole school to notice?" you hissed at him. You and Liz walked on either side of him, moving Tim toward the door. The goal was to not let anyone see the bright pink ruffled socks, Tim was now wearing. "Just be glad I only changed your socks."

"Where are you kids going? You still have 20 minutes of recess left," a recess teacher questioned you as you went inside the school.

"Bathroom," you and Liz quickly said in unison. The two of you went in with Tim before the teacher could respond. Fortunately, she didn't follow you. Pretty soon, the three of you had reached Tim's locker.

"You tried to turn me into a girl..." Tim whined.

"No, I didn't. You made me mad and I lost control of my magic for a second. I just wanted you to stop bothering my friend." You sounded a little panicked. You didn't want Tim spreading around rumors that you tried to turn him into a girl. You opened his locker. "Now where are your change of clothes?" you asked.

Tim pointed in his locker. His face looking miserable. He was milking this for all it was worth. No way was your mom not hearing about this. You fished around in his locker until you found a small bag with a change of clothes. Right on top were a pair of boys socks and you pulled them out and tossed them toward Tim.

"There you go. Now, you can put them on and there'll be nothing to be upset about okay. I'm sorry I lost control. Honest, Tim, I don't want to turn you or your friends into girls."

"Then why do you keep doing it?" Tim accused in a hurt voice.

"Why do you all keep picking on me? Being a jerk to me seems to trigger my magic. Why do you keep doing it anyway?"

Tim didn't have an answer for that. He looked at the socks from his change of clothes bag and blushed. "Ummmm...my socks wasn't the only thing your magic changed."

You and Liz looked at each other confused. Nothing about the rest of Tim's clothes seemed changed, when suddenly the answer dawned on you. You couldn't resist giggling. "Here." You tossed Tim his change of clothes bag. "I'm not touching your underpants."

Tim blushed one more time and took his change of clothes bag toward the bathroom to change, muttering under his breath, "Stupid cootie-brains."

After he left you and Liz immediately started laughing. Liz spoke first. "I know we shouldn't laugh. But that was really funny."

You nodded. "I know. I just hope I don't get in too much trouble."

"Why? You did everything you could do to fix it?"

"I guess, but Rachel and Stephanie are back too. I didn't mean to do that either."

"Maybe that wasn't you," Liz tried to reassure you.

"Maybe, but I need to get better at controlling my magic," you admitted.

After a couple minutes, Tim returned from the bathroom, having changed out of the clothes you transformed and into new ones. Tim looked you over suspiciously. "You sure you only changed some of my clothes? I'm not going to wake up tomorrow dreaming of being a princess, am I?"

Honesty seemed like the best tactic. "I really can't be sure. If you do, I didn't mean to and I promise to find a way to fix it." Liz shot you a look. Tim was a witch boy, which meant turning him back into a boy wasn't something you could promise. Universal magic might have other designs for him like it did for you.

Still, Tim accepted this and shook your hand. "Fine. I'll try to stop bothering you, if you can help me change my friends back."

Liz nodded. "But didn't my Mom say you only made them girls for a little bit. Just until they learned what it was like to be on. They should turn back on their own."

The three of you went back outside. Sure enough, you spotted Rachel and Stephanie playing with Hannah and her friends across the yard. Tim watched them for a moment before speaking. "I need my friends back, Lucy. You did this, please fix it."

The request took you aback. You couldn't remember Tim ever speaking so kindly to you before, or using your name. Even when you were John, you weren't sure he ever called you by your name. "I'll try my best, Tim." If it was because of you that Rachel and Stephanie were still girls, you did want to fix it. You'd focus on that, and try not to think about the evil witches hiding in the dark.

"It was some sort of shiny, silvery powder. Almost like glitter. It exploded on them when they opened their lockers," Mom explained.

You couldn't help but giggled. "So Rick and Steve got turned into girls by a literal glitter bomb?"

Hannah, who was lying on the floor nearby doing a sketch, nodded excitedly. "It was sooooo funny. I saw the whole thing."

Mom shot Hannah a disapproving look. "Then you should have reported it immediately, young lady. As it turns out, the witch council didn't find out until hours later when Tim informed his Mom about it." She shook her head. Sometimes, she worried her daughters were too strong-willed and independently minded. It was a good thing in many ways, but it also meant they could be very mischievous.

Hannah became flustered, but defended her actions. "They wanted to play with me and they were fun. I still like them better this way."

Before Mom could come down on Hannah again, you spoke up. "So this isn't temporary like the karma spell I put on them last week."

"Yes. They will remain girls until the spell is broken, and that's proving problematic. Normally, we would trace the spell back to the witch who cast it and force them to remedy it, but whoever did this is an expert at not leaving a magical fingerprint. Fortunately, we could at least determine it wasn't your magic that was responsible. It's the only reason the council hasn't forced you to go to Witchbloom."

"Witchbloom?" you said in surprise and a hint of panic. "I don't want to go to Witchbloom. I want to stay at home."

"Believe me, I agree. Six is a little young to go to a boarding school, and I honestly don't feel like it's safe there right now. But the Witch Council will not allow a witch who doesn't have control of her powers to remain in the company of regular humans. Fortunately, they've been too busy to notice the sock incident today."

You blushed deep red. You had forgotten to tell mom that part. She must have heard from somewhere else. "I'm really sorry about that."

"Don't worry. From the sound of it, you handled the situation perfectly, but we must do more to help you learn about and control your powers."

Did that mean MAGIC LESSIONS???!!! Your face brightened when you heard that. You were very excited about that prospect. "Are you going to teach me, Mommy?" In your excitement, the word "Mommy" slipped out. You didn't notice, but Hannah did and smiled to herself. She enjoyed any sign you were turning more and more into her girly little sister.

Mom shook her head. "I'm sorry, but I won't be. You four girls are keeping my hands full as it is, and given her new friendship with Cassie, I think I need to give Mel more of my attention." She noticed your face fall, so she was quick to reassure you. "But don't worry, I have a teacher in mind for you. I was thinking maybe Mrs. Belacourt could teach a few days a week."

She had helped you with your magic before during your sleepover with Liz, and having her as your teacher meant you'd probably get to spend more time with Liz. There was just one thing that bothered you about it. "But I thought the Belacourts didn't have very strong magic. Will Liz's mom really be able to teach me anything?"

"Absolutely. Her knowledge as a researcher of witchcraft makes her an expert and she's a wonderful teacher. She'll help you even more than I could. I've already spoken to her and she'll be happy to do it."

You jumped in the air excitedly. "Woo-Hoo, I get to have magic lessons!!!!" You couldn't wait to tell Liz.

Mom smiled. "I'm glad you're excited about it. I'm glad to have some good news after this rough day." She slumped back in an arm chair exhausted.

Suddenly, you remembered something Mom had said. "Wait, Mom. You said Witchbloom wasn't safe right now. What do you mean by that?"

Mom gritted her teeth. She had been hoping not to have to tell you about this, but realized she had slipped up. "Eva and Helena struck last night. A Witchbloom student went missing, a friend of Hayley's."

You and Hannah looked at each other with wide eyes and then back at Mom.

"Thanks," you answered. "Wanna play until dinner or something?"

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
The night had been a long one. Despite your efforts, Hayley's friend had never been found, but the Witch Council was more optimistic about finding her after the new information you had found. You all just had to keep hoping.

As you and Hannah walked into school, the subject of Rachel and Stephanie came up again. "Even if the magic that turned Rachel and Stephanie into girls is too powerful, I still feel like I should do anything I can to help change them back," you told Hannah.

Hannah sighed. She still thought Rachel and Stephanie were better as girls, but she understood you felt a sense of duty to Tim. "I guess so."

You felt bad. You felt a lot of sympathy for your sister's position, so you tried to cheer her up. "You heard Mom though. Whatever I do probably won't work. Rachel and Stephanie will probably be around for a while."

Before Hannah could respond, a familiar voice spoke from behind you. "Is that what you think?" It was Tim's voice. He was probably going to yell at you for giving up so easily or something, even though you hadn't given up. You and Hannah turned around slowly, knowing you were about to face his wrath, but as soon as your eyes fell upon him, both your jaws dropped.

Tim was standing there with Rachel and Stephanie, both of whom were wearing poofy dresses. The most shocking thing was that Tim wasn't a boy anymore. He, or she, now had long, well-groomed hair with a pink glittery headband. She had on a purple sequin shirt that read "girls rule," and a pink tutu skirt. The socks he wore were the same pink frilly pair you had given the day before, which made your mind jump quickly to a conclusion. This was your fault somehow.

"Tim..." you said as you recovered your thoughts. "Is...is this because of my spell?"

Tim giggled and shook her head. "No, this wasn't you. And my name is Tiffany now. Tim is a stupid boys name." Tiffany looked at Rachel and Stephanie. "You too go ahead and get things ready. I just want to talk to my cousins."

Rachel and Stephanie giggled. "Sure thing. We're going to have so much fun," Rachel said as she walked off toward her class's lockers.

"We'll see you in class, Hannah. It should be awesome today," Stephanie added. She and Rachel were, then, gone, leaving you and Hannah with Tiffany.

You and Hannah looked at each other. You both felt totally confused. Tiffany herself finally spoke again. "Actually, I'm a little disappointed your spell didn't change me, Lucy. It's so much better being a girl and not some cootie-brain."

"But aren't girls cootie-brains?" Hannah asked confused.

"I used to think so, but now I realize it's boys who have cooties. Fortunately, I got cured, and now I'm a pretty girl like you two." Tiffany's personality seemed exactly the same as Tim's, except now it was boys she hated.

"How exactly did that happen?" you asked worriedly.

"Yesterday afternoon. I had just gotten home when my doorbell rang. I answered it to see Stephanie and Rachel standing there with a package for me. They opened it before I could stop them and it turned out to be a device that released more of that powder that turned them into girls yesterday."

"Another glitter bomb?" Hannah asked in surprised. It was weird. Where had Stephanie and Rachel gotten another glitter bomb? They weren't witch girls. They wouldn't have known how to make them.

Tiffany smiled at Hannah's choice of words. "You're calling them glitter bombs? That's a good name for them. I think I'll use it from now on."

"Where did those two get another glitter bombs?" you asked Tiffany.

Tiffany shrugged. "Don't know. Don't want to know. Probably whoever put the glitter bombs in their locker in the first place. Whoever it was will get in a lot of trouble if they are caught, and I don't want them to be. This is the best thing that ever happened to me. I'm sure you understand, Lucy. I'm a witch girl now."

You nodded slowly, but you weren't sure you agreed. It took you a lot of time to come to terms with being a girl, yet Tim, who had hated girls, seemed to have adjusted instantly. Maybe whatever spell was put on him was messing with his brain too. "So what happened after you got hit with the glitter?"

I don't want Rachel and Stephanie to be boys anymore. In fact, I'm going to help them make sure there aren't any boys at school anymore."

Tiffany smiled. "You will, or you'll get a faceful of glitter too. You two are already girls, but the glitter will make you at least she things my way. You'll help us get rid of all the boys."

You weren't sure what to do. You didn't want to let anymore boys get turned into...well...basically, girly glitter zombies, but Tiffany would almost certainly put you under the spell too if you tried anything. You could also retreat and get in touch with Mom, but that would allow more boys to be turned in the meantime, including possibly Mike Cutie, who you spotted headed toward his locker down the hall. Who knew if there was a glitter bomb waiting for him there?

Hayley sighed and pinched the bridge of her nose. "This couldn't have happened at a worse time. The Witch Council is busy dealing with this, instead of looking for..." She trailed off before she finished her sentence. Her friend from Witchbloom was still missing, and she understandably wanted them to be found. But a thought had occurred to her. You looked embarrassed. "Sorry, Mommy. I know it would have been better to just get away and call you, but it was so hard to walk away."

"You stand up when you see others in trouble," Mom brushed your hair. "For that, I'm proud of you. I know you'll make a great..." She paused as if she was stopping herself from saying something. "...You'll make a great witch someday, but until then, try to be more cautious about things like this."

You nodded, though you also knew this kind of thing seemed to continue to happen. Why would next time be any different?

----------------------------------

She probably found out what we were doing, and then made sure it all went to hell." Both Cassie and Samantha enjoyed turning boys into girls. This meant Samantha probably had her typical fun and made sure Cassie would be blamed.

Mel gulped. "So we got lucky this didn't turn into a bigger thing. We would have really been in trouble if the whole school had been turned into girls."

Cassie nodded. "Yeah, but if Samantha planted any evidence that points to us, this could still be bad." She groaned. "I didn't think the witch would go this far. She really wants war." She took a second to collect herself. "Alright, we shouldn't be seen together, right now. Keep your heads down and I'll see you girls later." The three quickly split up and headed out into the school.

After about an hour's wait, Aunt Catherine stepped into the school office. She had been with Tim or Tiffany while some members of the witch council tried to assess how to help him...or her.

"Catherine, how's Tim?"

Christina stepped into Samantha Forrester's shop, looking back to make sure not one she knew was there. She was skipping school and she didn't need anyone ratting her out. All clear, she made her way to the counter with purpose. Samantha was there, smiling with curiosity as the girl approached.

I can't make any friends, and I have all these weird feelings I can't control. At least if I were six again, I could have time to adjust, and I could be with my friend again."

"I see. Well, those glasses you bought from me were cursed to turn boys into six-year old girls. You should have stuck with that age when you had the chance if you miss it so much."

Christina sighed. "If I had realized, I was going to be this miserable I wouldn't have let Mrs. Harrison return to being 13. It was a mistake. Now I'm asking you to fix it."

"Why me?" Samantha asked curiously.

"Mrs. Harrison says she can't. and it might be dangerous, and my Mom is listening to her. But you were famous for turning boys into girls back in the day. I know you still enjoy doing it. I figured you were the person to turn to," Harry responded. Samantha smiled. Harry wasn't wrong. She could definitely do it. Of course, they'd be a price.

"I can do it, but I don't do things for others for free, Ms. Rich. If you want me to turn you back into a six-year-old, you have to do a favor for me."

Christina nodded. "Anything. I'll do anything. I can't take another day like this."

A wicked smirk grew across Samantha's face and she reached down and pulled out a glitter bomb. "A member of Cassie's coven just used two of these to transform a couple of boys in Hannah Harrison's class into girly girls. I want you to give these new girls a few more..."

Mom considered the possibility, hoping Mel wouldn't have gotten involved in something so stupid. She, then, turned to Christina. "Christina, who put you up to this? I can help you, but you must be honest with us."

Christina thought for a moment. Even though she got caught maybe Samantha would still honor her part of the deal. Especially if she could still push the blame on Cassie's coven.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Make me!" Christina shouted back. She stormed into the guest bathroom and slammed the door.

"Well, that went terribly," Mom sighed. "She's forgotten most of the time she spent trying to adjust to being a girl, so it's like we're back to square one all over again."

You groaned. "Why can't we just make her six like me again?"

Mom shook her head. "It's dangerous countering the magic I used to make her 13 again in the first place." She said the next part of her thought loud enough so she could easily be heard in bathroom. "But if someone doesn't stop acting like a child, I'll risk it."

There was a loud huff that came from the bathroom, but that was all. Mom was clearly frustrated, so now probably wasn't the time to ask her about the whole witch royalty thing, but you thought of something that would probably relax her. You looked over the nail polish Mom had set aside, before choosing a sparkly purple color. You picked it up and showed it to Mom. "Could you do my nails while we wait?"

Mom smiled. "I wish Christina was as open to all this as you are. Sit. I'll do your toes too." She sat you down and took off your shoes and socks. Already she seemed to be calming down, which made you smile.

"It's fun," you said matter-of-factly. "Being stubborn about it is just going to make me miserable, besides being a witch girl is pretty awesome." You paused for a second while Mom focused on putting a coat of polish on your toes. "Hey, Mom. Am I going to like boys someday?" Christina's protest on the subject got you wondering.

Mom paused, unsure how to respond. "I suppose so, though sometimes girls prefer other girls as you know." She took a second to think and then presented a question of her own. "Does that bother you?"

You shrugged, honestly unsure what to think. "I don't know. I guess it should, but it doesn't really. I mean, I feel pretty weird and gross thinking about it, but it also sounds...kinda..." You trailed off, unsure of where you were going with that.

Mom finished your toes in silence, before moving on to your fingernails. Finally, she spoke again. "You sound like a regular girl your age and it's probably similar to how you felt about girls as a six-year-old boy."

You nodded. You guessed that made sense.

The two of you sat for another couple minutes until Mom finished your nails. "There we go. You should give them a minute to dry, but how do they look?"

You held out your hand and admired her work. "It's really pretty, Mom. Thanks."

Mom ruffled your hair. "I just wish Christina was as open to this as you were. If she was six, you could show her the ropes."

You made a face. You had only been a girl for a few weeks, you couldn't imagine being a mentor for another transformed girl. "Really?" You tone was disbelieving.

Mom nodded. "Really."

You thought for a moment. "Maybe she should be six like me then. You're looking after her, right? So you're allowed to transform her if you need to?"

Mom shook her head. "Yes, but it would be danger..." She stopped suddenly. Her face had an expression you recognized. Mom had an idea.

"What is your idea, mommy?" you asked, but mom answered by walking upstairs. You remained where you were, guessing this was something mom wanted to do alone. She walked to the bathroom, placed a hand to the door's handle, which instantly disintegrated. Christina, shocked at seeing the locked door opening, said, "How did you get in?!"

Mom smiled almost ruefully. "Witch remember, but I'd appreciate if you kept the whole 'ignoring the locked door' thing to ourselves. Its considered impolite, and more importantly, against one of my rules.

"I don't want your 'lessons'" Christina said, as she struggled to remove her bra. Mom sighed.

"Rejecting this new reality you've got won't change the fact you're now a teen girl, Christina, but I'm not here to give you a lecture, or girl lessons. I've realized something" mom said.

"Which is?" Christina demanded, as she still struggled with the clasps at the bra.

"Treating you like Lucy and the others was a mistake. No offense intended, but you're weak, magically speaking compared to them. Feeding them knowledge slowly is much safer for them. Not so much for you. I need to tell you more."

"Go on" Christina said cautiously, her struggles with her bra momentarily forgotten.

"You were advanced to your normal age to disrupt your life as little as possible. Unfortunately it is almost impossible to reverse any of it, no matter what Lucy, or Forester, or anyone else might say. Any attempt to 'regress' you would probably end up like this" mom said, pointing to one of Mel's cans of shaving foam. Instantly, the can crumpled, crushed by an unseen force, with some foam oozing out. Christina looked slightly horrified.

"I'm not doing this out of malice, or self amusement, like some have" mom said. "I want you to be able to function normally, and not to be a target of .mean girls. which unfortunately is the clique that Mel has foolishly joined. As for the stuff I've tried to teach you, they're kind of the basics. You have to know how to get out of... and into our own bra, unless you want backache. As for my 'no tomboy' rule, its there to act as a dampener on the girls' powers. Not a problem for you. You can dress however you want, but I insist you wear proper underwear, and no boys' clothes. I need you to be a role model for Lucy. I'll leave you to get dressed.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
The next day...

You poked absent-mindly at your lunchroom Mac and Cheese, thinking about everything that had happened the last few days. Today, there was no magical crisis or evil witches afoot. Sure Eva and Helena were still out there, but that didn't stop this day from feeling weirdly normal. You were just hanging out at the lunch table at school with Liz and your normal human friends, Ellen, Keira, Jennifer, Tammy, and Becky. Just talking about normal stuff, like what you were doing after school. The group had been having fun together, but you had gotten lost in thought and lost track of the conversation.

"Lucy?"

You looked up to see Ellen and Keira looking at you. The two had asked you a question, but you hadn't heard what it was. "Sorry, spaced out. What did you ask?"

Ellen repeated the question. "I asked if you knew what your costume for Halloween was."

You honestly hadn't thought about it, and Halloween was just a couple weeks away. John had gotten too old for dressing up, but now, as Lucy, you were pretty excited about the idea of trick-or-treating again. Still, with all the chaos going on you hadn't given it much thought. "I don't know yet. I guess I should figure someone out soon."

Keira and Ellen looked at each other and grinned. "You should join us," Keira said excitedly.

You nodded. "That would be fun. But I still have no idea what my costume should be."

Ellen shook her head. "You don't understand. Every year since Pre-K, the six of us have been doing a group costume and trick-or-treating together. Like, last year we were all the characters from My Little Pony. I was Twilight Sparkle. Keira was Applejack."

Liz, who was sitting next to you, piped in. "I was Fluttershy."

You smiled. "So you want me to be part of this year's group costume? Sounds like fun." You were getting excited about it. "What's the costume this year."

"Disney Princesses." Keira said this very matter-of-factly, but you winced a bit. Princesses were still a little too girly for your tastes, but as long as you weren't stuck wearing a poofy pink gown, you could probably manage.

"So can I be whoever i choose? Or do we just get whoever we can find in the store." you asked hesitantly. You tried to think of who would be the least objectionable princess to be.

"Well, my mom made most of the costume a couple weeks ago," Keira explained. "She's makes costumes for local plays, so she makes the best stuff. But I told her we had a new friend in our group and she said she could make one more princess dress before Halloween, so you just have to figure out who you want to be and she can make it."

"Which princesses are taken already?"

"I'm going to be Belle," Liz said. "Ellen chose Elsa, Keira chose Ariel, Becky chose Aurora, Jennifer chose Tiana, and Tammy is going to be Anna."

Well, at least all the pink dresses were already spoken for. Then Keira had an idea. "How about Cinderella? I bet you'd make a beautiful Cinderella and her dress is so pretty. Mom would love to make a Cinderella dress."

You hesitated. Cinderella's dress wasn't pink, but it was pretty poofy and girly. You weren't sure about that. Still, you wanted to join your friends and Cinderella's dress was pretty sparkly, which you did like.

Upon seeing you Tim stormed off, followed by Rachel and Stephanie.

"Is he still mad at you? You saved him," Liz whispered to you.

You shrugged. "He'll always find a reason to blame me somehow. Were the witch council not able to turn Rachel and Stephanie back?" That was the more pressing question for you.

Keira's face brightened as you said that. "I'm so excited to hear you say that. Let me talk to Mom. Maybe you can come by for a fitting in a day or two?"

"Let's be clear about something, Timothy," Mom said as she pulled his hand away from your hair. "If your mother knew I caught you doing this, she'd have absolutely no problem with me punishing you however I see fit. And my punishments involve frills."

Tim blushed. He hadn't noticed your Mom approaching and he was quickly trying to think of a way to protect himself. "I was just joking around. Geez, girls are so sensitive." With that he huffed, and walked away.

You sighed with relief. "Thanks, Mom."

Mom smiled. "Don't worry, Lucy. I won't let him bother you, and I can promise you I will be telling his mother exactly what happened here." You and Liz giggled at the thought, but Mom moved on to other things. "Now, where is Hannah? We don't want to be late for your first ballet lesson, Lucy."

Your face fell. You had forgotten that was today. Liz tried to cheer you up. "Just give it a try. You've enjoyed everything else you tried."

You nodded knowing she was right, but it still felt like another step you won't be able to take back. "I guess so. It seems so boring though."

Before Liz could respond, Hannah dashed up out of breath. "Sorry, Mom. I was talking to Rachel and Stephanie and lost track of time."

Hannah mentioning those girls sparked your memory. "Oh yeah, Mom. Why are those two still girls? Or did they turn back to girls? I thought the witch council turned all the glitter bomb victims back into boys, like Tim was." You hoped she had answers.

Mom bit her lip as she considered how to answer.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You moaned with great distress as you entered the ballet studio. "Why can't evil witches attack right now?" you asked aloud.

Mom shot you a look. "Don't even joke about that. Especially since we're in public where anyone can hear you."

"It's fine. I'm six. Regular humans will assume I'm just playing pretend," you responded. But Mom's face told you not to test her on this. "Fine. Sorry." You rolled your eyes. You looked over at Hannah who was looking way too excited about you joining the class. That was probably the most troubling part for you. You were turning into the little sister of Hannah's princess-filled dreams, and, to make matters worse, for the most part, you were enjoying it too. "Hannah, please don't get to crazy about this. I'm here. I'm trying it, but I don't want to be fussed over."

Hannah nodded. She understood. She did want you to enjoy yourself and you had a better chance of doing so if she didn't smother you. "Sorry, I'm going to say hello to some of my friends." She dashed off to join some girls her age.

While Mom got you signed in, you and Liz sat quietly on a nearby bench. You were nervous and didn't feel much like talking. Liz understood that and didn't pressure you, and you loved her for that. Finally, you asked her. "What's the point of a tutu anyway? Just to look girly or something?"

Liz shook her head. "Madame Sokolov, our ballet teacher, says its to help show off the feet and leg movements ballet dancers do."

You considered this. "Well, I just hope I don't have to wear one."

"We only have to wear them for recitals, but Madame Sokolov likes us to wear them sometimes so we get use to dancing in them."

You made a displeased noise at that news. You didn't want to wear a tutu. For one thing, you were afraid you wouldn't hate it as much as you felt like you should. "At least if I take this class, Mom will let me do gymnastics too."

"That will be fun," Liz agreed.

Mom returned with a woman in her early 30s who smiled and waved at Liz. Liz smiled back and called her named. This was Madame Sokolov, your new ballet teacher. She looked at you. "So you must be Lucy. Your sister Hannah is a wonderful girl. I look forward to having you in my class too." She spoke with a faint Russian accent.

"Thanks," you responded nervously. "Do I...have to wear a tutu?"

Madame Sokolov chuckled at this. "A leotard and tights should suffice for today, but you are welcome to wear a tutu anytime you want."

"Okay," you paused and looked at Mom nervously. "I'm going to need help getting changed," you admitted after a moment.

Madame Sokolov smiled in understanding. "Yes, many girls need help changing their first couple times. I'm sure you'll get used to it."

"I've got your ballet clothes right here," Mom said. "Let's go change in the bathroom." She thank Madame Sokolov andled you toward the nearest bathroom. You took a look at what Mom had picked out for you.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Ballet class was fun. Really fun. You had a great time. Ballet was relaxing and it made you feel at ease with your body in a way you hadn't before. You were nervous when you started, but Liz was placed next to you and she helped you find your feet. It was a good first class. And your outfit was comfortable. You liked the way it felt on your body and you were starting to not mind the color. Why were you so afraid of pink? It didn't hurt you. In fact you felt kind of pretty in it. However, your face looked absolutely miserable. Though it wasn't because you didn't enjoy the class. It was cause you knew you were going to have to admit to Mom and Hannah you really did enjoy it and you were actually looking forward to next time.

"You okay?" Liz asked with concerned as you both walked from the studio floor.

You looked around to make sure Hannah and Mom couldn't overhear. "I really had fun."

Liz smiled. "Yeah, I could tell."

"But I'm embarrassed to tell Mom and Hannah...cause I really said I didn't want to do ballet."

Liz nodded. "Yeah, I hate admitting I was wrong about stuff too. Maybe you don't have to tell them."

You sighed. "They're going to find out eventually anyway. And I want to be honest with them." You thought for a second. "I should be honest with myself to. I'm a doll-loving, ballet-taking, wannabe princess, girly girl and I love it." Saying that to Liz felt like a weight off your shoulders, like saying it aloud made it real and you were accepting it.

Liz giggled. "I'm one too. And I'm glad you admit it."

You grinned widely. "Can you imagine if I had never been turned into a six-year-old girl? We never would have become friends."

"I know, right? That would have been awful." Liz looked like she was trying to say something. "You're...you're my best friend, Lucy."

You blushed as you took that information in. Finally, you responded. "You're my best friend too, Liz." You pulled her into a hug. "Turning into a girl was the best thing to ever happen to me."

Liz's eyes went wide, which, of course, you couldn't see, then she coughed and you looked behind you. Mom was standing right there. You blushed deeply. How much had she heard? Mom smiled. "Well, Lucy, how was your first ballet lesson?"

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Oh..." You weren't sure what to say beyond that. "Anyway, this isn't a tutu. It's a ballet skirt." And you liked it, though you weren't going to admit that out loud to Christina of all people.

"Whatever. I'll survive not knowing the difference between a tutu and a ballet shirt," Christina retorted as she rolled her eyes.

That struck a nerve. You couldn't help but feel she was talking down to you. "Right back at you. Stop whining about your clothes and start learning to enjoy yourself," you snapped at her. "When are you going to realize how lucky we are to not be stupid boys anymore?"

You suddenly realized there was a presence behind you, and you turned around fearing that Mom or Hannah had just heard you. Fortunately, it was just Liz, who had just caught up with you. You looked back at Christina, awaiting a response from her.

However, Christina was basically speechless. Your loyalty to your new gender and your growing rejection of your old one she simply couldn't understand. Triumphant, you took Liz's hand and pulled her toward your room, leaving Christina to consider what you said and how to get out of her current predicament.

Liz giggled as you pulled her into your room. "Nothing's ever boring with you."

You nodded in agreement. "Yeah, but I wish it would be sometimes." Now was your chance to ask Liz about what Mom had overheard. "How much did Mom hear me say back in the ballet studio?"

Liz shrugged. "I don't know, maybe all of it. She was smiling when I noticed her." You sighed depressed by this news. "Is it really the worst thing that your Mom heard you say you're glad you're a girl?"

"I guess not," you admitted. "And she probably knows it already. She's really good at knowing stuff."

"Well, the sooner you tell them you like being girly, the sooner Hannah will stop trying to pressure you to be girly."

You had to admit Liz had a point, but it wasn't easy to crush your old ego, even though you really wanted to. "You wanna sleepover tonight?" you asked, changing the subject.

You and your sisters all shifted nervously, unsure what to do. "What are they going to do to her?"

Hayley sighed. "Steal her magic most likely."

Your eyes widen. "But if her magic is stolen, she'll be a girl forever. She won't be able to be a boy again."

Mel looked at you with a weird expression. "Weren't you threatening to make her a girl forever too?"

You blushed. "Yeah, we all were. But this is different."

Mel shrugged. "I don't care if Christina ever becomes a boy again, but these witches have to be stopped or they'll take all our power."

Hannah was starting to cry. You felt like you would at any moment too. "What do we do?" you asked.

Hayley went for the phone. "We call our Grandma. We need her right now."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Christina versus the rouge witches

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Minutes later, the Harrison house was swarming with Witch Council investigators and your grandmother, Elvira, was talking with you and your sisters. "You girls did the right thing. You couldn't have helped Christina. I know it must have been hard though, but you couldn't have fought them."

"Maybe Vader could have," one investigator chuckled to herself, causing you to blush deep red. A quick burst of magic from Elvira sent the investigator zooming out of the room and slammed the door.

"You're getting quite a reputation at the Witch Council, Lucy," Hayley muttered darkly.

"All the more reason I'm glad you two kept her from doing anything foolish," Elvira responded. You and sisters looked at each other, remembering you discovered Christina was missing immediately after planning to do something to her that would have qualified as foolish in Elvira's mind.

"What about Mommy?" Hannah asked.

"She's handling the Johnson child situation. We cannot afford to be exposed to humans and as such, she has to stay on that until she's finished," Elvira said before sighing. "I really thought she could have gotten through to the Rich girl, but I can't help but feel we should have just erase her mind of any male thoughts or memories and been done with it." You and your sisters didn't exactly disagree with that assessment.

You then asked the question everyone had been afraid to ask. "Will the Witch Council be able to find Christina in time?"

Elvira sighed. "I honestly don't know. We still haven't found the last couple witches the Morgana sisters took." Your face went white. Hannah hugged Hayley's arm. "I know it's scary to hear, but I don't believe coddling you with false hope will help. This world can be scary and you girls need to be ready for it. Especially if those women come back."

Mel raised an eyebrow. "What do you mean 'come back'? Like, wouldn't this be the worst place to show their faces again."

Elvira shook her head. "Logically, yes, but we have realized based on the missing witches, the Morgana sisters are targeting female witches who were born male and taking their power, thinking they make for easier targets."

Your eyes went wide. "They weren't here for Christina. They were here for me."

"Or both of you." Your grandmother really didn't pull punches. "But yes, given your extreme magic potential, we can't ignore the possibility that you are a target, even if you've essentially committed yourself to staying a girl."

You were going to ask what she meant by essentially, but Mel spoke first. "I have a really dumb idea." Everyone in the room looked at her with no idea what to expect. "If Lucy's a target, why not use her to draw out Eva and Helena? You could set up a trap with, like, the entire witch council lying in wait."

"You want to use your little sister as evil witch bait?" Hayley responded in surprise.

"Besides, why would we leave Lucy alone after this? The Morganas would never buy that," Elvira said.

Mel shrugged. "I said it was a dumb idea. But I'm just saying, Lucy has, like, a known history of running off half-cocked and taking on big bad witches. It wouldn't be so unbelievable." The room was silent. Mel actually made a decent point.

Elvira shook her head. "I'm still not endangering my Granddaughter like that. She's only a child."

"What if I want to do it?" you asked suddenly.

Mel, amused, patted your head. "See what I mean?"

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Christina sat tied to a chair with a rag shoved in her mouth, held in place with duct tape. In front of her two tall and slender women stood, sizing her up. Eva was the eldest with long red hair and hazel eyes while Helena had long strawberry blond hair and green eyes. Both were wearing long black dresses and flats. They watched in bemusement as Christina struggled against her bonds, throwing death glares at them.

"My, my are you feisty." Amused, Eva said. "Clearly you are a transformed boy."

"From what we had gathered, you are on a quest to return to your boyish state." Grinning, Helena added. "We can help you with that as we had helped many others."

Christina stopped struggling, looking at the two women with a distrusting eye. Eva removed the duct tape with a painful pull then took the cloth out of Christina's mouth. "What do you say, kid?" Calmly, she asked. "Do you want to become a boy again?"

"I already went to an expert in gender spells and she double crossed me for some mischief." Angry, Christina snapped. "What guarantee do I have that you won't do the same?"

"You don't." Simply, Helena replied. "It's take our offer or take a hike."

"Why kidnap me then?" Worried, Christina demanded. "Why not talk to me on the street?"

"i'm certain Elvira Strange told you." Coldly, Eva said. "We are wanted by the witch council for working outside of their silly laws."

"We give help to transformed boys who decide they do not want to be witches by ensuring they will never be witches again." With a smirk, Helena said. "The only catch is, the witch in question has to want it to happen."

Christina remembered mom talking about how she nearly lost her powers due to these two women and realized that her brother had stormed the house before she could say 'yes' to whatever offer they had tried to trick her into. She bit her lip, not certain of what to do. On one hand, she had an opportunity to become a boy again. On the other hand, she had no guarantee that they were trying to trick her just as they almost did to mom.

"What is your answer!" Forcefully, Eva demanded. "We don't have all night!"

"We had to" Helena said with faux-sweetness. It came across as menacing to Christina.

"Yeah right. Mrs H and her girls have lied to me and want to turn me into a girl..."

I wouldn't be too surprised if you've used magic to manipulate me, or turned my friend into such a bratty princess. So, as I said before, no, I will not take any of your 'offers' and for you to go to hell, you bitch!" 1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Eva thought for a second, then answered in a hiss. "You know I hate such decisions, sister, for there are just so many options. We should steal her magic, of course."

"Of course," agreed Helena.

"But we also may want to turn her into the happy girl she so fears being. Mind so focused on boys and looking pretty. Of course, that's not all there is to being a girl, but since it is all she seems to think it is than perhaps that's all it should be for her." Christina made another move to get free hearing Eva suggest this option, but it was to no avail.

Helena nodded. "That could be fun."

"Then again maybe leaving in her mind intact while trapping her forever as a girl would be more appropriate punishment for her rudeness. We could even age her down, so she could be reunited with her old friend."

"Ha, that one you can't do," Christina responded quickly, desperate to get some power back in this situation. "Mrs. H said my age is locked. She was only able to make me 13 again with a lot of struggle."

The two sisters laughed at this show of defiance. Helena quickly deflated Christina's retort. "What do take us for, child? We've been stealing magic from transformed boys in the area for a week, and we stole magic from many more in other regions before that. We've got more power than Natalie Harrison could ever dream of possessing. If we want to make you six, or eight, or one-hundred and three, we can do it with ease." This shut Christina up.

Eva continued to think. "You know, sister, we could also turn her into a cat, like we did those other transformed boys we've captured. Though I suppose we've collected a bit too many at this point. They can be ever so troublesome to take care of."

Helena shrugged. "I still say we don't need to keep every cat."

Eva made a pouty face. "Oh, but they are sooo cute, sister."

A lightbulb suddenly went off in Helena's head. "Wait a second, sister. This girl was friends with the new Princess." Christina perked up. Princess? Who was a Princess? "She's been living in the Princess's house after all. The Princess was even there at the window as we took this wretched one. You know how we've been waiting to get our hands on the Princess. She's got more magic of any transformed boy."

Christina couldn't help herself. "Are you saying Lucy's a Princess? What do you mean?"

Helena ignored her. "We could turn this girl into our mindless agent, tasked with the soul purpose of bringing the Princess to us. She could get closer than Elvira will ever let us get."

Christina suddenly had an idea, but what she was about to do was a total betrayal. She wasn't sure she'd ever be able to look Mrs. Harrison in the face again for even suggesting this, but she was desperate to be a boy again, and, as far as she was concerned the Harrison family had turned on her first by trying to have her accept her new form. "Wait. You don't need to put any spells on me. I'll bring you Lucy."

This caught the sisters' attention. They seemed assumed by the idea. "You'd betray them all? Why? To keep your magic?"

Christina shook her head. "No, you can take my magic too. It's brought me nothing, but trouble. But if what you say about having enough magic to change my age is true, you must have enough to turn me into a boy. Take my magic, make me a boy, and I will bring you Lucy Harrison."

The sisters looked at each other unsure. It certainly was a tempting offer, but this child had been obnoxious to them, and they would so like to torture him accordingly. And what assurance did they have that Christina would do what they ask once she got what she wanted. Besides, even if Christina would have an easier time getting to you, the two were confident that they could find a way to do it themselves. It just might be more troublesome.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"If you are so willing to betray your friends, it won't take much for you to betray us as well." Frowning, Eva said. "I'd much rather take your magic and leave you a normal little girl in an orphanage somewhere with no memory."

"That's too kind for this obnoxious little brat." Frowning as well, Helena said. "I'd rather take her magic and leave her in the middle of nowhere with the emptiness of having no magic like we did to the last transformed boy who crossed us."

Christina gulped, knowing she was in trouble and winced as she felt a spell hit her only... nothing seemed to happen. "What is this?!" Annoyed, Helena demanded. "Why is her magic not coming to me?!"

"You likely didn't rest up like I told you to, dear sister." Sternly, Eva snapped. "Let me show you how its done."

Again, Christina felt magic hit her but still nothing seemed to happen. Eva cursed before turning to Helena, motioning her to follow. The two stepped away and began to whisper to each other. Christina strained her ears to listen.

"The brat's mother and father have an immunity to magic." Hissing, Eva said. "Becoming a girl must have sparked that immunity within her which explains why Natalie did not make efforts to change her back into a boy."

Helena nodded, frowning. "Such immunity can be worked around but it takes a lot of power." Whispering, she said. "What do you suggest we do now?"

"She could become useful if we can get her on our side." Thoughtful, Eva whispered. "She can't me more difficult to sway than Natalie was."

"Or we can just increase our power, take her magic and be done with it." Serious, Helena quietly argued. "If we can't take her power, we can just wipe her memory and get rid of her."

Eva sighed before locking her jaws in decision...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: A strange twist.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Eva sighed before locking her jaws in decision. "We'll increase our power and be rid of her." Serious, she said. "There are other ways to get to the princess."

Helena nodded and the two turned to Christina only to see her slowly fade from sight before returning then fade from sight completely. Realizing that their captive had been teleported out, Eva screamed and blasted the wall, leaving a sizeable dent in anger. Helena took a startled step back. "I checked her for magical trackers!" Defensive, she said. "There were none!"

Eva took a breath. "Elvira is a clever one." Through gritted teeth, she said. "She had to have found a way to mask it somehow."

Inside your home, you cheered as Christina appeared, still tied to the chair. "It worked!" Ecstatic, you yelled. "I did it!" You giggled then yawned deeply as you pointed at Christina, smiling. "You owe me an ice cream!"

Christina blushed, embarrassed that she was rescued by a little kid even though she knew you were once as old as she was. "Untie me..." Pouting, she demanded.

"Elvira was wise to order a masked tracker on Christina when she first started acting out." Ignoring her, one of the witch investigators said. "Such transformed boys are easily swayed by the criminal element."

"Good work, Lucy." Bemused, mom said. "Only I believe its past your bedtime."

You gave another deep yawn. "But... I'm not, uh, sleepy." Lamely, you protested.

"Come along, kiddo." Smiling, Hayley said. "You've had enough excitement for one day."

Hayley urged you up the stairs and into your bedroom where she waved her hand, changing you out of your clothes and into a princess nightgown. "But I want to see Christina..." Yawning, you started to say.

"Christina is in trouble and you do not need to see or hear that happen." Turning serious, Hayley said. "You are our little hero of the day but doing what you did has drained you to the point of exhaustion." She ruffled your hair, smiling again. "You would not be able to stay awake to see it anyway."

You wanted to protest further but your body had other plans and you were very quickly fast asleep, having pleasant dreams. Hayley shook her head, bemused the left your room, quietly closing the door behind her.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You woke up the next morning to Mom gently shaking you. You rubbed your eyes trying to wake up. "Is it time for school?"

"I'm keeping you home from school today," Mom said. "You missed a lot last night and I really need your help today."

This got your attention. "What with? How'd it go with the Johnsons?" you asked hopping out of bed.

Mom sighed. She clearly hadn't slept much last night. "I made it just in time. They have no memory of last night and their son is back to being their son, but that's not the reason I need your help. It's about Christina. Come on, you can change later."

"Okay, Mommy" you said as you followed her.

"I heard about your adventure last night. I'm very proud of you. Proud of Mel too, oddly, even though I am very glad you didn't end up going with her plan. But you were very brave."

You smiled hearing this. "Thanks, Mommy."

"Anyway, after you went to bed last night Christina faced Elvira's judgment. She decided that Christina's out-of-control behavior recently has been so extreme because Christina doesn't have you as a friend anymore. When you were John and she was Harry, you kept him grounded. You kept him from falling apart like she is now," Mom explained.

"Well, he still bought magic items, which is what started this whole thing in the first place, so I guess I didn't do that great a job. Even though I'm glad it happened. I wouldn't be a girl otherwise," you pointed out.

"I'm not sure about that. I have a feeling you would have become a girl somehow anyway, but that's not the point." Mom got back on topic. "The point is that Elvira feels that restoring that friendship is key to helping Christina, and with the current age gap between you that is impossible."

"But Liz is my best friend now, and she's a way better friend than Christina ever was." Your eyes went wide in horror. "You're not going to make me 13, are you? I want to grow up normal, Mommy."

Mom was quick to reassure you. "No, we know how you enjoy you're knew life and we wouldn't punish you to help Christina. That girl is in a lot of trouble." She decided not to mention that Christina had been ready to sell you out to the Morganas to reclaim her boyhood, but Elvira had been very displeased about that. "And I'm not asking you to give up your friendship with Liz. I'm just asking you to show Christina the ropes."

"The ropes for what?" you asked as Mom opened the door to the guest bedroom. Inside sat a girl, about your age, wearing yellow pjs. "Christina?" you said in surprise. You turned to Mom. "I thought you said her age was locked?"

"I said only Elvira could possibly have enough power to change it. Turns out I wasn't wrong. This is part of your Grandmother's judgment."

"Hi, Lucy," Christina said meekly. You couldn't get a read on her. She seemed frustrated, angry, but also guilty and sad.

"Hi Christina," you responded cautiously. You turned to Mom again. "So she's my age now? I'm supposed to teacher her how to be a girl like me?"

Christina made a face that seemed to disapprove of that idea, but she didn't say anything. Mom spoke instead. "Go slow, like we did with you. If she wants any hope of being a boy again, she needs to be at ease with her situation. We've seen I can't do that for her. Neither can her parents. Only you can reach her, Lucy."

You nodded and turned back to Christina. "Don't worry, Christina. If you really want to be a boy again, I'll help you. I promise. But you're going to have to trust me, okay?"

Christina sighed. "Yeah, but Elvira says she won't make me 13 again. I have to age up naturally."

You nodded again. "Well, we can be friends again now, I hope. Even if you want to be a boy again." Though the thought of being friends with a boy was strange to you, but for Christina, you would try.

Mom smiled approvingly. Maybe this would work. "You two are going to stay home from school today so you can get used to this."

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom left the room but held back after closing the door so to listen in. Behind her was Hayley with a worried look on her face with Mel behind her, curious and Hannah behind her gripping her teddy bear nervously. "Do you think this will really work?" Wincing, Hannah asked.

"It better." Frowning, Mel said. "Christina is more stubborn than Harry ever was."

"If anyone can get through her thick head and ego, it's Lucy." Smiling, Hayley said. "They had a special kind of connection when they were boys."

"Hush." Whispering, mom scolded. "I'm trying to listen."

"Well, you got your first wish." Managing a smile, you said. "You're my age now."

"It was like pulling teeth with pair of pliers to get it though." Pouting, Christina countered. "Now, its gong to be even harder to be a boy again."

You thought back to when you went through your own transition, though it was not easy. It all seemed more like a distant dream then, only bits and pieces came to mind. Finally, you remembered something important and smiled a little more. "Girl trending a left turn off, what the deal-e-o?"

Christina turned to you, surprised then frowned. "False advertising, not the deal of the century and so not my style."

"What are they doing?" Wincing, Hayley asked.

Mom smiled. "It's nonsense language." Bemused, she said. "She and Liz made it up together to drive us all crazy when they wanted to talk in private." She chuckled. "When she and Christina were John and Harry, they had a similar secret language which is why she picked up on it so fast."

Your smile did not diminish. "By George, Ke-mo-sah-bee I'll have my mixed up friend good as new before you can say Abracadabra." Lightly punching Christina's shoulder, you said. "It's all the latest craze. Hurry on down, limited time offer."

A tint grin touched the corners of Christina's mouth. "You are so weird." With a half chuckle, she said. "What are you talking about?"

"You are afraid of the same things I was afraid of." Turning serious, you said. "Only you had it worse because you felt you had to deal with it alone." You sighed. "Mommy told me that when you and I were boys, I kind of kept you grounded."

"You were the only one who understood what I was going through." Looking hurt, Christina said. "Then they took that away from me and I was completely alone."

"No, you just were scared to ask for help." Scolding, you said. Sighing, you touched Christina's shoulder. "Mommy told me that I reached out to you before so I'm reaching out again. You just have to let me help you."

Christina began to cry and you pulled her into a hug and began to cry yourself.

"It's a start." Sighing, mom said. "Only, like before, its going to take a long time."

"What do you mean?" Worried, Hannah demanded.

Mom turned away from the door and urged everyone to the sitting room, out of ear shot. "When John first reached out to Harry, it took weeks for him to completely get through to him." Softly, she explained. "He had placed some rather thick walls around his heart and mind."

"As Christina, those walls are back and stronger than ever." Serious, Hayley said. "Mom and I sent John to try to get through to Harry because he was acting out at school and at home being left alone for weeks to months at a time."

"I don't remember that." Worried, Mel said.

"Most of that was wiped from your memories." Serious, mom said. "Harry's actions were bringing unwanted attention to this house and his obsession with collecting magical artifacts made it worse. John eased Harry's anger and helped mold him into a better person."

"So, as Christina, she fell into that loneliness all over again." Wincing, Mel said. "Is she really in serious trouble?"

"Not any more than the trouble she was in as Harry the first time." Bemused, mom said. "Only this time, she knows about magic and witches so she is on much thinner ice now."

"Hopefully Lucy can get through to her." Serious, Hayley said.

Mom nodded. "Time will tell."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: You and Christina hang out in her room and talk

Meanwhile, Eva and Helena plot their next move
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You frowned as you shifted through Christina's closet. "There aren't any kids clothes here. Only teenage stuff." Most of it was boy's clothes Christina had refused to give up.

Christina nodded. "Yeah, I only have the clothes I'm wearing. Elvira didn't bother to change anything else." She shifted uncomfortably in her pjs. Even they must be too girly in her mind. Probably the sunny yellow color.

You considered changing all Christina's clothes with magic, but you knew from experience she'd just refuse it all on principal, saying that the clothing was be too girly or worried that they'd make her think like a girl. Wow, you had a lot to teach her. "Let's go to my room. You can borrow some of my stuff."

Unsurprisingly, Christina froze up. "Your clothes? But you've gone all girly-girl."

You rolled your eyes. "You really need to stop saying that. You don't actually know anything about girls." You took Christina's hand. "Just trust me and come on."

Christina reluctantly followed. You liked her a lot better without all the raging teenage hormones. She was less resistant, though she still seemed concerned. "What do you mean I don't know anything about girls?"

"Well, you seem to think that all girls like pink and princesses and whatever," you explained.

"Don't you?"

"Only recently, when I realized how much fun they could be. But actually Christina, I started liking those things after I started liking being a girl."

Christina was surprised to hear this. You and her hadn't spent much time together before she moved into your house, so she didn't have firsthand knowledge of how you had moved from deviant boy trapped in a girl's body to happy ballet-taking 100% girl who dreaded the idea of being a boy again. "Well, what made you want to be a girl, then?"

"The more I thought about it the more I realized I felt more comfortable as a girl than I ever did as a boy. My friends, my magic, and my love for sparkles helped too." You giggled at this. Christina did not. She was deep in thought.

The two of you came to your room and you pulled her over to your closet. "The point is," you continued. "I learned that being a girl doesn't just mean you like princesses and stuff. It can mean anything you want, and that includes how to dress." You pulled out a pair of pants and a t-shirt. "See, girl's clothes, but not pink and princess-y."

Christina reached forward and looked at the shirt. It was light green with design of cheetahs running on it. The pants were basic black, but they did flare out a bit at the ankle. She was quietly thinking about it, while you wondered whether she'd go for it. You were pretty sure you'd hooked her with the shirt, since Cheetahs had been one of her favorite animals since she was a young boy, but the pants could go either way. You hoped she'd go for them though. You didn't have many pairs of pants, preferring leggings, and the other ones you had were bejeweled. You did like sparkles after all. Finally, Christina spoke. "I guess these are okay, but what about your mom's no tomboy rule?"

You shrugged. "She put me in charge of you. I have no such rule."

For the first time in a while, you saw Christina flash a genuine smile. "Thanks, Lucy."

You smiled back. You liked it when Christina called you Lucy, and not John. John was long gone, and hopefully Christina was starting to recognize that.

---------------------------

A few minutes later, the two of you were dressed for the day, Christina wearing the cheetah shirt and blank pants. You wearing a purple shirt that spelled out "Girls Rule" in sequins and grey leggings. Somehow you had convinced Christina to let you brush her hair. She seemed to be regretting that choice. "Ow, that hurt."

"Sorry, you got tons of tangles in there. It's like you have brushed your hair once since we became girls."

"I probably haven't," Christina admitted.

"Well, I promise it will feel better once it's brushed," you assured her. "Maybe we can get Hayley to take us to the mall today. We could buy you some new clothes so you won't be stuck borrowing mine."

Christina scoffed at that suggestion. "I've been there enough times already."

"Not with me," you pointed out. "I won't force anything on you. You can choose what you want." Christina smiled hearing this. "Except boys clothes," you added, sensing what she was thinking. Christina's smile quickly turned into a frown.

"Awww, why not?"

"If you want to be a boy again, you have to be comfortable with your girl self," you explained. That wasn't exactly right, but it was as close an explanation as you could muster. "Boys clothes are hiding from what you've become. You want to be something else, you can't hide from this."

Christina sighed. She didn't like hearing that, but it was a better offer than she had been getting from anyone else. "Fine. But only if we go to the arcade there too."

You grinned at this. "That's fine with me. I still love beating you at video games."
