1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
On this rainy day, Hayley brought you and Christina to the mall while Mom got some sleep at home.

Shopping with Christina was a mixed success. Anything that was too tight, she refused. Anything that was two loose, she refused. And it goes without saying that anything pink, purple or at all feminine, she refused. Even so, you, Christina, and Hayley managed to find a decent collection of clothes that Christina was able to stomach. Mostly tee shirts with unisex slogans and pants. Girls shorts were too short for her liking and skirts and dresses were out of the question. Socks and underwear were a bit trickier, but Christina eventually agreed to some plainer pairs of each. You didn't force anything on her, but you knew this was the first tiny step in a long journey. She seemed skittish and terrified that you were going to trick her into going further than she was comfortable with though. When you found a sparkly dress you wanted for yourself, Christina freaked a bit, but once you explained it was for you she calm down somewhat, but still didn't look happy with your excitement over the outfit.

As a result, you were somewhat afraid to tell Christina that Liz was supposed to sleep over tonight. You didn't know how she was going to react to that news.

------------------------------------------------------------

Once the new clothes were put in the car, the three of you returned inside the mall to visit the arcade, when Christina discovered a new drawback to her new age.

"Dammit," she shouted as her last Pinball went flying past the flippers. "I used to be better at this."

"Don't curse like that," you chided her quietly as you looked around to make sure no one had heard. Fortunately, no one was close. Hayley was sitting quietly on a nearby bench reading a book, but even she didn't hear. Christina's language was not surprising though. You had a similar tendency to curse before you mind had adjusted to match your current body. Now it felt...wrong. "Of course, you used to be better. You've got a new body and you're not used to using it yet."

Christina sighed, frustrated. "It's like I'm playing for the first time again."

"You are. So am I." You tried to be reassuring.

"You got a higher score than I did," Christina pointed out.

You grinned. "Well, I was always better at pinball than you." There was silence for a moment, then Christina started to giggle, which made you happy . "See, we can still have fun together."

Christina nodded. "I guess so. Feels kind of like when we were little kids."

"Christina, we are little kids." This resulted in more giggles.

"What are you two dweebs giggling about?" You and Christina turned to see a boy about a year older than you standing behind you. You didn't recongize him, so he must have gone to a different school. Though what he was doing skipping school on a Friday, you didn't know.

"Nothing. Just having fun with my friend playing pinball," you responded politely.

"Well, get out of the way." He pushed past the two of you. "What do a couple of dumb girls know about pinball? It's a boy's game."

Christina was shocked into silence by this behavior, but you weren't one to stand for being insulted. "Oh yeah, I bet I could get a higher score than you," you challenged him. At this point, Hayley looked up from her book to see if you needed help, but decided you could handle it.

The boy looked at you like you were talking complete nonsense, but proving your ineptness appealed to him. "You're on, sparkle-boots." He was referring to rain boots you were wearing, which were purple and sparkly. Christina had groaned when you chose them for yourself at home.

Not to be out done you responded, "Bring it, blondie." He clearly didn't like being called that, though his hair was indeed quite blonde.

-----------------------------------------------------

For the next five minutes, the battle raged (honestly, despite the heated competition neither of you were that good at pinball). It was close, but eventually you emerged victorious by 50 points.

"Ha!" you shouted at the blonde boy once the your run ended. "See, girls can play pinball." Christina rolled her eyes, well aware, that the scores both you and the blonde boy got paled in comparison to what John and Harry had achieved last summer, but they were 13 and better practiced.

"Whatever," the blonde boy rolled his eyes and began walking away. "Girls are the worst."

You felt a slight rage come over you. How dare this boy? You managed to control your magic so as not to be curse him unintentionally, but you also weren't going to let that insult go. With a wave of your hand and a quick chant under your breath, you cast a fabric alteration spell on the boys visible socks, making them pink and ruffled on the top. Total girl socks. The best part, he didn't noticed. He walked off, sure to be embarrassed and confused down the road. You noticed Christina watching you. "You have a problem with what I just did?" you asked as soon as the boy was out of earshot.

Christina bit her lip and thought, but then shook her head. "No, he was a jerk and it isn't like you turned him into a girl or anything. You just messed with his socks."

"You see why I think boys are annoying?"

Christina took a little offense to that. "Come on, not all boys are like that." You didn't dignify that with a response, choosing just to roll your eyes.

Hayley walked up to you two. "If you two are quite done getting into trouble with boys, what do you say to some lunch and ice cream?"

You and Christina looked at each other and smiled. "Let's get burgers!" you both said in unison.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You were back at home, cleaning up your room at bit before Liz arrived for your sleepover. Hayley had gone out and Mom was still asleep after her long night. Christina was also back in her own room napping. The day had been a lot for her and she had also had a tough night before, so some rest was very much needed. You still hadn't told her Liz was sleeping over tonight, and were worried how she was going to react when she found out.

Suddenly, there was a knock at your door. You looked at the clock, it was a little too early for Liz to be here, school was still going on for another 15 minutes, plus she would have rung the doorbell.

"Come in," you called. Mel entered the room, with Cassie following her, much to your surprise. "Mommy's going to freak if she sees Cassie here," you told Mel.

Mel rolled her eyes. "Mom doesn't choose who my friends are and she's still out like a light. You going to tell on me?" You looked from Cassie to Mel, then shook your head. "Good girl." You frowned at Mel's condescending attitude.

"What do you two want?" you asked.

Cassie smiled, clearly appreciating your fire. "Mel told me how you were ready to turn Christina's mind totally female before she got captured yesterday. And I heard about that stunt you pulled on that boy today in the arcade."

You blushed. "How'd you hear about that?"

"I'm always looking for promising new recruits for my coven. One of my coven sisters saw the whole thing. Told me about immediately." Cassie gave you an approving pat. "All this considered I think you're awakening to the truth about witches."

"What truth?"

"That witches are superior to humans and girls are superior to boys."

You shook your head. "Some of my best friends are normal humans and girls aren't better than boys. Boys can just be super rude and annoying."

Cassie nodded. "Name a boy who you haven't found rude and annoying since you became a girl."

"Well...uh...," you had to think for a second. Cassie was taking advantage of your young age to confuse you. "Well, there's Pi."

Cassie giggled. "Pi Cutie is well on his way to becoming a witch girl. He barely counts as a boy."

You weren't sure what to say next, so you eventually just conceded the point. "I guess that's true...Boys are pretty annoying."

Mel knelt down next to you. "And didn't it, like, feel so satisfying to give that annoying boy at the arcade those pink ruffled socks?"

You found yourself nodding slowly. "Yeah...I kind of wanted to do more too. But Christina was there." You hadn't admitted this to anyone yet.

Cassie patted your head. "See what I mean? You have the power to make sure boys don't annoy anyone ever again."

"But...that's wrong to do that...without they're say so," you protested weakly.

Cassie shook her head. "Why? Aren't the boys happier afterwards? Aren't you happier? Aren't Rachel and Stephanie happier?"

"Well, yeah...but, Tim..."

"Tim has always been a jerk to you, Lucy," Mel pointed out. "Why should you care what he wants?"

"I guess that's true." You felt cornered and confused. You felt like you were being pressured into something, but you didn't know what.

"Join my coven, Lucy," Cassie finally said. "We can show you your true nature as a witch and how to deal with all these annoying boys around you."

You thought for a second, but shook your head. "No, Cassie. I don't want to be part of your coven. I'm way too young for that."

Cassie frowned. Her mother, Darla, had promised her a new cell phone if she got Lucy to come to a coven meeting. She wasn't sure why, but she wasnt going to turn that offer down. Still, there were other ways to get Lucy to come. "Fine, don't join. But maybe you could come with your sister to one of our meetings. You could learn a lot about witch culture and you wouldn't need to do anything in return."

This idea appealed to you much more. No strings attached and a chance to learn more about witches and covens. "Okay, that might be fun."

Cassie's frown turned into a smile. "It will be." She looked at Mel. "You were right, Mel. You're little sister is pretty cool." You blushed hearing this, finding yourself sort of liking Cassie, not realizing how easily she was manipulating you.

Suddenly, there was the sound of the doorbell. "Oh, that's probably Liz." You left the two older girls in your room as you bounded down the stairs. You opened the front door to find...

Upon opening the door, you were greeted by a tall and slender woman in her early thirties with long red hair and fiery hazel eyes. There was something about her that gave you the creeps but you managed to politely say, "Can I help you ma'am?"

The woman smiled. "Yes, I am an old friend of your mother, Natalie Harrison." Kindly, she said. "I am hoping she is available. It is rather urgent that I speak with her."

"I am Lilly." Smiling, the woman replied. "Lilly Sweetie."

You turned pale, hearing the name. You remembered the story mom said about the two rogue witches who had tried to steal her power. Lilly sensed your panic immediately and opened her mouth to speak but it did not stop you from screaming at the top of your lungs.

Mel and Cassie came running with mom on their heels while, at another house, Hayley sensed your panic and teleported to the scene...

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
To everyone's surprise, it was Cassie who reached you first and pulled you back protectively. Purple flame appeared in her hand. "Back off my friend's sister, Lady. Who are you anyway?"

"Lilly Sweetie?" Mom said in surprise, still suffering from waking up suddenly due to your scream.

"That's Lilly Sweetie?" Hayley and Mel chorused in unison.

Cassie frowned. "Why do I feel like I'm missing something here? Who is Lilly Sweetie?"

"A member of the Morgana coven who went missing the day before Mom escaped," Mel explained.

Mom frowned, not eager for Cassie to be hearing all this. She also wasn't liking how you were hanging onto her for protection. "Cassie, Mel, would you two take Lucy upstairs and stay with her? I need to talk to Lilly in private."

You shook your head. "Awww come on, Mommy. I want to hear too."

"This matter does concern these girls. The three of them, in fact," Lilly said, as she pointed to you, Cassie, and Mel.

Mom thought for a moment, then directed everyone into the living room. Hayley paused. She wanted to get back to her friend's house now that the emergency was over, but she was curious. She soon decided to follow everyone in. You all took seats, before Mom asked the question on everyone's mind. "Where have you been Lilly? It's been almost 20 years with no sign of you." She quickly scanned Lilly magically to make she was indeed Lilly Sweetie. She was.

Lilly nodded. "I've...I've been trying to live a normal life. Far away from magic." She took a picture out of her purse and showed it to you all. In the picture, Lilly sat with another woman, both smiling happily with two boys sitting next to them. "That's my wife and our two sons. They don't know anything about witches, and I hope they never will."

Mom nodded, but knew that was unlikely. The two boys had magic heritage, which meant there was a high chance they'd be witches someday. "You all look so happy, Lilly."

"We are. It's almost worth me losing my magic all those years ago..." Even so, Lilly looked sad as she said that. "You see, the night before you escaped, Eva and Helena stole my magic from me. I fought them, but it was no use. They got everything and left me on the streets. I ran and built a new life for myself."

Sympathy was never Cassie's strong point, so she cut to the chase. "I don't get it. You said this involved us." She pointed to Mel next to her and you who was positioned in Cassie's lap. This familiarity didn't clearly displeased your mother, but Cassie was growing on you.

"I'm getting to that," Lilly explained. "Something went wrong during the magic transfer. They got my magic, but I got a part of them too. I'm connected to them, mentally. I...can hear they thoughts."

"They're controlling you?" you said in alarm.

Lilly shook her head quickly. "No, no, nothing like that. I just can hear them. Not all the time, but bits and pieces. I doubt they even know or they would have killed me. Still, it's been a torture I've endured for 20 years when all I want to do is leave that life behind."

Mom looked angry hearing this. "I assume you heard enough that you could have help capture them over the last 20 years, or at least informed the witch council they were alive. Many people have gone missing this past week, Lilly."

Lilly hung her head in shame. "I know. I just...didn't want to be a part of this all, but this afternoon I heard something I couldn't ignore."

"What?" you asked.

Lilly paused, thinking how to phrase what she next said. "You were always kind to me Natalie, so when I heard they were targeting your daughter, I had to do something. They are planning a trap for her, using the help of Darla Bane."

Cassie's eyes went narrow. She suddenly knew exactly what Lilly was saying. "That's why my mom wanted me to bring Lucy to meet my coven. So the Morgana sisters could get at her where the witch council couldn't watch her."

Mom's face turned fierce as she whipped her head toward Cassie. "You were going to recruit my six-year-old daughter to a coven?!?!"

"It only would have made him madder," Liz said, but after thinking for a second she added. "It probably would have been pretty funny though."

"Maybe, but I'm happier now that I'm a girl. Rachel and Stephanie seem pretty happy too," you said, basically repeating what Cassie had argued to you earlier that day. Cassie smiled and gave you an approving pat on the head, which caused you to smile back at her.

You nodded. "Being a witch girl is cooler than being a dumb boy." You looked at Cassie. "I guess I have you to thank for that, since you sold Harry those glasses." You hugged the older girl next to you. "Thanks, Cassie. You really are cool."

"What's wrong, Cassie?" you asked quietly.

"It's nothing," Cassie said as she tried to stop her eyes from watering. "This is just nice, you know? Your family is really nice to spend time with, Mel." Mel nodded and gave her friend a comforting pat on the back.

"Don't you play games and hang out like this with your family?" Liz asked.

Cassie bit her lip before answering. "No, my family isn't...so nice to each other."

"You're among friends here, Cassie," Mel assured her. "Get it off your chest."

My father never had any interest in being one and left us before I was born. My mom is a pretty power-hungry witch though she's never had much success at it, other than some allies on the witch council. She's always looking for ways to increase that power and basically sees my brother and I as tools to help her with that. She has been cold to me, as long as I can remember. She doesn't actually want children."

She paused at this admission, collecting herself before continuing. "My brother is a few years older, and, since I was born, he took his frustration with our mother out on me. He's magic is still dormant, which makes him even angrier, especially since I development my magic at a pretty young age, like you Lucy. He's pretty jealous of me. Granted, I probably don't help matters by turning him into a little girl all the time, but at least he's not angry then. And he gets really angry."

You, Liz, and Hannah were listening silently, hanging on every word. "I don't really have a family. I just live with a group of people who hate me. So I guess I play the bad, rebellious girl as a front, but really, all I've ever wanted is what you girls have. That's why I started my coven. For sisterhood. And that's why I feel a little envious and sad when I'm here with you all. Cause I don't have awesome little sisters like you do, Mel." You and Hannah smiled at this.

Mel hugged her friend. "You've got me. We're friends now and I will always be there for you."

Once Mel broke the hug, you moved in, giving a hug of your own to Cassie. "Like I said, you sold Harry the glasses that made me, Lucy. So I guess that makes me like your family too. Would you like me to be your little sister?"

Cassie chuckled at this while wiping away a lone tear that was streaming down her face. "Really, Lucy? I'd...I'd like that a lot."

"Don't get any ideas, though, Cassie. Just cause we're sisters now doesn't mean I'm joining your coven. I'm going to start my own coven someday. And it's going to be just as awesome as yours." You grinned up at the older girl, who grinned back.

Christina blushed. "Well, yeah. You are. But...now I'm bored." This revelation was met by a chorus of laughter.

"Well, you could join us, I suppose..." Mel teased. "But we've just been talking about what jerks boys can be and how we need a break from them."

Christina made a pouty face and groaned, but then quickly took the nightgown from you. "Fine, but this is one night only deal."

You grinned. "I can live with that."

Her next spell hit Mom, and in a second, Mom looked just like Mel.

"That's great and all. But you're still missing Vader," one woman commented, though she instantly realized it was a mistake to refer to Elvira's granddaughter as Vader in front of her. The stare Elvira gave her was bone-chilling.

Mom, disguised as Mel, looked over at Lilly. "I still think there's more to this then you are saying. She could be leading us into a trap."

Elvira, still disguised as Cassie, nodded. "There's an easy solution. She comes with us. Anything that happens to us happens to her."

Mom's eyes went wide. "She might give us away."

Elvira shook her head and cast another spell. "A spell of silence will help. She'll still be able to speak, but unable to reveal our true identities." Then, Elvira cast the spell of illusion again. Suddenly, where Lilly had been standing, the image of you appeared instead. "And she'll take the place of my granddaughter. Anything that might happen to us, will also happen to her."

Lilly started to freak now. "No, you can't do this. I can't see the Morganas again. They'll know I'm Lucy. I mean, they'll know I'm Lucy." She looked surprised at her inability to say her real name. "I'm a six-year-old girl...crud." The spell didn't even allow her to curse.

"Elvira, the witches aren't expecting these girls until tomorrow morning. How are you going to explain showing up in the middle of the night?" a witch council woman asked.

Elvira grinned and spoke in Cassie's voice. "That mean Harrison witch didn't want me in her house or near her daughters. If I was going to bring her, it had to be now. Now where is the cell phone you promised me?"
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Bane house

choices: Samantha tries to crash the sleepover.
The sting begins at the Bane house.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
While Christina finally got into the sleepover, a knock came to the door. A woman in the shadows stated, "I'll handle this, kids. Enjoy your game."

Having not seen the woman before, Cassie asked, "Who was that?"

"Aunt Sara." Smiling, you said. "Uncle Jack is here too. Mommy called them to watch after us, she thinks of everything." She giggled. "She will be back after that... whatever she was running of to do."

"Yeah... what was she doing?" Lost, Christina asked.

"Not sure." Shrugging, Christina said. She then smiled. "Probably nothing."

Elvira, as a precaution, had placed an unaware spell onto you and the other kids to prevent any of you from worrying and trying to help the sting operation. Sara approached the door before a mist surrounded her and she opened the door looking like Christina. There, at the door, was Samantha Forester. "You can drop the disguise, sis." Half smiling, she said. "I came to offer some extra security for the little ones."

"You only come when there is something in it for you, Samantha." Returning the grin, Sara countered. "Besides, I have all the help I need."

The floor shook as a towering, insanely muscular man in military fatigues approached from behind Sara. It was her husband, Jack Strange. He lightly pushed a lock of his longish black hair aside, revealing his gentle blue eyes. "Hey, sis in law." In a deep voice, he said. "What brings you prowling to this door at night?"

"Just came to offer my help but it seems you have it under control." Forcing a smile, Samantha said. "I'll be leaving now."

"Always a pleasure, sis." Flatly, Sara said.

With that, she closed the door. "She's up to something." Frowning, Jack said.

"That goes without saying, I'm afraid." Sighing, Sara said. "Natalie told me that she's been very interested in Christina's progress as Harry was like a son to her." She shook her head. "Either she has an interest in her or in something she still has in her possession."

"You think Christina still has some magical artifacts tucked away?" Worried, Jack asked.

"That or Natalie has something hidden away she took from her." Serious, Sara said. "Either way, Samantha wants it bad enough to come here behind Natalie's back."

Jack nodded. "I'll stay on guard until morning." Serious, he said.

Sara gave Jack a kiss on the cheek. "I'll keep watch over the girls."

With that, Jack stood watch by the front windows of the house while the sleepover continued.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Mom thinks of everything.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Cassie watched Samantha walk down the street from your bedroom window with a frown on her face. You stood next to her your eyes curiously focused on Samantha as well. "What did she want?" Cassie wondered out loud. She was trying to figure out if Samantha was there for you, her, or someone else.

"You two still feuding?" You sat on the window seat next to your new friend.

Cassie nodded. "Yeah, she's still holding a grudge cause of my stunt with the glasses. After the glitter bomb incident, I'm not to fond of her either."

You took a moment to consider this. "It's weird. You're both kind of similar. I'd think you'd get along great."

Cassie shrugged. "I don't get along well with people who are too much like me. It's part of why I like you and your sisters so much. You're...sunny." She smiled and ruffled your hair, which caused you to smile and lean into her. "Just do me a favor. Don't get involved. I don't want Samantha coming after you too."

"I'm already pretty involved," you reminded her. "I stopped the glitter bomb thing, remember?"

A hint of guilt appeared on Cassie's face. She didn't want to be reminded you had gotten caught up in it when her little war spiraled out of control.

"Hey, you two coming back?" Mel called over. "You got to see my work." She held up Christina's nails, which were now a sparkly pink, with little witch hats and broomsticks on. "I may not be great at school, but I rock at nail art."

You and Cassie moved over to take a closer look. Christina looked a little mortified that her nails were getting such attention, but as promised she acted like a good sport. Cassie smiled at Mel. "Nice job, Mel. But isn't it a little on the nose?"

Mel giggled. "All I could think off. I just, like, thought it should be something to welcome Christina here as one of us."

Christina blushed and pulled her hands back. She resisted the urge to declare that she wasn't actually one of you, but did say, "A simple 'glad you're here' would have been plenty. I didn't need my nails down."

"You shouldn't have landed on Park Place without enough money to pay for my hotel then," Mel teased, sticking out her tongue. "You had to pay you're debt to me some way."

Christina sighed in defeat. She handed you the dice. "Maybe they'll make you shave your head or something."

Cassie ran a hand through your hair. "These beautiful locks? I would never. Much as I might want them for myself." This caused you to blush and giggle.

You rolled the dice, but you clearly weren't having Christina's bad luck. You got exactly what you needed to complete a monopoly on the orange properties, causing you to cheer and Christina to groan. "You're not enchanting the dice or something, are you?" she asked.

"She's not aloud to do that anymore," Hannah said with a chuckle.

Mel nodded. "Our last monopoly game got pretty intense and primal. Limits had to be agreed upon."

"When was this?" Liz asked.

"A couple days ago when we were hiding from teenage Christina," you told her with a grin. "We have a lot of time at night cause of the curfew." Mentioning the curfew briefly broke the unawareness spell you were under, and you wondered how your Mom was doing with finding and catching the Morgana sisters. As quickly as the thought came, it went away again, as Elvira's unawareness spell took hold again. You went back to paying for your new property, unconcerned with what Mom was up to.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: continue.

choices: Mom returns to find the house ransacked.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Meanwhile, at the Bane house, two teenage girls sat in the back of a squad car with glowing handcuffs keeping their hands behind their backs while Natalie fumed inside the Bane house.

"We should have anticipated the Morgana's would send in stooges to do their dirty work." Angry, she said. "Only now, they know we are on to them."

"At least we now know what they are after and why." Serious, Elvira said. "The Pharaoh's rings were made to seal away a witch's power before she died so her magic would not be lost."

"Only it is a double edged sword as it will take the power of any witch and add it to another who wore the ring." Frowning, Elvira said. "The Morgana sisters must be after them to restore their own magic power."

"The rings were drained of their power and hidden away." Serious, a witch investigator said. "That explains the missing young witches. They all must have had one of the rings." She paused, gulping. "How many went missing all together?"

"Five." Frowning, Elvira said. "That means there are five more rings they need to find."

"Harry had one of the rings in his collection." Softly, mom said. "It is in my safe at home."

"That explains why they targeted Christina." Thoughtful, Elvira said. "Could Lucy have another of the rings since the Morgana sisters showed interest in her?"

Mom sighed. "I'm not sure." Wincing, she replied. "The rings do not give a magical signature unless they are close to another of the set."

"They must have a way of detecting the rings." Serious, Elvira said. "I will see if the two young witches know anything of use." She turned to mom. "In the mean time, I want all of the other rings found and locked up in the vault in Witchbloom."

"What of me?" Frowning, Lilly demanded. "I did my part."

"I still don't trust you." Serious, Elvira said. "If you can really hear the Morganas talking, you would have known what they were after and you said nothing!"

"What are your orders, madam head witch?" Curious, the witch investigator asked.

"Take her in with the young witches." Serious, Elvira ordered. "I will question them all myself."

With that, Lilly was taken away and mom headed back home to tell Sara the news.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: The Pharaoh's Rings.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Dammit," Christina exclaimed as she landed on one of Cassie's hotels. She looked depressed at her depleted funds. "What do I have to do this time?" Services or challenges in place of money had become a way to allow those with less money to stay in the game. Plus, it was fun. You had taken possession of a dress of Hannah's you admired that was now too small for her, Liz, for some reason, liked making people sing for them, and Christina now had bright pink nails with witch designs, courtesy of Mel, and her hair was braided, courtesy of Hannah. All the girls looked at Cassie, excited to see what she had in mind.

Cassie smiled, "Don't worry, Christina. It's an easy one. You just have to say nine simple words: 'Boys are stupid and I'm one of the girls.'" This got some giggles from the group.

Christina's face turned beat red. "No, please. I don't want to say that."

"Come on. It won't be so bad. You'd said you'd be one of the girls tonight," coaxed Cassie.

"Yeah, but I didn't think..." She resigned herself to her fate. "Fine...Boys are stupid and...."

Cassie suddenly shushed her and looked around, suddenly seeming very on edge. "Lucy, Mel, you two feel that?"

Mel looked confused, but your eyes quickly widened and you nodded. "Yeah, Uncle Jack's magical signature just disappeared."

Mel finally felt it too. "Yeah, you're right." She looked nervous, but then she felt something that sent her close to panic. "Now I can't feel Aunt Sara either."

Suddenly, something clicked in your mind. "Eva and Helena. I forgot about them. How did I forget about them?" Liz, Hannah, and Christina looked at each other in confusion and worry. Their magic either hadn't awakened or wasn't trained, so they couldn't sense what was going on, nor could they break through Elvira's unawareness spell. They just knew something was wrong, and that confusion made them all the more nervous.

Cassie frowned as she got up and faced the door, a fireball of magic in her hands. "Elvira or your mom must have done something to keep us from thinking about it. Lucy does have a way of finding herself in the middle of these things."

Mel shook her head as she also readied herself. "Totally didn't work though. We're all, like, still in the middle of it." She looked back at the younger girls. "Hannah, Lucy hide yourselfs and the other girls in the closet."

Hannah quickly complied, helping Liz and Christina to the closet, but to what should have been no one's surprise, you joined Mel and Cassie at the ready, a fireball in your hand. "Forget that, I'm fighting too." Cassie and Mel frowned but didn't have time to argue with you.

The door to your bedroom was kicked open.

--------------------------

Mom returned home minutes later. She could hear the sounds of magic firing upstairs, so she didn't have time to check on Jack and Sara, who were both lying, hopefully unconscious by the front door. She sped up the stairs, and headed toward your room where the noise was coming from. Before she could get there though, the door to Christina's room burst open and Eva Morgana walked out. She had one of the Phararoh's rings in her hand, one with an sapphire jewel. She smiled when she noticed Mom and held up the ring in triumph. "Remember these, Natalie?"

Memories of the night Eva and Helena tried to steal Mom's magic flashed through her mind. They had a ring then too, but it had topaz jewel. Natalie tried to keep her cool. "That's must be the one Christina bought. What's that number six?"

Eva looked surprised by that comment. "No, this is number four for us. We had ours to start with, and we took two more of the transformed boys."

Mom tried not to smirk. Eva did have a nasty habit of talking too much. She liked her theatrics, but it was a useful way for Mom to get info and Mom didn't want to let Eva realize this. "You only took two? But there were five transformed boys you kidnapped."

Eva chuckled. "Even if they weren't from ring-guarding families, they were still useful sources of magic for us. That's the reason Helena's taking The Princess's magic now, and that's the reason I'm going to take yours..." She grinned wickedly at Mom. "...and finish what we started all those years ago."

There was the sound of a crash coming from your room, followed by your voice screaming, "Hey, I just got that dress! You're going to pay for that." That was followed by a flash of light and a grunting noise that sounded like Helena.

Now it was Mom's turns to chuckled. "Sounds like the Princess is given you sister some trouble." She was relieved to know you were still alright and fighting, but she was still worried about everyone else.

Eva huffed. She couldn't believe it, but it sounded like Mom was write. It didn't matter though. She had to deal with the threat in front of her. Her dear sister would have to handle the kids. She had better handle the kids.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Raids and Redemption

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Don't worry, Lucy." Angry, Cassie said. "This rogue will pay for ripping your dress."

"You won't have any magic in just a few minutes." With a smirk, Helena growled. "All it takes is one spell while the ring is pointed at you."

"You mean these?" Smiling, Cassie asked. She held up three rings that used to be on Helena's fingers. Seeing the rogue's surprised look, she added, "I swiped them from you when Lucy hit her with her spell. I learned to be quick while dealing with my brother."

"You little terror!" Enraged, Helena snapped. "I'll have two new kittens before this night is over! I'll make you both the runt of the litter, I'll..."

She stopped mid sentence and gasped hearing deep, incoherent babbling coming from behind her. Slowly, she turned to see that the book bags belonging to you and your friends had somehow come to life! The shoulder straps had torn in half and were serving as legs and arms. The open zipper of the main compartment was their mouth. Helena screamed as they spit shredded paper at her before charging, leaping onto her body, hitting her with the school books that were inside them. The terrified rogue ran out of the room and down the hall with the book bags giving chase, babbling like angry natives from some forgotten tribe.

"Make her pay for ripping my dress!" Giving chase, you screamed. "Smack her silly!"

Helena was chased into a corner where she fell to her knees, screaming in fear and anguish. You wanted to make your new puppets hurt her for all she had done but Cassie took hold of your shoulder. "Lucy, you got her." Calmly, she said. "It's over."

Reluctantly, you released your control of the puppets and they returned to normal as mom stepped up, looking roughed up but okay, dragging an unconscious Eva behind her by the collar of her blouse. "Give it up, Helena." Serious, she demanded. "You are defeated."

Helena screamed and made one last jump at you only Cassie screamed in return, her purple flame becoming a bright blue before a powerful blast wave threw Helena off her feet and hard against the wall, cracking the reinforced blaster badly. Helena then slid to the floor, unconscious herself. "No one attacks my friends!" Angry, Cassie yelled.

"Yeah!" Smiling, you agreed.

You and Cassie exchanged a high five while mom gave a bemused smile. "Well done, Lucy." Kindly, she said. She turned to Cassie. "It seems I misjudged you, Cassie. I apologize. Well done, young lady."

You gave Cassie a hug, causing her to blush. Shortly after Elvira arrived with women in police uniforms, you found aunt Sara and uncle Jack just waking up after a hit from a knock out gas grenade that was thrown through the front window. They were unharmed but embarrassed that they were taken out so easily. "All of the rings have been secured and the children who had been transformed will be back to normal within a week." Serious, Elvira said. "We do, however, have a problem."

"What is it?" Sighing, mom asked.

"Lilly had more power than she let on." Frowning, Elvira replied. "She was working both sides of the fight to distract us both." She sighed. "For what, who knows."

"We'll be ready for her." Summoning a flame, you said.

Cassie patted your head. "You said it."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Helena vs. Cassie and Lucy

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Monopoly was done for the night. The board had been knocked over during the fight anyway, and not all the pieces had been found. With your room in need of repair and Christina's room looking like it had been ransack, you and the other girls had settled in Hannah's room, where everyone relaxed and caught their breathes.

You looked, depressed, at the torn rags of the dress you had won off Hannah during the monopoly game. The dress was beautiful purple gown Hannah had worn to a costume party when she was your age. You had been coveting it for the last week, but now, a half an hour after you won it and before you could ever wear it, it was destroyed. "Helena Morgana is the biggest evil bully who ever was," you groaned.

"At least the witch council has them," Liz said. She had spent the last few minutes on the phone with her mom convincing her that she was perfectly fine and didn't need to come home. After what she saw you do through the crack in the closet door, she actually felt safer with you. "Sorry about your dress though."

"It's just a dress. No big deal," Christina said dismissively. This comment resulted in quick angry stares from you, Hannah, and Liz.

"Watch what you say," you warned. "Or I'll make you understand exactly what a big deal it is." Your hands crackled with purple magic.

Christina blushed, getting the hint and quickly back tracked. "I mean, I wish I could have seen how pretty you would have looked in it."

You and Liz giggled at this, but Hannah was too busy watching Mel and Cassie who were talking quietly in a corner. "What do you think they are talking about?"

You shrugged. "I don't know. Teenager stuff. I'm more interested in what the grown-ups are talking about." You look curiously toward the door. "I wish we could listen in."

Christina shook her head. "Yeah, right. The witch council is all over this place. They'd spot you in a second. It's not like you can turn invisible or anything." Your face suddenly brightened and you flashed a grin a Liz who returned it quickly. Christina quickly caught on. "You know an invisibility spell, don't you?"

----------------------------------

Across the room, Cassie and Mel were deep in conversation, not paying attention to what the younger girls were doing.

"Mel, talk to me...you're clearly upset about something," Cassie implored her friend.

Mel sighed. "Fine." She took a deep breath. "I just, like, feel weak. I only got one shot off on Helena before she knocked me out, and it didn't even phase her. Now I'm learning that not only did you hold her own against her, but Lucy, my little sister, did too." She put her face in her hands. "I feel totally pathetic."

Cassie wrapped an arm around her friend. "You're not pathetic. Helena Morgana is one of the most powerful witches ever."

"Then how did you and Lucy hold you're own?"

This was a question Cassie had been wondering herself for the last hour. "Well, Lucy's powers are special. She has the potential to stronger than even your grandmother someday, and I..." She looked at her hands. "...I honestly don't know. I've never been able to wield that much magic before. You went down, and suddenly all I could think about was protecting you." Suddenly, Cassie blushed deep red. "And Lucy, of course, gotta protect that crazy Lucy. Plus, there was everyone in the closet." She chuckled nervously.

Mel looked at her friend with a little confusion, but then noticed something else amiss. "Speaking of that crazy Lucy...where did all the other girls go?" Cassie and Mel looked around the empty room with puzzled expression.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: the sleepover continues.

choices: "I'm a what?" you yelled, giving away your presence.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom sat in the living room with Jack, Sara, Elvira, and two other witch council members, sipping tea as they talk about the many topics they needed to wrap their heads around. They were tired, tired enough that none of them noticed the four invisible girls, you, Hannah, Liz, and Christina listening in. Elvira was currently the one speaking.

"...So no sooner did we return to the witch council with the Pharaoh's rings, but Lilly vanished and the rings disappeared from our vault."

Jack shook his head in disbelief. "How though?"

"If I could tell you, we would have been able to stop her. It was like she was a ghost," Elvira responded.

Sara sighed. "So there are ten rings each one decorated with a different jewel and Lilly has four of them?"

"Five," Mom corrected. "The Morganas took her magic, she would have needed a ring of her own to get her magic back. Plus, the four we recovered from the Morganas and that's five."

"The problem is that knowledge of the Pharaoh's rings is rare, as most of the texts that mention it were destroyed hundreds of years ago. Even which families were charged with protecting them has been partially lost to time," Elvira said.

"Great for secrecy, not great for keeping them away from an enemy," Jack added dryly.

"I'll have the Belacourts start researching this in the morning. If anyone can find some information about the rings they can," Elvira announced.

Sara turned to Mom. "Did Christina really have a ring?"

Mom nodded. "She had a collection of magically artifacts from when she was Harry. The sapphire ring was in there."

Suddenly, Jack slapped his head and groaned. "I'm such an idiot. That's what Samantha was after."

"Samantha was here?" Elvira and Mom said in surprised.

Jack nodded. "Sorry, we didn't get a change to tell you in the confusion. She came by, acted weird, and then left quickly."

"That's my sister for you," sighed Sara.

This news exhausted Mom. "So Samantha is looking for the rings too...Where can we find the other five?"

No one really knew the answer to that, though Elvira tried. "We need to check with some of the five most renowned witch families. Strange is one, but I don't know of any ring. Maybe I should reach out to your father, Natalie." Mom looked nervous at that news. "The Kruses are a possibility, maybe the Banes as well...oh and the Merlins and the Greys. Let's start with these families and hope for the best. We also need to investigate more about where Lilly has been for the last twenty years."

Mom leaned back and groaned. "There's so much to do."

"One more thing," Elvira added. "Lucy needs to start training in combat magic."

Mom shot up. "Are you kidding mother? She's six."

"Same age as I was when I got my powers," Elvira argued. "Besides she keeps finding herself in fights no matter what we do. She can't get through them all by sheer force of will. She needs to learn to protect herself, especially being the Princess." Her last sentence caught you completely off guard. You were a princess?
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Eavesdropping on the grown-ups

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Everyone in the room turned in your direction before a stern look fell upon mom's face. You sighed, knowing you were caught and became visible only not before signaling the others to go back to Hannah's room. Upon becoming visible to all, mom opened her mouth to scold you only Elvira interrupted her by saying, "Thank you, Lucy for showing us how Lilly stole the rings."

Mom turned to Elvira, surprised. "What..."

"A non-corporeal spell." Bemused, Elvira explained. "It's very simple but requires a lot of power to use properly. Lilly had a lot of power but could only use it in short bursts, likely because her ring was not fully charged."

"Only Lucy has such power." Sighing, Sara said. "If Lilly gets a hold of her..."

Elvira smiled. "Lucy has too much power for the ring to handle." Bemused, she said. "You see, they were designed to hold the power of a dying witch whose power had already been fading."

Jack snapped his fingers, catching on. "So if they were to attempt to take the power of a witch in her prime, it would cause the ring to explode from overload."

Elvira nodded. "Exactly. That is why the Morgana sisters targeted young witches who had not yet peaked then transformed them to keep them as familiars."

Sara sighed. "As young witches, they would gain their power back in a few weeks." Sad for the young girls, she said. "By making them cats, they get to siphon off more and more magic."

"Like vampires." Shaken, you said.

Elvira nodded. "A bit of a crude analogy but... yes."

"You are still in trouble, young lady." Sternly, mom said. "This meeting was private for a reason and I expect you to respect my rules, am I clear?"

"Lucy's actions were of innocent curiosity, not disrespect." Serious, Elvira said. "Besides, she answered the question that was on all of our minds and we now have a way to detecting her should she try that again."

"You said I was a princess..." Taking a chance, you said.

Everyone in the room smiled, making you nervous. "Well, what did you expect?" Amused, Elvira asked. "I am, after all, the queen of all witches."

"That makes me a prince and your mother a princess." Bemused, Jack added. "It makes you and your sisters princesses as well."

"What about Cassie and Liz?" Wincing, you demanded.

Mom sighed. "We researched that after the fight." Patiently, mom explained. "The Banes are a magically powerful family but Darla was a normal girl they had adopted and was granted magical power by her new mother."

"Which is why her magic is not particularly strong." Serious, Sara added. "Cassie, however, is a natural at magic, which infuriated her mother and brother to no end." She sighed. "Her brother has potential but a hatred of magic due to his mother. As for Cassie, it was only her lack of confidence, again due to Darla that held her back."

"So, when she made friends, real friends, it all came out." Smiling slightly, you said.

Mom nodded. "That's right." Softly, she said. "As for Liz, she is still very young. Very few witches gain powerful magic at that young of age." She giggled. "Still, like Hannah, she has a lot of potential they just needs to be patient."

"Will Mel get powerful magic?" Hopeful, you asked.

Mom smiled. "Melanie's magic is different." Calmly, she said. "Mel is like my sister, Catherine. She is a healer witch, a powerful one at that."

"How do you know?" Curious, you asked.

Everyone in the room chuckled. "Look at yourself, child." Bemused, Elvira said. "Do you see a single scratch on you? A single bruise?" She shook her head. "Helena was no doubt knocking the two of you around like rag dolls before you finally snapped and sent your puppets after her."

"Even while unconscious, Melanie managed to protect all of you from harm." Smiling, mom said. "That is a seriously powerful magic, young lady."

On the landing, having come out looking for you, both Cassie and Mel were in tears. Only they froze, blushing as Elvira then called out, "You got the answers you were looking for, girls. Now go back to your sleepover and let us adults finish our talk."

Albeit reluctantly, the girls walked back to Hannah's room with you following. "Sorry..." Wincing, you said.

"No harm done, young lady." Bemused, Elvira said. "Just remember that trick rarely works more than once so don't make a habit of it."

You smiled then giggled as you hurried up to your room. Hayley, who had been silent during the meeting merely shook her head in bemusement.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Innocent curiosity.

choices: Next morning, Mom and Cassie talk
Next morning, Samantha appears before Christina
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
As Sara saw you disappear into the rooms upstairs, she looked over at Elvira. "You didn't want to tell her the whole truth. That the rest of her family may be princesses, but she is The Princess, your heir apparent."

Elvira shook her head. "Undue pressure to put on a child that young. Besides, even though anyone can see that Lucy is the most likely candidate, she isn't my only possible heir. Hannah's magic might end up being even more powerful than Lucy's, and Tim could easily end up being an extremely powerful witch girl. Besides, Lucy hasn't even had her confirmation ceremony yet."

Mom nodded. "I need to start preparing her for that. I wasn't expecting her to be ready for it so soon. She's taken to magic like no one I've ever seen before." She was trying to make a mental list of everything she needed to do, but it was a long one. She had to talk to Cassie in the morning too, thank her for standing up for her daughters and maybe find out if the Banes had one of the Pharaoh's rings. "Maybe if I give Lucy something else to focus on, she won't get involve in this ring business."

"I highly doubt that'll work. She probably heard us talking about the rings anyway," Jack said. Mom sighed, knowing Jack was probably right.

There was silence in the room as everyone considered everything that they had talked about. Finally, Elvira spoke. "The rings' locations, Lilly's whereabouts these last twenty years, and Samantha Forrester's interest in the rings. We need to start figuring these things out in the morning, but for now, we all need rest. Get some sleep everyone."

--------------------------------------

Late that night, Mom went to check on you as you slept. The witch council had repaired the room, so you and Liz were sleeping there, but Mom was surprised to find you weren't asleep at all. You were sitting up in your bed, staring transfixed at a magic flame in your hands. Liz, on the other hand, was sleeping soundly in the bed next to you.

"Lucy," Mom whispered, getting your attention. You extinguished the flame and walked out of the room to talk with her. "What are you doing?"

"Just thinking. Playing with the flame helps me think."

"What are thinking about?"

"Everything," you sighed. "Fighting those witches, me being a Princess, these ring thingies."

That was not what Mom was hoping to hear. "You did hear about the rings..."

You nodded. "Why are they called the Pharaoh's Rings, Mommy?"

Mom didn't want to tell you, but she had a feeling you weren't going to be able to sleep unless you were got the answers you wanted. "Long ago, people were very aware of witches. But us witches had such power people were scared of us. One of the ancient Pharaoh's of Egypt thought he could find a way to control us, and he created these 10 rings as a way of doing so with some of his loyal witch followers. They could steal powers from witches who didn't do what the Pharaoh said and keep the powers of loyal witches in their hands when those witches passed on. It was a dark time for witches everywhere, but eventually one witch was able to steal the rings and hide them. That's one of the reasons we try to keep our existence hidden from regular humans."

Maybe Cassie is right about boys and humans, you found yourself thinking, but you hated to think negatively about your human friends. "So why now? Did Lilly really steal those rings?"

Mom nodded. "I'm afraid so. What the Morganas did to her all those years ago must have really hurt her."

"But what about the family she showed us. Do you think they are real?"

Mom hadn't thought of that. It would be worth looking into. They might have some information on Lilly Sweetie. "Could be honey, but you should really go to sleep. There may be no school, but you have ballet tomorrow."

"Easy said then done. I've been trying to sleep for hours."

Mom smiled. "Well, there are ways to help with that." She waved her hand and suddenly you were put into a deep sleep, falling into Mom's arms. She kissed your forehead and put you into bed, pulling the covers over you. Tomorrow was going to be a new day. Who knew what was going to happen then.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: The adults finish their talk.

choices: Skip to Cassie and Micheal saying goodbye.
Darla fights for her magic power.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
The next morning, before anyone had awakened, mom gently shook Cassie awake and hushed her silent. "We need to talk, young lady." Whispering, she said. "Come with me."

Fearing a lecture, Cassie tearfully followed mom to her study where she found Elvira and Jack waiting for her. "What did I do wrong?"" Trembling, she asked.

"You did nothing wrong, dear child." Patiently, Elvira said. "In fact, we are all very proud of your actions last night."

"This meeting regards your mother, Darla Bane." Serious, Jack said. "You may wish to take a seat when you hear this."

"Is mom okay?" Wincing, Cassie asked. "She wasn't hurt, was she?"

Elvira was silent for a moment before speaking. "I am afraid that the witch council has unanimously agreed that Darla Bane should be stripped of her powers for the remainder of her life due to her cruel treatment of you and your brother, Micheal." Serious, she explained. "As such, she cannot raise a young witch or witch boy."

"You are pulling us away from her?" Frightened, Cassie demanded. "What will happen to me? To Micheal?"

"Katie Thompson has agreed to raise you as her own." To Cassie's surprise, mom said. "Your brother, Micheal will be taken in by Jack Strange."

Jack nodded, a small grin touching the corners of his mouth. "I have three sons who are powerhouses like myself." Calmly, he explained. "They will straighten him out; make a real witch boy out of him."

"Dr. Katie Thompson is my family's primary physician and is immune to all magic." Serious, mom said. "She does, however know how magic works and can fight against it if needed."

"Who will be teaching me magic, then?" Worried, Cassie asked.

"I will." Smiling, mom said. "You and your small coven will all receive your training during each and every coven meeting which will all be held here in my house."

Cassie's eyes watered then overflowed. She did not know how to react. On one hand, she was being taken away from her abusive mother and brought closer to her first true friends. On the other hand, she was losing her brother, as annoying as he was. "Will- Will I see my brother again?" Tearfully, she asked. "Will I see my mother?"

"I live on the other side of the country but we visit every three months so you will see your brother again." Smiling, Jack said. "He will be a better man by then, count on it."

"Your mother is still just that, your mother." Serious, Elvira added. "Nothing will change that. She has the right to visit you and your brother but not alone. Her mad quest for magical power has cost her everything." She placed a light hand onto Cassie's shoulder. "Hannah told us all about your plight and we investigated. It turns out that your brother, as obnoxious as he is, kept detailed records of your mother's actions including secret video recordings. It was all the evidence we needed to prosecute her. She goes on trail next week."

Cassie was now crying freely. "So... Micheal was looking out for me." Saddened, she said. "To think I thought he was just plain mean."

"Oh boys are a nuisance." Smiling, mom said. "Still, they do care in their own obnoxious way."

"Witch boys are the defenders of witch families." Smiling, Jack said. "Their senses are far more acute and their heightened strength, speed, and agility easily allow them to take on any normal threat to the household."

"Only its a double edged sword." With a grin, Elvira said. "It also makes them overly energetic and obnoxious, more so than normal boys, which is why they annoy young witches so much."

Jack childishly stuck his tongue out at mom and Elvira, causing Cassie to giggle.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Sadness and hope for Cassie.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"There's one more thing I need to ask, Cassie," Mom said. "Have you heard of the Pharaoh's Rings?"

Cassie nodded slowly. "Yeah, my mom told me about them a few times." Something clicked in her mind. "Wait, are those what I grabbed off Helena?"

Elvira nodded. "Yes, but now Lilly has them. Centuries ago the rings were split up and each was given to a witch family to guard, the ten most powerful families at the time, but records from that era are scarce, witch trials and all."

"You want to know if the Banes were one of those families," Cassie said, understanding. Elvira nodded again. "It's very possible. Mom kept a lot of magical artifacts for safekeeping, but she never told me where. Probably wise of her. I would have pawned it all off to Samantha for some quick bucks. If we have one you'll need to ask my Mom."

This was not what Elvira and Mom had wanted to here.

--------------------------------------------------------

An hour later, Darla was sitting in the witch council with a big smile on her face, much to the annoyance of Mom and Elvira who were acting as her interrogators. She knew she had something they wanted, and she was going to use that leverage for all it was worth.

"So, you two want my Pharaoh's Ring. This is just delicious. But what makes you think I still have it? You yourselves are accusing me of working with Eva and Helena who we both know were collecting them." Darla's words with powerful and angry, but a hint of amusement was peppered in there.

"We know you too well, Darla. You never willingly part with power, even for the Morganas," Elvira retorted.

Darla grinned. "Very true, so let's cut the bull. I do have a Pharaoh's ring. It has a beautiful diamond jewel, but you'll never find it without my help. And you'll never get my help without me getting what I want."

"What do you want?" Mom had to force the words out. It hurt to say.

"My freedom. Drop all charges against me and I'll give you the ring. You can keep my children. I certainly don't need those failures back."

"You horrible..."

Darla cut Mom off. "Don't bother arguing with me. I have nothing to lose. You want to take my magic from me, and this ring will be my only method of ever getting it back. So if these charges stand, I have no incentive to give it up."

Mom and Elvira looked at each other feeling frustrated. They didn't see another option, but they hated the idea of letting her go. "It's a deal," Elvira muttered reluctantly.

Darla smiled. "I know you are a woman of your word." Feeling victorious, she said. "The diamond Pharaoh's ring is in my safe inside my study. "Go on and get it."

Elvira then smiled at Darla like a python would smile at a rat, causing her smile to immediately falter before Elvira touched an ear piece radio. "Have you found it, Jenny, dear?" Kindly, she asked. "Darla said it was in a safe in her study."

"Nah, she had two rings." Came a young, melodious voice through Elvira's speaker phone. "One with a diamond and another with a sapphire. They were in the eyes of a portrait of her." Jenny giggled. "Talk about an ego."

Elvira giggle in response then turned to Darla. "My granddaughter, Jenny Strange is a clairvoyant witch, she can find things that would seem invisible to other witches."

Darla huffed. "Fine." Through gritted teeth, she grumbled. "You got your precious rings." She ignited a very weak flame. "Now honor your end of the deal!"

"We did." Grinning, Elvira replied. "We restored your power." She giggled. "That is exactly what you demanded as well as we drop all charges."

"Then why do I only have the flame of a teenager?!" Furious, Darla demanded. "Also, why am I still in these blasted handcuffs?!"

"All of the magical artifacts, magic books, and potions you had illegally acquired to boost your magic have been returned to their proper owners." Simply, Elvira explained. "They were not yours so you were not permitted to have them back." She leaned in close, still grinning. "As for the handcuffs, you are still facing civil charges pressed by those you had stolen from and those you had harmed in your quest for power."

Mom smiled, catching on. "That includes my brother, Jack Strange who is pressing charges against you representing your former son, Micheal."

"It also includes Cassie Thompson's coven, which was recognized by the witch council four hours ago, who are pressing changes of attacking its members namely Cassie herself."

"All of these charges have nothing to do with Natalie, the witch council, or myself." Calmly, Elvira said. "We do not have the power to drop these charges as we did not place them against you but our charges, as promised, were dropped."

"What am I looking at with these charges?" Worried, Darla asked.

Elvira shrugged. "That is up to the judges who hear your case." She giggled, giving Darla a wave as a police officer took her away. "Good luck, deary."

Darla screamed and cursed as she was removed from the room. After she was gone, mom shook her head, bemused. "That is why Elvira is the head witch."

At home...

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Hold still. I've almost got it."

You complied as Mom helped you into your leotard. You were much more willing and eager this time around, and the pink color and ballet skirt didn't bother you anymore. Annoyingly though, Hannah sat nearby, already in her own leotard and ballet skirt watching triumphantly, an 'I-told-you-so' look on her face. You tried to ignore it and tried to keep the conversation on literally anything else. "So you found two Pharaoh's Rings at Darla's house?" you asked.

Hannah rolled her eyes, wise to your ploy, but Mom answered nonetheless, hoping that keeping you informed would keep you from trying to get involved on your own. "Not exactly. One of the rings, one with a diamond jewel, was a Pharaoh's Ring, but the other, the sapphire, was a different kind of magical ring. I should have known immediately since the Pharaoh's Ring Christina had bought was a sapphire. Each ring has a different type of jewel. Still, at least we have one ring, even if Lilly has four."

"Mom, come on. The rings are boring," Hannah whined. "Let's talk about how cute Lucy looks in her ballet outfit."

You blushed deeply. "Hannah, leave me alone."

"Nope, not until you admit it."

"Admit what?" you asked innocently, though knowing full well what she meant.

"That ballet isn't boring and you like it and you like wearing a pink leotard and ballet skirt."

You looked at Mom for help, but none was coming from her. You sighed and turned back to Hannah. "Fine, you were right, Hannah. I should have listened to my big sister. Ballet is awesome and I love it." Hannah's smiled was bigger than you had ever seen it. You groaned. "I'm turning into a mini-you."

"You say that likes it's a bad thing. It just means you have good taste," Hannah said as she ruffled your hair.

"Do I really have to go to this thing?" Christina asked as she stomped into the room. The open-mindedness of the night before was a thing of the past, she was dressed in her most tomboy-ish clothes and she was extremely resistant to idea of spending an hour in a ballet studio. Liz followed her, dressed in her own leotard and ready for ballet.

"You don't have to participate," Mom told Christina for the fifth time in the last half-hour. "But I can't leave a six-year old alone in this house. Hayley is off running an errand for me and I assume you don't want to be left alone with Mel and Cassie." Christina's eyes went wide. She definitely didn't want to be left alone with Mel and Cassie. They were part of a coven that believed all guys were better off being girls. She didn't trust to them to not mess with her.

"Do even have time to take us? Shouldn't you be off looking for those ring things?" With these questions, Christina tried one last escape strategy.

Mom shook her head. "I can take time off to take my daughters to ballet. Spending time with family is what is truly important."

Christina knew she had no chance. "Fine, I'll go. But I not dancing or touching anything pink."

As soon as Christina finished her pronouncement, she felt something touch her cheek. You had the sleeve of your bright pink leotard on her face and was sporting a big smile. "Oh no, you touched pink. You're a girly girl now." This prompted laughter from Hannah and Liz, even Christina cracked a smile.

"Ha ha," Christina said, moving your arm off her. "Get off me, Miss Priss." She stuck her tongue out at you, prompting you to smile.

Mom checked her watch. "We'd better get going. Christina, grab a book to read so you aren't bored. Let's go girls." She ushered the four of you out to the car.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You all arrived at the ballet studio with ten minutes to spare. Mom checked you, Hannah, and Liz in. Christina found a bench and sat down with the book she had grabbed, which unfortunately she hadn't really look at before hand. It was a graphic novel from a series you and Hannah loved about a girl and her unicorn. It was funny, but not what Christina wanted to read for the next hour. The receptionist asked Mom a couple times if Christina was sure she didn't want to join, as there was space in the class. Christina refused repeatedly, using only a single word: "No." Hannah went to mingle with her ballet friend and you and Liz began to wander and practice as you waited for class.

"This one is fifth position, right?" you asked as you showed Liz a pose.

"Yeah, but careful, you're losing your..." Liz tried to warn as you started to wobble and fall backward. You gave a little shout, but someone caught you from behind.

"Your form is terrible," the voice said. It sounded oddly familiar to you, but you couldn't place it.

"Well, it's only my second class," you explained as you picked yourself up. "And whatever. Ballet is about having fun any..." You went speechless when you turned around and saw who had caught you, the boy from the arcade whose socks you had used your magic on. He was surprised to recognize you as well.

"Sparkle boots?"

"Pinbrat," you said calmly trying not to be intimidated. You had called him blondie last time, but pinbrat sounded cleverer you thought. You had figured you'd never see him again. "What are you doing here?"

"My ballet class just finished up." Sure enough, he was wearing a white boys leotard and black shorts. "I'm glad you're here. I'll give me a chance to thank you for the socks thing, yesterday." He didn't sound like he was actually thankful. You winced. He knew you had something to do with it? Did he know about magic?

"Well, I wouldn't have done it if I knew you liked girl things," you retorted, referring to his enrollment in a ballet class.

He scoffed at that. "Shows what you know. Ballet isn't for little girls like you who just want to twirl around and giggle. It's for serious athletes who want to be strong and fast." Okay, it was official. You couldn't stand this kid.

"What? Are you like a ballet expert now?" you tried to retort. Not your best.

"Compared to you, I'm Baryshnikov." You had no idea who that was.

Liz stepped in now. "Wait, but the class before ours is for beginner level students too."

The boy blushed. "I said compared to Sparkle Boots there," he said quickly. He looked back at you. "You know, thanks to you, I had to spend last night turned into a girl. My teacher wanted to make sure I wasn't slipping when he saw those ruffled socks. I'll get you back somehow."

"You're a witch boy?" you and Liz said in surprise.

"Yeah, pretty strong one too," he bragged. "My magic awakened last year. My teacher says I'm one of the best he's ever seen."

"Well...my grandma tells me the same thing. And she's head witch!"

The boy's eyes widened. "You're a Strange?"

"Kinda. That was my Mom's name before she got married."

The boy groaned. "Just my luck. Teacher told me to stay away from you guys." He turned around. "Enjoy your twirling, Sparkle Boots."

That was the last straw. You felt your anger grow and you shot a quick spell at Pinbrat, intending to turn his boy's ballet outfit into a pink and sparkly leotard and tutu. Unfortunately, this time, Pinbrat was ready for you. He waved a quick counter spell, even without looking back at you. The magic reflected back at you. In a moment, your basic pink tutu and ballet skirt were gone, replaced by a formal pink tutu dress, with sparkles all over the place. You looked like you were supposed to be playing a sugar plum fairy at a ballet recital. Your eyes went wide with surprise and embarrassment, as Liz's eyes darted back and forth to make sure no one had been watching. Looks like you got lucky.

Pinbrat turned back at you and grinned. "Told you I'd get you back. You look good." You turned red with embarrassment and fury. "My name is Sean, by the way. Sean Knightley. Just in case you want to know the name of the boy who put you in your place. See you Sparkle Boots."

"I prefer calling you Pinbrat," you called after him, but it was too late. He was gone.

"You okay?" Liz asked.

You growled. "I'm seriously thinking about helping Cassie turn every boy into a girl for all time, but other than that I'm good." Liz hugged you sympathetically. It was appreciated.

"Welcome back, Lucy," said a new voice. It was your ballet teacher. She was looking over your new outfit. "Well, I'm glad to see you are so enthusiastic about ballet outfits, but that's really more the kind of costume and tutu we only wear for performances. You're welcome to wear it today, but try to stick with just a leotard and skirt next time, okay?"

All you could do was nod and apologize, and quietly plan your revenge on Pinbrat.

Ballet class began, but Christina stayed sitting on the bench in reception, reading the graphic novel she had borrowed. She didn't even notice the boy from the arcade pass by her and go out the door. Mom sat next to her, but her attention was focused on the ballet lesson and watching her daughters, though he was confused about what you were wearing. Did you ask your teacher to borrow one of the costumes or did magic play a role? She'd have to ask you after the class

About fifteen minutes into the class, Mom got up. "Christina, I'll be right back. I just need to make a few phone calls." Christina barely nodded and Mom stepped out of the studio.

"Must be a good book." Christina looked up to see Samantha Forrester sitting next to her. She wasn't sure how to react. She had always liked Samantha. The woman had helped her collect all kinds of magical artifacts over the years. But between coercing Christina to help with the glitter bomb incident, which she couldn't really remember that well, and finding out Samantha's favorite past time was turning boys into girls, Christina wasn't sure if she was safe around the woman. Samantha sensed the unease. "Calm down. If I wanted to turn you into a girl, I could have done it for years."

That was true. You had been coming into her store for three years before the thing with the glasses happened. And that was because of Cassie, not Samantha. "Sooooo...you don't want me to be a girl?"

"Oh, I wouldn't say that. You're much better off as a girl than a boy, but I had never met a kid with such curiosity about magical artifacts, Reminded me of me when I was your age. I didn't want to drive you away by turning you into a girl."

Christina nodded. That kind of made sense. "Why are you here?" Her tone was one of curiosity, not contempt.

"To check on you, I suppose. You've been through a lot with the Morganas."

"I heard you were looking out for me. Thank you."

Samantha frowned. "I didn't do nearly enough. You still got attacked again." She reached into her bag and pulled out a bracelet. "Here."

Christina looked at it with suspicion. "What is it?"

"A linking bracelet. It allows you to summon me when you need me. Just in case you get in trouble again. It's an incredibly rare item. Otherwise, all witch parents would want their children to have them," Samantha explained.

"I'm not your child," Christina said.

"Of course not. But you are someone I see great potential in, and I want to make sure you reach that potential."

"I have potential?"

"Yes, you do. But you're the only one who doesn't see it," Samantha explained.

Christina thought about that for a second and looked over the bracelet. "You're sure this isn't some trick to turn me into a girly girl or something? I'm not going to put this on and then sign up for ballet and hate boys like you, am I?"

Samantha chuckled. "If I wanted to turn you into a girly girl, I wouldn't need to ask." Christina nodded, not picking up on the fact that Samantha didn't actually answer her concern directly. Nonetheless, Christina put the bracelet on.

Christina gave a hick-up like chuckle. "Darth and Vader... nice."

Christina giggled at that.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Ballet class ended and you, Liz, and Hannah moved off the studio floor to join with Mom and Christina. "Good work today, Lucy." your ballet teacher called after you. "You're getting the hang of it. Just no more extravagant costumes for class, okay?" You grumbled.

Once you reached Christina, you and her looked each other over, appraising your new outfit and accessory respectively. "What happened to you?" you both asked each other at the same time. Christina felt confused suddenly. Wasn't she just talking about what happened to you with Mom? But she hadn't see anything. How could she have known. She couldn't remember.

Christina went first. "Oh, Samantha gave me this bracelet. I put it on like an idiot. Where'd that outfit come from?"

You sighed. "Some boy reflected my spell. The same one from the arcade, remember? Turns out he's a witch boy. I should have turned him into a girl while I had the chance. Said his name was Knightley or something. Sean, I think."

"Knightley?" Mom said with confusion. "There was an old witch family years ago by that name. They disappeared though. I wonder if there is any relation?"

Christina looked at Mom. "Wait? I thought you said you knew of him?"

"Knew of who?"

"Sean Knightley!" Christina said. "We just had a conversation about him." Mom looked at Christina like she honestly had no idea what she was talking about. "You said your father told you about him."

Mom now looked worried and knelt down. "Christina, I haven't heard from my father in years. And I've never heard of this Sean boy." She held up Christina's arm and looked at this bracelet.

Christina was starting to get scared. "But...we talked, didn't we?"

Mom nodded. "Yes, I found Samantha with you, then we talked about your time with the Morganas and how the witch council was calling you Darth. After that you went back into your graphic novel."

Christina shook her head. "That's not how I remember it, but...I also can't remember how I remember it."

"It's the link bracelet. It allows Samantha access to your mind, so she can communicate with you at all times," Mom explained. "But it takes some time to adjust. Samantha must have given you information, but your mind, well, imagined it as a conversation with me."

"That link bracelet can't be legal," Liz said.

Mom sighed. "I'm afraid it is, as long as the person wearing took it willingly." Christina groaned. "Let's get you home. We'll have to drop Liz off at her place on the way." You were disappointed. You were hoping to hang with Liz some more, but Christina's health came first.

Hannah took Christina's hand and helped led her to the car. As the group walked there, you had some questions for Mom. "Why would Samantha do this to Liz, Mom?"

"Knowing Samantha, she's chosen Christina to be her apprentice. Most likely due to her skill with magical artifacts, one of her interests as well." You felt like Mom was holding back more.

"What aren't you telling me?" you asked.

Mom sighed. "Apprenticeships among witches is very serious. The teacher can have the power to project thoughts into the student's mind. If they want, they can shape what that student believes and thinks."

"That's horrible."

"It can be, which is why they are rare. But Samantha probably wants someone who thinks like she does and has Christina's talent. If we don't find a way out of this for Christina, Christina Rich will be no more, and we'll have Christina Forrester to deal with." Mom didn't enjoy telling you this, but she wanted to make sure you never accepted a link bracelet from a witch, ever.

"So what do we do?"

"I'm going to see Susan. I find it hard to believe she allowed this to happen." But deep down, Mom knew Samantha wouldn't have tried something like this without the permission of the guardian.

Hours later, mom invited Susan over to her house for a private talk. She went straight to the point and told her about the bracelet and of what it was already doing to Christina's mind. Susan seemed troubled by it. "I only gave Samantha my blessings to help look out for her." Serious, she explained. "I never gave her permission to take her under her wing in any way, shape or form."

She sighed. "Fortunately, Pi had no interest in learning magic then and took it off, giving it back to Samantha."

"How would it benefit Samantha to have Christina remembering different events?" Annoyed, Susan demanded. "It makes no sense."

"To confuse her, manipulate her." Serious, mom replied. "Samantha has always seen both Pi and Christina as the children she never had." She winced adding, "Perhaps she wants to get closer to at least Christina."

"Can you remove that bracelet?" Startled, Susan demanded. "This is not what I agreed upon when I talked to that Forester woman."

"Only Christina can remove it as she put it on willingly." Frowning, mom replied. "However, she did not seem keen on removing it once she discovered what it was so I wonder if Samantha tampered with it somehow."

"What can we do?" Worried, Susan asked. "I don't want to lose my daughter."

Mom sighed. "We have a few options. We can reverse the bracelet's function so to track and listen in on her."

"We could also rid the bracelet of its magic and make it useless." Thoughtful, Susan said.

Mom turned to the window, thinking. Finally, the two agreed to...
