1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
While mom and Susan talked, you looked at Christina curious as she took the bracelet off and put it on her nightstand. "What is that thing Samantha gave you?" Curious, you asked.

"Oh, she said it was something she can use to look after me." Lightly, Christina replied. "She told me that I have a lot of potential." She then frowned. "Not that I'm interested in learning any magic right now."

"Aren't you worried that it will make you more girlish?" Teasing, you asked.

Christina sighed. "Yeah, kind of." Softly, she replied. "But I sort of miss my collection. It was the only thing, other than you and Melanie that kept me from going mad."

You tilted your head, confused. "What collection?"

"I used to collect rare and unusual antiques when I was Harry." Serious, Christina said. She looked at you then slowly shook her head. "Ms H made you forget that, didn't she?"

"I don't know." Shrugging, you replied. "I can't remember much of when I was a boy." You giggled and added, "Being a girl is so much better."

From the hall outside of Christina's room, mom frowned deeply. "So that's it." Whispering, she said. "Samantha forgot about Christina's addiction to magical artifacts."

"What does that mean?" Wincing, Susan whispered back.

Mom urged Susan away from the door. "The link bracelet allows the apprentice to see the logic and memory of the master, or teacher." Serious, mom explained. "Christina is seeing Samantha's side to everything including her thoughts. It is basically a symbol of trust between the two as neither can lie to each other."

"Only because Christina does not know this, she thinks she is hearing things differently." Catching on, Susan said. She moaned. "What can we do?"

"We need to make certain Christina knows exactly what she is getting into with this link bracelet." Firmly, mom said. "She needs to decide if she wants Samantha as a teacher or me or Witchbloom boarding school."

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom and Susan walked into Christina's room, where Christina was lying in the bed. The bracelet was back on her wrist and you sat by her bed with a look of concern on your face.

"I think they're talking in their minds," you whispered to Mom. Mom sighed, knowing exactly what you meant.

Susan tried speaking to Christina. "Christina, could you take the bracelet off for a moment?"

Christina shook her head. "Don't worry, Mom. It's fine now. My brain couldn't handle the bracelet at first, but it's getting used to it now. Samantha's sorry. She didn't know it would be so rough."

Susan looked at Mom for help. "Christina, we need you to take off the bracelet so that we know we are talking to you, not Samantha."

Christina sighed, but did nothing. She just lay there for a minute. You realized she was talking the idea over with Samantha in her mind. "This is seriously creepy," you muttered to yourself. Mom wouldn't ever have to worry about you accepting one of these bracelets. You didn't want anyone else getting inside your head.

Finally, Christina took the bracelet off and looked at Susan and Mom. "What is it? I told you. I'm okay with this now."

"Christina, I'm not okay with you wearing that bracelet and allowing that witch full access to your mind," Susan exclaimed. She looked really worried.

Christina rolled her eyes. "Mom, you just don't understand cause you're a regular human."

Mom stepped in at this point. "Christina, I'm a witch and I think linking bracelets are an archaic practice that should have been outlawed centuries ago. My mother would have outlawed them if it wasn't for certain members of the witch council who like to keep the old ways alive."

Christina shook her head. "It doesn't matter. I'm allowed to make my own decisions."

That didn't sit well with Susan. "You most certainly are NOT, young lady. You are only six-years old and you don't get to decide for yourself if you can."

"Actually, Susan," Mom said apologetically. "Under witch law, any witch whose magic has awakened can accept an apprenticeship, even if she is six."

Susan looked aghast. Christina looked triumphant. "I hate this," Susan said. "I feel like my child lives in a completely different world than I do. I just want her to be okay."

"But mom, Samantha is helping me with that. I've always had so much anxiety and anger. Lucy's helped me with that a lot, but Samantha can help me even more. I feel calmer than I have in a long time. Learning from her I can become my best self and I can learn more about the things I love." Christina seemed pretty sure of herself.

"What about being a boy again?" you asked, remembering the promise you made to Christina that you'd help her become a boy again.

This question caught Christina off-guard. "I'm sure Samantha...will let me be a boy again once I can be." No one bought that. Christina was deluding herself on that one.

Susan was beside herself at this point. This world was so foreign to her and she felt like she was losing her child. "Well, maybe I should just take you away from here. Make sure you can never see Samantha again."

Mom shook her head sadly. She really should have better prepped Susan for this. "Susan, you know that won't work. Witch society doesn't usually recognize human law. If you took Christina, she'd be taken from you by the witch council, and adopted by a witch to raise her in the proper culture. Most likely, Samantha would have first claim to her. They'd probably wipe your memory too, so you wouldn't be able to contact her either."

Susan felt her heart break inside. "Well, maybe I hate witch society then. It's brought me nothing but trouble." Mom flinched. She saw a real anger in Susan. She had been thrust into a world she didn't entirely understand. She couldn't imagine how it must feel to be so powerless.

Christina felt bad for her mom, but she couldn't not accept this at this point. She hadn't been this excited for anything since her magic had awakened. Suddenly, she had an idea. "Mom, if it really upsets you that much I won't wear the bracelet." Everyone looked at Christina in surprise.

"You mean it, sweetie?" Susan asked.

"Of course, Mom. You mean more to me than some bracelet." It felt like a weight had lifted off Susan's shoulders and she hugged her child sobbing.

The whole event had been extremely emotional for Susan, and Mom asked Mel to help Mrs. Rich down to the kitchen and make her some tea to calm her nerves. As soon as Susan and Mel were out of earshot, Mom turned to Christina. "You have no intention of getting rid of that bracelet, do you?"

Christina shook her head. "Not at all, but you can cast a spell, can't you? A spell that will make the bracelet invisible to Mom and Dad?" She smiled like she had thought up this great idea, but you were rather horrified at this suggestion.

Mom clearly didn't like it either, but she knew she didn't have much choice. Witch court rarely favored human parents and if she wanted any hope of preserving the relationship between Christina and her mother, she had to do this. "I...I can, but your parents can NEVER find out about this."

Christina nodded and put the bracelet back on. Mom said a quick chant and waved her hand over the bracelet. "It's done. Only witches can see the bracelet now." Christina was about to thank her, but Mom cut her off. "Now, I want you to use that thing and summon Samantha. She and I need to have a serious chat."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Mom and Susan talk to Christina.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Christina nodded and touched her bracelet. In a moment, Samantha appeared. She smiled at Christina and you, which made you slightly uncomfortable. Then she turned a stony expression to Mom. "You wanted to talk, Natalie?"

Mom quickly cast a noise bubble around the room. No one outside could hear what was happening inside, so Susan wouldn't interrupt. No matter how loud it got. There was fire in Mom's eyes. She was ready to yell. "I don't appreciate you manipulating myself and Christina into this position."

Samantha chuckled. "I didn't manipulate Christina. I just didn't ask you for permission."

"You didn't tell her that the bracelet would give you direct access into her mind," Mom pointed out.

Samantha had to admit that was true. "Okay, yes, but I was just looking out for the girl. She's like the child I never had."

"Makes me glad you never had a child," Mom retorted.

Samantha shook her head. "You may not be a fan of the old ways, Natalie, but they are still perfectly legal. Christina needs a proper witch to guide her."

"You're Mom was a fan of the old ways. I want to make sure you're not trying to do the same thing to Christina that Elena tried to do to her and Lucy. And Christina already has me to guide her," Natalie responded.

"You? You already have four daughters to take care of who demand fairly constant attention. One with power beyond her comprehension," she said, looking at you. "One who's fallen in with that awful Bane child, one who doesn't get near enough attention, and one who's going to crack under all the pressure you put her under."

"Nonetheless, the witch council put me in charge of Christina." Mom was holding fast.

"Fine, but that still doesn't prevent Christina from serving in an apprenticeship if she wants." Samantha's smirk was annoying.

"And I do want to," Christina interjected.

"I could still fight you. We'd be tied up in witch court for a good long while," Mom pointed out.

"Which is why I'm willing to agree to whatever protections and assurances you want," Samantha responded.

Mom nodded. "First, you must swear that if you lie to me, ever, about Christina, even if it is about what she had for lunch, you will never talk to her again."

Christina objected. "What? No. You can't do that." Her objection was ignored.

Samantha frowned. The kind of swear Mom was looking for was magically binding. If she broke it, her powers would be forfeit. "Fine...but only for as long as the witch council has you assigned as her magical guardian."

That was the best Mom could hope for on that point. "Agreed then. Secondly, Susan must never know about any of this, nor can you get in the way of her and Christina's relationship." That was all fine with Samantha and she nodded. "Third, her apprenticeship will be monitored at first. Myself or Hayley will be present when Christina is at your shop." She kept going before Samantha had a chance to object. "Fourth, when I want to talk to Christina alone, she will take off the link bracelet with no arguments."

Samantha looked back at Christina, then nodded again. "Those are all fair terms, Natalie. I can agree..." She was interrupted.

"Wait, I have two more. You must drop your feud with Cassie Bane."

This took Samantha aback. "Natalie, that girl seriously damaged my reputation with the witch council."

"Don't care. What's more important to you? Getting revenge on Cassie or taking on your new apprentice?" Mom crossed her arms to emphasize her point. You were kind of in awe of her and the way she was taking on Samantha.

Samantha sighed. "Very well. I see Cassie has made some friends over her. What's your last term?"

"You tell me everything you know about any Pharaoh's Rings your family might have."

This surprised Samantha. "That's fine, but I really don't know much about the Pharaoh's Rings. I didn't even realize what that ring I sold to Christina was until about a week ago when the Morganas resurfaced. I do know the Forrester family was one of the ten witch families given a ring to protect, but I had never seen on before. My mother never let me."

Mom groaned in frustration. "So I need to talk to Elena..." She had been hoping Darla was the only witch prisoner she'd have to deal with while searching for the rings.

Samantha nodded. "Yes, you will. And I agree to your terms." She reached out her hand which Natalie took. There was a crackle of magic and the deal was now binding.

"I get to keep my bracelet?" Christina asked.

"How do we know this will be safe for Christina, Mom?" you also asked with great concern in your voice.

Mom nodded to Christina and gave you a look that told you to trust her. She turned back to Samantha. "Lucy and I will bring Christina by for her first lesson tomorrow. We'll start with just an hour."

Samantha smiled. "Good, I'm looking forward to it."

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"How do you expect for Christina's parents to avoid seeing the bracelet?" Samantha asked. Mom proceeded to explain the spell she put on the bracelet. Samantha grinned thinking it was a great idea, which worried you. "That's very clever, Natalie," she said. "A wonderful way to get around that human's immunity to magic." She sounded too pleased about that.

Mom frowned. "Alright. I'm going to go lie to Susan and tell her everything is okay. Meet me at the witch council, Samantha. I might need you when I talk to Elena." She suddenly had a realization. "She must have a Pharaoh's Ring. How else would she have gotten her powers back when she escape from prison last time?"

Samantha didn't like the idea of talking to her mother, but anything she could do to get Natalie's good will worked to her advantage. "Okay, I'll head there now." She turned to Christina. "Christina, keep the bracelet off for the next couple of hours. I don't want you near my mind when I talk to my mother. You should never have to think about her again."

Christina nodded. "Sure thing, Wi...ummm...Samantha." You raise an eyebrow at that. What had see been about to say? Christina took off her link bracelet. "I'll talk to you later, and see you tomorrow." Samantha disappeared and Mom got ready to leave the room.

"Sit with her a bit," she instructed, kissing your forehead. You nodded.

After Mom left the room, you turned to Christina. "Alright, are you insane?"

Christina looked hurt by that. "What do you mean?"

"Letting Samantha mentor you after she tricked you is crazy."

"She's doesn't know how else to get along with people. You saw how messed up her Mom was."

"So? She was Aunt Sara's mom too, and she doesn't trick people into letting her into their minds." You couldn't understand what Christina was thinking. "What were you about to call her anyway?"

Christina wasn't sure she wanted to tell you, but she gave in. "Witchmother...cause she's like my fairy godmother, but a witch. I came up with it, but she really likes it when I call her that."

"But, Christina..." you began, but Christina cut you off.

"You know what, Lucy? I'm really sick of you questioning me. You don't realize how good you have it. You figured out so quickly how to adjust to being a girl and who you were meant to be. You're a princess and a gifted witch. Hooray! Not all of us are that lucky. I have struggled to figure out who I am now. My mom couldn't help me. Your mom couldn't help me. Your sisters definitely couldn't help me. But Samantha is the first person who has given me hope that I might be okay and that I might be able to do something I'm good at and like."

You were taken aback by Christina yelling at you. Your mind had adjusted to be six. Her mind hadn't, which meant she could argue circles around you. But it did surprise you, and hurt you. "I...I thought I was helping you with all that."

Christina sighed realizing she had gotten too angry. "I'm sorry. You were helping, but when I talk with Samantha about magic artifacts, I feel like...that's my destiny. Like you do with doing spells, you know?"

You nodded. "I guess that makes sense, but Samantha won't let you be a boy again. She doesn't like boys."

"She liked me fine when I was a boy, so I'm not sure that's true, but it is a risk I'm okay with. And I need your support, okay? And I still need you to help me figure out starting first grade next week."

"Okay," you said quietly. "I'll support you if this is what you really want. But if she turns you into a mindless glitter zombie, I'm coming after her."

Christina giggled. "That's why I'm not scared to try this. I know if I get in trouble, you and Mrs. H will save me." She pulled you into a hug, which you returned. This talk helped you feel much better about the whole thing. Still, you were glad you were going with her tomorrow. You'd better be able to see that she was okay.

Meanwhile, Cassie entered Katie Thompson's home with two small bags of luggage. She was nervous and frightened, uncertain of where her future was going to take her. She was greeted by Megan, Katie's daughter who surprised her with a warm hug. "Welcome to our home, Cassie." Smiling, she said. "I've always wanted a sister and I hope you will see me as such soon."

Cassie blushed. "Thank you." Softly, she said. "That would be nice."

"Your room is all set up for you, Cassie." Kindly, Katie said. "I hope it is to your liking. We talked to Lucy and a few members of your coven to get ideas of what you liked."

Nervous, Cassie followed Katie to the bedroom. It had pastel pink walls with a blue boarder along the hardwood floor, an antique canopy bed, a white vanity, and oak dresser. The curtains were plain white and the bed was decorated with princess sheets. Seeing them, Cassie blushed. "Lucy must have told you about the princess theme sheets." Softly, she said.

Katie chuckled slightly. "She did. Do you like it?"

"It's perfect." Smiling, Cassie said. "Thank you."

"You only have two small pieces of luggage?" Curious, Megan asked. "Do you have more outside? Do you need help?"

Cassie teared up slightly. "I don't have very much to my name..." Embarrassed, she said.

"Well, there's only one way to solve that." Grinning, Katie said.

Megan beamed before taking Cassie's arm, surprising her. "Mall trip!"

Cassie let out a surprised yelp as Cassie pulled her towards the door with Katie following. "You don't really have to do this for me." Blushing, Cassie said. "I mean, it could be a lot of money."

"I am the primary witch doctor in this area." Bemused, Katie said. "I assure you, money is one thing we do not worry about."

"Come on, Cassie." Giggling, Megan said. "This will be fun!"

Cassie gave a small grin, not sure what to say. Her life had gone from hell to heaven in less than a day. She hoped her new friends were doing as well.

Elsewhere...

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
While mom was off with Samantha dealing with the rogue witch, Elena Kruse, you found yourself more and more curious about Christina's bracelet. "What does she really see in that trinket?" Whispering to yourself, you wondered. "Voices in your head is a bad thing." You shuddered, vaguely remembering hearing voices in your own head what seemed like a lifetime ago.

Christina was off talking to Mel, Hayley was in her room studying, and Hannah was on the phone with Liz. You had the perfect opportunity to take a closer look at the bracelet and see for yourself why Christina suddenly shifted from wanting your help to wanting Samantha's "It's really not fair."Pouting, you said. "I thought I was supposed to be helping her, not aunt Samantha."

You picked up the bracelet and found it rather light. You did not feel any urge to put it on but your curiosity moved you do do so. "What does this thing do anyway?" Snapping it on, you wondered.

As the bracelet went on with a click, you suddenly found yourself somewhere else. You were in a strange house, standing beside Samantha as she watched her mother, Elena Kruse flipping through a huge magic book. "I cannot have you and Natalie getting too close, dear." Serious, Elena said. "Your combined power is too much greater than my own."

"Why are you so afraid of our friendship?" Defiant, Samantha demanded.

"My other daughter, Sarah is already swooning over Natalie's brother, Jack!" Angry, Elena snapped. "I can't get her to listen anymore! I will not lose you to the same accursed family!"

She then chanted something that caused a flash to fill the room. When the light faded, you found yourself in a prison somewhere with Samantha looking right at you with a cross look on her face. "Take that off this instant, child!" Screaming, she demanded. "You have no right to eavesdrop on my affairs!"

You let out a scream of fright and tore off the bracelet to find Christina looking at you in surprise and annoyance. "Why did you put on my bracelet?" Irritated, she demanded.

"I- I was curious." Shaken, you asked. "I saw Samantha, she..."

"I don't want to hear it." Firmly, Christina said. She sighed. "Look, I know you want to help me but right now Samantha can help me better than you can so just let her do it, okay?"

"Besides that, the bracelet was not meant for you." Startling you, Hayley said.

You turned to see her standing at the door. "What do you mean?"

Hayley sighed. "The link bracelet causes hallucinations for a short time before the wearer is used to seeing through another's mind." Firmly but kindly, she explained. "Those hallucinations can be worse if the bracelet is not meant for you."

"Okay..." Pouting, you muttered. "I was just trying to help..."

"No, you were being nosy." Half grinning, Hayley countered. "You're just as bad as Hannah."

Christina giggled. "Just don't do that again."

You shuffled out of Christina's room, not sure if you should tell anyone what you had seen while wearing the bracelet.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Hannah sat on the couch in the living room of your family's house lazily flipping through tv channels. She was bored and there was nothing good on. You were upstairs with Christina, Mel was taking Susan Rich back home, and Hayley was off with her friends. She was lonely. It felt like everyone had someone to play with but her. She had been hoping Stephanie and Rachel would solve that problem, but she always felt like a third wheel with them. She had thought she could hang out with Mike Cutie, but he had told her yesterday at school, he didn't want to hang with her anymore. The other boys in the grade were making fun of him for spending time with a girl, especially one as princess-obsessed as Hannah.

The door opened and Cassie walked in. Hannah looked up confused. "I thought you went over to Megan's house."

Cassie nodded. "I did, but...I don't know. They're nice and all, but a little too..."

"Happy?" Hannah asked, making room for Cassie on the couch. Cassie sat.

"Yep. Super eager to have me there." Her eyes moved to the floor. "I'm...not used to that. I needed a little breathing room."

"Come to see Mel?" Hannah questioned, in a teasing sing-song voice.

Cassie blushed. "What? I mean, I guess. She's my friend."

"Have you asked her on a date yet?" Hannah asked.

Cassie looked completely taken a back. "I...I...What kind of question is that for someone your age to ask someone?"

Hannah shrugged. "When you are my age, you can ask anyone anything and get away with it."

Cassie shook her head. "Well, it's not...she's not..." She had not been expected to be interrogated by an 8-year-old. "She's probably into boys anyway."

Again, Hannah shrugged. "She doesn't take about them much anymore. Not since you two started hanging out."

Cassie sighed, looking for anything to change the subject. "How come you are by yourself."

Hannah huffed and crossed her arms. "Cause boys are stupid. Mike Cutie doesn't want to be my friend anymore. Just cause I'm a girl and boys are making fun of him." Cassie smiled. Changing the subject had been remarkably easy.

Cassie nodded. "It's what I've been saying. Witches are better than humans, and girls are better than boys. Mike's a potential witch, right?"

"Yeah, like Christina. I wished he'd turn into a girl too. Then maybe he wouldn't be so worried about what stupid boys think."

"Maybe I could help with that." Cassie pulled out a vial of silvery glittery powder.

Hannah's eyes went wide at the sight of the powder. She recognized it. "That's glitter bomb glitter."

"Yep. Pretty cool, right? You may not have magic yet. But with this you can make him a girl easy. Might even awaken his powers. Either way, he's better off as one of us than one of them."

Hannah nodded staring at the vial. "Yeah, cool. But...it won't turn him into a glitter zombie, will it?"

Cassie shook her head. "That was a little something Samantha added when she tried to frame me."

"Oh, yeah. Doesn't that mean we could get in trouble for doing this?" Hannah asked.

"Only if you get caught, which won't happen. Everyone's been expecting Mike Cutie to turn into a witch girl anyway."

Hannah took the vial from Cassie. "Okay, I'll think about it." She suddenly glared at Mel. "But you better treat my sister right when you start dating."

Cassie chuckled as she leaned back on the couch. "I don't know what you're talking about kid." But her mind did drift to Melanie Harrison.

No even sure what you saw was real, you resolved not to tell anyone. You sighed as you looked down of the railing of the stairs. Hannah was asleep on the couch down below. Mel was probably still taking Susan Rich home. Cassie was probably gone. It looked like the sun had set without you realizing it. You heard a noise behind you as Hayley stepped out of Christina's room.

"Mom just called. She'll be back in a few minutes. I'm going to back to my friends, Lucy. Try not to have another emergency for a while. I tired of getting warped back home to help you. It's wrecking havoc on my social life." Hayley seemed both annoyed and amused.

"I guess, Mom knows about me trying on the bracelet..." you sighed, preparing yourself for another earful later.

"Yep." Hayley got prepared to teleport herself, but looked you over first. "Nice outfit, by the way. DIdn't know you'd take to ballet so much?" You blushed as you realized you were still wearing the performance tutu from ballet that you got thanks to that Knightley kid reflecting your magic. With all the Christina stuff going on, you hadn't had time to change.

You were about to explain yourself to Hayley, but she was already gone. Teleported away. You sighed again and began to walk back to your room to change. But suddenly as you opened the door, an extreme terror gripped you. You stumbled into the room and fell to the floor wanting to break out into tears. Suddenly, you noticed a large man standing in the middle of the room. You quickly realized her was the cause of this fear. Something about him, an aura, was making him terrifying to you. He step closer. You wanted to scream, but you couldn't. You were two scared. As he reached you, he bent down, reached out and put a necklace around your neck. Suddenly, you felt much better. The extreme terror was gone and you could move again, but there was still a man you had never seen before in your bedroom. You stepped back still worried, but he seemed friendlier now, and there was a warm smile on his face.

"Hello," he said kindly. "Sorry about that. I was cursed years ago. Makes those with witch blood very afraid of me. That amulet should protect you though."

"Who are you?" you asked warily.

"Why me?" He laughed a hearty laugh, like how you'd imagine Santa Claus would laugh. "I'm your grandfather, Moriarty. Moriarty Strange. Your mom left a message for me at our drop to come right away. So here I am."

This was really a shock to you. You had heard stories of your grandfather, but no one had ever told you why you had never met him your entire life. You hadn't known if he was alive or dead. "Here you are...in my room."

He scratched his head. "Yeah, sorry about that. I'm not very accurate with teleportation. That's more of a skill you witches have. Though you probably don't have your powers yet." He sure did like to talk a lot.

"I have powers. Really strong ones." You did your flame to show off.

He looked amazed. "Wow, that's real impressive. Wonderful that one so young as you is already learning magic. I'm very proud of you, Hannah."

"I'm not Hannah, I'm Lucy," you corrected.

"Oh, yeah. I'm sorry. I don't remember your mother mentioning a Lucy. I just thought she said the young girly one was Hannah." He pointed to your outfit as evidence. "But maybe I'm confusing grandkids. Easy to do when you haven't met any of them." He laughed again.

"Hannah's my big sister," you tried to explain. This was getting too weird. "Look, Grandpa, what are you doing here?"

He smiled. "Grandpa...I've never been called that before. I like it. Definitely could get used to it. I like you, kid." He tussled your hair, which made you blush. Why did everyone love doing that to you so much? "Well, as I said your Mom left a message for me. She only does that in emergencies, but if the rumors I heard are true, I'm guessing she wants to know about the Pharaoh's ring I'm guarding." He showed off a ring with a opal stone at the center. "Pretty neat, huh? I bet you love jewelry."

"Yeah, I got my ears pierced last week." You showed off the sparkly ear studs you were wearing in your ears. You weren't sure why you were so open with this man. He just made you feel comfortable.

"Very pretty, sweetheart," he complemented. "I also thought I'd meet your older brother while I'm here. John. I hear he's got the potential to quite a powerful witch boy. I was thinking of offering to train him." Your eyes widened. You tried to interrupt him, but he kept talking. "You know, there's a prophecy that a grandson of mine is going to be one of the most power male witch there ever was. I'm thinking its probably him. Of course, there's also a prophecy one of my granddaughters will become an insanely powerful witch. Maybe that's you, eh?" He chuckled again.

"Well, they can't both me, Grandpa. I'm...well...I used to be..." You gulped. "John's gone. I'm Lucy now and I don't want to be a boy ever again."

Your grandfather's jaw dropped.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom peered into the room with a cross look on her face which vanished the instant she saw grandpa standing in your room. "Dad!" Surprised, she said. "What are you doing here?"

"Discovering that there had been many changes to this family and its associates since the last time we talked." Patiently, Moriarty replied. "I can already see that my wife and I are long overdue for a serious discussion."

"Please, dad." Eyeing you, mom said. "Not here."

Moriarty turned to you with a kind smile. "Your mother and I are going to have a little chat, pumpkin." Smiling, he said. "I will be back in just a bit."

With that, Moriarty followed mom out of the room and closed the door. Eager to know what was going on, you ran to the door and put our ear against it to try to listen only you heard nothing. "Mom and her privacy spells..." Irritated, you muttered.

Frustrated, you went to your dresser and changed out of the elaborate tutu dress and into a knee length skirt and blouse. Just as you had finished, a knock came to the door and mom peered in before entering with Moriarty. She seemed frustrated but carried a patient smile as she turned to you. "Curiosity is not a sin, dear." Firmly, she said. "Still, you should not play with anything you do not understand."

"Okay, mommy." Pouting, you said. "I'm sorry."

"Live and learn." Shrugging, Moriarty said. He gave a short laugh. "Your mother wanted to give you a lecture you would not forget but I'm guessing the vision you got scared you enough not to try that again."

You quickly nodded. "What I saw was scary." Shuddering, you said. "It had something to do with aunt Samantha's mom."

That got mom's attention. "What did you see?"

You explained what you saw to which Moriarty laughed again. "That could mean anything." Amused, he said. "Elena hated Samantha and Sarah with a passion."

"Why?" Wincing, you asked. "Was she not their mother?"

"Step mother." Flatly, mom said. She paused. "Do you remember the story of Cinderella?" You nodded to which mom said, "Same thing only Elena is the step mother from hell."

"Nothing you need to worry yourself about, my dear." Smiling, Moriarty said. He held out a lollipop for you to see. "Why don't you run along and forget all about that crazy vision the bracelet gave you."

Reluctantly, you took the lollipop and gave it a small lick. To your surprise, it tasted like strawberry icecream, your favorite treat. "Delicious!" Beaming, you said.

With that, you were running off, forgetting all about even touching the bracelet. Mom sighed then turned to Moriarty. "Really, dad?" Frowning, she demanded. "Lucy is hyper enough to be eating sweets before dinner."

"A distraction was needed." Serious, Moriarty replied. "I couldn't think of anything else." he smiled. "Besides, this is the first time I get to spoil my grandchildren." He then turned to Christina who was watching in fear from her room.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You sat on the couch enjoying the lollipop as Hannah napped next to you. You considered waking her up, but you decided against it. You didn't know how many of those amulets your Grandfather had, and you didn't want her to experience the terror from the curse on him that you had. Besides, you really didn't want to have to share this lollipop. It was super calming and you imagined magic was at work.

Suddenly, the doorbell rang. Thinking nothing of it, you popped off the couch and headed to answer the door. Your state of relaxation was immediately ruined by the sight you saw at the door.

"What are you doing her, Pinbrat?" you said with great distain and surprise. You had figured out what revenge you were going to take yet. This was too soon.

Sean Knightley groaned at the sight of you, but he didn't seem quite as surprise to see you as you were to see him. "Looking for my teacher, Sparkle Boots. So you can get out of my way."

"Your teacher?" you said with confusion. Sean had mentioned him last time.

"Ahhhhh, Young Knightley. You found the place! Good, good," your Grandfather's voice boomed from behind. Color drained from your face as you realized who Sean's teacher was. "Glad to see my teleportation spell didn't send to too far afield."

Sean stared daggers at Grandpa Moriarty. "It sent me into the pool, Sir." It was only now that you noticed Sean's clothing was completely soaked. Which made you giggle.

"Well, come on in. Come on in. I'm sure Natalie has plenty of clothes your size here," Grandpa said as he ushered the dripping boy into the living room.

"I'll be fine, Sir. I don't want to borrow any clothes." He glared at you. "I see your not wearing that silly outfit anymore." He was referring to the elaborate tutu you had taken off only minutes before.

You blushed deeply and lied quickly. "Yeah, right. I took that off hours ago. First chance I got."

Unfortunately, this was the point when your Grandfather noticed you were no longer wearing that very same outfit. "Hey, you're not wearing that ballet outfit anymore, Princess. You didn't have to take that off on my account."

You wanted to die. You actually wanted to die. Especially as Sean's face twisted into a smug expression with the realization of what Grandpa was taking about. "Oh, I would have loved to have seen you in such a pretty outfit, Sparkle Boots. I'm sure you looked lovely." His voice was dripping with mocking.

Your hands started to crackle with magic. "I'll give you a matching one, Pinbrat!" you shouted.

"Try it. It'll go about as well as last time," Sean responded, readying himself for whatever you threw at him.

"ENOUGH!!!!" Grandpa bellowed. Both of you snapped to attention, facing him. It was fortunate that Hannah was able to sleep through anything. Grandpa sighed as he looked back and forth between you. "I take it you two know each other."

"Sir, this is the girl who made my socks all pink and ruffly," Sean explained.

You giggled. "That was pretty awesome." You remembered something. "Wait, you had to spend the rest of the day as a girl, didn't you? My grandpa turned you into a girl." You were at this point laughing hysterically.

Sean gestured toward you. "This girl is unbearable, Sir."

"This girl is my granddaughter, Lucy," Grandpa emphasized.

"I know, but still, she's annoying." Sean looked at you again. "Super annoying."

You smiled at him. "It makes me soooooo happy that I annoy you."

"Can you introduce me to someone else?" Sean asked. "Anyone else? What about your grandson John. He sounded pretty cool." Sean's eyes lit up with admiration as he mention your former self. You started giggling again, knowing he was about to be severely disappointed.

Grandpa grimaced and rubbed his shoulder awkwardly. "Actually, young Knightley, I've just learned that Lucy here...well, she was John." Then, he smiled sheepishly. "But Lucy's pretty great, isn't she?"

Sean's jaw dropped and he looked at you in complete and utter shock and horror.

"YOU??" Sean shouted in shock. "You used to be a boy? But your such a girl?"

"That's the first nice thing you said to me," you teased him.

"Why would you choose to be a girl over a boy?" Sean demanded in confusion.

You shrugged. "Being a boy is lame and being a girl is awesome."

"NO! It's the other way around."

"Well, I should know. I've been both."

"So have I!" Sean countered.

"Only for a day."

"No, for three weeks when my magic awakened. But unlike you I didn't give into girliness or whatever. You must be super weak-willed." With this Sean, got another rise out of you and you got ready to try and zap him again, but Grandpa interceded before it came to that.

"Calm down, kids. It's different for every witch boy. Some are meant to stay boys and some are meant to become wonderful witch girls," he wrapped his arms around the two of you. "We can all be friends here, right?" That question got a very unenthusiastic response from both you and Sean.

"What's all this noise?" Mom asked coming down the stairs. "I finally got Christina settled down, but this noise isn't helping." She looked at Grandpa and held up the amulet she was wearing to him. "How many of these anti-curse amulets have you got?"

"I have two more," he answered. "I thought it was enough. I didn't realize about Lucy or your houseguest."

"How come you don't need one?" you asked Sean, almost pleasantly.

He smirked. "Witch boys are immune, cause we're not wimps like girls are."

Before you could respond, Mom finally took notice of Sean. "Who is this boy dripping on my carpet?" she asked. Sean blushed.

"Oh, this is my student, Sean Knightley," Grandpa explained. Mom looked at Sean with surprise upon hearing the name. "I've been starting to take students again. Isn't that wonderful?"

Mom nodded. "It really is, Dad. Better than you just sitting miserable around that castle." Grandpa lived in a castle? Mom turned to Sean. "Maybe I have some clothing you can change into."

"That's okay, Ma'am," Sean said very politely. "I don't want to wear any girl clothes."

"You won't catch cooties," you said, rolling your eyes. Sean shot you a look.

Mom chuckled. "That wasn't exactly what I had in mind, Sean." She waved her hand and Sean's clothes disappeared, replaced by a sweater and slacks, dry socks and shoes. He seemed pleased with this result. You weren't.

"Thank you, Ma'am. You're very kind." You suddenly became concerned that Mom might not realize that Sean was the most annoying person on Earth. You needed her to know that. "Oh, I have something for you." Sean reached on to his hand and pulled off a ruby ring. You realized it must be a Pharaoh ring.

Mom smiled and took it. "So the Knightley family had one too. This means we have 4 and Lilly Sweetie has 4. That's progress."

"You found Elena's ring, Mommy?" you asked.

Mom held up an Onyx ring. "Yes, the witch was vain and oblivious enough that she was just wearing it on her finger. I can't believe no one found it until today." She looked at the four rings in her hand, one ruby, one diamond, one opal, and one onyx. "I should take these back to the witch council."

"You really think you can find a way to destroy them?" Grandpa asked.

Mom looked optimistic. "Not yet, but we got some good people working on it. These rings have caused enough trouble."

"Well, now that you have the rings. I'm afraid Knightley and I should be off," Grandpa said.

You felt extreme disappointment all of a sudden. "Wait, Grandpa. You just got here. I was hoping to get to know you a bit."

Grandpa bent down in front of you. "I'm sorry, sweetheart, but the longer I'm away from my castle. The more powerful the curse grows."

Your face fell. "What's the deal with this curse anyway?"

Grandpa smiled. "Maybe I have time to tell my granddaugther one story." Sean looked like someone had just told him he had to have teeth pulled.

"There is a balance between witches and witch boys." Serious, grandpa said. "Witch girls have magic while witch boys have incredible physical powers including great vision and hearing."

Later that night, you were lightly shaken awake by a familiar hand and opened your eyes to see Samantha Forester sitting at your bedside. You opened your mouth to scream in fright only nothing came out. "I'm not here to yell at you, child though I should." Whispering, Samantha said. "What you did was foolish and dangerous."

"I said I was sorry." Pouting, you protested.

"You could have been more than just sorry." Serious, Samantha said. "You got off lucky." She let out a low sigh then managed a smile. "Still, what is done is done just don't do that again unless you want me to be your teacher too."

You quickly shook your head. "I want mommy to teach me." You then became curious. "Did you sneak into our house just to chew me out?"

Samantha giggled. "Not quite." Bemused, she said. "I came here to help you understand the relationship I have with Christina. I know you have been worried about that."

"Sort of..." Wincing, you replied.

"When you and she were John and Harry, you were both feeling lonely for different reasons." Calmly, Samantha explained. "He was left alone in the house for weeks to months at a time and you were the only boy in a house full of girls."

"I guess that's why I like being a girl so much better." Smiling, you said. "Because i'm not alone anymore."

"Something like that." Smiling, Samantha said. "You and Harry filled that void in your lives but now that loneliness you share has changed."

"How so?" Wincing, you asked. "We're both girls..."

Samantha sighed. "Christina is struggling with her new found femininity as she still has the mind of a teenage boy." Patiently, she said. "Add to that she is still not seeing her mother or father for weeks or months on end due to her now having magic."

"So how can you help her?" Wincing, you said. "I thought I was helping her."

"Christina still has a fondness for magical artifacts." Smiling, Samantha replied. "That is something I specialize in, among other things. Though this approach, I can reach her faster and better than most."

"What about me?" Curious, you demanded. "I thought I was helping her."

"You were helping but your approach and your mother's approach takes months to work." Serious, Samantha said. "Christina does not have that type of patience." She then roughed up your hair, making you blush. "As for your loneliness, you have so much magical power at your command but you are not allowed to use it. I know that drives you crazy."

You teared up, nodding. "It does... what can I do?"

"Well, acting out as you had will only strengthen your nickname of 'Vader'." Bemused, Samantha said. "You need a magical outlet."

"Like what?" Curious, you asked.

You were now hanging on every word not knowing Samantha had a gift for convincing people of her arguments. "Well, you could..."

"Well, you could join Christina as my apprentice," she held up another link bracelet. Immediately upon seeing it, she lost you.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
The phone rang the next morning as Mom was just about to start making breakfast. Hayley had slept over at a friend's house, but that still left four hungry girls who needed to eat. Though the only up was Hannah, who was sitting at the table deep in thought as she flipped through some chapter book about fairies.

When Mom answered the phone, she discovered Clara Belacourt on the other line. "Hello, Clara. How are you? I'm sorry we didn't get a chance to talk when I dropped off Liz yesterday."

"That's fine, Natalie. Sounded like a real emergency. I hope it worked out."

Mom sighed. "Jury's still out on that. How's Liz after everything that happened on Friday." She still felt guilty about the Morganas raiding the house while Liz was here.

"She's surprisingly okay. I think she sees Lucy as some sort of Superhero figure. Someone who will keep her safe no matter what. It makes me feel much better knowing Lucy looks after her. My magic isn't that strong, so I'm not much good in a fight, so I'm glad to hear your family has her back."

"It's hard to believe they've only been friends for a little over a week," Mom remarked. She was relieved to hear Clara wasn't too upset about the whole incident. "They act like they've been best friends for years."

Clara chuckled. "Anyway, the reason I called is that I got some information on your rings."

"That's amazing. I know information on them is pretty scarce."

"Well, this is my job," Clara said, downplaying the complement, but still quite flattered. "Much of this you already know. There are ten rings, each with a different kind of jewel or gemstone decorating it. There's amethyst, sapphire, ruby, emerald, diamond, opal, onyx, topaz, moonstone, and garnet."

Mom quickly ran all the Pharaoh's rings she had seen through her mind. "Lilly has four and we have four. I guess that leaves only the moonstone and the emerald unaccounted for. Did you have any luck matching the rings to the families protecting them?"

"It was difficult, but I am good at what I do. You know the Morganas had one to begin with and they stole one from transformed boys from both the Havendale family and the Beaumont family."

"There was also the one Christina bought at Samantha's shop," Mom mentioned. "Some family must have lost theirs."

"That was most likely the ring belonging to the Ravenwood family. The sapphire, right?" Clara said, checking her notes. "They fell on some hard financial times about 20 years back and sold off most of there prized artifacts. Then they were disgraced by the witch council due to that scandal and things just went downhill from there."

Mom nodded. "I remember the trial. Well, those are the four rings, Lilly has possession of."

"Well...I hate to break it to you Natalie, but she probably has five."

The color drained from Mom's face. "The Sweeties were one of the ten families?"

"Yes, they had the emerald, most likely. That's probably how Lilly got her magic back."

Mom cursed herself for not thinking of that. "Well, the four I recovered are the ones that were protected by the Banes, the Kruses, the Stranges, and the Knightleys."

Clara was quite surprised to hear that. "The Knightleys? I was sure that would be the hardest to find. That family was wiped out in that incident three years ago."

"That's what I thought too, but just yesterday I met their last living heir," Mom said, thinking of Sean.

"That's amazing. You'll have to explain later." Clara flipped through her notes searching for the info she needed. "So the last ring is the Moonstone. I'm afraid that one might be tricky as well. It was given to the Frey families."

Mom groaned. The Freys were strong believers in the old ways and witch and female superiority. They lived out of town in the mountains and were very cautious about who they let near them. "On the bright side, there is no way Lilly will get near them."

Clara was in agreement on that. "I know it goes against your maternal instincts to get them involved, but you might want to bring Lucy or Hannah with you when you approach them. I met the matriarch, Gwendolyn Frey at a conference a few years ago. She has a soft spot for fiery, independent-minded little girls. They might help you get your foot in the door. I'm guessing Lucy's reputation has even reached them."

Mom groaned again. She really didn't want to get her daughters more involved then they already were, but Clara had a point. "I'll think about it. What about destroying the rings? Did you find anyway to do so?"

"It's possible, but you would need to have all ten rings together. They have to be destroyed all at once," Clara explained. "You sure the witch council is going to go for that. I know a few want to keep the rings around in their hands."

"They've caused too much trouble for us recently," Mom said, remembering Elena, the Morganas, and Lilly all made use of the rings in some way. "They had to be destroyed. Thanks for the information, Clara. You truly are impressive."

"Anytime." And with that, the two hung up.

Meanwhile, Christina walked into your room as you had just finished getting dressed for the day. Upon seeing her, you noticed she was wearing the bracelet and had a good idea what was weighing on her mind. "You know she visited me last night." Softly, you said. "No, I'm not wearing the bracelet but no, I'm not telling on you or aunt Samantha because it means too much to you."

Christina sighed, a hint of relief but also a hint of disappointment. "We used to do everything together, Lucy." Sadly, she said. "What happened to that?"

Christina's question made you feel uncomfortable. You still wanted to be her friend but you were not keen about having aunt Samantha in your head. Also, you were still freaked out about what you had seen when you put on Christina's bracelet for only a moment. "I guess we changed." Scoffing your feet, you replied. "We are still friends, right?"

"We still are friends." Almost defensively, Christina said. "We... I mean I would just like it to go back to what it was before when we were more like siblings than friends."

You caught Christina's slip up and sighed. "If you want to convince me, you'll have to do it without Samantha telling you what to say." With a slight frown, you scolded. Tears formed in your eyes. "You want us to be closer as friends? Then speak from your heart like we always did before."

You then walked past Christina but whispered in her ear. "I know you can hear me, aunt Samantha." Quietly, you said. "Christina is not your puppet."

Christina winced, hearing that and watched you walk out of the room. Only she sighed as she heard Samantha's voice in her head. "Don't worry, child." Calmly, she said. "We just need to be more careful the next time we try."

"I want her to understand that you are not evil." Tearfully, Christina thought back.

"She understands." Reassuringly, Samantha said. "Only, just like her mother, she has her own set of rules for these things. We just need to work around them."

Christina nodded then became thoughtful. It was Saturday morning which meant no school and two days in which to form a plan. "She wants me to talk from the heart..."

You still felt a little bit of temptation to try the link bracelet, and figured the further you were away from it, the better. So pretty soon, you found yourself playing your Nintendo DS on the couch downstairs.

Mom had breakfast ready. She made pancakes every Sunday morning, which was your and Hannah's favorite. You ate quietly, though to make sure Mom didn't notice you and Christina were slightly at odds, you avoided talking to anyone. It wasn't too hard. Mel was absorbed in a magazine and Hannah seemed to be deep in thought about something else.

Just as you were finishing breakfast, the phone rang. Mom went to pick it up, but after talking for a few moments, handed the phone to you with a smile. "Lucy, it's for you. It's a girl named Keira. She says she's your friend from school."

You nodded excitedly and picked up the phone. Keira had never called you at home before, so this was potentially exciting. "Hey, Keira. What's up?"

"Hey, Lucy. How are you feeling? I was worried when you didn't come to school on Friday."

You had to think back and remember Mom kept you at home to help Christina adjust. Seemed like forever ago. "Oh, yeah...I was sick, but I'm feeling a lot better now."

This seemed to make sense to Keira. "Yeah, Tammy was out too. Something must be going around, but I'm glad you're all better."

"Thanks," you responded.

Keira then got to the point of her call. "So my Mom says your dress is ready. She was wondering if you could come by today to try it on." This got you really excited. You and your six new friends were doing a group costume for Halloween, which was in about a week. You were all going as Disney Princesses, you as Cinderella. Keira's mom was a seamstress and had been making a beautiful Cinderella costume for you. Finally, it was ready.

"That's so cool. Let me ask my Mom." You quickly and eagerly told Mom what was up. Christina rolled her eyes in the background, annoyed that you were so excited about trying on such a girly outfit, but you ignored her. Mom reminded you that you and her were taking Christina to the mall for her first lesson with Samantha, but suggested maybe you all could swing by Keira's place first.

You got back on the phone and told Keira the news. "But there is one thing. A friend of mine has been staying over this weekend. Is it okay if she comes too just to watch." You knew Christina wouldn't be excited about it, but she'd just have to deal with it. You weren't going out of your way for her at the moment.

"That should be fine. Someone else might be swinging by as well." Keira giggled, getting you curious.

"Oh, yeah? Who?" you asked.

"You'll see later. See you soon."

You hung up, a bit nervous about having Christina meet Keira. She was going to meet all your human friends eventually, but you were still worried she'd do something to mess things up for you.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: You try to enjoy the weekend.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"What? No, that sounds so lame?" groaned Christina as you informed her where you all were going before visiting Samantha. "At least your interested in magical artifacts. I'm not interested at all in Disney Princesses."

You rolled your eyes. "You will be pretty soon, once Samantha done with you." You were packing up a few things in your bag for the day in your room. The main thing you wanted was your spellbook. You thought it might be useful when you were in Samantha's shop. You might be able to find ingredients for some cool spells to try.

"She's not going to do that with me, Lucy," Christina assured you. "Witchmother respects that I want to be a boy." But you knew she was wrong. Samantha had manipulated Christina before and she'd do it again. You just had to make sure you didn't get caught in Samantha's web too.

"Just try to be nice to my friend, okay?" you implored your friend. "She's not like Liz. She doesn't know about witches. She's just a cool girl from school who helped me when I was feeling really lonely."

Christina frowned. "How about I make you a deal? I'll go to this dress thing if you put on the link bracelet. I'll even put on a dress if you want." Christina was clearly desperate to get you to try on the bracelet.

"There isn't going to be a dress for you, Christina, so you don't have to worry about that," you said. "Keira's mom makes custom dresses. So they base it off measuring you. You haven't been measured."

Christina looked confused. "When did you get measured? I thought you said you'd never met Keira's mom."

"I haven't. Keira knows how to measure too. She did it for me at school." You finally got the spell book to fit in your backpack. You smiled. "Alright, I'm ready to go." The clock on your wall said you still had a half hour before you needed to leave though.

Christina groaned again and went into your nightstand, pulling out the link bracelet. "Fine, but I'm bringing this too. Just in case Witchmother can convince you to change your mind. You're really missing out, Lucy." She slipped the bracelet into one of her pant pockets and walked out of the room.

You were happy to be able to sit in your room without feeling like that thing was in your drawer waiting for you, but you were a bit nervous about what Christina or Samantha might try to pull during Christina's lesson. Mom was going to be there, but you didn't feel like you could tell her what was going on. You needed other backup. There was one person you knew who would never miss the chance to see you all dressed up like a Princess and you decided to invite her.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Christina tries again with the link bracelet

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You walked to Hannah's room and knocked on her open door. She looked up at you and smiled. "Hey, sis." Kindly, she said. "What's up?"

"I sort of have a problem." Wincing, you said.

That caught Hannah's attention. "What happened?" Sighing, she asked. "Did you go 'Vader' on someone again?"

You blushed at that. "No..." Defensively, you replied. "I'm going to try on the dress Keira's mom made for me to wear at the costume party..."

Hannah shook her head. "That's not the problem and you know it." Scolding, she said. "Come on, what's the real problem and why did you not tell mom about it?"

"Mom kind of knows." Wincing again, you said. "I have to go with Christina when she gets her first lesson from aunt Samantha."

Hannah frowned. "You're scared she's going to try to rope you into becoming her student too, aren't you?" Serious, she asked.

This shocked you. "How did you..."

"Mom told Haley, Mel, and I that aunt Samantha might try to convince other witches than Christina to let her tutor them." Frowning, Hannah explained. "Did she ask you?"

You quickly shook your head. "Uh-uh."

Hannah smiled, a look of relief on her face. "If she does, tell mom right away." Softly, she warned. "Aunt Samantha is a hard witch to read, you never know what she will do next."

"Well, I sort of want someone to back me up when I go..." Worried, you said.

Hannah nodded. "I thought you would." Smiling, she said. "Don't worry, your older sister will look out for you."

You smiled at that.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: The cool older sister.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
A half hour later, with you, Christina, and Hannah in the backseat, Mom pulled her car up in front of Keira's house. You felt a wave of excitement as you got ready to get out of the car. However, any excitement you may have had paled in comparison to the excitement that was radiating from your older sister.

"Geez, what are you getting so crazy for?" Christina asked Hannah. Hannah was making little squealing sounds.

"This is so exciting. It's Lucy's first PRINCESS DRESS!!!!! Well, it's her first that she's wanted to put on," Hannah explained.

Mom chuckled up front as she got out of the car. While not intentional, bringing Hannah to watch your back was a stroke of genius. The second she found out about you trying on a custom made dress, she demanded that Mom bring her too, or else face her 8-year-old wrath. Mom didn't suspect the real reason Hannah was coming along.

You and the other girls filed out of the car. It was then that Christina noticed a camera gripped tightly in Hannah's hands. "Wait, you're going to take pictures?"

"Of course," Hannah responded like it was the most obvious thing in the world. "This event must be remembered...for science." You started giggling.

Christina shot you a look. "I can't believe you're okay with this."

You shrugged. "Of course, I'm okay with it. Hannah's my sister and I like making her happy." Hannah smiled at you. "Plus, I want to have pictures too to show how awesome I'm going to look."

Christina shook her head in despair. Her best friend had lost her mind. You had gone full girl.

You reached the door and rang the doorbell yourself. Your friend, your job as far as you were concerned. The house was nice, bigger and fancier than yours, as Keira's family had more money. While her mom worked as a seamstress (mostly because she enjoyed the work), her father had some big corporate job in the city and Keira and her two sisters lived a very comfortable live.

The door flew open to reveal Keira's smiling face. "Good. You're here." The two of you squealed and pulled each other into hug. This was actually the first time you two had hung out outside of school, so it was an exciting affair. Christina rolled her eyes, while Hannah felt a pang of sadness and envy. "You excited?"

"So excited. I can't wait to see the dress." You remembered introductions were in order. "Oh, Keira. This is my mom, this is my friend, Christina, and you probably already know my sister, Hannah."

"Yeah, I've seen Hannah around at school." Keira waved at all of them. "Why don't you all come in? Mom's in her studio with a client." She giggled a bit at the word client. "Just wait until you see who it is." She whispered the last part to you.

"You have a very lovely home, Keira," Mom commented as the four of you followed Keira through the different rooms of the house. Sure enough, it seemed pretty fancy.

"Thanks, Mrs. Harrison," Keira responded. "It's nice to hear that." She waved a younger girl playing with dolls in what looked like a playroom. You guess it was Keira's younger sister, which Keira confirmed a second later. "That's my little sister, Molly."

Finally, you reached a door in the back, which Keira pulled open to reveal a studio full of fabrics and figures for hanging clothes on. Keira's mom (or so you assumed based on their shared fiery red hair) sat in the center working on an Alice in Wonderland dress that was being worn by a girl. The girl's mom stood nearby beaming. What shocked you was that you recognized the mom. It was your Aunt Catherine, which meant...

You took a close looked at the girl in the dress and your jaw dropped. Next to you, Hannah was having the exact same reaction. Christina, on the other hand, was a little more puzzled. Finally, she stated, "Hey, doesn't that girl look kind of like your cousin?"

Tim Towers fumed at your sudden appearance, but also seemed extremely embarrassed to be caught in this situation. His voice portrayed a mix of anger and panic.

"What...what are you two cootie-brains doing here?!?!"

The only was response was the flash of Hannah's camera.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: At Keira's house.

choices: Hannah tries to talk to Tim
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Hey, no pictures!!!!" Tim shouted.

"Hold still, please," Keira's mom instructed. Tim blushed, noticed his mom's stern gaze, and complied.

"What...what is happening?" you asked super confused.

"I don't know, but I've had dreams of this moment," Hannah replied.

Keira's mom smiled as she turned toward your group. "Wow, so many of you. Which one is Lucy?"

You smiled and raised your hand. "I am, Mrs. McCarthy. Thank you for having me and making me a dress."

"It's no trouble, dear," Mrs. McCarthy responded. "Keira said you girls have been getting very close. And as far as I'm concerned that makes you part of the family." You blushed.

"You sure we can't pay?" Mom asked Mrs. McCarthy.

"Not for this. I do this every year for my daughters and their friends. It's a fun challenge for me. But if you like my work, feel free to purchase something else down the road." She finished one last tuck on Tim's dress. "There we go. Walk around see how it feels."

"It feels like I have cooties," Tim grumbled, but after his Mom coughed threateningly, he followed that with: "Thanks, Mrs. McCarthy." He looked back at Aunt Catherine. "I don't have to curtsey or anything lame like that, do I?"

--------------------------------------

Keira introduced her Mom to everyone, including Christina, who still looked like she'd rather be anywhere else. Tim sulked off in a corner, while your mom and Aunt Catherine greeted each other.

Finally, Hannah asked the question that was on both your minds. "Aunt Catherine, why is Tim here? And why is he wearing that?"

Aunt Catherine smiled. "Well, I hear from both your mother and the school about the way Tim has been treated the girls at school."

"He pulled my pigtails," you said.

"He threw mud at my dress," Keira added.

"He pulled my seat out from behind me," Hannah also shared.

This led to an embarrassed nod from Aunt Catherine. "And those are just a few examples. So I decided if he was going be so hostile to girls, he could spend some time as one." You wanted to ask why not change him with magic, but you couldn't with Keira there. "Faye is an old friend of mine and she offered to make Tim a dress for Halloween."

"I wanted to be Darth Vader," Tim called deviantly from the corner, which made you smile. If only he knew what the witch council was calling you.

"Be nice to the girls this week and maybe you still can be," Aunt Catherine responded. "Otherwise you're going to be Alice." Tim groaned loudly at that news.

You giggled, but stopped when you felt a hand on your shoulder. Mrs. McCarthy was smiling down at you. "Well, Lucy. You ready to become Cinderella?"

You nodded eagerly. "Super ready. I can't wait."

Mrs. McCarthy handed you a garment bag and pointed you to the back. "There's a changing room back there."

Keira grabbed your hand. "Come on, Lucy. I'll help you out." She led you to the dressing room.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Tim is really not happy

choices: You talk to Tim before you go
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"So what's Christina's deal anyway?" Keira asked as she led you to the changing room.

You sighed. "She's...a total tomboy. And she's worried I'm trying to get her to not be, cause I used to be a tomboy too."

Keira giggled. "Yeah, I remember when you used to say ballet was boring."

You couldn't help but giggle about that as well. "Okay, I was super wrong about that." You hung the garment bag up and zipped it open, revealing the beautiful Cinderella dress inside. "Oh wow. Keira, it is absolutely beautiful." Indeed it was, a sparkly blue gown with poofy sleeves and froofy petticoats. Most princess costumes you saw in the stores looked cheap. This didn't. You couldn't wait to put it on.

You took off your blouse and skirt and Keira helped you into the dress. It fit like a dream and it felt super comfy. "I feel like a princess," you marveled.

"You look like one. Come on, let's show the others."

You lifted your gown as you walked and followed Keira back out to the others. You were met with mostly smiles and complements, though Tim was still scowling and Christina just rolled her eyes again. Hannah started taking pictures, which you were happy to indulge.

Aunt Catherine leaned over to Mom. "She looks like a real Princess. Almost like she was destined for it." She winked.

"She could very well be. Of course, that could still be Tim too."

Aunt Catherine sighed, "I don't see Tim going for that." Tim was still brooding in the corner in his Alice dress.

Hannah was all over you admiring your dress. "This dress is beautiful. I NEED one in my life."

"Which princess would you like to be?" Mrs. McCarthy asked.

Hannah smiled. "I want to be my own princess."

"Oooooo me too," you agreed. "I want more princess dresses."

"Well, maybe after Halloween we can make you girls something like that," Mrs. McCarthy said. You and Hannah hugged excitedly. Mom sighed. She had a feeling you two were going to have her spend a lot of money here.

Mrs. McCarthy spend a few minutes making sure everything fit you right, but the dress seemed perfect. As much fun as you were all having, eventually, Mom needed to get Christina to Samantha's for her lesson. You reluctantly changed back out of your gown, which you thanked Mrs. McCarthy for a million times, but you were looking forward to Halloween more than ever.

"We got to hang out outside of school more," Keira told you.

"Definitely. You're really nice, Keira. Thanks for all this. I'm so glad you all are my friends." The two of you hugged, feeling closer than ever.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: You and Keira chat

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
As you passed Tim, you carefully whispered "Why didn't aunt Catherine..."

"Let her try and see what happens." Glaring, Tim whispered back. "What they did to you and Christina and Rick and Steve is criminal."

This shocked you. "Criminal...?" Confused, you asked.

Aunt Catherine sighed then pulled you out of ear shot of the others with mom following before casting a spell that would keep others from hearing them. "Tim believes that witches have no right to transform boys against their will." Whispering, Catherine explained. "He believes it is a violation of their bodies and birthright as boys so he lashes out at all he thinks are witches."

"It is actually far more complicated than he could imagine." Quietly, mom added. "That is why we are keeping him male so 'she' doesn't go on some big hearted and empty headed crusade that would bring her more trouble than she can handle."

"So you are humiliating him instead..." Wincing, you said.

"I promise I won't take it too far." Patiently, Catherine said. "Tim is still very young but he needs to learn that there are better ways of doing things than lashing out."

With that said, mom dropped the privacy spell and turned to Mrs McCarthy. "Lucy was afraid that we might humiliate Tim too much." Smiling, she said. "We explained it to her."

Mrs McCarthy smiled. "Wearing a dress to a costume party will be embarrassing but it will not be the end of his reputation." Bemused, she said. "Other boys are wearing girls costumes to the costume party as well so he won't be the only 'girlish boy' going."

You giggled at that, feeling a little better about the situation. Still, inside, you were worried. "Was changing a boy without asking him first really a crime?"

Mom sensed your question and gave a bemused smile before whispering, "We will discuss it later, Lucy."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: You talk to Tim before you go

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
A half hour later, you, Mom, Christina, and Hannah arrived at Samantha's house. Mom parked the car down the street and Christina immediately darted toward the door. Mom had to rush to keep pace. You and Hannah hung back a bit. You were still thinking about what Tim had said and Hannah wanted to ask you something.

"You okay, sis?" Hannah asked, noticing that you were deep in thought.

"Oh, yeah, sure." You didn't sound super enthusiastic, but Hannah assumed that was cause of seeing Samantha, so she asked her question anyway.

"So can you help me with something later? Since I'm helping you with this?" She smiled when she saw your curiosity piqued.

"Anything for you. What are we doing?"

Hannah looked to make sure Mom was out of earshot. "I'm going to turn Mike Cutie into a girl. Don't tell Mom."

You looked up in surprise. After what Tim had said, the idea of turning another boy into a girl filled you with uncertainty. You had more questions for Hannah, but the two of you had caught up to Mom and Christina at Samantha's doorstep. You'd have to talk to her later. Now, it was Christina's turn to ring the doorbell.

The door opened a minute later, revealing Samantha wearing an old-fashioned gothic gown. "Wonderful. You're all here." She looked down at Christina and smiled. "Hello, Christina."

Christina smiled back. "Hello, Witchmother." She didn't hesitate to call Samantha by that title in front of your family today. She was growing more comfortable. Though, Mom frowned.

"Come on in, all of you," Samantha said as she waved you all in. You stepped into her home and your eyes widened with wonder. If you thought her store was a witch's playground, that made this house a witch's amusement park. There were cool looking magic items everywhere and a library filled to the brim with magic books. The whole house seemed to have a dark and gothic theme to it, but that somehow made the place more appealing to you.

"This place is really cool-looking, Aunt Samantha," Hannah said in wonder.

"Yeah, I bet it's really fun to explore," you agreed.

"Just don't touch anything," Mom warned. "You don't know what effects some of these items might have."

Samantha waved off Mom's concern. "Oh, don't worry. I don't keep the dangerous stuff lying around. The worst anything out could do is turn a curious boy into an eager girl, but I don't think that will be a problem will it." She winked at you and chuckled. This did cause you and Hannah to laugh, though Mom and Christina weren't so amused.

"Can we start the lesson now?" Christina asked.

"Of course, sweetie," Samantha said, patting Christina's head. She looked at you and Hannah. "Feel free to join us or make yourselves at home." You thought for a second. You were curious to see what Christina was going to be learning, but you also kind of wanted to explore the house. You could also use this chance to talk to Mom about your concerns about what Tim said or you could look through some of these magic books.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Reaching Samantha's house.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You decided to whisper your burning question to mom as Samantha lectured Christina about the basics of magic. "Is changing a boy against his will a crime, mommy?" Wincing, you asked.

"Mom grinned. "Well, yes and no." Cryptically, she replied. "Each case is different but basically, temporary changes are tolerated so long as our secret little world is safe."

"It is the intentional, permanent transformations that are illegal." Jumping in, Samantha said. "In the case of Tim Tower's friends, Steve and Rick, their less known actions have actually earned them the gift of womanhood and possibly magic."

"What do you mean?" Curious, you demanded.

Samantha smiled. "My first lesson is a lecture." Patiently, she said. "Listen in and I may answer a few of your questions."

Mom sighed, frustrated while you turned your attention to her. "I'm listening." Calmly, you said. "But, if you don't mind, I'll ask mom later too."

Mom smiled at that, though you did not see it. Samantha smiled back and, to Christina, it was clear there was a rivalry between the two. "This must be why all the rules." Looking between the two women, she thought. "They had to have been bitter rivals for years."

Christina turned to you and saw that you seemed to be clueless to it all. She guessed that was why you were so hesitant, you likely only knew mom's side of the story. She made the decision to talk to you again later when you could be alone.

"Steve and Rick, although they act like jerks around school, have saved a number of girls both normal and witch born from serious harm." Serious, Samantha began. "After several incidents, it became clear to witch investigators that the two boys were diamonds in the rough."

"Diamonds in the what...?" Confused, you asked.

"Good boys who put on 'bad boy' personas to blend in with the crowd." Translating, mom said.

"Rick and Steve had thwarted more than a few true bullies who had targeted the weak or, in this case, young witches who are not aloud to use magic." Serious, Samantha said. "They had also stopped a fair share of burglars who had broken into their neighbors homes." She paused, smiling, "To many witches, having to owe a boy a debt of honor can be more embarrassing than losing a fight to one. Something had to be done to reward the two for always running in like knights in shining armor."

"The same could be said for you two." Pointing at you and Christina, mom said.

Both you and Christina blushed at that and turned to each other. It made sense, in a way and it caused you both to give a rueful smile. "So, we would have both been girls and witches one way or another anyway." Smiling, you said.

Samantha nodded. "Exactly." Smiling, she said. "You two had saved so many young witches that they considered it a blessing in disguise when Harry, now Christina was sold the corrupted magic glasses."

"Which was why they did nothing to end the corrupted test." Sighing, mom said.

"I think it worked out for the best." Smiling, you said.

"Yeah..." Reluctantly, Christina said. "Same here."

You then winced. "Does that make Tim a criminal?"

"Tim is hurt and confused." Patiently, Samantha said. "He is a jerk around young witches but his actions are no worse than say you changing a boy's socks."

That caused you to blush. "Does Tim have a nickname too?"

Mom smiled. "Trouble."

You and Christina giggled at that before you said, "Why don't you both give the lecture? It seems to me that you work better as a team."

Mom and Samantha blushed slightly, though they both tried to hide it.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Christina's lesson

choices: Demand to know why they fight so much
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Samantha and Mom pretended that you hadn't just said what you said and Samantha tried to bring the subject back to where it had been, hoping you'd follow along. "So as I was saying, while some males may disagree, most witches see boys turning into girls as a wonderful thing, a blessing."

Hannah was excited to hear all this and you found it reassuring as well, but you did have some questions. "Then, why does the witch council not allow witches to do that whenever?" you asked. "You got in trouble after Christina and I were turned and you would have gotten in more trouble if the witch council could have proven you were behind the glitter bombs."

Samantha chuckled. No had talked to her directly about the glitter bombs, even though everyone knew she was one of the forces behind them. "You don't hold back, Lucy." She thought how to phrase her answer, not wanting to freely admit to the glitter bombs in front of Mom. "The witch council likes to make sure that when boys are turned to girls, it won't cause chaos or expose us witches."

"You remember our neighbor's son?" Mom added. "It could have been really bad if I hadn't been able to turn him back and erase all their memories. We don't want the witch trials starting up again."

"But you don't agree?" you asked Samantha.

Samantha nodded. "Not exactly. I do agree that we have to be smart about using our magic. I don't agree that the witch council always knows best. I've changed many boys into girls over the years and I've never risked exposing us."

"Except with the glitter bombs," Mom pointed out.

Samantha chose her next words carefully. "Well, whoever was responsible for that was trying to cause chaos. She was trying to frame Cassie, after all, if I read your summary of the events right." She smiled at Mom.

"Can you two stop?" Christina begged. "It doesn't help me to learn if you two are fighting all the time."

"I just want to make sure this woman doesn't radicalize you girls," Mom explained.

"And yet you let them be friends with Cassie Bane. I just want to make sure they hear different perspectives," Samantha responded.

"Why do they fight so much anyway?" Hannah asked.

You shrugged. "I've heard like three different stories." Fed up with the fighting, you made a choice to do something.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: They change the subject.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You stood up and marched between mom and Samantha before igniting a flame in both of your hands and cast a spell. Christina watched, curious as mom and Samantha here knocked off balance into a chair behind them. Fearing she would lose all hope of learning anything from Samantha, Christina jumped up and joined you. Only she was surprised by what you said next.

"Mrs Belacourt told me that there is a magical fail safe in every witch household." Firmly, you said. "It turns to fighting witches into three year olds until another witch can change them back." You frowned. "I am not old enough to babysit so stop it!"
