"That's right." Nodding, Christina said. "Besides, Ms Harrison, you promised not to interfere so long as Samantha followed your rules."

"Why do you two fight all the time anyway?" Pouting, you demanded. "You get mad at us when we fight what makes you two different?"

Mom and Samantha looked at each other surprised. Mom wanted to say it was because they were adults and you and Christina were children but she knew that was not going to satisfy either of you. "Sometimes two witches simply cannot settle their differences or work well with each other but must still work with each other."

"You made Samantha drop her feud with Cassie." Defiant, Christina pointed out.

"Cassie has changed." Frowning, mom said.

"How has aunt Samantha not changed, mom?" Curious, you asked.

Now both mom and Samantha looked uncomfortable. Only, after a moment, Samantha grinned. "We are being lectured by Darth and Vader, Natalie." With a chuckle, she said.

Mom chuckled at that. "They are too much like ourselves." Grinning back, mom replied.

"The two of you are just as Natalie and I were as kids." Turning to you, Samantha said. "We were almost inseparable."

"What happened?" Wincing, Christina asked.

"Did it have something to do with that vision I had?" Also Wincing, you asked.

Samantha sighed. "My step mother did not like what Natalie and I had." Sadly, she said. "She did all she could to tear us apart."

"A curse." Wide eyed, you gasped. You then frowned. "Mom, aunt Samantha, by acting like you are, the evil step mother wins!"

"It's not that simple, Lucy." Sighing, mom said. "You don't understand."

You shook your head. "Then explain it until we do." Holding your ground, you demanded. You took Christina's hand, surprising her. "The evil step mother tore you apart but I am not letting her do the same to us!"

Taking a chance, Christina whispered, "The link bracelet..."

After a thought, you said...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Darth and Vader.

choices: Samantha shares her plans for Christina
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You remained silent. You still didn't trust the link bracelet.

Mom began to speak. "Lucy, Elena did curse us and what she did to us was wrong, but we are the people we are today because of it. I've told you about my history with covens when I was younger. I was much like Cassie and Samantha. In fact, while rebelling from my mother, I let Samantha inform my own way of thinking. I had no love for males, especially after my father vanished, and I believed witches were superior to regular humans."

"Which they are," Samantha interjected.

Mom ignored the comment. "Elena's curse and my inability to get along with Samantha for better or worse allowed me to be the person I am today. It allowed me to pursue friendships with regular humans, much like your doing. And when I found out what had happened to my father, it allowed me to repair my relationship with him. And I had a son, who I loved and adored for 13 years before he became my daughter. I don't think I would have given you the freedom or choices I did if Samantha and I were as close as we once were. I would have turned you into a girl the second you were born."

You considered that for a second. "But...friendship is a good thing."

Mom nodded. "Yes, it is, but it's complicated. Sometimes a friendship isn't always healthy for you."

It must be. You felt super confused, which prompted Samantha to respond. "Your mother's right, Lucy. She's become a fine witch. More independent and powerful than she ever would have been if she just stayed with me." She sounded sad as she said this.

"Think about Keira. If I hadn't been curse, I might not have let you be friends with girls like her. Because I would have thought you were too good for her. Samantha believes deeply in the old ways, and I just don't anymore," Mom explained further.

Samantha nodded. "We both like the people we are now, and we don't spend time thinking about what might have been instead. I might be more like your mother, or your mother might be more like me." Neither thought seemed to appeal to her.

"Still, you could break the curse. Be friends again," Christina suggested. You felt very sad for them.

Mom and Samantha looked at each other and sighed. Mom spoke first. "Girls, we broke the curse years ago, though Elena hasn't caught on. We're just different people now. That happens sometimes. Your childhood best friend isn't always your best friend for life."

You felt a twinge of guilt, as you understood exactly what she meant. Christina, as Harry, had been your best friend for years, but if someone asked you now who your best friend was, you'd answer Liz without a second thought. You cared deeply for Christina, but you weren't as close as you had been and you had a strange feeling that divide was only going to grow over time, especially if she continued to learn from Samantha. You were curious about what Samantha had to teach too, but you knew at the end of the day, you were your mother's daughter and you would always take her side. You looked over at Christina and wondered what she was thinking about.

Mom frowned, then said something that surprised you. "The girls are right, though. Us fighting is going to do them no good. I don't approve of the old ways, Samantha, but you aren't breaking any witch laws by practicing them, and Christina seems to want to learn from you. If she understands the risks, I need to be comfortable letting her do so."

Samantha nodded. "That's fair, but you're also right to worry. I did take advantage of Christina during the glitter bomb incident." She realized she had just acknowledged her involvement in that.

"Don't worry. As long as the feud with Cassie is done and there are not more public incidents like that, I won't turn you in," Mom assured Samantha.

Samantha smiled. "Thanks, Natalie. I respect your protectiveness of these girls. I will also do my best to respect that."

Natalie's face turned stern all of sudden. "So no more late night visits to my daughter." Color drained from your face and Samantha's. "Yes, I know all about that."

"You do?" you said in surprise. "Do you know everything? Why didn't you say anything?"

Natalie chuckled. "I don't know everything. But I know when a witch transports herself into my house. I didn't say anything because I wanted to see if you would. You didn't and I'm disappointed about that, but you also didn't take the link bracelet, so I'm proud of you too."

"Sorry. I thought I was protecting Christina."

"Protect yourself first, young lady," Mom scolded.

"I apologize too, Natalie," Samantha said. "In my desire to instruct Christina, I overstepped my bounds."

Mom nodded. "You did, and it will take me some time to forgive for that, but unfortunately late night recruiting attempts are also still legal according to the witch council and you are far from the first who has tried it. But understand my daughters are off-limits. Their grandfather would be very cross if someone took advantage of them."

This surprised Hannah, who rarely heard her grandfather mentioned. You remembered she didn't know about his visit either. Still, referencing him turned Samantha even whiter. "I understand," she said nervously. Mom smiled, satisfied that Samantha wouldn't try something like that again.

"Now, Christina," Mom said. "I think it is high time we all listened to what exactly you want."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: remained silent.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"I know you are trying to help me, Ms Harrison." Serious, Christina said. "But... having to live alone in my house for weeks or moths at a time, I got used to living by my own rules."

"I wanted to take you in, so did Katie Thompson but the council, loyal to the old ways, would not allow it." Sadly, mom said.

"Because I was a normal, I know." Frowning, Christina said. "It's ironic, really that I became a witch after all." She shook her head. "Witchmother was always there for me when I needed help, she became like a second mother to me so I became like the kid she never had."

"You know you could always talk to me about anything, Christina." Softly, mom said.

"Except about Samantha." Serious, Christina countered. "Witchmother had earned my trust over time. I could call her morning, noon, or night and she would come to me." She then smiled. "She might not be perfect but she is not a rogue either. She's like I was... alone."

"I don't want to lose you as a friend." Pouting, you said.

"We might not be best friends anymore, Lucy but that doesn't mean we have to be rivals." Turning to you, Christina said. "Samantha can teach you a lot, I promise."

"My teaching methods are deeply rooted and time tested." Serious, Samantha said. "The best way to reach a student is to work with what the are most interested in."

"Like Christina's magical artifacts." Thoughtful, you said. "What would your method be with me, aunt Samantha?"

Samantha smiled. "Your love for princess themes." Calmly, she said. "Not every princess is a delicate flower though they are all very feminine when they need to be."

You blushed at that then an idea came to you. "How about a balance?"

"What do you mean?" Curious, Christina asked.

"I will agree to let aunt Samantha teach me a little if you agree to let mom teach you a little." Serious, you said. "I will not wear the link bracelet but I will wear an awareness amulet."

"So you will know everything I teach Christina and I will know everything you teach Lucy." Ruefully, mom said. "A balance of trust."

"Only, we have a few demands." Frowning, you said.

"We do?" Curious, Christina asked.

Mom listened, slightly taken back by your sudden boldness while Samantha raised a curious eyebrow.

"First, no lying to us." Serious, you said. "It has only caused us trouble thus far."

Christina nodded on that point. "It has..."

"Anything else?" Curious, mom demanded.

You nodded. "We don't want your rivalry to get in the way of our learning magic." More calmly, you said. "So it will be a neutral party watching over the lessons to ensure everything is fair."

"That would make things less stressful." Eyeing mom, Samantha said. "That and you will see and hear everything from the awareness amulet."

"Who do you suggest?" Worried, Christina asked.

You smiled and replied...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: A balance of trust.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"What about grandma?" you suggested.

Samantha shook her head. "Absolutely not. I don't need the witch council looking over me."

Mom put her hand on your shoulder. "It's a nice idea, sweetie, but I'm not ready to trust Samantha with any of your education. Not after the stunts she's pulled."

"But, Mommy..." you pleaded.

"No buts. I'm still your mother," Mom was firm. You knew not to argue. "I understand you want to learn about artifacts, but I'm not sure there's any aspect of magic you don't want to learn about. You have to have some patience, especially because there are other parts of your magical education that are more pressing. It's my job to raise you. Christina is in a different boat."

"If you say so, Mommy," you responded.

Samantha nodded, adding, "You have a wonderful mother to guide your education, Lucy. Christina's mother loves her, but is clueless when it comes to magic. She needs someone else to guide her, and frankly, you and your sisters keep your mom's hands plenty full."

"One of these children alone would keep my hands full," Mom admitted. "But I love them with all my heart." She swooped you and Hannah into a hug.

"What is best for Christina is not what is best for you," Samantha added. "You both have your own journeys to go on. You must come to terms with that."

"Okay, I get it, I guess," you said, giving in. "I guess I'm just worried about what will happen to Christina if she lets you teach her. She wants to be a boy again." Christina nodded.

Samantha chuckled. "Christina and I have discussed that quite a bit. I won't magic away her wish to be a boy, but she also knows that my influence will likely have her embracing her new identity." That of Samantha's daughter, but she didn't say this part out loud.

"Yeah, we'll just see what happens," Christina said.

Samantha noticed the clock. "I feel like we've made some major breakthroughs today, but our hour is up. I have to go see to the shop."

Christina looked very sad to hear this. "Can't I stay with you, Witchmother?"

Samantha shook her head. "We need the witch council to sign off first, and ideally your human mother would give you permission too."

"Well, what if Mom went with Aunt Samantha and Christina to the shop? That way you could continue the lesson a little longer," Hannah suggested. "Lucy and I can walk home. We aren't far."

Mom turned down that suggestion quick. "You have to cross that big street. Not an option."

"Teleport us, then," Hannah countered.

Mom raised a suspicious eyebrow. "What are you up to, young lady?" You knew exactly what Hannah was up to, but fortunately she lied better than you did.

"Mike and I are supposed to hang out. I told Lucy she could come too. Pi might be there," Hannah said non-chalantly.

"It would be good for Christina to get some time with me without Lucy," Samantha agreed. You felt a little hurt, but knew what she meant. You had made this meeting all about you and Mom and Samantha, not Christina.

Mom nodded. "Very well." Mel was at home too, so she wouldn't be leaving you two unattended. She waved her hand and suddenly you and Hannah were back in the Harrison living room. Mel was indeed flipping through a magazine, but didn't acknowledge you two other than a grunt hello.

Hannah smiled at you. "Time to get to work, Sis."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: your choice.

choices: Mike is surprised to see you and Hannah
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Once Mel had called Mom and confirmed that you and Hannah had her permission to go to Mike Cutie's house, you and Hannah headed for his house, which was only five houses down from yours. Your proximity was one of the things that made Hannah and Mike playmates in the first place about five years ago. Hannah marched forward with confidence and purpose. You weren't so eager.

"I don't know, Hannah. We might get in real trouble for doing this," you said nervously.

"You heard Samantha. Changing a boy to a witch girl is a blessing to a lot of people."

"I also heard her say the witch council doesn't like it when other people do changes like that," you pointed out. "Why do you want to do this anyway? I thought you wanted Mike to stay a boy?"

Hannah sighed and stopped. "That was before he said we couldn't be friends anymore..."

"What?"

"Friday at school, he told me that he couldn't be friends with me because some of the boys at school were making fun of him for being best friends with a girl. He told me not to talk to him anymore." Hannah's eyes were tearing up as she spoke.

"What a jerk," you said. You couldn't believe he would do that to your sister, especially when she was always such a good friend to him. For such a stupid reason too. Who cared if his best friend was a girl? You felt your nervousness vanish as your anger rose.

"So I figure if I make him a girl, then we can be friends again," Hannah explained as she revealed the vial of glitter in her hand. "And no one will care if he likes girly stuff either." You nodded. It seemed to make sense. "Besides, he's been super exposed to magic all his life. Everybody thinks he's going to turn into a witch girl anyway." She looked up at you. "I was hoping you'd come with me, but if you're afraid of getting in trouble I won't make you."

You shook your head. You were all in. "I don't care about getting in trouble. This boy hurt my awesome sister cause he was being a dumb boy. Let's make him a girl so he knows better." You grabbed Hannah's hand and joined her in her determined march to the Cutie house.

Once there, Hannah rang the doorbell and Mike's mom opened the door. "Oh, hello, Hannah. Mike's upstairs in his room playing. I'm guessing you and Lucy want to join him."

Hannah smiled politely. "Thanks, Mrs. Cutie." She led you up the stairs to a door that had Mike's name on it in colored letters.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Follow Hannah and Lucy

choices: Mrs Cutie comes up to see Michelle.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Hannah opened Mike's bedroom door, hoping to catch him by surprise only she was caught completely off guard to find that Mike had been severely beaten up! He had a bad black eye that was swollen, a scratch from his left ear to the corner of his mouth, a bruised jaw, and various cut and bruises all over his arms and legs where his clothing had been ripped. Hannah gasped upon seeing him and shoved the glitter back into her pocket. "Mike!" Shocked, she cried. "What happened to you?!"

"Two kids from school, Karl Dusty and Greg Waters." Sobbing, Mike replied. "They started picking on me last week." He winced as he tried to sit up. "I tried to keep you away so they wouldn't go after you next."

"Oh, Mike..." Wincing, Hannah said. "Does your mom know?"

Mike shook his head. "I sneaked upstairs." Miserably, he replied. "I don't know how to tell her." He then began to cry openly. "I'm sorry... I'm sorry..."

Hannah knotted her jaws in decision. "Mike, you need help and I know just how to give you it."

"You- You do?" Surprised, Mike asked.

Hannah pulled out the vile magic glitter and popped off the cork. The glitter went flying all over Mike and, before, he could respond, he had transformed into a girl with his, or rather, her injuries completely healed. She looked at herself, stunned then gasped as a small flame appeared in her left hand. "Welcome to the witching world, 'Michelle'." Smiling, you said.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: A bully situation.

choices: Mom has to finish with Samantha and Christina first
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Hmmmm, I kind of thought we'd have to fight him a bit more," you commented as Mike Cutie looked over her new body.

"Her," Hannah corrected with a smile.

Mike, on the other hand, was still trying to wrap her head around what had happened. "What...what did you do, Hannah?"

"Made you into a girl," Hannah said with a grin. "And a witch, I guess, but that was a surprise."

"But...I...," Mike stammered, confused and unsure.

"Why'd those guys beat you up?" Hannah asked.

"They...um...said I was a sissy cause I liked hanging out with a girl. I thought if I stopped hanging with you I could protect myself, but...but they didn't care. They said I still acted too girly." Tears formed in Mike's eyes as she recounted the story.

"Well, now you don't have to worry about that," Hannah said triumphantly. "You're a girl so no one can bother you for hanging out with one or acting like one."

"Really?" Mike asked hopefully.

"If they do you can fight 'em off with magic like I do," you added. Of course, it wasn't really that simple. "But you'll want to learn how to use magic."

"That sounds okay. This might be pretty cool," Mike said with a smile. Hannah saw this as proof that she had done the right thing, though you understood that part of the glitter's magic was to make the victim's mind accept the change.

"But don't tell anyone Hannah and I made you a girl," you said quickly. "We could get in trouble."

Mike nodded. "Of course. I don't want to get you girls in trouble."

Suddenly, the door opened and Mrs. Cutie stood there in surprise. She was holding a tray of lemonade and cookies, but dropped it all in surprise. You guessed she came to give you all refreshments. "It's...it's happened. Oh my goodness, my child." She swooped Mike into a warm hug. "Is this a good thing?" she asked him.

Mike nodded. "Yeah, Mom. I'm really glad I'm not a stupid boy anymore. Plus, I can do magic." She showed her mom the flame she could make. You chuckled. Mike's mind was really adjusting quickly if she was already decrying stupid boys.

In fact even Mom noticed that. "Wow, I heard Lucy took over a week to enjoy being a girl." She turned to you and Hannah. "Is...is this normal?"

"Oh, totally," Hannah answered quickly.

"Yeah, I was the weird one," you added.

"I think...we'll call you Mikayla. Maybe Kay for short. How's that sound?" Mom asked her new daughter, thankfully not questioning the two of you further.

"Ooooo...that's pretty." The newly named Mikayla approved.

"I've got to call Mrs. Harrison," Mrs. Cutie stated standing up. "She'll be able to help us know what to expect. I'm so happy for you sweetie." She ran out of the room to get the phone.

"She's calling Mom?" you and Hannah said in unison as you looked at each other nervously. You hadn't been expecting this. Hopefully, she wouldn't come over. And if she did, hopefully, she wouldn't catch on to what you two did.

"Thanks, Hannah," Mikayla said again as she pulled her friend into a hug. "You really are my best friend." Hannah smiled as she felt her friend hug her and affirm her importance. Her worries about Mom disappeared. Even if she got in trouble, this was worth it. She had her best friend back.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Mrs Cutie comes up to see Michelle.

choices: Elvira is lenient with you and Hannah.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom arrived almost immediately and spoke to Mrs Cutie for several minutes before walking up to you, Hannah, and Mikayla. "I am so happy for you, Kay." With a patient smile, mom said. "I have made arrangements for you to be trained at Witchbloom all girls boarding school where your mother and father work."

Kay paused, confused. "Can't I be trained here?" Curious, she asked.

Mom shook her head. "I'm afraid not, dear." Patiently, mom said. "You see, while your mother and father are aware of magic and are immune to it, they know nothing about it and I already have more than enough students."

She did not mention that she felt she had a little more than she could handle with having to help train Cassie as well as Christina. Although she would never admit it, she was pleased to see Samantha take on some of the work load by training Christina. Although the two did not see eye to eye, they both begrudgingly agreed that they were fine teachers of magic.

"Should I pack, then?" Worried, Kay asked.

"Your mother will help you with that, my dear." Smiling, mom said. "Run along now. I need to speak with my children."

Kay nodded then ran off to her mother who took her out of the room. Once they were gone, mom turned to you and Hannah with a stern look on her face. "There is a reason we have laws behind the use of magic, girls." Annoyed, she scolded. "Mike Cutie was slowly changing inside and would have become a girl and a witch within a month. No one of the normal world would have blinked an eye to it." She shook her head. "Only you had to take matters into your own hands rather than allow Ms Cutie and I to investigate."

"But Mike told me..." Hannah started.

"People do not change so radically overnight, Hannah!" Angry, mom snapped. "Mike's actions raised red flags all over the board! Did you not even think for a second that he might have said those things to try to protect you?!"

"He mentioned that..." Hurt, Hannah said.

"Kay now has to go to Witchbloom at a very young age because of your actions." Fuming, mom said. "Did you seriously think I would not detect the use of magical glitter?" She sighed. "You will have to be the one to explain this to your grandmother."

Hannah was now crying as mom then turned to you. "Because you helped her, you will be explaining this as well, young lady."

Although you were hurt, you slowly nodded. "Okay, mommy..."

The following day, at school, Karl Dusty was a ten year old boy with sand blond hair and green eyes walked into the lunch room with his friend, Greg who was also ten but had black hair and brown eyes. The two were known as vicious bullies around school but yet no one has come forward with enough proof for the school to take action.

"It looks like another victory for us, Greg." Gloating, Karl said. "I haven't seen that Cutie creep all day long."

Greg chuckled. "He must be sick." Grinning, he said. "The poor soul."

The two laughed at their sick joke but fell silent as they saw Tim Towers enter the cafeteria with his fists clenched. Everyone in the room could tell he was furious as he marched right up to the two bullies. "How many times do I have to tell you upperclassmen jerks!" In a rage, he shouted. "No one picks on my class but me!"

With that, he landed a heavy punch into Karl's gut that forced him to keel over before Tim grabbed him by the belt and literally threw him over a table! Greg took a swing at Tim only to hurt his hand against his jaw. He took a step back, shaking his hand in pain. "Is that all you got, jerk?" Unimpressed, Tim demanded.

"You- You're just a kid!" Startled, Greg shouted.

Tim took a step forward and Greg jumped back, causing him to grin. "I pick on girls, sure." Darkly, he said. "Only its nothing serious. When I see bullies like you picking on the weak, that's when I get serious!"

"You'll pay for this, Towers!" Limping away, Karl shouted. "We'll make you sorry!"

Tim lifted his foot slightly but stopped as a strong female voice commanded, "That's enough!"

Everyone turned to see principal Jessica Wells step up to Tim. "My office, now." Sternly, she said. She then turned to Karl and Greg. "You two go see the nurse then come to my office. Do not make me come looking for you!"

Karl and Greg reluctantly walked out of the cafeteria, giving Tim death glares but ran as he held up his fists. Jessica took a hold of Tim's hand and he immediately felt magic. "It is one thing to stand up for your classmates." Whispering, she said. "It is quite another to use boyish magic in a fight."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Here comes trouble.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Elvira had offered to take you and Hannah to school today, so she could talk to you too about the incident. It was a weird experience, as she had a driver and rode in a small limo. You and Hannah had never ridden in something like that before, and, under normal circumstances you both would have been super excited, but today you were too nervous about what your grandmother was going to do to you and Hannah was upset that Mikayla was going to Witchbloom.

After a long ride of silence, Elvira finally spoke as the limo pulled up in front of the curb. "You two look worried, but not ashamed of what you did."

You crossed your arms and spoke deviantly. "He hurt Hannah's feelings. He was being a stupid boy. Now, she isn't one anymore. I'd do it again."

"Me too." Hannah wanted to make it clear she stood with you."

Elvira nodded. "Peer pressure can be a powerful motivator. I'm very sorry he rejected your friendship."

"Mom thinks he was trying to protect me from bullies," Hannah said.

Elvira shook her head. "That I don't believe. He was scared, and he was protecting himself, and he hurt you in the process. It's not uncommon for kids to do. What he did was hurtful and wrong. People don't protect people by driving them away. Remember that." You both nodded. This wasn't the way you had been expecting things to go, so you were caught off-guard. "Your mom is nervous because something similar happened to her as a child. She DID get in trouble with the witch council. You two will not."

"We won't?" You thought this sounded too good to be true.

"Your mom was there to figure out what really happened. The witch council was not. They think this was Mikayla's magic waking up," Elvira explained. You sighed with relief. The last thing you needed was the witch council on you again.

"What about Mikayla? Does she really need to go to Witchbloom," Hannah asked.

Elvira shook her head. "Witchbloom is no place for an 8-year-old girl. Your mom's plate is full, but I got Aunt Catherine to agree to tutor Mikayla for now. However, Hannah, you must be responsible for this situation. You turned Mike into Mikayla so you must protect her. Keep her from using magic in school and be the friend she needs. It couldn't be more important."

"Of course," Hannah said confused. "But why is it so important?"

"A newly transformed witch girl usually forms a tight lifetime bond with whoever they feel is there for them during their adjustment period. Lucy connected with Liz. Christina connected with Samantha. You must make sure you are that person for Mikayla. You don't want her to fall under the sway of someone who will use her for her power, understand?"

Hannah accepted the task. "I'll do whatever I can for her."

"Good, but there is one other thing I need you to do to make up for you recklessness," Elvira said sternly. Hannah got worried. "Tim is spiraling. Keep an eye on him for me." Hannah groaned, but accepted this job as well.

"What about me? Am I going to get punished?" you asked.

"This isn't about punishment. This is about being responsible for your actions," Elvira explained. "There are two new students in your class today. I need you to help them get adjusted to being first-graders."

You looked confused. "Well, I know Christina's one, but who is the other?"

"I'm afraid you're not going to like this part," Elvira said with a sigh. "The student is a boy. His teacher, who had been homeschooling him, felt after seeing him without other kids his age, he needed to spend more time in a social environment. He'll need a friend to guide him."

Your eyes went wide as you realize who she was talking about. "No. NO! You can't mean...not him...anyone, but him..." As if on cue, there was a knock on the limo door. Elvira opened it and standing there, dressed way too preppy for your school, was your mortal enemy, Sean Knightley.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Elvira is lenient with you and Hannah.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
After Hannah had run off to find Tim, Elvira turned to you and Sean. "I got an earful from my husband for not keeping him in the loop regarding you, Lucy." Bemused, she said. "He was hoping to train 'John' as he did Sean."

"Being a girl is so much better." Smiling, you said.

"That is a matter of opinion." Grumbling, Sean countered.

Elvira smiled. "This is exactly why I am pairing you two with each other." Calmly, she said.

"Because we can't get along?" Pouting, you asked.

"You may not believe this but a lot of girls are beginning to look up to you, Lucy." Surprising you, Elvira explained. "Just as a lot of boys are beginning to look up to you, Sean."

"What does that have to do with us?" Frowning, Sean demanded.

"You two need to learn to work together so that other witch boys and girls will hopefully follow your example." Turning stern, Elvira said. "With a little luck, all of this nonsense at school and in town will become more controllable."

"Um... Elvira, why did you say it was all peer pressure that turned Mike against Hannah?" Wincing, you asked. "I heard him, or rather her, say..."

"Do you really want Hannah to live with that kind of guilt, Lucy?" Interrupting you, Elvira asked. "Mikayla was going to change with or without anyone's help. That alone was tearing Hannah apart as close as they were." She sighed before ruffling your hair, smiling. "It is better that she believes Mike gave in to peer pressure rather than trying to be a little knight in shining armor."

"Do I really have to spend all day with her?" Pouting, Sean asked.

You childishly stuck your tongue out at him, causing Elvira to chuckle. "You'll both have to deal with it as you will share the same classes." Calmly, she said. "That is my final judgement as you both need to learn responsibility."

You and Sean both looked as if you were going to be sick as you slowly walked to your first class together. Elvira had a bemused look on her face as she watched you. "To think 'John' and Megan Thompson started out this way."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Elvira instructs you and Sean

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Hannah was not new to finding people by sensing their power. It was how she was able to keep taps on you when you were a teenage boy and later a little girl. She found Tim sitting outside of the principal's office with a scowl on his face. "What did you do this time?" Sighing, she asked.

"None of your business." Sour, Tim snapped.

"He took on the school's two most notorious bullies." Stepping up, Catherine said. "Though I am proud that he stood up for his classmates, I am disappointed that he so blatantly used boyish magic in public." She shook her head. "If it were not for a forgetfulness spell, everyone in school would have known him as a child powerhouse by now."

"But that is what I am!" Frustrated, Tim argued.

"We discussed this last night, young man." Firmly, mom said. "We need to appear just like everyone else to protect our secret world."

"Um.. Elvira asked me to keep an eye on him." Wincing, Hannah said.

"I was told." Smiling Catherine replied. "Thank you for agreeing to this. You did such good work with your sister, Lucy that I am hoping you can help Tim as well."

"I'll try." Managing a smile, Hannah said.

Catherine nodded. "I'm off then." Calmly, she said. "Good luck."

After she was gone, Tim turned to Hannah with a frown. "Are you going to change me into a girl with your glitter too?" Angry, he demanded. "Try it and I'll turn you into a boy."

"Why do you not like girls?" Folding her arms, Hannah countered. "They are so much better."

"Are they?" Standing up, Tim asked. "As I see it, you witches change those you fear or do not agree with instead of learning who they really are or what they are really like. They couldn't change grandpa so they hit him with a fear curse." He paused. "Now, you tell me, cousin... how do I have this all wrong?!"

"You aren't much better with the use of your own magic, Tim." Softly, Hannah replied.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Hannah finds Tim.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Hannah, hi!" Hannah and Tim turned to see a girl approach them. Tim looked at the girl in confusion, recognizing her somewhat, but not sure from where. Hannah smiled at the girl, as she did recognize her, despite the fact that this girl was wearing boy's clothes the last time they saw each other.

"Hey, Mikayla. You look great. I love your dress," Hannah complimented. Mikayla was wearing a yellow floral print dress with a jean jacket and a glittery headband in her head. You wouldn't know she had been a boy yesterday.

"Thanks." Mikayla looked herself over. "Your mom turned some of my old clothes into girl clothes. I picked this out for my first day as Mikayla."

Tim scrunched up as his face as he studied this new girl. Suddenly, he had it. "Mike? What did they do to you? I guess you were basically a girl already, but this is..." Tim stopped talking as Hannah gave his head a small whack. "Hey, what was that for?"

"Watch yourself, Tim, or I'll tell your Mom to put you in that Alice dress for Halloween," Hannah threatened. Tim went white as a sheet and shut up immediately. Hannah turned back to Mikayla. "Let's talk over there." She pointed to a couple seats on the opposite side of the room for where Tim was. The two moved over there.

"Thanks. I don't want to deal with the Toad this morning. You know he's the only person so far who remembers I was a boy. Everyone else thinks I've always been a girl." Mikayla seemed amazed. She was still getting used to this change.

"Yeah, that's witch magic, I think," Hannah wasn't sure on the specifics. "Tim remembers cause he has witch blood...I think."

A guilty look came across Mikayla's face. "Listen, Hannah. I wanted to saw I was sorry. I shouldn't have told you we couldn't be friends anymore."

Hannah nodded. "Why did you say that? It really hurt my feelings." She had heard different things from different people. She wanted Mikayla's story.

"I was scared. Scared that the boys weren't going to leave me alone if I kept being your friend." Mikayla sighed. "I get scared a lot you know. That's why I like being your friend because you don't seem like you get scared at all. Plus, you play awesome games with me."

"I do get scared. A lot. I just remember my Mom and my sisters and then I feel braver," Hannah said.

Mikayla nodded. "I should have talked to you. But those boys said that if a boy gets protected by a girl, he''s weak. I didn't want to be weak."

"Those boys are stupid," Hannah said.

"I know that now," Mikayla said. "And I understand why you turned me into a girl." She finally smiled. "Besides, I feel a lot braver when I'm with you and now I don't have to worry about not being your friend. I'm just sorry it took being turned into a girl to realize that."

"Me too," Hannah agreed. "But now we can play princesses together."

"Hannah, we played princesses when I was a boy," said Mikayla with a giggle.

"Oh," Hannah nodded. "Well, now we can...talk about how boys are the worst." She was realizing that not much was going to change between them, even with Mikayla being a girl.

"Sounds good," Mikayla agreed.

Tim groaned. "Just so you know, I can hear you both over here, and I hate it. You both are so whiny."

Hannah rolled his eyes and turned back to Mikayla. "By the way, my grandma wants me to spend time with him, so...get out while you still can." It was going to be a fun day in third grade.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: continue.

choices: You introduce Christina to Sean reluctantly
Hannah is trapped in her own nightmare with Tim
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"This is called a locker. You put your stuff in here."

"I do know what a locker is, thanks." Sean didn't sound thankful.

You sighed. Fifteen minutes of this and already it was unbearable. All you and Sean did was bicker and try to one-up the other. Why did your grandparents have to put you two together. "You think other witches really see us as role models?" you asked, trying to change the subject and be cordial.

Sean scoffed. "Sparkle boots, tell me you didn't believe that. We're the two youngest witches in the country, possibly the world. No one's looking up to us."

"We're the two youngest witches with powers," you corrected. "Maybe there are witches you haven't awoken yet who know about us."

Sean wasn't buying it. "Yeah, right. They aren't looking up to us."

"Then why tell us that witches were looking up to us?" you asked.

"Because your grandparents want us to get along for some stupid reason. They're trying to trick us into it," he said.

Now you scoffed. "Yeah, right. You and I can't get along. That isn't happening."

"Because you're too thick-headed to see that I'm better than you," Sean said with a smirk. He suddenly came to a embarrassing realization. "How exactly do I open this locker?"

You showed him the latch that opened the locker. "Oh, yeah...you're so much better than me."

"I've never used a locker before, okay?" Sean said, defensively as he put his backpack in his locker. "Are...you allowed to bring toys in the classroom?"

"Yeah," you told him. "Wait, you have toys? You don't seem like a kid who likes toys?"

"Dinosaurs are cool, okay?" Sean said as he pulled out a toy tyrannosaurus.

You rolled your eyes. "I found dinosaurs boring even when I was a boy."

"There's nothing boring about dinosaurs. You'd know that if you could stop thinking about pink and sparkles for five minutes."

"That's not all I think about!" you countered, but you decided maybe today wasn't the best day to show the other girls your new sparkly pencil set.

You sighed in relief as Christina approached the two of you. She would be a welcome break and hopefully would allow you to ignore Pinbrat. However, Christina's look of confusion made you realize that Christina hadn't met Sean since the arcade. She didn't know the whole story since she was wrapped up in Samantha stuff. You were going to have to reintroduced them and she was going to have questions. In fact, all of your friends were going to be wondering who this rude little boy you had to show around was. This was a nightmare.

It was going to be a fun day in first grade.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Lucy shows Sean around

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"I remember you." Stepping up, Christina said. "You're that guy from the arcade."

"This is Pinbrat, I mean Sean Knightley." Frowning, you said. "Grandpa has been training him and now I have to show him around."

You gave a brief explanation of what had happened with Sean interjecting here and there to your annoyance. When you had finished, Christina shook her head. "I don't know who to feel more sorry for." Frowning, she said. "Anyway, I have my own problems so I wish you two luck."

With that, she walked away leaving you fuming. In your mind, she was supposed to take your side but instead, she took no sides and left you alone to deal with Pinbrat. Tears formed in your eyes, though you tried to stop them. "We used to be like brothers." Whispering, you muttered.

"What happened?" Hearing you, Sean asked. He did not sound too worried, just curious.

You shrugged, sighing. "We changed."

"Your grandfather told me that when you fall off the path, its sometimes better just to pick another one." Serious, Sean said. "Just forget about her and move on."

You whipped around, anger on your face. "And you call yourself better?" Almost shouting, you demanded. "I do not give up on friends easily! If you can't see that, you will never have friends!"

Before Sean could respond, you ran off in tears. After you had ran to your next class, he shook his head, frustrated. "Stupid girl... "
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: You introduce Christina to Sean reluctantly

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You walked into your first grade class annoyed, with Sean trailing behind you. Christina was already there drawing in one end of the room with Pi. You didn't realize Christina knew Pi. Or did she? You remembered someone saying Samantha had been interested in Pi once. Maybe she still was. Whatever. It wasn't your problem. Elvira may have asked you to help Christina get adjusted, but it didn't seem like she wanted your help. You had to deal with the problem at hand. Who was still following you.

"Do you have to follow me like this?" you asked Sean annoyed.

Sean looked confused. "Your grandparents told me to stay with you today. I don't like it, but I'm just doing what they said."

You groaned. "You don't have to listen to them, you know."

Sean rolled his eyes. "That's why I'm a better witch than you."

Your furious response was interrupted when Liz approached. "Hey, Lucy. You okay?" she asked noticing your anger. She then took notice of Sean. "Hey, weren't you the boy from ballet?"

"Hi, I'm Sean Knightley." Sean put out his hand politely to Liz. Liz shook it. "You're Liz Belacourt, right? I've heard about your family. I love reading about witch history."

Liz blushed. "Thanks. I'm not really good at reading myself yet, but my Mom loves talking about witch history. You should meet her."

You weren't sure what you expecting when Sean met your friends. Politeness was not even something you considered. For whatever reason, it annoyed you more. "Don't be nice to my friends, please. I want them to hate you as much as I do." Sean smirked at you.

Liz looked confused. "Why is he here?"

"He's my grandfather's student. Grandpa wanted to send him to school, so I have to guide him around," you said with a sigh.

"I missed some stuff after I went home, didn't I? I knew I should have stayed another night at your house," Liz said.

"I really wish you had. I have a lot to tell you."

Before you could start your story, Ellen, Keira, and most of your other friends approached, which meant the witch talk had to stop. They, of course, were wondering who the boy with you was and you began reluctantly introducing Sean to them all as a new student you had been asked to show around. To your horror, Sean continued to be super polite to them all. This was going to be a long day.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: continue.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Later that day, Christina met up with Pi Cutie talking to his cousin, Mikayla at an isolated table. "Hey, Pi." Sitting down, she said. "How are you coping with your cousin being a girl?"

Pi shrugged. "It'll be my turn soon enough." Nonchalantly, he replied. "You see both our moms had a fascination with magic since they were our age. They told us that they had discovered magic was real when they were kids and had been studying it since."

"That must be how they had absorbed so much magic." Thoughtful, Christina said.

Mikayla nodded. "From what mom tells me, Miss Forester was very helpful with their studies." Smiling, she said. "She was fascinated with them because magic can't change them, at least not for long."

"You mean they are immune?" Curious, Christina asked.

"You make it sound like an illness." Wrinkling his nose, Pi said. "Mom told me that magic can't effect everyone so witches have to be careful who they let enter their little circle."

"That makes sense, I guess." Shrugging, Christina said. "Samantha told me that she's teaching you too, Pi."

"I like magical things." His eyes dancing, Pi said. "She told me that she can only show me so much because I'm a boy."

"Hannah can change that." Giggling, Mikayla said.

Pi shook his head. "No, I want it to happen on its own." Firmly, he said. "Samantha said that is the best way for it to happen and I trust her."

"Lucy doesn't trust her." Pouting, Christina muttered.

"Samantha told me about that." Wincing, Pi said. "She told me that Lucy is scared and something about her being too much like her mom."

"Yeah, that makes sense." Sighing, Christiana said. "Ms H has too many rules." Both Mikayla and Pi giggled, confusing her. "What?"

"Look behind you." Grinning, Pi said.

Christina turned to find...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Meanwhile, Christina and Pi

choices: With you and Sean at lunch.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Christina turned around but saw no one directly behind her then turned back to see Pi holding what looked like a wand. "Got you..." Grinning, she said.

"What did you..." Startled, Christina began. Only she grinned upon hearing the two giggle again. "Very funny, you two."

"You looked down so we decided a little joke will cheer you up." Smiling, Mikayla said.

"It's just a stick, I can't work magic yet." Also grinning, Pi added.

Christina smiled. "Thanks, guys." Kindly, she said. "I did need that."

"Who's the boy with Lucy anyway?" Curious, Pi asked. "A boyfriend?"

Christina laughed. "No... they can't stand each other from what I heard." Amused, she replied. "Elvira wants them to learn to work together. Something about boys and girls starting looking up to them."

"That doesn't make much sense." Confused, Mikayla said. "What do you think it means?"

Christina sighed, shrugging her shoulders. "You never know with Elvira." Softly, she said. "Sometimes, I think she talks in riddles."

Mikayla and Pi giggled at that.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: they were joking.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You sat with your friends at lunch: Ellen, Keira, Liz, and the gang. The only girl who was missing was Tammy, who was out sick again. Much to your frustration, Sean had chosen to sit with you all. What was worse was the other girls all seemed to think he was very nice and they were happy to have him join in.

"You guys really like him?" You asked when Sean had gotten up to get another helping of cafeteria food.

Ellen shrugged. "Yeah, he's pretty nice. Why does he get under your skin so much?"

"He acts like he's better than me," you explained.

"Well, I'm sorry you feel that way," Keira said. "But I like him too. He's way nicer than your cousin."

"Maybe. I don't really want to hang out with either of them though. I feel like he's just being nice to all to annoy me," you said. Ellen rolled her eyes. Clearly, your friends were getting a little tired of you obsessing over how much Sean annoyed you. "Sorry, I've probably been talking about him too much."

"It's fine," Ellen said. "I have people who annoy me like that too, even though everyone else loves them." Ellen was referring to her twin younger brothers who made her life a living nightmare much of the time.

"Hopefully, he'll make some friends with some boys in our class, and then he'll leave you alone more," Liz pointed out.

You liked the sound of that, but you knew your grandparents wanted you to get along with Sean. It wasn't going to be easy though.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: With you and Sean at lunch.

choices: Hannah talks to mom about Tim.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
After school, Hannah sat down with Tim at an outside bench while waiting for their moms to pick them up. "Seriously, Tim. There as to be some other reason why you hate witches." Softly, Hannah pressed. "Why won't you tell me?"

"You already know." Sourly, Tim said.

"Then remind me." Frowning, Hannah said.

Tim rolled his eyes. "You remember Anna Reed, right?" Angrily, he whispered.

Hannah nodded. "The little shy girl who died last year."

"She was my friend." Sadly, Tim explained. "Her father was a drunk bastard who kept hitting her for any reason, just to make himself feel better. I wanted to stop him just as I stopped those two bullies in the cafeteria."

"What happened?" Curious, Hannah asked.

Tim's lips trembled slightly. "Mom would not let me near her as it was a 'normal' problem." Furious, Tim replied. "Her father killed her that night..." Tim rubbed at his eyes. "Witches are bullies who only care about keeping their precious powers a secret!"

"That's not true." Pouting, Hannah said.

"Is it?" Crying, Tim demanded. "You imagine your mom keeping you from helping your normal friends or change them so much they aren't your friends anymore! How would you think of magic and witches then?!"

Tim then ran off, vainly trying to hide his tears as Rachael and Stephanie stepped up, curious. "What's wrong with Tim?" Softly, Rachael wondered.

"Maybe he got a taste of his own medicine." Grinning, Stephanie commented.

"No." Sadly, Hannah said. "He just misses his friends."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Tim's broken heart.

choices: You are still grumpy from school.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom sighed after hearing Hannah's report on what she had learned from Tim. "You were supposed to look after Tim not council him." Lightly scolding, mom said. "Your cousin is complicated and needs a professional to help him sort out his issues with the magic world."

"He thinks all witches are bullies." Wincing, Hannah said. "Are we?"

"There is good and bad in everyone, sweetie." Patiently, mom said.

"Why couldn't you or aunt Catherine save Tim's friend?" Worried, Hannah asked.

Mom wanted to tell Hannah that they had, in fact saved the girl, Anna Reed but the drunken man was led to believe he had killed his daughter so to eat at his conscience as a punishment for his deeds. Still, he had not changed despite it so she could not let it slip. The girl had been stripped of her memory of her former life and placed in the care of her uncle with both having memories of her growing up. Unfortunately, in return, she forgot all about her former friends, including Tim.

"All I will say is that we did do something." Serious, mom said. "That is what we told Tim."

"But that's not enough." Whining, Hannah protested.

"Tim will know the whole story when he is older." Firmly, mom scolded. "Now drop it, young lady; I mean it." She sighed. "There are reasons why we keep things from you kids and I am sorry that bothers you. We do it to keep you safe."

"I understand." Albeit reluctantly, Hannah said. "Still, Tim doesn't."

Mom nodded. "I know. We are working on getting him some help."

Later that day...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Hannah talks to mom about Tim.

choices: Some local girls come up and ask about you all
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Later that day, after your magic lesson, Hannah and Mom picked you up in the car with a surprise. The three of you were driving out into the mountains that evening.

"What? How come?" You were just thankful to be free of Sean again, though your magic lesson at Liz's house had helped calm you down quite a bit as well.

"The last Pharaoh's Ring is kept by an old witch family that lives in a gated community in the foot of the mountains. We need to convince them to give to us for protection," Mom explained.

"What's a gated community?" Hannah asked. You felt like you once knew the answer to that, but lots of things you knew when you were thirteen had began to slip away from your mind. You couldn't even remember how to do multiplication, but that kind of math wasn't done in the first grade. You knew what you needed to know.

"A gated community is like a neighborhood that only people who live there are aloud to enter. This witch family is called the Frey family and they protect the moonstone Pharaoh's ring. They are very private, but very big. And they don't like men very much at all. Any boy born is almost immediately turned into a girl," Mom explained.

"If only people who live there are allowed in, how can we see them?" you asked.

"I called the head of the family, Gwendolyn Frey, this afternoon. She agreed to meet us."

"Okay," you said as you considered all this information. "But why bring me and Hannah? I thought you wanted to keep us out of this ring thing."

Mom sighed. "I do, but Gwendolyn Frey has a soft spot for strong-minded young witch girls like you two. I was advised that bringing you two might make the meeting go smoother."

"Cool," you and Hannah said with a smile.

"But all your going to do is be polite and friendly. Don't worry about the ring. I'll take care of that. Just listen to what I tell you. If either of you step out of line, I will not hesitate to teleport you to Hayley. She's expecting you," Mom instructed. Hayley had taken Christina to her lesson with Samantha, but this trip sounded way more interested, so both you and Hannah agreed to be good. Mom nodded at this. "I must admit, I was reluctant to bring you two after the incident with Mikayla Cutie, so don't test my patience."

You and Hannah looked at each other. So you were still in the doghouse with Mom, even if Elvira had been kinder about the whole thing.

Eventually, you arrived at the gate to the Frey community. Mom rang the buzzer out front, and the gate began to open, allowing Mom's car to enter. You and Hannah looked out the window as you drove though this community. It looked like a paradise for girls your age. All sorts of girls running around playing freely, some even practicing magic. Grown-up women were doing yard work or washing their cars. The houses were pretty big too. Everyone seemed so happy and there wasn't a single man or boy in sight. After the day you and Hannah had, these place was a welcome change.

Mom parked the car in front of the largest house you had seen yet. You got out of the car, eager to explore this new place.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: continue.

choices: You both meet a girl your age in the house.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom walked up to the front door of the house, ignoring the stares of the local girls who watched with a certain curiosity from a distance and made use of an old fashioned knocker on the door. Both you and Hannah kept a weary eye out on the local girls who seemed less than thrilled to see strangers in their little neighborhood. Presently, the door opened and you and Hannah quickly turned forward. You were all greeted by a short, elderly woman with white hair tied into a small bun near the top of her head and jewel blue eyes behind half moon glasses. She was dressed professionally and carried a willow wood cane with a small crystal ball on the top. Both you and Hannah sensed powerful magic, almost as powerful as mom.

"Good afternoon, children." Calmly, she said. "Please, enter my humble home."

You all entered and removed your shoes in the mud room to Gwendolyn's request. The inside of her house looked like a witch's paradise, there were magical artifacts everywhere. It made Christina's old collection look small by comparison.

"Thank you for agreeing to see us, Gwendolyn." Kindly, mom said. "These are my daughters, Lucy and Hannah."

"A pleasure, I'm sure." Politely, Gwendolyn said. "Please, just call me Gwen." She gave a short giggle. "It's easier to remember." She then turned to you. "I see you have an interest in magical things. Was this that transformed you from a boy?"

You were taken back that this woman knew you were once a boy but you smiled back politely. "I love magic and being a girl is so much better." Politely, you said. "My friend, Christina loves magical artifacts more though."

Gwen chuckled. "I think you like them too only they have to sparkle to get your attention." Kindly, she said. "I have spent my life understanding how other witches think which was what made me the greatest witch counsellor of my generation." She ruffled your hair, making you blush then said, "Why don't you and your sister explore a bit while I talk to your mother."

You turned to mom, uncertain. "May we?"

Mom gave a reluctant nod. "If Mrs Frey says it is okay..."

"You have nothing to fear, child." Smiling, Gwen said. "Everything in this house is set to only work with my magical signature and anything they try to put into their pockets will become too big to fit and everything fragile is protected by a magic shield so they will not be touched." Mom opened her mouth to speak but smiled as Gwen added, "All little children will try to put something they like in their pockets, it is in their nature. Also, children their age have not yet learned the art of being delicate so I have learned to prepare for such visits."

With that said, mom and Gwen began to talk about the Pharaoh's ring.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Gwendolyn Frey greets you all

choices: Athena shows Hannah and you around the community
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Wow, this house is huge!" Hannah commented as you and her went from room to room exploring. "Even bigger than Keira's."

You nodded in agreement. "I wonder if Gwen lives alone here."

You and Hannah stumbled into found yourself in a big dining room with a huge table, set for at least 20 people. "Maybe 20 people live here," Hannah said as she say that.

The two of you heard a giggle behind and turned around to see a girl Hannah's age standing there. She was dressed in a fancy dress that might have been wore by noble girls a hundred years ago. "This room is just for entertaining guests," she explained. "Grandma has a lot of dinner parties."

Hannah nodded. "I'm Hannah Harrison and this is my sister Lucy. What's your name?"

"I'm Athena Frey," the girl answered. "I live here with my grandmother and mothers. It's nice to meet you."

"This place is awesome," you say. "It must be so much fun to live here. It's like the island Wonder Woman is from."

The girl giggled. "I guess so. Would you like me to show you two around the neighborhood?" You and Hannah nodded eagerly. "Cool, let me just let my Grandma know." She disappeared for a few minutes, then returned with a smile. "Grandma said it was fine. Your mom looked worried though."

You nodded. "We have a habit of getting into trouble."

Athena winked. "Cool. So do I."

As the three of you walked toward the door, Hannah admired Athena's outfit. "I love your dress. You wear stuff like that all the time?"

"A lot of the time. People here like to dress up in beautiful dresses most of the time, but we wear pants sometimes too."

"Wish I had a dress like that," you commented.

Athena smiled, mumbled something under her breath and waved her hand. In an instant, your pants and t-shirt were gone, replaced by an old fashioned dress and petticoat like the one Athena wore. A sun hat sat on your head now too, in place of your headband. You looked over to see Hannah was now wearing a similar outfit. "Now you do," Athena said with a smile.

"Your magic has awakened?" you asked in surprise.

Athena nodded. "Yeah, about a year ago. It's been really cool."

You and Hannah thanked her happily for the dresses before the three of you stepped out into the sun. All around you kids were playing and in yards and grown ups were going about there day happily. Not a single boy or man in sight. "So are all these people part of your family?" Hannah asked.

"Kind of," Athena responded. "Many are my blood relatives, but a lot of witches who just decided they didn't want to deal with guys anymore. So they moved here and joined our family like that."

"So you guys never see boys?" you asked.

Athena shrugged. "Not if we can help it, but we leave the community for shopping and stuff or vacations. So it's not like we never see guys."

"You probably see them in school too," Hannah added.

Athena shook her head. "Actually, we have a school here. That way we can learn about witch history without humans or boys getting in the way. We don't go to Witchbloom either. Everything we need is here."

Hannah nodded. "That's really cool, Athena."

Athena smiled. "Thanks. Ready to look around?"
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: You both meet a girl your age in the house.

choices: Later, Athena gives her offer to mom
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Athena introduced you and Hannah to a number of girls and women in the small community including a shy little girl named Robin Dove. She was about an inch shorter than you with long flowing forest brown hair and soft green eyes. She at first hid from you and Hannah but Athena's presence gave her some courage. "Robin and her mother joined our community just a few days ago." Kindly, Athena explained. "She is still adjusting."

"What do you mean?" Wincing, you asked.

"Well... Robin has had trouble with boys." Smiling, Athena said. "They scare her. Here, she can get over that shyness boys put in her and be more confident."

"I can name a few boys that annoy me." Muttering, you said.

This caused Robin to giggle slightly. "Yeah... boys are the worst."

You smiled at that. "Not all are bad." Honestly, you said.

"No, not all boys are bad though they are all annoying." Winking, Athena countered.

This brought a laugh from all before Athena asked, "So... what trouble do you two have with boys, just curious."

"Well, my cousin, Tim Towers seems to think all witches are bullies." Somewhat sadly, Hannah replied. "It has to do with a girl he liked who was killed."

"Magic can't fix everything." Shrugging, Athena said. "Why don't they just erase his memory of it all so he won't be so hurt?"

Hannah shrugged herself. "I'm not sure."

Athena sighed then turned to you. "How about you? What boys annoys you?"

You went on to explain your situation with Sean Knightly to which Athena gave a smile. "Yup. He would annoy me too." Bemused, she said. Then a thought came to her. "Why don't you and your family move here?"

"Move here?" Uncertain, you asked.

Athena nodded, her eyes dancing. "Here, you don't have to worry about annoying boys coming to your house or have to deal with them at school." Grinning, she said. "You can be rid of them for the most part forever and ever."

"I don't know..." Wincing, Hannah said.

"Think about it." Smiling, Athena said. "We'd love to have you here."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: A strange offer.

choices: All is good. You, Hannah, and Mom stay for dinner.
There is an issue at home. Hayley needs you all back.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
The initial conversation between Mom and Gwen focused mostly on small talk. Gwen was curious to know about what was happening at the witch council, as her family didn't really have much contact with the council at large. Of course, this was all an important part of the conversation. What Gwen was trying to find out was whether she could trust the witch council as she had some serious reservations. Mom, of course, caught on to this.

"I understand your worries, Gwen. I know there have been members of the witch council in the past who have advocated for breaking up your community."

"Is it really that surprising?" Gwen asked. "Male witches see this place as a threat and us as radicals."

"Well, you do advocate for total gender conversion and total separation from humans," Mom pointed out. "You know how protective men can be about their masculinity."

Gwen rolled her eyes. "Only too well. The Pharaoh's ring guarantees our safety. We can keep any...hostile forces at bay."

"I am not a hostile force," Mom assured. "Nor is my mother. She's always been very protective of your community."

"She's allowed us to exist, but we both know she does not share our philosophy. Nor do you. Lucy seems like a lovely girl, but she never should have had to live as a boy."

"I wanted that to be her choice," Mom said. She was getting worried Gwen's answer was going to be a 'no'. "You'll be happy to know she has rejected her old self completely. She's one of us now, but even more committed to her new identity because she got to discover it for herself."

Gwen paused to think. "What will you do with the rings once you have them all?"

"Once we get all ten, they can be destroyed. They are too powerful to let continue to exist," Mom responded.

Gwen nodded. "I suppose it's like nuclear disarmament." She thought for another long second. "If I agree to give you my ring, I will need something in return."

Mom nodded. "I expected as much. My mother gave me authority to negotiate. What do you have in mind?"

"The Amygdala Orb."

Mom sighed. "The object used to curse my Grandfather."

"It has no effect on female witches, but it is a powerful too for keeping male witches at bay," Gwen said. "I know the witch council has had it ever since your grandfather was cursed."

"It's our best chance at reversing the curse on my father," Mom pleaded.

"It's been almost 30 years since he was cursed. You've made almost no progress in that time. I can put it to better use here." Gwen wasn't going to budge on this. It was clear in her eyes.

"Very well," Mom conceded as she conjured up the orb. Elvira had predicted that this was what Gwen would want in trade for the Pharaoh's ring, so Mom had brought it just in case.

Elvira pulled the moonstone ring of her finger and the exchange took place. Each person took a moment to authenticate the item now in there possession. Once they both were satisfied, they smiled at each other and the tension that had been there before eased.

"Why don't you stay for dinner?" Gwen suggested. "We're having on last neighborhood bar-b-que before the weather turns too cold. I'd love to get to know you and your girls a bit more."

Mom looked out the window and saw you and Hannah happily playing with Athena and some other neighborhood girls. You all seemed to be having a fun time. "Let me check with my older daughter, Hayley, to see if things are okay at home. If there is no pressing emergency, we'd be happy to join."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Mom and Gwen talk.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom called Hayley to ask if all was well at home and smiled. "Well, that should keep Tim busy for a while." Bemused, she said. "Keep me informed. The Frey family has invited us to stay for dinner tonight. Order whatever you want for dinner, we will be back home late."

Mom then ended the call and turned to Gwen smiling. "It seems that my nephew, Tim has found a friend who is a young witch." Smiling, she explained. "A fragile little girl named Tina Moon."

Gwen grinned. "I detect a hint of hope in your voice." Bemused, she said.

Mom nodded. "Tim has always believed that witches were bullies who target boys merely because they had no or limited magic." Softly, she explained. "I am hoping this girl he befriended will change his mind about all that."

"I'm curious." Raising an eyebrow, Gwen said. "What led your nephew to this belief?"

Mom sighed and told Gwen the story to which she slowly nodded. "A broken heart will always lead to rash actions beliefs." Calmly, she said. "Why have you not erased his memory of the event to save him this trauma?"

"It's because of a last request from Catherine's husband." Sadly, mom replied. "He requested that Tim grow up to be a man."

Gwen sighed. "I see... and Catherine is a witch of her word."

Mom nodded and Gwen smiled again. "Well, care to help me prepare dinner?" Changing the subject, she asked. "Perhaps we can get your two daughters to lend a hand as well."

Mom smiled. "I'd love to."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: All is good. You, Hannah, and Mom stay for dinner.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
An hour later, the sun had set and the Bar-B-Que was in full swing. It was a lively and fun party. A local group of women had gotten out instruments and were playing folk music and there was lots of dancing. The kids played a lot of fun games on the lawns and you and Hannah found yourself making a lot of friends. The food was fantastic as well. The woman working the grill knew how to grill up the best burgers you had ever had. Even Mom was having a good time and she felt her anger with you two girls start to subside a bit.

"I wish we could live here," Hannah said as she bit into another burger. She was sitting at a picnic table with you, Athena, Robin, and Gwen. Mom was engaged in conversation with an old friend of hers who had joined the Frey community in another part of the party.

"That'd be awesome," Athena agreed. "You have no more boys in your family, right? So you'd fit right in."

"Well, there's our cousin like we said before," you mentioned.

"Well, there is an easy solution to all your cousin's problems," Athena said with a smile. "Turn him into a girl like us."

"But won't that just make him think witches really our bullies if we change him against his will," you pointed out.

Athena shook her head. "That's not being a bully, that's freeing him from an unhappy life as a boy. It's a good thing."

"What makes you think he's unhappy?" you asked.

"Because all boys are. That's why they are mean to us," Athena assured you. "Do you know any witch girls who were happier when they were boys?"

You mind flashed to Christina, but even she seemed to be slowly accepting her new self. "I guess not..."

"Changing boys into girls is saving them, making them better," Robin agreed. "My dad and I started as boys, but we're much better off now."

You thought about this and looked at Gwen. "Do you believe all this too?"

Gwen nodded. "The girls put it a little more simply than I do, but yes. The world of men is filled with evil and aggression. War, environmental disasters, hate. Here we've found a better way to live. One free of male and human influence."

Hannah nodded. You could see she liked the sound of all that. You weren't so sure. "But shouldn't people have a choice if they are boys or girls?"

"Choice only leads to disaster. Robin and her father weren't given a choice and they are much happier now. If I understand correctly, you weren't given a choice either. You just stumbled upon a magic artifact, didn't you?" Gwen said.

"Well, yeah, but Mommy let me made my own choice after that."

"But once you opened your mind to your new self. There was only one choice," Gwen added.

You nodded. That was true. Hannah spoke up. "Lucy and I have turned a few boys into girls."

"I heard. And do those boys seem happier now?" Gwen asked.

Hannah grinned. "They sure do. It was fun for us too. Maybe I should try turning Tim and you could turn that boy who's annoying you, Lucy."

You shook your head. "Sean would probably be annoying as a boy or a girl."

Gwen chuckled at this as Mom returned to the table. "You having been radicalizing my daughters now, have you?" Mom asked with a sly smile.

"These girls aren't the type to be easily influenced by others," Gwen said with a smile. "Hasn't stopped me from trying though, but I'm guessing that's why you're so at ease having them here. Many witch families I know would keep their daughters far away from us. Worried we'd corrupt them or something."

Mom sighed. "As I said, I believe in my daughters making their own choices in life. I want them to see as much of our world as they can." She patted you on the head.

"Well, your girls are welcome back anytime," Gwen said. "They've made a very good impression here." You and Hannah grinned at this. You may not have agreed with what Gwen was saying about boys, but you did like the people here and were happy to hear they liked you too.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Dinner with the Frey family.

choices: Lilly just takes the ring and leaves
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
As fun as the evening was, eventually it had to come to an end. Hannah was particularly sorry to leave. She had really bonded with Athena, but the two exchanged phone numbers and promised to talk soon. Pretty soon, you and Hannah were in the backseat as Mom drove back toward town.

"I wish we really could live there," Hannah said with a sigh. Making friends had been hard for her the last couple years, but here she had made so many friends. Friends that understood her as well.

"You wouldn't want to, honey," Mom told her. "You wouldn't be able to see Mikayla anymore."

"What do you mean? She could live there too," Hannah argued.

"Her dad couldn't," Mom responded. "Even if he was turned into a woman, which would be difficult with his immunity, he'd still be human. Her mom's a human too. Do you really think Mikayla would want to say goodbye to her parents."

"I guess not," Hannah admitted. "Her parents are really nice."

"I know the Frey village seems like paradise, but there is lot you'd have to give up to join it. I'm not sure you'd enjoy that in the end, Hannah." Mom chuckled at her next thought. "Besides you both may want boyfriends someday." This comment was made with a disgusted sound from both you and Hannah.

"I wouldn't like to live there," you stated. "I think people should have the choice to be a boy or a girl. Although I did like visiting." A thought occurred to you. "How come Aunt Samantha doesn't live there? She seems like she'd agree with them about a lot of stuff."

"She would," Mom agreed. "But Frey Village doesn't have much contact with the witch council. Samantha is very interested in influencing the council, so she wouldn't want to join."

That made sense. You were about to answer a follow-up question when Mom spotted a figure in the road. Instinctively, she stopped the car, breaking hard, but when she looked up again, the figure was gone. Before Mom had a chance to respond, the figure reappeared in the passenger seat. It was Lilly Sweetie. "Hello, ladies. Out for a night drive?"

"Lilly!" Mom said in surprise. Before she could react he was hit full on by a blast of magic. The driver door of the car blasted off onto the road and Mom went flying with it, totally dazed.

"MOM!" you screamed. You tried to hit Lilly with your own blast of magic, but before you could, Lilly had cast a spell on your car seat, which keep you from moving.

As you continued to scream and struggle, Lilly stepped out of the car and walked toward Mom's dazed body. Hannah was frozen, too scared to move, but her magic hadn't awakened yet anyway. There was nothing she could do. Lilly bent down and slipped the pharaoh's ring Mom had gotten from Gwen off her finger. "Six down," Lilly said with a smile. Then she took another look at Mom, considering what to do next.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Driving home

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You watched in horror as Lily placed the ring on her finger and was about to chant something. Only, she froze as the towering figure of grandpa Moriarty appeared. Without the amulet he had put around your neck the last time, you were completely frozen in terror. Turning to Hannah, you saw that she was crying but not daring to make a sound.

"Strike my daughter again and I will end you, witch." Gravely, Moriarty said. His voice was deep and threatening. "I am always watching."

Lilly was wise not to respond. She instead vanished from view. Moriarty then helped mom back to her feet before summoning two muscular boys to him. "Jessie, Hank, ensure the Harrison family arrives home safely." His voice booming, he instructed.

"Of course, head wizard." Bowing, Hank said.

"No one shall harm them, sir." Firmly, Jessie added.

Moriarty nodded then turned to mom. "This is Hank and Jessie Moon, two more of my students." Serious, he explained. "They will insure nothing else happens to you or your children tonight."

"Lilly took the Pharaoh's ring I got from Gwendolyn Frey." Shaken, mom reported.

"I will inform Elvira and the other wizards." Calmly, Moriarty said. "Lilly made a mistake attacking the royal family directly. She will learn there is a price for power."

With that said, Moriarty vanished and Hank and Jessie helped mom back to the car. Jessie waved his hand at you, allowing you to move again then took a seat up front. Hank then sat in the back and smiled at you and Hannah. "Fear not, young witches." Smiling, he said. "We wizards only annoying because we care."

This made you and Hannah grin slightly as mom drove the rest of the way home. Upon arriving, you asked, "Why did they call grandpa head wizard?"

"Because that is his title." Smiling, mom said. "You have your witches and your wizards. How the magic works for each is still being debated."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Grandpa is always watching.

choices: You ask how Christina's lesson went
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Pretty soon, the three of you were home. Mom lay on the couch with an ice pack nursing her head, while Hayley prepared some tea. The rest of you were gather around Mom. Even Christina was there. Mel and Hannah, while glad that their mother was alright were both a little frustrated.

"Why didn't you tell us Grandpa was alive? And how come Hayley and Lucy knew?" Mel demanded, trying not to get to angry. Her voice was still loud though.

"Don't shout, dear. My head is still pounding. But you're right. I should have told you two," Mom groaned. "Lucy only found out by accident and Hayley...well, I thought when she went to Witchbloom she would find out somehow if I didn't tell her."

"Why did you keep it a secret at all?" you asked. You had never been clear on that.

"The curse on my father prevented us female witches from being near him without soul-crushing fear. I thought it would hurt too much to know you're grandfather was out there, but you could never see him."

"But he's got those amulet things that protect us from the curse," you pointed out.

"Those are recent. I only learned he had them during his last visit. And with everything that is going on, I couldn't figure out a way to tell you all about that. I am sorry. I should have been more on top of that." Mom winced in pain again and gratefully accepted the tea Hayley had just brought into the room.

"So you're grandfather was that scary man?" Christina said in amazement, remembering when she had glimpsed him over the weekend. "And he's head witch?"
