"Those boys called him head wizard," Hannah corrected.

Mom chuckled, but laughing hurt and she immediately regretted it. "Wizards are just what some male witches call themselves, because they find the term witch too threatening and feminine, which is silly. The male witches with the strongest potential, like your grandfather and Sean, mostly realized those distinctions are ridiculous and embrace the term witch. I would guess those boys we met aren't as secure in their masculinity. They certainly didn't act like they were."

You nodded, remembering that both your Grandfather and Sean had called themselves witches in the past.

"So is your grandfather the head of male witches then?" Christina asked.

"No, he just has some students," Mom explained. "Male witches answer to the witch council same as the rest of us, well, except for rogue witches and witches like Gwendolyn Frey. They tend to be scattered about. Many of them keep to themselves. They aren't organized."

"So Sean's one of Grandpa's students?" Hannah said.

In an attempt to steer the conversation away from Sean, you quickly brought up something else. "What about Lilly? She's got six rings now."

"She does, but the last four rings are safely locked away with the witch council. You don't have to worry about that," Mom said. "We'll catch Lilly soon enough."

You nodded, but felt unsure. You had a feeling Lilly had much more planned.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: continue.

choices: Christina shows you what she learned.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Trying to keep the subject off of Sean for the time being, you asked Christina, "Um... how was your magic lesson?"

Christina smiled. "It was great!" Excited, she replied. "I learned that there is way to tell how old a magical artifact is by the way it shimmers and sparkles." She giggled. "I can't believe something you love was in that lesson."

You giggled at that. "Ms Frey told me that she thinks I like magical artifacts too but they have to sparkle to catch my attention."

Christina nodded. "The newer the artifacts are, the more they glitter and sparkle." Kindly, she explained. "I had, and still do love artifacts that don't shine, that are not as obvious to others."

"You knew..." Shrugging, you said. "We still have something in common."

Both you and Christina laughed at that. "Samantha told me about the term wizards." Changing the subject, she said. "It's something new made up by a few witch boys who think they are better than witch girls so to separate themselves from them."

"That's lame." Wrinkling your nose, you said.

"I'm guessing your grandfather tolerates it but I never heard Sean referring to him like that." Smiling, Christina said. "He's okay... for a boy."

"Don't tell me you like Sean too." Moaning, you complained.

"He's not rude to me so I'm not rude back." Honestly, Christina said. "It's not like anyone is swooning over him or anything." She shrugged. "No one can get along with everyone."

"I guess so..." Sighing, you said.

Seeing you were uncomfortable, Christina decided to move back to the subject of her lessons. "If you want, I can show you what Samantha taught me."

"Okay." Smiling again, you said.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: You ask how Christina's lesson went

choices: You, Mom, and your sisters go to dinner that night
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
The next day, school was comfortingly normal. Of course, after visiting a community of female-only witches and having your mom be attacked by a rogue witch, solving math problems and reading early chapter books seemed pretty mundane. Tammy was back, which was exciting, but she didn't look fantastic, so you and the other girls try to help her throughout the day. Sean was starting to talk to more of the boys in class, so he gave you a bit more space, which was great for you, but at recess time, he approached you and Liz while you were both on the swings. You had finally gotten a chance to tell Liz about everything that had happened the day before and had just reached the part where Lilly got away, when you noticed Sean approaching.

"What's up, Pinbrat?" you asked. Despite the nickname, you tone was kinder than usual. He had given you space, the least you could was be a little kind.

"You hear about tonight, Sparkle Boots?" he asked.

You looked confused. "What's tonight?"

"Master Strange invited your family over for dinner," Sean explained. You felt mixed emotions about that news. On the one hand, you got to spend time with your Grandpa. On the other hand, it meant more time with Sean.

"Why do you call him Master and Teacher all the time?" Liz asked, before you had a chance to react.

Sean blushed. "It's the proper way for a student of witchcraft to address his teacher. Calling him anything regular like his name would be disrespectful."

You doubted your grandfather cared much, but you didn't comment on it. "I guess he wants to get to know our family. Is anyone else coming?"

Sean shook his head. "I don't think so. Master Strange only has five amulets, so that's you, your mom, and your sisters."

You nodded, but that wasn't what you meant. "What about his other students, like those two..." You chose your words carefully. "...big mouths I met yesterday."

Sean chuckled, but you couldn't tell if he was laughing with you or at you. Probably at you. "No, they all have there own families to be with. And I think he wants to be alone with you guys anyway. Except for me, of course. I'm the only one who lives with Master Strange." He sounded a bit sad when he said that. He must have been thinking of his parents, who as far as you understood, had died.

Liz, however, didn't know this and kept asking questions. "Where do you guys live anyway?"

Sean snapped out of his thoughts and look around to make sure no one was listening. "You know that abandoned construction site on Briar Street?" You and Liz nodded. That construction site had been there as long as you could remember, but you had never seen anyone working there. You always found it weird, but most people seemed to barely notice it. "That's an illusion. Master Strange and I live in a castle that's hidden there."

You and Liz looked at each other. For a second, Sean thought you didn't believe him, but the two of you shouted in unison, "That's so COOL!!!!"

"How'd you hear about all this anyway?" you asked. "You do know cell phones aren't allowed in school, right?"

Sean blushed. "Master Strange sent me a raven...with a letter."

You weren't sure what to make of that. "My grandpa is weird." Sean didn't entirely disagree. One of the recess monitors freaked out when the raven had flown down at Sean.

"Anyway, I'll see you tonight, Sparkle Boots," Sean said as he walked off. "Try not to be too annoying and bubbly, will ya?" That made you red. He had almost gone an entire conversation without angering you. Now though, it was too late.

"I'll be as annoying as I want!" you called after him, but you knew it wasn't a great comeback.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Next day at school.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Hannah did not understand Tim's sudden change in personality though she liked it. He had not gotten into a single fight in school and he had not thrown a single insult or played a single prank on any girl all day. Instead, he was constantly hanging around the new girl and boy in school, Tina and Paul Moon. Tina was a delicate short girl with doll like features, blue eyes and long blond hair. Her twin brother was near the same height with soft features and blue eyes only his blond hair was cut short. Hannah met up with them after school while they were waiting for their parents to pick them up. "I'm glad to see you in better spirits, Tim." Smiling, Hannah said.

"Yeah, well Tina kind of keeps me calm." Blushing, Tim replied.

Tina giggled at that while Paul only smiled. "There's good and bad in everyone, regardless of who or what they are." Kindly, Paul said. "Dad told me that if you only look for evil, that's all you'll find so look for the good instead."

"Good point." Smiling, Hannah said. She then moaned seeing a familiar pair of boys walking their way with mean sneers on their faces. "It's that Karl Dusty and Greg Waters again. They're the biggest jerks in school."

"What do we have here?" With a grin, Karl asked. "A bunch of pipsqueaks just waiting to be given a few boxing lessons."

Tina sighed before grabbing a necklace under her blouse which Greg noticed. "Are you afraid we're going to rob you?" Chuckling, he asked. "I doubt a squirt like you has anything of real value though you might."

"Take a hike." Frowning, Tim grumbled.

"Oh-ho!" Smiling, Karl said. "We have our first volunteer!"

Tina opened her mouth as if to scream only it was Karl and Greg who screamed as a massive pair of hands grabbed each of them by the collar. The first one was about thirteen with crew cut brown hair and green eyes in a football jersey and blue jeans. The other was about a year older with short brown hair and blue eyes wearing similar attire. Hannah recognized them as the powerful boys, Jessie and Hank who had escorted your, her, and mom home after the attack.

"Are these two nobodies bugging you, sis?" Firmly, Jessie demanded.

"They were trying to." Softly, Tina replied.

Hank turned to Greg who was hopelessly struggling against his iron grip. "If I catch you bugging my sister or her friends, if I hear even a whisper of it, I will make you suffer."

"The same goes for you, snowflake." Snarling, Jessie added to Karl. "We're the big boys on campus now so make yourselves scare!"

"That's enough, boys." Calmly, a booming voice said.

Everyone turned to face a massive man in his early thirties with brown hair and green eyes wearing casual clothing. "There is no need to frighten anyone." He then turned to Karl and Greg. "Run along now, kids and do try not to get into any more trouble."

Hannah did not know why but Karl and Greg seemed terrified of Mr Moon and ran off without daring to say a word. Mr Moon smiled at Hannah's expression. "I know how to inspire fear in normal people." Calmly, he said. "It comes in handy from time to time though the council frowns upon it."

Later...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Meet The Moon Family.

choices: There is silence. It is awkward.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"Lucy, stop fidgeting," Mom told you as your family got out of her car and approached the abandoned construction site. You had all dressed up for the occasion. You were wearing a sparkly blue dress, yellow cardigan, and a flower in your hair. It was an outfit you picked out yourself, but you still felt nervous wearing it. "You look lovely, honey. Your grandpa is going to love it."

"Yeah, but I bet Sean makes fun of it," you groaned, remembering Sean's behavior the last time you were dressed up all girly in front of him. Mel giggled for some reason when you said that. For the life of you, you couldn't figure out why.

Hannah had been quiet the whole car ride, thinking about her encounter with the Moon family. It weirded her out, especially Tim's change in behavior. But she perked up when Hayley tapped her shoulder. "Come on, aren't you excited to meet Grandpa, Hannah?" Hayley asked.

Hannah pushed the Moons from her mind and focused on her Grandfather. "Yeah, Lucy says he's really funny."

Mom stepped toward the gate of the construction site, and, as the five of you walked through it, the world around you simmered. Suddenly, the construction site was gone, replaced by a large beautiful castle that looked like it was out of a fairy tale. There was even a drawbridge and a moat. Once you all crossed the moat, you found Sean on the other side, dressed in former shorts, a collared shirt, and a tie. Of course, Sean usually dressed more formal. He was holding five amulets and handed each on to a member of your family.

"Thanks, Sean," Mel said as she took it. "I hear you've been torturing my sister. Keep up the good work." Sean smiled at that.

Hayley examined her amulet before she put it on. "Are we sure we should be doing this? I mean, someone should be home with Christina."

"Christina is having dinner with her parents. She's fine," Mom assured Hayley. Mom was a little surprised to notice Hayley was very nervous about all this.

Once everyone had an amulet on, Sean called out. "It's safe, Sir. You can come on out."

There was a huge puff of smoke in front of you, and...no one came out of it. You all watched quietly as the smoke vanished into the air. "HELLO FAMILY!!!" It was coming from behind you. You jumped in surprise to see Grandpa standing there behind you all, but you were happy to see him. You leaped into his arms and hugged him tight.

"GRANDPA!!" you shouted as you squeezed him. Mom smiled warmly at her father, but your three sisters paused unsure. None of them had really ever met the man. What were they supposed to do?
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Dinner at the castle.

choices: you are placed next to Sean.
Christina with her mom and dad.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
After a moment of awkward silence, Hayley introduced herself, Mel and Hannah before asking, "What made you so feared that a witch felt she had to curse you?"

Moriarty sighed, a sad look on his face. "Like all other things, there is a balance between witch born boys and girls." Calmly, he explained. "The physically stronger a witch boy becomes, the harder it is for a witch girl's magic to effect him. The magically stronger a witch girl becomes, the harder it is for a boy's magic to effect her."

"Your grandfather become so powerful he can now block any and all magic regardless of how powerful it may be." Serious, mom said. "He is rarely caught off guard. That one witch managed which is how he became cursed."

"So immunity to magic is like a shield of will power." Guessing, Mel said. "It's only as good as your ability to see it coming."

Moriarty gave a bemused smile. "It's a bit more complex than just that."

"He's not going to bite you." Wincing, you said.

Hayley blushed slightly then stepped forward and gave Moriarty a hug with Mel and Hannah soon joining. Mom had to wipe away a tear seeing her father embracing all of her children for the first time. Moriarty was shedding joyful tears. "You have no idea how long I had waited for this one moment." Tearfully, he said. "I am so proud of you all."

Sean stood by mom's side, smiling as well. He wanted to ask her why you were so annoying but he did not want to spoil the moment. Only mom seemed to sense his question and held back a chuckle. "From what I have heard, Lucy's annoyance towards you started with you stepping on her pride back at the arcade."Whispering, she said. "Something about you saying 'what do a couple of dumb girls know about pinball... and that its's a boys game'..."

Sean sighed, rolling his eyes. "You mean she's still sore about that?"

"Lucy is just as guilty." Bemused, mom whispered. "Instead of trying to resolve the issue at hand, she is trying to win the 'battle'." She giggled. "Some things never change."

"What do you mean?" Curious, Sean asked.

"It took weeks for Lucy to finally accept things as they were and to admit she loves ballet." Smiling, mom explained. "I have no doubt it will take the same amount of time for her to accept you as a friend. Have patience."

Minutes later, you were all escorted to the dinning hall where Elvira was waiting for everyone to arrive for dinner. You greeted her with a hug with mom and your sisters following before you were shown to your seats...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Your sisters introduce themselves

choices: Sean gives you and Hannah the tour
Grandpa talks with Hayley and Mel
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"How are you here, Grandma?" Hayley asked. "I thought...uhhh...Grandpa only had five amulets." She was still uncomfortable saying Grandpa. It was weirder for her than the rest of you it seemed. Perhaps because she was the oldest.

Indeed, Elvira wasn't wearing an amulet. "Because I'm not really here. I'm astral projecting. A very advanced witch technique, but since my body isn't physically here, I'm not affected by the curse."

You didn't understand what she was saying, but Mel whispered to you. "She's like ghost, only alive, but she's not here." That made more sense.

"But we hugged you?" Hayley said with confusion. "I felt you here."

"Did you? Or did your mind trick you because it is what you thought was happening?" Elvira said with a laugh.

Hannah reached out her hand and sure enough it passed through Elvira like a ghost. "Cool!" Hannah proclaimed. She did it a few more times until here mother called her to sit down.

You frowned when you saw your place setting, right next to Sean's. You found yourself even more annoyed when he pulled out your chair for you. "What are you doing?" you asked.

"Being polite," he answered, bothered by you questioning his action. "You don't like me being nice?"

"I don't like you treating me like some weakling who can't pull out her own chair," you responded.

"Sean, Lucy, let's not fight," Grandpa scolded. You blushed and let Sean push in your chair once you sat down. You hated it, but Mel had a huge grin on her face.

Soon food appeared on the table, though no one was carrying it. It just materialized. Eagerly, you all began to dig in. It was unsurprisingly delicious. "Did you cook this Grandpa?" Hannah asked.

Grandpa shook his head. "I'm a terrible cook, I'm afraid. I use a witch catering service for dinners like this. They make the meals and teleport them here."

"So they are cooking for someone they've never met?" you said in surprise. Grandpa nodded. The witch world was cool.

Dinner continued. Grandpa started asking about all your lives and your interests. Hannah was happy to share and Grandpa learned all about what was happening with Tim, though he kept his thoughts on the matter to himself. You and Hannah told him all about Ballet, which Sean was also happy to talk about. You two also talked about what you were learning at school and Sean talked about how the first couple days had been. He didn't hate it, but he wasn't sure he didn't prefer being homeschooled. Mel and Hayley were still pretty quiet though and both seemed uncomfortable with Grandpa. Soon dinner was finished, and you sat there satisfied with the delicious meal.

Sean, however, was giving you a look. "You eat like a pig," he said under his breath. You were pretty sure only you heard him say it too.

"You act like a pig," you retorted quietly.

Grandpa then spoke up. "Sean, why don't you show Lucy and Hannah around the castle. I'm sure they'd love a tour." You annoyance at Sean didn't trump your desire to see the castle, so you eagerly agreed. Hannah too.

"Come on," Sean said, leading you two from the table.

As the three of you departed, Grandpa turned to Hayley and Mel and smiled. He wanted to talk to them about what was bothering them.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: you are placed next to Sean.

choices: There is an intruder in the castle
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
"This castle was built here two hundred years ago." Motioning to a plague on the wall, Sean explained. "The head witch has the choice of where to call home. The previous head witch resided in a castle built in England."

Sean went on to show you and Hannah many aspects of the castle including a few secret passages he had used during his training. "Only guards who serve the castle may use the secret passageways without an escort." Serious, Sean said. "Some lead to areas that are strictly off limits to all but the royal family."

"Aren't we part of the royal family?" Curious, Hannah asked.

Sean smiled. "I'll rephrase... the adult members of the royal family."

"Why do some boys call grandpa the head wizard?" Wincing, you asked. "Just curious."

Sean rolled his eyes. "There are a few witch boys who think they are better than witch girls." Patiently, he explained. "They believe that 'witch boy' is too feminine of a title so they picked 'wizard' because it is more man like." He sighed. "As your grandfather is married to the head witch, they call him the head wizard." You smiled and began to speak but Sean cut you off. "I know there are also witch girls who think they are better than boys but both are a myth."

"What do you mean?" Smiling, Hannah asked. "Girls are better than boys."

Sean chuckled. "You are young, you'll learn." Calmly, he said.

Hannah pouted at that then whispered to you, "He is kind of annoying."

You smiled at that, feeling you had gained a small victory. Sean only shook his head and patiently continued with the tour. As he showed you around, you began to wonder about the secret passageways.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Sean gives you and Hannah the tour

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Curiosity got the best of you and you sneaked into one of the secret passageways Sean had pointed out to see where they lead. The hidden hallway was dimly lit with torches that burned with a cool flame. You guessed magic was at work there. Following the hall, you found several doors of which all were locked. There were plagues over every door but they were in witch writing of which you were just now beginning to learn so you could not make out all of the words.

"It's not fun to explore if they lock everything." Frowning slightly, you muttered.

You were tempted to use your magic to unlock a few of the doors but you figured you would be in enough trouble for exploring them in the first place. Presently, the hall spit into three directions, right, left, and forward. You noticed one door of which you could read the plague. It read, 'Harry's collection'. "So this is where they took Christina's antiques when they confiscated them." Smiling, you whispered. "She would be anxious to get these back since she is a witch now."

You were tempted to open the door but you also wanted to explore more before you got caught.

What do you do?
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: You explore a secret passageway.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You continued down the secret passage, walking carefully so that you weren't heard. There were a couple interesting things along the way, a two-way mirror looking into a study of some sort and a room marked "Single Sock Storage," which contained a lot of socks that didn't have a pair. At the end of the passage, you found yourself brought into another hallway, which seemed disappointing, but you noticed a light on in a room nearby. Curiously, you walked over to the room and opened the door.

It was an ordinary room for a young boy, full of toys and books and clothing, all very neatly kept and organized. You noticed a dinosaur themed bedspread and several dinosaur models and you realized were you were. You had stumbled upon Sean's room. You grinned, knowing this was your chance to get back at him, and tried to decide what magical prank you wanted to leave for him, when you noticed a picture on the bedside table. You walked closer to it and picked it up. It was a picture of a toddler, who looked a lot like Sean, being held in the arms of a couple you had never seen before. You guessed they were Sean's parents.

"What are you doing in here, Sparkle Boots?" Sean's voice came coldly from behind you. You turned to see him staring daggers at you from the doorway.

You immediately realized you had gone a bit too far. "I'm sorry. I...I got curious. I didn't realize it was your room until..."

Sean marched over and grabbed the picture of his parents from your arms. "You had no business being in here."

"Yeah, you're right," you admitted. You suddenly realized he was alone. "Where's Hannah?"

Sean's eyes widened in surprised and he quickly looked behind him. He groaned in aggravation when he realized Hannah wasn't there. "Can't you girls go five minutes without sneaking off or doing something you shouldn't?"

"Our mother has the same problem with us." You looked at the floor feeling a little guilty. "Are those your parents? In the picture?"

Sean paused, unsure whether to share that with you, but something compelled him to do so. "Yeah..." He looked wounded, sad, lost.

"What happened to them?"

Sean shrugged. "They were...they died. That's all." He didn't sound eager to share the whole story and you didn't press him further. "I really miss them," he admitted after a moment.

"Mom says the Knightleys were powerful witches. She was surprised to hear about you." You weren't sure what that was.

"Most people think I died when my parents did. Your grandpa kept me secret for a while. I had to tell everyone my last name was Woodhouse. He only let me tell people my real name a few days ago when I gave up my family's pharaoh ring," Sean explained.

You nodded. Grandpa must have been worried someone would target Sean if they knew he was a Knightley. Suddenly something occurred to you. "Wait, you told me your name the day before you gave up your pharaoh ring."

Sean blushed. "I was...annoyed at you. I wasn't thinking smart."

You giggled. "Yeah, I wasn't either."

The two of you smiled at each other silently, enjoying each other's company for the first time ever. But the peace was short lived. "Just so we're clear. Don't tell anyone about my parents, and you still really annoy me," Sean said.

"Don't worry. I won't tell. And I still find you super annoying too," you said. "Plus, you think you're better at magic than me, which is so not true."

"I wasn't the one who wound up in a super girly tutu the last time we squared off," Sean retorted.

"Maybe I like that tutu."

"That'd be worse. It was so frilly." Sean smiled again, which you returned. There was something comforting in knowing you annoyed each other.

"Hey, maybe we can be rivals," you suggested.

"Rivals?"

"Don't you read any comics or watch cartoons?" you asked. Sean shook his head. Of course, he didn't. "A rival is someone you compete against and don't really like, but you both make each other stronger."

Sean chuckled. "Like I need you to make me stronger."

"That's perfect," you said with grin. "That sounds just like what my rival should say." You smiled and skipped out of the room.

"I'm not your rival," Sean objected as he followed you out.

"Too late. I've already decided," you stated happily as the two of you headed back out into the castle.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: You keep exploring.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Back in the dining room, Hayley and Mel were still with Mom and the grandparents. Grandpa had strategically gotten you and Hannah out of the room, so he could talk with the two teenagers. "I've notice you two seem a little reserved around me tonight. I imagine this hasn't been as easy for the two of you as I was hoping it would be."

Hayley and Mel looked at each other, before Hayley spoke. "It's an adjustment. Even though I knew you were alive, I guess I never really considered that you'd be part of our lives. I just figured you were gone for good."

Mel nodded in agreement. "It's kinda weird. We've never met you before, but now, like, suddenly you're our grandpa."

"Yeah, how are we supposed to act? Just pretend like you aren't a complete stranger to us. Lucy and Hannah are younger. It's easier for them to accept this, but for us...I feel like this is all moving very fast," Hayley added.

Grandpa nodded. His face looked very sad. "I understand. I've always wanted to be part of you life, but with this curse..."

Mel cut him off. "We, like, understand the whole curse thing. But it doesn't make this not weird. You know what I mean."

"I do and I understand your perspective. This must all be strange for you." He smiled, hoping his pun broke the ice a bit, but no such luck. "Sorry, bad pun."

"That was a pun?" Mel said quietly in confusion.

"His last name is Strange," Hayley explained to her sister. Mel made a noise of realization.

"We don't have to rush things," Grandpa said. "I want to have a relationship with you two, but we can do it on your terms."

"Thanks," Hayley responded. "That's what we want too. But just one step at a time so we can get used to having you around." Mel nodded in agreement and Grandpa smiled again.

"I can't ask for more. And I'm happy to see my granddaughters are two such wise, young ladies." There was hope and that was all Moriarty Strange could ask for.

Mel, in particular, blushed at the complement. She wasn't often called wise. Mom and Elvira were happy to hear this airing of feelings. It was a good first step in bringing Moriarty back into the family. It would take time, but any forward progress was encouraging.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Mel and Hayley with Grandpa

choices: Opened a hidden door, revealing Hannah.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Minutes later, as mom was in the middle of catching up with her father, Moriarty, her cellphone rang to the tune of Beethoven"s Moonlight Sonata. "That's Hannah." Sighing, she said.

"You set your children's calls to classical music?" Bemused, Moriarty asked.

Mom nodded. "Hannah is a night owl." Smiling, she replied. "It takes some doing to get her to go to sleep." She giggled. "It also some doing to get her to get up."

With that, mom answered the phone. "Hey, sweetie." Calmly, she said. "Are you having fun?"

Hannah responded with frightened sobbing, which worried mom. "Mommy... I'm lost." Crying, she said. "Lucy sneaked away into one of those hidden hallways. Sean and I went in to find her but I couldn't keep up..." Hannah then fell into tears.

"Hannah is lost in one of the secret passageways." Sighing, mom explained. "It would seem that Lucy decided to explore in there and she could not keep up with Sean when they went looking for her."

"Tell her to look for a small wooden plague on any one of the doors." Calmly, Moriarty said. "It should be a number and a letter."

Mom nodded then relayed the message to Hannah who read the number and letter to mom which she repeated to Moriarty. "It's D-123."

Moriarty shook his head, retrieving a cellphone of his own. "I better call Sean and let him know where Hannah is."

With that, he...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Mom gets a phone call

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Hannah looked surprised as she was suddenly revealed to Mom and her Grandpa. "Ummm...hi," she said meekly.

Grandpa chuckled. "D-123 connects to this room. Hannah could see us the whole time."

Hannah blushed. "Sorry. I saw you guys while I was exploring and I thought it'd be funny."

"Hannah, you can't worry me like that." Mom was not assumed by this joke.

Grandpa rolled his eyes. "Be fair, Natalie. You used to play games like this all the time when you her age."

"Yeah, but I wasn't the one being tricked then," Mom grumbled.

It was getting late and Mom had to get you all home. You and Hannah had to go to bed and Hayley and Mel had homework. It had been a good dinner, but not it was time to say goodbye to Grandpa, be he promised he'd see you all again very soon.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Opened a hidden door, revealing Hannah.

choices: You and Liz talk on the telephone.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You were all smiles upon returning home, which mom found refreshing since you were anxious at dinner being seated next to Sean. She caught up with you in your bedroom. "I take it you and Sean are getting along a little better?" Guessing, she asked.

"Yeah, he's okay..." Reluctantly, you replied. "For an annoying boy, that is." You sighed, picking up a framed photo of your father. "We kind of have something in common... I miss him."

Mom pulled you into a warm hug. "We all do, sweetie." Softly, she said. "Everyone deals with loss in their own way." Deciding to change the subject, she asked, "Are you two friends now?"

You shook your head. "We're rivals." Smiling, you said. "Someone you compete against and don't really like, but you both make each other stronger."

Mom held back a giggle. "Well, rivals sometimes end up becoming close friends in the end." Bemused, she said. "I have seen it happen with my own eyes."

You blushed at that though you were not sure why. "Yeah... well, we'll see..." Quietly, you replied. "Isn't Cassie holding her next coven meeting here tonight?"

"She is but you will be in bed when it starts." Firmly, mom said. "I am still not comfortable with you being in one, you are not old enough."

"I'm never old enough." Pouting, you said.

Mom smiled. "You'll get there." Calmly, she assured. "Have patience."

With that, she left your bedroom, closing the door behind her. There was a bemused smile on her face. "The more things change, the more they stay the same." Whispering, she said to herself. "John and Megan Thompson started off as rivals and later became boyfriend and girlfriend." She sighed. "Now, its starting all over again only now its Lucy and young Sean Knightley."

Hayley giggled, hearing mom. "I wonder who Christina will swoon this time around." Smiling, she said. "Maybe our cousin, Tim towers."

Mom giggled. "I think he has eyes for that young Tina Moon though he won't admit it."

Hayley smiled.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Echoes of the past.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom's thought process was interrupted by the phone ringing. She left Hayley to go pick it up in her bedroom, but was surprised to find it was her mother, who she had just seen an hour before, though in astral projection form. "Mother, is everything okay?" Mom asked Elvira immediately.

Elvira was quick to ease her mind. "Oh, don't worry. It's nothing too exciting. We just got some information that might be useful."

"This about Lilly?" Mom asked slightly annoyed.

"What's wrong, daughter?" Elvira was extremely practiced at sensing her daughter's moods.

Mom moaned. "I've done a lot for this investigation already, Mother. You have actual investigators. I've got a family to raise. Hannah and Lucy had nightmares last night after we were attacked."

"I know and I'm sorry, but you knew Lilly Sweetie better than anyone else involved with the council. You're best qualified to lead this."

"Maybe so, but I don't want Lucy or Hannah near this again." There was silence on the other line, which told Mom Elvira was about to suggest the exact opposite. "Mother, you must be joking? They're children."

Elvira sighed, feeling a bit of guilt. "Yes, but we've located Lilly's family, her wife and two sons. The boys are 7 and 5, so..."

"...you think they might let some information slip to children their own age, while I interrogate Lilly's wife," Mom said, finishing Elvira's thought.

"Exactly."

Mom thought for a second. She turned her head to notice you, now dressed in your Disney Princess nightgown, peering into the room with a picture book in your hands. You wanted her to put you to bed.

"Fine, we can go after school tomorrow, but I want Dad there too. Not in the open, but, out of sight there, in case anything goes wrong. Just him, not any of those obnoxious students of his. They'd just get in the way," Mom decided.

"You know, he'll need to bring Sean. There's not one else to watch him," Elvira responded.

Mom nodded. "Sean's fine. He actually listens to instructions and might manage to keep Lucy out of trouble." Emphasis on the might, she thought to herself, but she didn't say that with you listening. You had already perked up the mention of Sean and your name. You were now moving to sit on the bed next to Mom.

"Good, I'll call your father and let him know," Elvira responded.

"Fine, but don't ask for anything like this again. My girls have been through enough." With that, Mom hung up the phone and turned her attention to your curious face.

"We going on another adventure?" you asked excitedly.

Mom wasn't crazy about you calling these adventures. "We are after school tomorrow, but we'll talk about it then." She looked at the book you had brought her. "Cinderella?"

You nodded. "Hannah had it in her room. I was hoping you could read it to me, since I'm going to be Cinderella in a few days."

Mom smiled. "You might not remember this, but I read this all the time to you when you were five. It was one of your favorites. Before you started insisting that boys didn't like princesses."

You looked confused. "Really? I remember you reading it to me and me loving it, but I don't remember saying boys didn't like princesses. That's silly."

"Are you starting to forget things about being a boy," Mom asked, her face a little concerned.

Again, you nodded. "Yeah, it's getting hard to remember some stuff. Is that bad?"

Mom shook her head. "Not at all. It's quite normal for witch boys who become girls. You'll never forget that you were a boy, but those memories will fade as they become less important to you. We're going to have to start planning your confirmation soon."

You leaned your head against Mom as she began to stroke your hear. "What's a confirmation?"

"Every transformed witch girl has one. It's a celebration where you accept your new identity as a girl and sever any remaining ties to your former self," Mom explained. "It's a lot of fun. Like a birthday party, but celebrating your rebirth. Of course, we only have one when you are absolutely sure you don't want to be a boy again."

You smiled imagining it. "That does sound like fun, and don't worry, I'm a girl now. I never want to be a stupid boy again."

Mom hugged you and kissed your forehead. "You make a wonderful daughter. Now let's read that book and put you to bed." She stood up and took your hand, leading her youngest daughter to her bedroom.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: continue.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
The next day, you woke up to the sound of birds outside and gasped as you discovered it was morning. Worried you would be late for school, you quickly got dressed and ran downstairs to find mom sitting at the dinning room table, quietly sipping on some tea. She smiled upon seeing you. "Good morning, Lucy." Calmly, she said.

"Mommy, you forgot to wake me up!" Scolding, you said. "I'll be late for school!"

Mom giggled. "Lucy, there is no school today." Bemused, she replied. "It's spring break, everyone has the week off."

You blushed at that. "I forgot..."

Mom smiled. "Would you like some breakfast or do you want to sleep some more?"

"I guess I'll have some breakfast." Shrugging, you said. "Is everyone else still asleep?"

mom nodded. "I'm always up this early." She yawned. "Besides, Cassie's coven meeting went well into the night."

"I missed the coven meeting?!" Surprised, you demanded. You moaned. "I wanted to meet them..."

"You will when the time is right." Smiling, mom said. "Now, about that breakfast..."

Minutes later, you and mom were sharing a light breakfast, talking about anything and nothing when you asked, "When are we going on our next adventure?"

"Later today." Sighing, mom said. "Hopefully, it will be the last adventure for a while."

"Why?" Curious, you asked.

Mom smiled patiently. "Too much of anything is not a good thing." She then turned to the window, thinking. "I do hope things will return to normal soon."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: The next day

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Seven years had passed since that morning breakfast, Lucy is now thirteen years old and getting ready to go to Witchbloom all girls boarding school to learn magic. She and Sean Knightley became boyfriend and girlfriend just last year. He is getting ready to go to Witchstone all boys boarding school to further hone his own magical skills. At least the two of them will be too busy to miss each other too badly.

Hannah had graduated from Witchbloom two years prior and Mel is a teacher there, I have heard rumors that she was dating someone. Hayley had married Paul Connors and is now living with him across town. Christina is now working with Samantha Forester, tracking down and policing the sale of magical artifacts and potions so they do not fall into the hands of normal people. Both of them had come a long way and my trust in them both is a little stronger... a little stronger.

Tim Towers is dating Tina Moon and Hannah has been dating Pi. He ironically did not transform, he instead became immune to magic. Tim's sister, Brooke is also going to Witchbloom this year, the teachers are going to have their hands full. Cassie has come a long way since Katie Thompson adopted her. She and her coven now help other young witches who go astray.

The Pharaoh's rings have all been collected and destroyed. The pieces have been melted down and used to make shield pendants. Instead of stealing magic, they now protect against it. Elvira said they would be used for normal friends of the royal family who are aware of magic.

Mom looked up from her journal and sighed seeing you wearing the Witchbloom school uniform. "You have come so far, sweetie." Tears forming, she said. "I am so proud of you."

"Don't get sentimental on me, mom." Blushing, you said. "You'll get me started."

Mom giggled before putting down her journal and standing up. "You have gone through a lot of adventures growing up." Hugging you, she said. "Just promise me you'll come back from this one too."

"I'm just going to school, mom." Bemused, you said. "You can be so weird at times."

Mom smiled but said nothing. She remembered the many adventures you had as John growing up into a fine young man and then the adventures you had as Lucy growing up all over again into a fine young woman. "Your adventures are not at an end, Lucy." Sighing, she thought. "They are just beginning."
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: seven years later...

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
You were pulled from your thoughts as Sean suddenly stopped, holding a hand back in a protective posture. "I do not recall seeing you enter at the gate, witch." In a guarded tone, he said. "Identify yourself."

You looked passed Sean and gasped seeing a familiar slender figure. "That's Lilly Sweetie!" Frightened, you screamed. "She's the one who attacked mommy!"

Lilly rose her hand, holding one of the Pharaoh's rings, and pointed it at you! Only she did not get to mutter a single word as Sean stomped the ground with one foot, shaking the entire hall the the point of knocking you, Hannah and Lilly off balance! He then charged Lilly, striking a hard blow against her jaw, sending her head reeling back! Lilly cursed before casting a spell but Sean had a shield up causing the spell to nothing more than push him back. "Stay out of this, boy!" Angry, Lilly hissed. "You are no match me!"

With that, she teleported passed him and tried to raise her ring at you again. You summoned a flame to your hand in defense, not knowing that was exactly what Lilly wanted. "I'll make you pay for hurting mommy!" Threatening, you screamed.

"That's right, child." With a smirk, Lilly said. "Use your magic against me."

You were about to do just that when Lilly suddenly let out a low yelp of surprise. Sean had grabbed her by the leg and literally threw her to the other end of the hall! "I don't have to beat you, witch!" Strongly, he countered. "I just have to stall you!"

As if on cue, grandpa Moriarty appeared between Sean and Lilly, looking furious. "I warned you, witch..." Darkly, he boomed.

Moriarty raised his fist as if to do something only Lilly vanished with her mad laughter echoing into the hall. Moriarty huffed then turned to Sean. "Take my granddaughters back to their mother then join me." Angry, he ordered. "I want every hall, every room searched!"

"Yes, Master Strange." Bowing quickly, Sean replied. He turned to you and Hannah. "This way, quickly and no back talk. This is serious."

Frightened by your encounter with Lilly, you and Hannah obeyed immediately and were escorted back to mom in the dinning hall where a large number of witches and witch boys had appeared to guard them...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: The power of a witch boy.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Mom called Hayley to ask if all was well at home and frowned. "Slow down, Hayley." Patiently, she said. "I can hardly understand what you are saying."

You exchanged startled looks with Hannah. It was very rare that Hayley was so upset she would talk too quickly for mom to follow. You both watched as mom's frown deepened before she let out a low sigh. "Tell your aunt Catherine we will be back as soon as we can."

"Trouble at home?" Concerned, Gwen asked.

"It's my nephew, Tim." Frowning, mom replied. "He is suddenly acting unusual and my sister cannot detect any magic as the cause only combat magic is not her cup of tea."

"You suspect a curse?" Raising an eyebrow, Gwen asked.

"I try not to make any conclusions until after I look over the situation." Patiently, mom said. "Tim had a firm belief that all witches were bullies, out to destroy all men. Only he has suddenly changed his position to the complete opposite." She sighed. "If this is a personality spell effecting him then it could backfire in a very dangerous way."

Gwen nodded. "It could cement his belief and place him on a reckless crusade." Serious, she said. "I hope, for his sake, it is something more simple than that."

"As do I." Serious, mom said.

The ride home was quick but uncomfortable as both you and Hannah pondered over the many possibilities that could have changed Tim so quickly. Was he turned into a girl? Was he cursed? Beat up? You shook your head, trying not to jump to conclusions but it was hard not to as not knowing was the worst type of fear.

Upon returning home, mom entered the house to find Catherine with Tim who had an odd smile on his face, making a low sigh here and there as if he had been literally slapped silly. "How long has he been like this?" Kneeling down in front of him, mom asked.

"Since he got home last night." Wincing, Catherine said. "I had to go looking for him because he had run off from school."

Hannah winced at that then explained what had happened to lead to that only mom shook her head. "I highly doubt this is your doing, dear." Serious, she said. "I do detect magic but its not yours its from another witch." She sighed and turned to Catherine. "I fear your son, Tim had run into a siren witch."

Catherine sighed. "Oh boy...."

"What is a siren witch?" Confused, you asked.

"A siren is a mythical mermaid like creature found in ancient Greek mythology that was said to be able to lure men to their doom with the sound of their singing voice." Serious, mom explained. "A siren witch is typically a young witch who has the power to swoon or hypnotize boys and men with either their words or song."

"Most of the time, it is a form of defense." Serious, Catherine added. "To lure boys away from her or others when she feels threatened."

"Um... how long will he be like that?" Worried, you asked.

"Normally, the effect wears off in a few hours." Becoming bemused, mom replied. "However, in extreme rare cases, the one effected truly falls in love."

You and Hannah reacted the same way. "Ew!"

"The point is we need to find this siren witch." Serious, Catherine said. "It is quite possible she does not know she has this power."

Mom nodded. "I agree."

Hours later...
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.title: Music tames the savage Tim.

choices: She was no where in sight.
She was running down the street.
Mom had returned and caught her.
1113133213224114222111331211211222223322.content:
Just as one of the two rogues was about to make a move, a towering figure appeared from the shadows and confronted them. Christina shrieked and slowly stepped away from the figure but he ignored her completely, focusing upon the two women. Hayley gulped, feeling a heavy sense of dread as if death itself was near. Your eyes widened in surprise as your body started moving against your will. You sat peacefully on the bed and when your spoke again you found you couldn't bring yourself to yell or throw insults at the woman. "Where's Christina?"

"She's in her new bedroom, sleeping. I thought it best to keep you two separate until you both calm down a bit."

You shook your head. "I don't see much of a reason to be calm. You kidnapped us."

Elena's voice was sweet, filled with love which somehow made her scarier. "Oh, no. I didn't do that. I just took my daughters home. That's the right of any mother."

"You're not my Mom. My real mom will save me." You had to have faith in her.

"Natalie Harrison will never find this place. It's completely invisible to Witches I don't welcome here. Not even Samantha knows about it." She grinned as she grabbed a few tools and began to dab some sort of potion on your face. You tried to stop her but your body was still held in position by Elena's magic. You felt terrified.

"What are you doing?" you asked, trying to keep sounding brave.

Elena patted your head, presumably trying to be reassuring. "Just a dark magic spell to help you adjust. It won't hurt I promise and you'll feel much better afterwards."

"Mom will save me," you repeated, trying to reassure yourself.

1113133213224114222111331211211222223324.content:
Almost instantly, the potion on your forehead begins to feel warm and tingly. You fall back on the bed as this feeling begins to spread to your entire body. You can feel something changing, not obvious things, but subtle aspects. It felt weird, but not painful, but it still scared you. Everything feels similar, but also a little bit different. It was hard to tell exactly what though as your mind had trouble focusing. The spell seemed to be at work there too.

"What's...happening...to me?" you manage to ask through this overwhelming feeling.

Elena spoke softly in a comforting tone. "It's forbidden magic made to alter your DNA. I used strands of hair from myself and Samantha's late father to introduce our genetic code into your body. Right now, it's finding all your Harrison DNA and rewriting it as ours. It's going to feel strange for a minute."

You retained enough of you knowledge from biology class to understand what she was saying and it terrified you. Well, disturbingly there was a part of you that wasn't bothered by the idea and that part felt like it was growing. Your head started to feel like it was swimming getting harder and harder to think. You face showed the fear and confusion.

Elena reached out and took your hand, rubbing her thumb against it as she soothed you. You could remember Mo...Natalie Harrison doing something similar when you used to get sick or scared. "Shhhhh, this is the tough part, but your doing great. it'll all be over in a minute. You're so brave. My brave little girl." Strangely, you found her comforting to be...nice. Everything would be okay, you could get through this.

And just like that, it passed. The overpowering feeling in your body and mind were gone and you started to sit up, rubbing your head and trying to orient yourself again. "I'm...I'm okay now, Mommy," you said to reassure the woman sitting by your side. You quickly realized with surprise what you just called her. "Mommy..." You repeated, as if you weren't used to the idea. Indeed you weren't. You had thirteen years of memories of your mom being Natalie Harrison, but ever fiber of your being was telling you that your true mom was right next to you. She was the one who came in your mind when you though of your mom, and she was the one you felt love for. But it still felt strange. "Why am I calling you, Mommy?"

Elena smiled. "Because I am now. That's my blood coursing through your veins. There's not a hint of Harrison left in you." She nodded toward a full length mirror. "Go take a look."

Curiosity overtaking you, you sprang up and scrambled to the mirror. As you saw your new reflection, you mouth flew open. You were still a six-year-old little girl, but that was the only thing that looked the same about you. Gone was any trace of Harrison in your face. Instead, the face looking back at your reminded your of Elena Kruse and Samantha Forrester. Your hair was raven black and you had piercing green eyes. Freckles that use to be on your body were either moved or gone. A small birthmark had appeared on your ankle.

As you gazed into the mirror, studying your face carefully, you saw Elena come up behind you. She stood over you proudly. "I know it must be a weird feeling. And part of you is thinking that this isn't real. That I made you feel this way." You nodded hesitantly. The thought was crossing your mind. Elena continued. "I assure you that is not the case. I just altered your DNA. But one of your most notable character traits has also been your loyalty and protectiveness of family, and now, your family is me now, not the Harrisons." You nodded. Elena had taken one of your personality traits and found a way to use to her advantage. You knew that should anger you, but it didn't. You just felt unsure.

Elena knelt before you and smiled. "Do you still want Natalie to find you? "

You thought about it for a second, but then shook your head. "No, I don't feel any connection to her. Natalie doesn't feel like my Mom anymore. You do. And she'd try to separate us and I don't want that." You eyes teared up a bit at the thought. "I want to stay with you, Mommy." You jumped into her arms.

Elena patted you on the back, reassuring you. "Don't worry, sweetie. I won't let that happen. I know it will take some getting used to, but I promise you will come to love it here. And I promise I won't lie to you like Natalie did."

You nodded and wiped away your tears. "She did lie to me all the time. And she would always tell me who I should be."

Elena smiled. She knew Natalie's secrets had weakened the wall of trust you two had share. It wouldn't take much work to bring that wall crumbling down. You'd be so easy to mold. "Well, you don't have to be Lucy Harrison anymore."

You looked up at her. "Then, who am I?"

Elena turned you around so you faced the mirror again. "You are my youngest daughter, Tabitha Kruse." You couldn't help but smiled. The name sounded nice to you.

"Yes, Mommy. I am Tabitha." You repeated as you feel yourself begin to embrace your new identity.

Elena smiled. Lucy Harrison was gone. Tabitha Kruse was born.

"There are laws for the use of magic and breaking the law will bring swift punishment once you are caught. This court is adjourned!"

You knew you couldn't saw anything resembling the truth. 'Tell her that we're uncomfortable wearing these overalls'
 the voice suggested.

1113321323323131121321212112312122222221.content:
Megan's concern for you grew as she seemed to sense the conflict through your wavering eyes. "Lucy, I have known you since you were born." In a motherly tone, she said. "You can't hide anything from me."

"Part of that is true enough." Pouting, you thought. Then you whispered, "I'm hearing voices in my head; its dwiving me cwazy."

Christina winced at that, knowing that you were near the breaking point despite being able to relax a little earlier that day. Megan sighed patiently and asked, "What is this voice saying to you?"

"She wants me to be vewy girlie." Tearing up, you said. "It's not me..."

Megan smiled slightly, looking at both you and Christina. "You know that Hannah is the ultimate princess type, right?" Softly, she asked. You and Christina nodded. "You also know that Mel is a bit indecisive and that Hayley is a bit of a tomboy."

"Yeah, so..." Your girl voice blurted out.

Megan giggled. "You two look up to your older sisters but you can't be like all of them at once." Bemused, she said. "Hannah got into trouble, assuming she is the 'princess' and can do anything she wants when she wants."

"I warned her she'd get into twouble." Frowning, you said.

"That's not the point, Lucy." Patiently, Megan said. "The point is don't try to be just like your older sisters; just be yourselves." She touched your nose, forcing a giggle to escape your lips. "That voice in your head is likely that small part of you that wants to be just that but its better to simply be you, a unique individual unlike anyone else."

Before you could stop yourself, you asked, "How do I do that?"

Megan laughed. "You do that by not over thinking what you are doing." Amused, she replied. "Just do what you think is right for a girl your age." She held up the small cheer uniform. "It's not going to bite you and there are no boys around to peek under it. You will never know if you like or don't like anything unless you try it."

You sighed, knowing Megan had a point. "You never back down, do you?" Pouting, you said.

Megan winked at you. "A girl can't back down, Lucy." Confident, she said. "If I did, I would not be cheer captain now instead of that bi... err, bad girl, Kristy Hart."

You could not help giggle. Kristy Hart was the queen bitch cheer captain until she graduated last year and moved on to college. Megan got bumped up to cheer captain almost immediately after. Still, you were not certain about wearing a cheer uniform but you decided to humor Megan for nothing else than avoiding an argument.
1113321323323131121321212112312122222221.title: continue

1113321323323131121321212112312122222221.content:
Albeit reluctantly, you walked into the bathroom and changed into the child's cheerleader uniform. It looked just like Megan's with a red and blue stripped pleated skirt and a blue blouse with red stripes down the side under the short sleeves. You stepped out and caught Christina grinning at you. "It looks good on you, sis." Teasing, she said. "You'd make a great cheerleader."

You were about to protest but stopped and grinned yourself as Megan produced an identical uniform from the same bag. "I'm glad you like it, Christina." Smiling, she said. "Because I got you one too."

You giggled at that. "Yay! We're going to be jeer leaders!"

Christina smirked, noticing that you emphasized the word, jeer. "This might be fun after all."

Megan giggled. "That's cheerleader." Bemused, she said. "Still, yes, we do tend to lovingly mock the rival team in our cheers."

Minutes later, you and Christina were practicing cheers with Megan. Only you were both inwardly cheering on the 'home' team in your mental battle to keep what was left of your former selves. "Go Boys, Go!" You and your sister cheered. "B! O! Y! S! Go Boys!"

Megan shook her head, "You two are only five years old." Lightly scolding, she said. "Boys should be the last thing on your minds."

"It's all Mel talks about." Wrinkling your nose, you said.

Megan grinned. "Ah! You're being sarcastic." She laughed. "Let's try a cheer that won't get you into an argument with your sisters, okay?"

You and Christina nodded then watched as Megan did a cheer. "Our team is great, the least in the fleet! Save yourself face and admit defeat!"

"Not bad..." Applauding, you thought.

"Now you two try a cheer." Standing aside, Megan said. "Keep it simple but make it loud and proud, from the heart, use your imaginations."

You smiled, knowing a good cheer. It was one you had cooked up for Megan to stick it to Kristy when she was the cheer captain. You found it fitting to stick it to the girl voice, trying to take away all that was left of who you once were. "I am who I am, not who you want me to be! Waving your pom poms, you yelled. "My defense is strong! Come at me and see!"

Megan giggled. "That would have been a great cheer to throw at Kristy Hart." Bemused, she muttered. Then she said, "That was good, Lucy! I think you're getting the hang of it!"

You and Christina smiled at each other, knowing you now had a discrete way to vent out your frustrations without looking like whinny little girls...

Elsewhere...

Before you could tell Hannah that her 'help' was freaking you out and accelerating your change, you felt tired. Extremely tired, which you instinctively knew was magic related. "Before you ask, I haven't done anything. You knew if you're stressed, you'd get more like the girly girl you really are, and you're just starting to see your new true form."

"I know what I want to be. I want to be a pretty girl. Stop changing my words, you thupid poop head!. I'm going to teach you a lesson you won't forget. This is my life you're ruining!"

At those words, you woke up. The first thing you saw was Robyn standing over you. She was still in her school uniform, looking concerned. "I knew this would happen. All victims of the sugar and spice suffer though it. I hope it wasn't too scary."

"You still should have warned cootie brain even though it would have freaked her out...." It was Trina

"We're going to be blunt with you, Lucy." Serious, Trina said. "You only got a partial dose of the sugar and spice which is the only reason you were able to separate the boy you from the girl you."

"What about Christina?" Wincing, you demanded.

"Harry was the initial target." Chiming in, Robyn said. "He got the full dose but his biological parents are immune to magic." She frowned. "They went after him to get at his parents who had busted them and their parents for rogue activities."

"Hence the use of sugar and spice." Frowning, Trina said. "You were attacked second because you got too close to figuring out their little scheme."

"The partial dose of sugar and spice you would have beaten by now." Serious, Robyn said. "The curse gave it a power boost, so to speak. The same curse broke through Christina's immunity defense."

"So what is with the voice in my head?" Morbidly curious, you demanded.

"That is where it gets complicated." Sitting down, Trina said. "Every witch boy and girl has a mental state and a magical state. The girl voice inside your head is your magical state who has been trying to coach you through this from within."

This shocked you. "What?!"

"You speak from inside out." Serious, Robyn said. "The girl voice who kept interrupting your thoughts and changing your words is the magic of the sugar and spice trying to worm its way in. So far, it has transformed your magical state into a tomboy. That, by the way, is whom you assumed was the 'girl' trying to destroy your life."

"The sugar and spice potion was designed to completely change the physical and mental state of a witch who had gone mad or unruly." Calmly, Trina explained. "It's basically a more powerful version of the reset potion; dubbed the girl maker."

"Right now, you are fighting yourself, Lucy." Serious, Robyn said. "That is why the sugar and spice is slowly taking over." She sighed. "You got lucky this time but luck doesn't last."

"The only way you will have a chance to keep what it left of your memories and core beliefs is to allow your mental state and magical state to join forces." Sternly, Trina said. "Unless, of course you wish to have a split personality and a double life like me."

You shuddered at the thought. "How do I make this happen?" Worried, you pleaded.

Robyn turned to Trina who nodded. "You need to start listening to the voice in your head." Serious, she explained. "However, you need to separate her voice from the sugar and spice."

"Okay..." Nervous, you said. "Easier said than done..." You stopped mid sentence as a thought came to you, one you did not notice before now. "The voice in my head often changes in tone. One minute she is serious while the next she is sickly sweet."

"Of course!" Smiling, Robyn said. "That was why the potion was dubbed sugar and spice! The invading magic had a sickly sweet tone, almost like a..."

"Like a princess." Your eyes narrowing, you said. A steel like glint formed in your eye. "Now I have some ammunition to fight back with."

"Go get her, tigress." Smirking, Trina said.

With that, the two vanished from the room with a dull flash.

"You may have figured out who I am but it won't save you now." Sweetly, a voice said. "You will be a girlie girl in body and mind."


"It won't save you either, brat princess." came the voice you now recognized as your magic. "A princess we will be but not the kind you think."

A smile came to your face; the first genuine one in a long time. "Okay... its the end of the half and the visiting team has most of the points." Serious, you thought. "Let's show this intruder how we Harrisons fight as a team."

"I hope I did not wake you, sis." Calmly, a male voice said. It was her brother, Jack.

"No; you didn't." Tiredly, she said. "Still, its been a long night."

"Sarah told me." Sighing, Jack said. He took a breath. "I pulled a few favors and got some news."

"Lucy and Christina, formally John and Harry both had numerous run ins with a notorious family of witches known as the Banes." Darkly, Jack said. "This was when they were both completely unaware of magic; meaning no action other than verbal warnings were taken."

"How do you know this?" Worried, mom demanded. "Why was I not informed?"

"Sarah works for the D.D.M.C; Department of Dark Magic Control." Serious, Jack explained. "No witch laws were broken in any of the incidents but they were still noted in case either boy might seek retribution upon learning the secret."

"Okay..." Frustrated, mom said. "What did these incidents entail?"

"It was different for both boys." Calmly, Jack said. "For 'Harry', it was his collection of magical artifacts. You must know that the huge collection he possessed would be a tempting prize for any witch, rogue or otherwise." He sighed. "There were many attempts made to buy his collection and even to steal it. However, because of his family's immunity and where he lived..."

"All discrete attempts to acquire the collection failed." Feeling a headache coming, mom said. "Did they seek revenge then?"

"They hired the two rogue hunter drop outs to go after the collection by any means necessary." Startling mom, Jack replied. "We found physical evidence to back it up, linking this family to the crime."

"They took the job because they had a beef with that family to start out with." Pale, mom said. "Stealing such a collection from a non magical boy could be seen as an attempt to save him."

"That and, if successful, they could have made his parents look bad under witch law for allowing such a collection as it could have made him a witch against his will." Annoyed, Jack said. "This family is bad news, Natalie."

"What about about Lucy?" Wincing, mom asked.

"We believe Lucy, formally John, was a personal matter." Darkly, Jack replied. "The eldest daughter of that family is into girls and has a record of transforming boys into girls so to add to her list of conquests in the form of girlfriends." He huffed. "We have evidence that she had made many attempts to seduce John but you know he only had eyes for Megan Thompson."

Mom gasped. "Do you think this family may go after her next?" Worried, she asked.

"It's hard to say." Serious, Jack said. "Just say the word, sis. Sarah and I can be on our way to you with Lu and the boys at a minute's notice." He let out a low chuckle. "We haven't had a full family reunion in a while anyway."

Mom giggled slightly, touched by her brother's concern. He was not immune to magic but his resistance to it was insane as was his three sons. His daughter, Lu was only seven but was as powerful as Mel magic wise. Sarah, she was Samantha Forester's younger sister. That, unfortunately made Samantha mom's sister in law. As if on cue, the doorbell rang. Mom sighed, preparing herself, and answered the door. She had not liked or trusted Samantha for various reasons, all of them going years back. However, she conceded her older brother's point, Samantha Forester was very knowledgeable when it came to gender spells and witch law.

Samantha was tall and slender with shoulder length strawberry blond hair and fire hazel eyes. She had come wearing casual jeans and a loose fitting blouse. This surprised mom as she usually always wore dresses or skirts. "I had been looking into Lucy and Christina's case ever since I was named a likely suspect in the magical attacks against your family." Annoyed, Samantha said. She showed mom a medical bag she had been carrying. "Now that we have strong evidence that the Bane family is involved, I believe I can determine how they are continuing to torment your daughters and put a stop to it."

"They are in their bedroom." Motioning to follow her, mom said. "This way."

Samantha followed mom into yours and Christina's bedroom and looked around before pulling a short wand out of the bag and pointed it various objects in the room. Frowning, she placed the wand back in her bag before taking out various viles of different colored liquids. She had you sniff a number of them and ask if you remembered smelling them before. Mom watched as Samantha conducted a number of tests before finally standing up to face her. "We need to talk in your study." Serious, she said.

Mom nodded and lead Samantha to her private study where she closed the door and cast a privacy spell to ensure no one would listen in. "What did you find?" Patiently, mom demanded.

"The Banes are using a back door approach to attack your daughters." With distaste, Samantha replied. "They are making themselves appear to be just like the sugar and spice potion by magically attacking their subconscious minds."

"That explains their unusual high potential for magic." Thoughtful, mom said. "Magical attacks at the subconscious level causes their own magic to build defenses against it, increasing their power."

"That's why such practices are highly illegal." Fuming, Samantha said. "Although it makes it all but impossible for the target boy to fight back with his will or wits, it transforms him into a powerful witch."

"There has to be a way to combat this!" Angry, mom said. "If I know my mother, Elvira, charges have already been pressed against them but that has not stopped them... yet."

Samantha sighed. "The Bane family is currently on the run." Serious, she said. "However, there is a way to fight this. You are just not going to like it."

"How did I know you were going to say that?" Annoyed, mom demanded.

Samantha shook her head. "This is not the time for us to fight, Natalie." Sternly, she said. "Lucy and Christina are suffering and need our help."

Mom conceded her point. "You're right." More calmly, she said. "What must we do?"

Samantha frowned and said, "We must..."

After much deliberation with Samantha, mom was persuaded to send both you and Christina to Hannah's ballet class. Hannah told her instructor, Miss Terra Swanson that you and your twin sister had daymares and thought ballet might help them. "They have been dealing with it by talking back to their nightmares as if they were a person trying to get a rise out of them." Worrisome, Hannah explained.

"That's unique." Smiling slightly, Tera said. She turned to you and Christina. "Ballet requires a lot of focus, you can't allow your mind to wander while you are dancing on your tip toes. Otherwise, you might trip up or twist an ankle."

"You make a cute ballerina." Giggling, the voice said. "Maybe you'll get a solo in the recital."

"I'm more cute than you'll ever be." Taunting back, you whispered. "I likely dance better too."

Terra looked at you, confused then grinned seeing Christina frown slightly. Hannah saw this as well and giggled, though she felt nervous. "The LC twins are seriously competitive."

Terra giggled. "I can see that." Bemused, she said. "In my class, we work as a team; is that clear?"

You and Christina nodded though you had a slight grin as you heard the voice respond, rather annoyed. "You are so not cuter than me! I will make you a cute girl though!"

You felt a wave of relief, not to mention a certain satisfaction. "So, you are not me, as you had claimed!" Angry, you thought. "You're another witch! Who are you?!"

"That's for me to know and you to find out... after I'm done with you." Smugly, the voice retorted. "I out class you by a mile; you can't hold a candle against me!"

"Forget the candle, I carry a flame thrower!" Grinning, you thought back. "You are like a haggish disease; once you give it a name, you can fight it no matter how bad it is."

"You smug little rugrat!" Angry, the voice thundered. "No one calls Cassie Bane a hag!"

You smiled from ear to ear and turned to Christina. Having heard the voice, she smiled as well. "Hook, line, and sinker."

You giggled at that then thought, "Why are you hiding, Cassie Bane? Are you afraid of a little girl?"

The voice screamed then fell silent. That was enough of a victory for you at the moment; you and Christina now knew who you were dealing with.

**************************************************************************** ********************************************

Elsewhere, in an isolated cabin somewhere, Cassie Bane huffed as she turned away from a crystal ball. She was Hayley's height with shoulder length auburn hair and piercing green eyes. She was still in her girl's school uniform, wanting some fun after school. Only she cringed as a hand viciously slapped her across the face. It was her mother, Darla Bane, a near duplicate of her but with dark blue eyes. "You arrogant, prideful, sloppy bitch!" Furious, she screamed. "It's bad enough that you botched obtaining the largest artifact collection to date! Now you just blurt out your name to the two girls who 'got in your way'?!"

"It just came out!" Defending herself, Cassie wailed.

A second slap sent her head reeling back. "Lucy and Christina are daughters of one of the most magically powerful families in existence!" Screaming, Darla Scolded. "You heard what happened to those two amateurs we hired who got caught! What do you think will happen to us?" Suddenly, she smiled, much like a python would to a rat. "Then again..."

"You have a plan, mom?" Hopeful, Cassie demanded.

Darla raised a dramatic hand to her forehead. "Oh, Cassie, where did I go wrong?!" Sarcastically, she declared. "My eldest daughter gone insane... butting heads with the family of the head witch..."

Cassie's jaw dropped as she realized her mother fully intended to make her the escape goat. "You can't seriously be considering throwing your own daughter under the bus!"

"Well, you did orchestrate most of the operation." With an evil smile, Darla said. "I was merely playing the role of a loving mother, blind to your true selfish intentions."

Cassie screamed in anger and ran from the room, grabbing the crystal ball as she did.

**************************************************************************** *******************************************

Back to Hannah's ballet class, you and Christina had joined the class, trying a few moves they had been practicing when the voice, you now knew as Cassie, returned. "Lucy, you got to help me!" Almost pleading, she said.

"Why would I help you?" Annoyed, you thought. "After all you did to me..."

"Please, Lucy!" Desperate, Cassie begged. "Hear me out, I was forced to do this!"

You excused yourself from practice, saying you needed to use the restroom and walked to the washroom where you sighed then replied....

"Mom, we need a break from everything!" Stomping one foot, you blurted out. "You know what we've been put through with that Bane family! Give us a break!"

You really did not want either one but at least mom gave you a week to think it over rather than force you as the Bane family did when they were tormenting you and your new twin sister. "Okay, mommy." Still pouting, you said. "We'll play with Lily for a while."

Mom smiled. "Good girl."

Twenty minutes later, you and Christina were dropped off at Lily's house to find she had everything set up for a slumber party. You turned to your sister who seemed just as surprised. "Do you think mom knew about this?" Whispering, she asked.

You sighed. "If I didn't know better, I'd say she set it up." Pouting, you whispered back.

Lily walked up to you two, smiling. "It seems as if the order for our cheer uniforms are back ordered for a week." Shrugging, she said. "At least the coach only allowed Kristy on as an adviser rather than an assistant because of too many complaints against her last year."

That made you feel slightly better. "We were not expecting a slumber party." Honestly, you said. "We didn't bring any night clothes."

"Then what are those?" Pointing at the door, Lily asked.

You and Christina turned to find two small overnight bags by the door, each with a tag with yours and Christina's name on them. "Mom strikes again." Sighing, you muttered.

"She seems to be always ten steps ahead of us, doesn't she?" Wincing, Christina asked.

"That's a mother's job, girls." Came a feminine voice.

You and your sister turned to find a short, plump woman entering the room. "I am Dina Moore, Lily's mother; it is a pleasure to meet you two." She then giggled. "You need to remember that your mother was also a little girl at one point. She has tried everything you two have and likely more."

You winced at that but decided not to press the subject. "It's a pleasure to meet you, Mrs Moore."

"Please, Dina." Smiling, Dina said. "What do you say we get this slumber party off the ground?"
