Turning to your hand, you saw Harry in the form of a kitten purring away. He looked up at you and gave a happy meow which somehow melted your heart.

"Did you hide away in my overnight bag?" Smiling, you whispered.

Harry replied with a meow and began liking and rubbing his face on your hand as he purred, wanting your attention. You could not help giggle at your magical pet, now in the form of an adorable kitten. You found it ironic that he had the same coloration as the spider you once knew and eventually feared. It had taken on a new form which you could not help love. You were about to pull Harry in for a hug when you were startled by a chorus of all the girls cooing, "Aw! How cute!"

Instinctively, you pulled Harry into your arms and jumped away. This only brought on more coos and giggles from the girls. "It looks like the big bad tomboy has a soft spot for cuddly kittens."Half giggling, Becky teased. "Who is your friend? How did he get here?"

You could not hide the fact you were blushing so so turned away slightly. "This is Harry." Softly, you said. "He's easily hurt and frightened; he needs me."

"Grandma gave him to her to keep her calm." Using the panic attack angle Dina used earlier, Christina said. "She sort of freaks out easily since someone..." She stopped herself before wincing and throwing you an apologetic glance. You responded with an impatient glare but sighed when the girls looked at you with a sense of sympathy.

"Someone did something bad to you, Lucy?" Worried, Lily asked.

"A bunch of bullies went after Lucy and I a few months ago." Truthfully, Christina explained. "They got me good but they hurt Lucy worse." She teared up. "Calling us mean names, following us around, threatening us with getting hurt or taken away...." She sighed, fighting her own tears. "Now, because of those bullies, Lucy thinks she always has to be the 'tough girl' and stand alone."

"So Harry keeps her calm by giving her someone to protect." With a sad look, Becky said. "I can't imaging going through that."

"Were the bullies caught?" Concerned, Zoe demanded.

"My whole family worked hard to track them down and they get arrested." Tearfully you said. Still... I don't ever want to feel that scared again."

You then began to cry, petting Harry for whatever comfort you could get. Falling to your knees, Christina knelled down and pulled you into a hug. Lily, Becky, Emily, and Zoe quickly joined in as you cried out your frustrations. In a way, it felt good to talk about what had happened to you even though it was a half truth and you were glad to find that kindergarten kids had a better grasp of what you were going through.

"You never need to stand alone, Lucy." Entering the living room, Dina said. "I heard every word; what you and Christina went through was terrible. I would be on my guard after that too." She then smiled. "Only try surrounding yourself with friends rather than pushing them out."

"She already is surrounded by friends." Grinning, Emily said.

The others giggled, causing you to blush more. Harry meowed his approval, making you giggle as well.

The first person to run up to you was the principal, Ms Julia Thorn who you noticed was also wearing a flattering prom gown though she did not look thrilled at all to be wearing it. She pointed to her office with a stern look on her face. "We need to talk, Miss Harrison." Firmly, she said. "Please step into my office."

You sighed, sensing magic, and walked into Julia's office and sat down as she walked around her desk and took a seat herself. "Changing the school girl uniform into a prom dress like your own was an interesting choice... princess." Frowning, she said. "However, this move is a double edged sword."

"What- What do you mean?" Worried, you demanded.

"Your move proved that you are resourceful and can think quickly." Motioning to her own dress, Julia said. "It also proved that your magic is very powerful as it also changed the dress code for the female teachers as well and if it were no for the non-interference rule behind the princess test..."

"I didn't do this on purpose!" Defending yourself, you protested. "All I wanted was not to look stupid wearing a prom dress to school."

"Then you need to learn to control your magic, young lady if you want the results of the tests to of your own will rather than your own power controlling you." Darkly, Julia countered. "Normally, I am not permitted to interfere with the test but I have a loop hole."

"A loop hole?" Confused, you asked.

Julia nodded. "It is part of my job to guide all students, witch or normal, through the struggles of school life." Serious, she said. "This test is one of those struggles so I am permitted to give you advice and a few helpful hints when you need them."

"Any advice about the change I just made?" Wincing, you asked.

Julia smiled. "Don't make any changes until after you have some rest." Bemused, she replied. "Magic is very draining; I can't have you falling asleep in class. Also, try not to use magic in class, it will only bring you trouble; all young witches learn this the hard way." She motioned to the door. "You better get to your first class, Miss Harrison.

1113321323323131121321212112312122233131.content:
The rest of your day at school was one of the oddest of your life. Having every female looking like she was going to the prom was bad, but with a few exceptions, it was even more unnerving to see nearly everyone, including the guys, thinking it was normal. You was glad to get out of there, especially as Cassie spent a good part of lunch staring at you. Another was more friendly, but still unnerving; how could Megan figure things out?

"If I have to go to school tomorrow looking like this, I'm going to strangle you, 'Lucy' Do you have any idea how hard it was to do any sports wearing this?" Megan said crossly the minute she, you and Mel was alone.

"What..." you said, surprised.

"What do you expect? That I wouldn't notice when one of my friends grew breasts?" Megan said.

You was stunned into silence; How did Megan perceive that truth? For the entire day, she had been acting like there wasn't anything wrong. Plus, why wasn't she freaking out? You certainty did.

"Mel told me two days ago. She then told me about your miss-adventure last night" Megan said.

"What? You know you're not supposed to tell anyone. You didn't even tell me, little miss witch" you angrily turned on your sister.

"Like, don't be such a princess. I totally did it for her protection. You saw that Cassie stare at you, and trust me, she is so into you" Mel pouted.

"Its true, John. I'm your closest female friend, and Mrs H...." Megan started, but you felt upset.

"You're saying mom allowed you to know? Why didn't she tell me? Why didn't you tell me? I.. I can't deal with this..." you said, almost incoherently.

"Relax, you're not used to being a teen girl, Lu. Calm down, head to my house and we'll talk. Mom won't have any issues since we're both girls" Megan said, giggling slightly.

"Okay, but I want everything you know. Plus any thoughts on how to get rid of these damn gloves" you said.

1113321323323131121321212112312122233131.content:
Meanwhile, back at home, mom walked up to Christina with a small vile of a strange liquid in her hand. "Christina, this is called a suppression potion." Gently, she said. "It's original purpose was to strip a witch of her magic until the antidote was given."

"Are you guessing that potion will rid me of the magic I have been absorbing?" Worried, Christina asked.

Mom nodded, her face serious. "That is exactly right; I am guessing." Flatly, she replied. "There are some risks involved as this was never used to reverse a critical magic build up in a non witch boy."

"What?!" Alarmed, Christina demanded. "I'm not going to be some beta tester for alternative uses of a potion!" She paused, looking desperate. "What are the risks, anyway?"

"It could remove the magic keeping you a girl and allow me to change you back to normal." Serious, mom said. "However, as it was made for girls... witches, it could trap you as a normal little girl and you would have to grow up again into womanhood."

Christina began to shake. "You said critical build up." Gulping, she whispered. "Does that mean..."

Mom nodded. "You are now fully female with the powers of a witch." In a forced calm, she replied. "Your first test flame could ignite any second and that would seal your fate." She held up the vile. "It is this or you embrace your new life as a first witch due to your magic addiction."

"So, it's all or nothing at this point." Pouting, Christina said.

Mom sighed. "There is another option but its a long shot; you could live with Megan and her mother for the next six months." Ruefully, she said. "As long as you do not use your magic, it may deplete enough to change you back to normal."

Christina sighed. "How long do I have to decide?"

Mom winced. "Sorry, Christina but I need your answer now; we are out of time and your options are quickly running out."

Christina bit her lip, wondering what to do.

Elvira nodded. "You see, Christina, you come from a long blood line of people who are immune to magic." Sitting down, she began. "However, although the magic does not effect them, they still absorb the magical energy and that is accumulative."

"You were already gaining resistance to magic before you were born, Christina." Smiling slightly, Elvira said. "Only you happened to be the generation in your family to become the first witch."

"Your mom and dad are fully aware of magic, Christina." Calmly, Elvira added. "Your mom is not a witch, just immune to magic, as is your father." She frowned. "They have already been informed that they now have a daughter who is a witch."

"This isn't enough stress?" Exasperated, you demanded.

Elvira sighed. "You used your powers to solve your problem but created a problem for others." Firmly, she pointed out. "I understand that it was not an intentional spell but part of this test is to see how well you fix your mistakes as well as make your decisions work."

"What is the goal of it all?" Pouting, you demanded. "What does this test prove?"

Mom sighed. "The goal is to find your balance, be who you truly are." Calmly, she replied. "The test proves that you don't always know which direction to take when you are the one making the path."

On the other side of the room, Mel laid in her own bed, unable to sleep. Unknown to you, mom also talked to her in private before bed.

"If you had a rivalry with another witch at school, you should have come to me." Scolding, mom had said. "Training yourself, regardless of the reason, is not only irresponsible, it is dangerous."

She shook her head. "He still might change, depending upon how many of those items he kept for his personal collection of oddities."

Mel frowned, remembering her talk with mom and looked at you, apparently asleep with your back turned to you in a separate bed on the other side of the room. "Of all the rotten luck!" Annoyed, she muttered under her breath. "Harry just had to find the one magic book with a broken cover lock."

You both jumped as your cellphone rang. Irritated, you looked at the number; it was not one you recognized and rolled over intending to ignore it. Only the phone answered on its own and you heard a voice coming from the phone.

"Hello, John dear." Sweetly, a voice said. "I heard you had an encounter with the feminine kind." The voice giggled at her own joke. "Tell me, what new name did they give you?"

"Who is this?" Highly annoyed, you demanded. "How did you get my number, how did you get my phone to answer your call?"

Mel, hearing the feminine voice, jumped from her bed and hurried over to you. She recognized the voice as her rival, Cassie Bane from school. She intended to stop the call before Bane could answer but was not fast enough.

"Why I'm your new best friend." Amused, Cassie replied. "I got your number off of your sister's notebook; the poor thing has so little brain, she simply has to write everything down." She giggled then added, "I am Cassie Bane, a fellow witch. I used a simple spell to make your phone answer my call. I would like to talk to you about many things..."

"What do you want, Bane?" Coldly, Mel demanded.

"You two are sharing a room?" Genuinely surprised, Cassie asked. She laughed. "Well, this is awkward. I was hoping for a private call."

"What do you want?" Ice in your voice, you demanded. "I'm not in a good mood."

"Still grumpy in the morning, deary?" Teasing, Cassie asked. "All I want is to help you embrace your new found womanhood." She gave a cackle. "Poor Melanie has not a clue though she was ironically born a girl. Such a plain, ordinary, dismal wall flower..."

Mel turned red at Cassie's casual insults and was about to throw a few insults of her own only you surprised her by talking first. "Listen up you smug, arrogant, pompous nobody!" Angry, you said. "Melanie and I might not always get along but she is my sister and I will not have you insult her in my presence!"

With that, you picked up a three inch heel shoe mom had earlier transformed from a pair of your tennis shoes and drove the thin heel hard onto the phone, breaking it and ending the call. Once Cassie's voice had been silenced, you turned to Mel. "I want answers, sis!" More concerned than annoyed, you said. "Who is this Cassie Bane, what does she have against you, and why have you not told me about this when I was still your brother?"

Too bad, you are one" mom said, getting out of bed. She seized your tiny hand and started pulling you away. "Where are you taking me?"

"What caused it?" you asked in a shaky voice.

"Simple. Your temper, Lucy. You must learn to control your temper, granddaughter" Elvira gently scolded you.

You took several deep breaths. "Okay. Please, can you stop treating me like I'm a girl? And can you bring me Melanie? I promise I'll have a friendly talk"

"You are a girl. Even to the genetic level. As for your twin, I don't know whether she left the book out."

"What do you mean?" you said as another surge of anger swept through you. Mercifully, you flame didn't reignite.

"If Mel did it, it would had been out of carelessness, not a desire to have a so called true twin, but there are several other possibilities. You know how Hannah is good sneaking. She could have seen the book, and since she doesn't know what it does...." Elvira warned.

"Okay. I get it? Who else could have done this to me? Mom? Does she want an all girl family?" you hissed.

"If Natalie wanted that, she would have changed you openly like Jacinta. I think Tim must had gotten his hands on the book. I know he knows about magic ever since he was scared half to death by our 'friend' Samantha Forester" Elvira said.

"What?" you said. The idea that you girl taunting cousin could have done this to you angered you more than the idea of Mel possibly having done the deed, and learning that the creepy woman at the mall was a witch shook you badly. "When will you know?"

"In about ten minutes. In the meantime, there are a few things I need to tell you. Like I said, you're biologically female now, and you can get pregnant....." Elvira said, as she started to give you the talk, much to your extreme embarrassment and discomfort.
It ended ten minutes later, and Elvira gave a thin smile as she saw the message that had flashed onto her study's computer.

.
1151211211.title: Ask about who did this to you

choices: You find a quiet place to think.
11512112112.content:
Elvira gave you a thin smile. "It was Hannah. I can only assume she found the book in Melanie's room and took it to see what it was." She shook her head. "As she is too young to work magic, the pages would appear to be blank; she likely tossed it aside, uninterested."

You sighed, frustrated. "Where I later found it."

Elvira shook her head, seeing tears forming in your eyes. "There is no way for any of us to change you back to who you once were as it would be unfair to you."

This both surprised and startled you. "Unfair?"

Elvira nodded. "You see, magic can not change a person's gender and or age back and forth as easily as hitting a light switch. It causes a certain shock to the body, even slow transformations; just measure your level of stress right now."

Although reluctantly, you had to admit what Elvira said made sense. "Can I ever be changed back?"

Elvira smiled. "Only you can change yourself back. However, that requires learning magic and that is where we have the double edged sword."

"Are you telling me that this magic is addictive?" The thought was disturbing to you.

Elvira nodded, maintaining her thin smile. "You are very perceptive, Lucy. Yes, the more you use magic, the more you will be tempted to keep it and that requires you remaining a girl." She sighed. "However, if your will is strong enough, you can learn enough magic to change yourself back into a boy."

You pouted. " Only the temptation to use magic will still be there."

Elvira again nodded. "Correct. Eventually, the temptation will get the best of you; each time it does, your chances of regaining your male state becomes less and less."

You slowly sat down onto a chair, covering your face with your hands. "All of this because of a book..."

Elvira rose from her seat behind her desk and approached you with a bemused smile. "You might not believe this now but you were lucky it happened this way."

You shot your head up at Elvira but paused, realizing what she was referring to. "You mean I could have been changed by mom or one of my sisters."

Elvira touched your shoulder with her slender hand. "It would have been harder on you if it had happened that way as your trust in them would have been strained." She smiled again. "This way, there is no one to blame other than your own curiosity. I suggest you think long and hard on what you wish to do."

You sighed. "You mean if I want to fight this and regain my manhood or accept that I'm a girl for life and learn magic."

Elvira shook her head. "No, you need to decide if you are going search someone to blame or accept that things just happen and roll with the punches."

She then opened the door to her office and bid you to return to your dorm.
11512112112.title: It was Hannah

115121121122.content:
You returned to your dorm, not knowing what to think of your new situation. Everything had happened so fast that you really had no time to give it any serious thought. A lot of emotions were running through your head including anger and fear only your confusion trumped them all. You say down on your assigned bed and asked the one question that haunted your mind. "Why did this happen to me?"

"Everyone who comes here asks that question, Miss Harrison." Startling you, a young woman said. "Even the girls ask that, not knowing what to think of their new found powers."

The young woman was tall and slender; professionally dressed. "Who are you?" Curious, you asked.

"I am Mrs Maria Porter." Kindly, the woman replied. "I am the head guidance councilor for Wicthbloom boarding school and it is my duty to help those who are having a rough transition here."

"All I did was look into an old book..." Sighing, you muttered. "How was I supposed to know it would turn me into this."

Maria smiled gently. "It was not the book that did it to you." Softly, she corrected. "It was your own dormant magic that brought about the change. Hence only you can change yourself back."

This startled you. "Are you telling me I changed myself?"

Maria slowly nodded. "You have magic within you, though it can not be used because you are a boy." Calmly, she explained. "However, certain conditions will bring it to the surface and change your gender to allow you to use magic."

"Like curiosity?" Raising an eyebrow, you asked.

Maria smiled. "Not just curiosity; wonderment."

Your eyes widened as you remembered slightly hoping that magic was real from the storybooks you had read to Hannah to occasionally help her fall asleep. "It was Hannah who left the book in the sitting room."

"Innocently left the book." Kindly, Maria stated. "Remember, the pages would be blank to her as well."

"Why was I left here?" Pouting, you asked. "Couldn't mom have taught me magic?"

"Mom sent you here so you could safely learn magic." Smiling, Maria replied. "You see, all boys born in witch families can develop a resistance to magic very quickly. However, for non-magical people, it takes anywhere from two to ten times longer."

You gasped at that. "Harry and Megan..."

"It is best that your friends be kept out of this for now." Gently, Maria said. "As for you, there is an entirely new world of opportunities open before you. Take your time to explore them as you learn magic and I promise you that you will see things in a whole new light."

Maria then left the room as your teacher entered, calling for everyone's attention.
115121121122.title: You get a visitor.

choices: Tim tells you that he only wanted you to protect him from the ugly old witch
Elvira sends Tim home before things get really ugly
11512112113.content:
"You're not going to like this, Lucy" Elvira said slowly.

"What? Did Melanie do this to me? Did she deliberately want me as her girl twin" you hissed as you folded your arms across your chest.

"No. Tim did this. He took Melanie's magic book and placed it where you'd find it" Elvira said.

"That doesn't make sense. How could that jerk even know about magic?" you ranted. Tim was your seven year old cousin, and just as much a pain as Hannah. Where Hannah was excessively girly, Tim was excessively girl taunting. While most kids his age feared and thought the opposite gender were alien life forms, Tim took it to the next level. The other thing about Tim was that he was smart; his taunts, while childish, annoying, and tiresome, were actually well thought out and somewhat clever. He even taunted you and Harry, as you could do what he couldn't; be friends with girls.

"Tim was over your house two nights ago, Lucy. He stole the book then" Elvira said. That was true; Tim and Hannah were reluctantly forced to work together on a school project. Not much work had occurred.

"That doesn't explain how he knows about magic" you snapped.

"Samantha Forester. I think you know who she is, granddaughter. She is a witch and quite an expert in gender transformations. I know Tim has had run ins with her in the past, and I think she has scared him badly. Why don't we find out?"

"Find out?" you spat out

Elvira smiled as she waved her hands. Even after everything, it was shocking to see your cousin appear from nowhere. Elvira must had teleported him from school.

"Where am I?" Tim said, stunned by the change of surroundings.

"Doesn't matter you little toad. YOU did this to me, and I want answers. NOW!" you said.

"Oh, hi. Jonnie. You look better like that" Tim said.

"If you like it, you can wear it" you snarled
11512112113.title: The cousin's trap

choices: A curse: he becomes a girl at night

Elvira doesn't tell, preferring to tell you to discover a way to find out
115121121133.content:
"No thanks. Just admit it. You've always wanted to wear pretty dresses and be one of the girls" Tim said, foolishly teasing you. He seemed to had forgotten that you yourself had magic powers, or that you could just as easily throttle him. You were planning on that, when Tim disappeared.

"Where did that little bastard go?" you snapped.

"I sent him home, Lucy. One other thing. Try toning down the language, young lady. It's unbecoming" Elvira said.

"You can't be serious. This isn't some 1950's finishing school! I can't believe you're letting him get away with murder" you protested.

"I sent him away before I saw it in your eyes. You wanted to strangle him, Lucy and while I strongly sympathize with you, I still have a duty of care for both the students here and any guests" Elvira scolded.

"What now?" you asked. You figured if Elvira could do a long range teleportation, you could place a long range curse onto him as well.

"The first thing is I need you to dump the idea of putting a long range spell onto him, Lucy. You'd have children of your own before you get sufficiently skilled to even try."

"C-children?" you stammered.

115121121133.title: Elvira sends Tim home before things get ugly

"Tim's actions could not be left unanswered, yet it is clear to me he has been traumatized to the point that he thinks girls have magic powers and are out to get him. The best way I could deal with this is the classic 'were-girl' curse?"

Tim will be perfectly his, or rather her normal self in girl form, and would hopefully see girls aren't the horrors he perceived us to be. I will be warning him of this curse before the initial transformation, and necessary way to break the curse should he desire it."

"Am I going with you?' you asked in a way that meant you demanded that she took you.

"No, Lucy. Even though you're the aggrieved party in all this, you're still a Witchbloom schoolgirl" Elvira said, moments before she vanished.

11512112113312.content:
"What does that mean?" you said to empty space, but Elvira was gone. Stunned, and not wanting anyone to see you, you decided to wait in her office. After ten minutes, the door was flung open, revealing Paula.

"What are you doing? You're late for class" Paula demanded.

"Class? I'm not going to a class. I want answers" you said, pouting slightly.

"You're a Witchbloom student, Lu, so you have to attend a magic class. Even if you choose to be non practicing, you have to know about your powers" Paula said as she grabbed your hand.

"Wait. Why do I have to be here at all" you demanded.

"I wouldn't leave, if I were you. The school has an enchantment. Oh nothing too bad" Paula said, seeing your panicked face. "Anyone present on school grounds is enrolled as a student unless they have special permission. It kind of gives us a bit of privacy. If a student leaves without permission, it's their choice, but they'll be stuck in whatever form they're in. For you, me and my sister, that is not an issue."

'Then why are you still here?" you demanded.

"Jacinta has nowhere else to go, and I want to learn about magic" Paula said.

"You want to learn about this stuff?" you said, surprised.

"Yeah. partly because I want to protect myself, and trust me there are plenty of people out there that shouldn't have magic powers. Partly, because once you get over the girl thing, you'll realize these sort of abilities are cool."

"O-kay" you said in disbelief as Paula dragged you into a classroom. Inside, there were four other students, but you only recognized the slumped figure of Jacinta." The teacher was a woman in her thirties and had a slight frown on her face.

"You're late, miss Harrison" the teacher said.
11512112113312.title: Your first magic class

115121121133121.content:
"I was forced to come here!" Snapping, you countered. "You get what you pay for!"

The class fell silent, all of the other girls looked at you in shock and disbelief. However, the teacher, Miss Clara Jennings, raised a single eyebrow before giving you a bemused smile. "No one is forcing you to stay." Softly, she said. "The doors are not locked."

"If I leave, I'm a girl for life." More softly, you said. "Some insane safeguard, so I hear. So, yeah, I am forced to stay here if I want to be a boy again."

"There is far more to this than you can possibly realize, young lady." Patiently, Clara said. "What magical topic most interests you?"

"Gender spells." Firmly, you said. "The faster I can change back the better."

Clara grinned. "Well, that is a two week course in itself." Calmly, she explained. "Not to mention the age regression and progression lessons which take another two weeks of study. Then, there is the clothing change spells which take another..."

"Okay!, Okay!" Quickly, you yelled, "I get it!"

Clara giggled at your frustration, annoying you more. "Your mother sent Hayley here to learn magic so she can help her train her two daughters." Turning serious, she said. "Do you seriously think this school offers such courses for free?"

"Mom is paying to send me here?" Disturbed, you asked.

Clara nodded. "It's not as expensive as college but its not cheap either." Now frowning, Clara said. "There are witches who can not afford to go here so their mother must train them as best they can. Be grateful you are not learning magic as a play-toy to your sisters."

You gulped. "Since you put it that way... I apologize for being late." Timidly, you said.

Clara smiled. "Your apology is accepted, Miss Harrison." Kindly, she said. She then turned to the class. "This was your first lesson in magic, girls. The reason transformed boys are sent here is not to make them girls for life but to give them that choice to make on their own."

The class quickly became uncomfortable the moment Jacinta voiced her opinions about Clara's truthfulness.

"Yeah? If that is the case, why not have a live example of gender spells? Transform me into a guy" Jacinta challenged.

After five minutes of explaining and counter-arguing with your dorm's most bitter resident, Clara was forced into a humiliating backdown. "Okay, I admit it. There is no choice for you, young lady. Elvira said...
1151211211331212.title: After class, Elvira returns.

11512112113312122.content:
You stared at Elvira, stunned. "Are you saying that I don't have a choice?"

Elvira shook her head. "We all have a choice, Lucy." Firmly but kindly, she said. "In regards to gender, Jacinta has no way back to her male self because her magic is now too powerful."

"You lost me." Confused, you said.

"Her magic needs an outlet and her male self is not strong enough to contain it." Patiently, Elvira said. "True, Jack's mother made him Jacinta against her will. However, she allowed her anger to get the best of her, increasing her magic's power." She frowned. "Jacinta was warned that strong emotions augment magic but ignored it; she had made her choice."

"What does that have to to with me, nervous, you demanded.

Elvira looked at you darkly. "You were born into one of the most magically powerful families in existence, Lucy; do the math."

You paled considerably. You felt your knees weaken and Elvira summoned a chair behind you for you to fall backwards into. "I didn't have a choice from the start..." Mumbling, you moaned.

"Of course you had a choice." Flatly, Elvira said. "You were simply too angry and bull headed to listen to the warnings." She frowned at you. "Reap what you sew, Lucy Harrison."

"What are my choices from here?" Tearing up, you asked.

Elvira shrugged. "It's simple, really. Once you graduate from here, you can either be an active witch or a 'normal' teenage girl marching into womanhood." She sighed, releasing her frustrations with you. "Does it really matter what gender you are, child? I would think that all that really matters is what lies within."

This caused you to think for a moment before a tiny smile formed onto your face. Elvira smiled with you, glad that she had finally chipped away at least a piece of your wall of stubbornness. "Think it over, Lucy." More softly, she said. "Once you really begin to discover magic, you will find your situation less of a curse and more of a blessing."

With that, she walked you out and had a prefect escort you back to your dorm. Once you were gone, she turned to her secretary. "She has a lot of her father in her." Shaking her head, she said. "Still, I believe I finally got through to her."

"Do you think she'll embrace her femininity?" Raising an eyebrow, the secretary asked.

Elvira giggled. "I doubt it; not for a long while." She sighed. "I think now she will be hitting the books hard to find a way back her her old self. Only when she realizes it is a futile effort will she truly embrace her new true form."

11512112113312122111.title: Hayley.

1151211211331212211112.title: On the warpath

Upon entering your dorm, Jacinta immediately noticed the rage and tears in your eyes and the fact you were still wearing the cheer uniform rather than the school uniform. She sighed but remained silent for the time being as she listened to you rant.

"That Hayley..." Fuming, you muttered. "I won't be a girl forever, she and grandma can forget it!"

You barely hear her, you were too angry with your entire situation. Jacinta watched you grab your spare uniform, which Hayley fortunately did not touch, and stormed into the bathroom, slamming the door, shaking the walls of the room. You came out of the bathroom, grabbed the dorm phone, which everyone had to share, and stormed back into the bathroom, closing the door. Jacinta sobbed slightly, hearing you begging to mom to be brought back home, promising a number of things in return to just being 'John' again. Jacinta sighed, again shaking her head. "Bargaining. That's stage three." She sighed then sarcastically muttered, "Yeah, I got far with that one."

Turning to a letter she had received that day, Jacinta freely began to cry. It was a formal letter from the witch courts, concerning her and Paula's mother. It read....

To Jacinta and Paula,

Before Hayley could act, a tall, well dressed woman with long blond hair and wild hazel eyes, your aunt Sarah, gently took your hand and pulled you into a warm hug. "It's been years, John." Softly, she said. "I heard all about the troubles you've been enduring, I'm so sorry..."

"Can you get me out of this, aunt Sarah?" Tearing up, you asked. "I don't like being a little girl..."

Sarah giggled. "No boy does, young man." Bemused, she said. "Just as no girl likes to be a boy but they are transformed during their training to get a taste of what it is like."

"I need to get out of here." Crying, you said. "This is all driving me crazy."

"Have you considered the fact that, once you know magic, you can change yourself back?" Smiling, Sarah asked. "Or were you too frustrated and annoyed to think of it?"

"I was told I can't be changed back." Confused, you said.

"That's true because it's illegal to do so." Simply, Sarah said.

Now you were really confused. "You- You lost me..."

Sarah laughed kindly. "Witch born boys and girls both have power." Calmly, she explained. "Girls have magic and boys have heightened physical attributes and senses. Understand so far?"

You nodded though you were not sure where aunt Sarah was going with her reasoning. "Go on."

"Upon becoming a girl, you lost all of those heightened attributes and senses so you became weaker and slower." Serious, Sarah said. "Also, everything became quieter and softer. It is quite unnerving; am I right?"

You were crying freely at this point. "You have no idea..."

Aunt Sarah offered you a tissue, which you accepted. "On the same coin, you gained magical power strong enough to shatter the forces that were keeping you male." Serious, she said. "For anyone else to change you back there is the risk that the change will not last and that will lead to even greater physical and psychological damage. Only you can change yourself back as it takes both magic and will to make it work."

"I- I guess that makes sense." Wincing, you said.

Sarah smiled. "It is not the fact you became a girl that is the real issue, John." Softly, she said. "It's the fact you lost your powers and were offered a power you know nothing about." She paused then asked, "Would you like to know why you are really here?"

You nodded as the question had plagued your mind since you were sent to the school. "Okay, aunt Sarah; I'll bite." Frowning, you said. "Why am I really here?"

"The boy of a witch family is sort of an early warning system and a guardian against normal threats such as burglars or bullies." Serious, Sarah said. "An intruding witch will change that boy into a girl to disorient her and possibly use her as a shield as she would not know magic. She then would try to change any young witches into boys as they would not know how to use their physical powers."

This caused you to think. "So boys and girls have to learn how to use the powers of both genders?" Taken back, you asked. "That's messed up, aunt Sarah."

"Perhaps but it helps to keep a witch family safe." Serious, Sarah said. "No one wants to see you permanently changed because it is the boys who carry the witch gene." She then smiled as she ruffed up your hair and added, "So, do try not to be so bull headed and just learn magic. You will have the chance to change yourself back, if you really want to, upon graduation."

You giggled slightly then asked. "Why wasn't this explained to me like this earlier?"

"You didn't read the school literature." Lightly scolding, Sarah replied. "It is all there."

This caused you to blush brightly as Hayley was smiling in the background. "You got to love aunt Sarah." Bemused, she thought. "She can talk an Eskimo into buying an ice machine." She then asked out loud, "Are you ready to go back to your dorm, sis?"


You turned to Hayley, still blushing. "Yeah, I'm ready." Timidly, you said. "Sorry for the trouble."

Hayley giggled. "You are nothing compared to a few transformed boys I met in my year here." Smiling, she said. "One of them literally tried to escape by jumping from one rooftop to another and ended up falling through the roof into Elvira's office."

You winced at that as it was your plan to do that as well. "That had to have been awkward."

Hayley shook her head. "Come on, sis." Calmly, she said. "I'll teach you how to heighten your senses with magic so you don't go completely insane."

As Hayley escorted you back to your dorm, talking about magic, Sarah took a cell phone out of her pocket and dialed a number. "I got Lucy to calm down and go back to her dorm, Elvira." Smiling, she said. "She may try to cram her studies to graduate early though."

On the other line, Elvira sighed. "She's almost as bad as 'Jackie' was." Weary, she said. "Thank you for the help, Sarah."

Sarah smiled. "Not a problem, Elvira." Calmly, she said. "With some girls its just a matter of pushing the right buttons."

Later on, your teacher, Lucy gave a bemused smile seeing you...

12122111.title: Hayley calls your friends to help with the reno...

choices: I think your mom is bringing it in.
It wasn't given time to pack.
121221111.content:
"Well, its a time honored tradition in our family but it is very rarely discussed outside of the household." Wincing slightly, Hayley replied. She gave Harry and Megan a genuine smile. "We trust you guys but this is something that can only be revealed when mom feels the time is right."

Harry slowly nodded. "I think I understand." Honestly, he said. "My folks are always away for weeks at a time and they told me the same thing." He then imitated his father's voice. "When the time is right, we will tell you and not a moment before."

Hayley giggled slightly. "Joanie here is just as much in the dark as you guys are." Smiling, she said. "Only she's pouting because she thinks John will be furious if we tamper with his room and personal belongings."

Harry chuckled, making you blush slightly. "Don't worry, kid." Amused, he said. "I know John. He will be annoyed to find everything taken out of his room but not furious."

"He'll get over it, though." Smiling, Megan added. "Just as long as nothing is lost or broken." she knelt down to your level. "No offense but I'm sure he'd rather you not touch his things anyway. It's best to put it all in storage until he comes back."

"Where did he go, anyway?" Curious, Harry asked. "Can we at least know that?"

"Oh, he's not far." Shrugging, Hayley replied. "Neither was I, really. I was just too busy studying to write any of you and, like I said, it sort of stays in the immediate family."

"You mean learning this time honored tradition." Guessing, Megan said. "I take it that its John's turn to learn about it all."

Hayley discretely eyed you. "I was not happy with having to leave without saying anything and neither was John." Honestly, she said. "I learned later on the importance of it. I can only hope John will soon learn that importance as well."

You sighed wearily, blushing brightly. "Well, I guess if John gets everything back when he returns..."

Hayley hugged you warmly. "Thank you for understanding, Joanie." Releasing you, she said. "Did you bring in your luggage?"

You looked up at Hayley to find that she was being mischievous again. Somehow, you sensed that your answer would determine the style of your new wardrobe for at least the next six months.

After a brief thought, you replied...
121221111.title: Hayley tells a half truth

choices: you head downstairs to complain, but you found Mel reading the magic book
1212211113.content:
"... I wasn't given time to pack. All I've got is what I'm wearing" you replied, figuring it were the best option. While it meant you'd get a mall trip, you knew it wouldn't leave you as open to getting something super girly compared to saying you had lost luggage.

"That's rough" Megan said, sympathetically. "Have you got anything to wear?"

"Not really" you said. "Guess I'm going to have to go to the mall to get some new stuff. Hayley, when I'm going to go?"

"I think mom is going to take you to the mall tomorrow, Joanie" Hayley said.

"Why not now?" you asked, hoping to prevent your room from being torn apart. Even if you could manipulate one of them to take you, you knew it would be enough to wreck Hayley's plans. Plus you hated the idea of having mom buying your outfits for the next six months.

"I can't take you, Joanie, because I need to get your new room ready for you. I need to push all the furniture away from the walls so they can be repainted. It should dry fairly quick" Hayley said.

"I'm okay with being in this room, Hayley" you said, uncomfortably staring at her. You knew that the only paint Hayley had was a light pink paint that was recently used for Hannah's room. Both Megan and Harry knew it too.

"I don't think it's quite her style, Hayley" Harry warned as he eyed you pouting. Neither he or Megan saw that Hayley had teleported in the paint cans.

"Maybe, but could you imagine John's reaction? I've already got the paint. Think mom placed them in here" Hayley said with a slight laugh. That seemed to settle things, and you helplessly watched as your bedroom walls were painted a light pink. The thing that made it worse, was the eagerness of both Megan and Harry. It was almost a relief when they left, though you knew that over the weekend, they'd be back to finish off the job.
1212211113.title: No time to pack.

choices: Later, you see your new room.
Megan visists with some of her old clothes.
12122111131.content:
You glared at Hayley who merely shrugged. "I know... you'll make me pay for this." Bemused, she said.

You huffed and turned on your heel as you marched out of the room and down the stairs. Upon nearing the sitting room, you saw mom in the hall and hurried over to her to complain about Hayley's actions. Only she hushed you quiet and pointed into the sitting room. Curious, you peered in to see Mel looking into the same magic book you had found earlier. There was a hint of excitement in her smile as she read through the pages, making you feel nervous. Mom quietly ushered you into the next room and knelt down to your level.

"Why are you doing this to me?" Pouting, you demanded.

"I'm not doing this to hurt you." Firmly, mom said. "I'm sure Hayley explained some of this to you."

"She said that magic was addictive and opening the book would have made me her sister for life." Sourly, you said. "Still, she doesn't have to..."

"Change John's room?" Interrupting you, mom asked. She giggled slightly. "Actually, yes. She does."

"Why?" Frustrated, you demanded.

"Magic is a powerful and useful tool in the hands of a trained witch." Patiently, mom explained. You noticed she emphasized the word 'trained'. "However, in the hands of an untrained witch, it can be a dangerous force." She smiled flatly. "Mel tends to be overly bossy when offered any authoritative power. She would be tempted to toy with John... if he were here."

Your eyes widened slightly. "You're hiding me from her?"

"Mel needs to be trained but its not necessary to send her away with two trained witches to guide her." Softly, mom said. "However, temptations will slow down that training. As Hannah and Joanie are too young to know magic, she is forbidden to reveal it to either one."

"So I have to hide in plain sight until Mel is trained?" Worried, you asked. "Perfect!"

"It's a bit more complicated than that." Grinning, mom said. "You also have to fool everyone into believing you are our visiting cousin, Joanie." Her smile vanished. "If you think your current situation is bad, consider Mel trying to change you back to normal. Worse, toy with you with a lack of proper training."

You gulped, imagining the possibilities, none were pretty. "Just six months?" Wincing, you asked.

Mom nodded. "I know it won't be easy, Joanie. However, it is better than the alternative." She rose to her feet and offered her hand. "Come along now. It's time for dinner."
12122111131.title: Mom offers some advice.

Mom wakes you up for school.
121221111313.content:
As you reluctantly walked to the dinning room with mom, a knock came to the door. Mom changed course, taking you with her and answered. Standing at your doorstep was Megan with a large box in her arms.

"Hello, Megan." Politely, mom said. "What's in the box?"

"Sorry for coming over so late, Ms H." Smiling, Megan said. "I really felt sorry for Joanie having to spend a good amount of her vacation money on clothes so I figured she could use some of my old hand me downs. Many of them are still in style."

You shyly smiled at your friend and eyed the box nervously. Megan was as much a princess as Hannah was when she was around seven. Mom smiled kindly and accepted the box. "Thank you, dear." Sweetly, she said. "That was very thoughtful of you." She turned to you, grinning.

You rewarded Megan with a shy smile, though you felt like screaming. "Thank you, Megan... You didn't have to go though all the trouble."

"Oh, no trouble at all." Genuinely happy, Megan replied. "These clothes are not exactly tomboyish but there is no harm in looking pretty."

"I agree completely." Smiling, mom said. "I was about to have that discussion with Joanie over dinner." She gave you a discrete wink. "It won't hurt you to be more feminine every now and then."

After Megan had left, mom began to pull out the clothes. As you feared, they were mostly skirts and dresses with white tights, a few pairs of mary janes, and an assortment of frilly undergarments. Sighing, you commented, "She has a good heart..."

Mom smiled. "Yes, she does." Softly, she replied. "John is lucky to have her."

You smiled at that but instantly panicked, blushing brightly as mom pulled out a schoolgirl uniform. "You aren't going to send me to school, are you? I'm on 'vacation'!"

Mom giggled. "Nice try, young lady." Amused, she said."You are going to school tomorrow; its all a part of the experience and besides, I can't play favorites." She then called everyone to the dinning room and added, "Remember to stay in character, Joanie."

Later the next day...
121221111313.title: Megan tries to help.

1212211113131.content:
... you woke up, hoping that everything were a unpleasant and weird dream, but one glance at your now light pink walls told you otherwise. Worse, there had been significant changes since you'd went to sleep. Before, the only thing that had been done was the pink painting of your room. Now, it was decorated, with posters of princesses. Even your bed now had a pink, princess theme, though the actual bed frame itself was still normal. You were so stunned, you didn't, at first, notice Hayley watching you, looking pleased with herself, and a very tired looking Mel.

"What happened to my room?" you said to yourself.

"We thought we'd pretty it up for you" Hayley said, causing you to jump.

"W-what?" you stammered.

"We continued to do some renovations while you were asleep" Hayley said.

'I see" you said, knowing exactly what would had happened. Hayley had given Mel a magic lesson whilst you were sleeping, but made sure it was something that was possible. That said, you had no idea how much of it was Mel's doing, as both seemed to want to girlify you a bit. "Can you leave me to get ready. Aunt Natalie told me I have school" you said sourly.

"I'll help her get ready" Hayley said to Mel. While Mel looked disappointed, she obeyed and left your room. Once alone, you turned on your sister.

"What are you doing to me?" you demanded.

"Safety precautions. I can't have you telling Ms Ditz your secret, Joanie" Hayley giggled. "That spell will wear off soon."

"But my room..." you said, outraged.

"It was a little plain, sis. We should have it all done by the weekend"

"I don't want a pink, girly room" you pouted as Hayley walked over to your still normal wardrobe and started taking some clothes from it. "Hey! What are you doing?"

"Like what I told Mel. Getting you ready for your day at kindergarten" Hayley said as she held out a pale blue dress and white tights.
1212211113131.title: You wake up in your girlified room.

choices: Tim wanting to meet his cousin.
12122111131311.content:
You sighed, fuming as mom walked you into the kindergarten class at your school. The blue dress and tights you were wearing were not uncomfortable. Still, it was not something you were used to and you could not stop blushing. Looking around, you saw and heard the other children excitedly talking and giggling among themselves. You then saw the teacher, a short, plump woman approaching you and mom.

"I can't believe I'm doing this!" Hissing under your breath, you muttered.

"Its better than sulking at home all day." Whispering, mom replied. "At least here, you'll be kept busy." She giggled, adding, "And out of mischief."

"Who is this little cutie?" Smiling, the teacher asked.

"This is my niece, Joanie Harrison." Returning the smile, mom replied. "She's a bit of a tomboy; I'm trying to get her to come out of her shell."

The teacher giggled, making you blush more. "Well, I'm Deedee Vane." Kneeling to your level, she said. "Everyone calls me De."

You shyly smiled, though you felt like screaming. "Hi."

"I can see you are a little shy." Maintaining her smile, De said. "Don't worry, once you get used to wearing a dress, you'll see its not such a big deal. It's looks very pretty on you."

You winced slightly. "Um... thanks."

"Well, I can see Joanie is in good hands here." Grinning, mom said. "I will pick you up after school, Joanie; be a good little girl."

She giggled and walked out, leaving you with the kindergarten class. It was not as bad as you had originally feared. De acknowledged that you were surprisingly intelligent for your age. Fortunately, you stayed in character, leading her to believe you were not emotionally ready to skip any classes. The last thing you wanted was to end up a tiny girl in high school; you knew how mean students could be.

Finally, it came time for recess. The kindergarten class was kept removed from the higher classes but it did not stop some students to come over and visit during their lunch. You were reluctantly playing with a few of the other students when a familiar face approached you and the other kids.
12122111131311.title: at kindergarten

121221111313113.content:
"What are you doing here?" you demanded, as you saw Hayley's approach.

"I wanted to see how you're setting in. I know how it's like to be the new girl, Joanie" Hayley said.

"I don't need you checking up on me" you said, eying some of the other students. They were all girls, as at your supposed age, none of the boys wanted to play with you. They were the more physical ones, preferring to jump rope, and you saw it as the least bad option. You certainly didn't want to spend your break talking whatever little girls talked about, or playing with dolls.

"Okay, miss grumpy" Hayley teased.

Frowning, you walked towards your sister to somewhere quiet, and out of hearing range of the others. "Why are you really here?"

"I told you, Joanie. I wanted to see if you're okay. I thought you might have blown your top by now" Hayley said.

"I haven't even though this is so boring. What to you expect?" you snapped.

"So who are your friends?"

"The one with the bow in her hair is Penny and the one with the braid is Amber... I think" you said. Hayley shook her head which you took as disapproval of your inattention. Naturally, your temper exploded. "You've been away for a year yourself and you're sticking your nose into what I do? If I'm going to be stuck here, I'm going to be a tomboy and keep to myself."

Hayley raised her hands defensively. "Okay. I get it. You feel awkward. I'll leave you in peace."

Later on after kindergarten had ended for the day, you were picked up by mom. "Aren't you going to drive the girls?" you asked, surprised that you were the only passenger.

"Hayley told me about kindergarten. I got you a present in the bag" mom said.

"What bag...." you said as a brown bag materialized next to your booster seat. "I see. Hannah can't see your trick and Mel cannot know that I know about magic. So what is in the bag?"

"Open it" mom urged. Reaching from the seat, you opened the bag and found...

Your face turned red with embarrassment as you pulled out a pink one piece costume with matching tights and ballet flats. "Mo- err Aunt Natalie!" Irritated, you whined. "This is Hannah's ballet costume!"

"Not quite." Grinning, mom said. "It's a gymnastic leotard."

"Why did you get me this?" Morbidly curious, you asked.

"Hannah had asked me why you were avoiding her." Calmly, mom replied. "I told her you had asked me the same thing." She giggled. "Hannah suggested she could teach you some ballet moves at home."

"Of course, you thought it was a good idea." Rolling your eyes, you said.

"You need an outlet, something to keep you busy while Hayley and I train Mel." Maintaining her smile, mom said. "That and Hannah will be tickled to be the 'big sister' for a while." She laughed. "Think of it as a bonding experience."

You sighed, holding the costume up against yourself. "You're not going to use any of this to blackmail me later, are you?" Wincing, you asked.

Mom laughed harder, causing you to worry. "Is that your biggest worry?" Amused, she asked. She shook her head. "Any pictures we take will show Joanie, not 'John in drag'."

This was a great relief to you. Mom saw your relief and giggled. "We do not want any distractions while we train Melanie. John is a distraction."

You screamed, suddenly finding yourself wearing the gymnastic leotard as mom pulled into the garage. "Aunt Natalie...!"

Mom grinned as she pulled you out of the boaster seat to meet Hannah who looked at you as if all of her birthdays had come at once. "You really want to learn ballet!?"

"She couldn't put the costume on fast enough." Winking at you, mom said.

You threw mom an irritated glare before Hannah hugged you, nearly taking the wind out of your lungs. "Thank you, Joanie!" Happily, Hannah said. "You are going to love Ballet, I just know it!"

"I can't wait." Forcing a smile, you said.

Play nice, girls." Giggling, mom said as Hannah dragged you up to her room. "I'll have Hayley fetch you when dinner is ready."

As soon as you were in Hannah's room, being taught/tormented with ballet moves, Mel went to mom. "Now that the girls are busy, I can ask a few questions. Where is John?"

"Your brother is in a safe place, and no, I will not tell you where he is. I know you, Melanie Harrison and I will not jeopardize this family or your training just because you desire a female twin. John will, of course, learn about us and the best way to deal with us" mom said sternly.

"My dolly" you said, though internally your mind were screaming. What!? I didn't want to say that. Mom, you witch....

"You have a favorite doll?" Surprised, Mel asked. "I pegged you as being a total tomboy."

"Didn't your mom teach you?" Curious, Hannah asked.

1212211113131132213.title: Staying in character.

12122111131311322133.content:
"Finally" you muttered, as kindergarten finished for week. While you weren't looking forward to the weekend as it meant that the Hayley would finish what she had started and remainder of your room would be girlified, you were looking forward to getting home, away from the other little girls who wanted to play with you, and out of the dress that mom had placed you into. Masquerading as your non existent, tomboy five year old cousin sucked.

"Glad that kindergarten is over, Joanie?" mom asked as soon as you reached her car.

"Yes, aunt Natalie" you said, pleased that only Hannah was around. While your little sister was still extremely annoying, trying to introduce you to more girlish things, and trying to get you to reconsider the fact you wanted to do gymnastics instead of ballet, her presence meant mom couldn't do any magic. For some reason, Hannah was pouting in her booster seat, like if something bad had happened.

"What's wrong with her?" you asked as mom strapped you into a booster seat or your own.

Before mom could answer, Hannah blurted out. "Timmy the toad is coming"

"What?" you said, but mom lightly chided Hannah, "I know you don't like him, but you shouldn't call him that, Hannah. Joanie, but you're going to be introduced to the rest of the family."

"Why don't you like him? Is he the only other one? Will Melanie and Hayley be around?" you asked, trying to stay in character.

Again, Hannah cut in. "Timmy calls me princess cootiehead. He's the gross one!" Hannah whined, which caused you to smile slightly, which fortunately Hannah didn't see. "He also has this disgusting frog that he carries around and likes to put it on my dress."

"He has a frog? Nice" you said, trying to reinforce the idea of Joanie being a tomboy.

Mom smiled to herself, as she decided to step in. "Tim isn't your only cousin, Joanie. There's Brooke. She's ten and I think you're going to like her. As for Mel and Hayley, they're currently at the mall."

You sat silently, knowing that Mel and Hayley were either playing with magic to get you the most girlish gift they could or actually doing it for real. After ten minutes, you were back home, but somehow, your aunt Catherine, and her two kids had somehow beat you home.
12122111131311322133.title: Your cousins come for a visit.

"Hello, Natalie." Politely, Catherine said. "We heard that John is taking a leave of absence and that you are hosting our brother in law's daughter."

Mom grinned as she released you from the boaster seat and put you onto your feet before getting Hannah out of hers. "I'm sure you remember Joanie, Catherine." Calmly, mom said. "She is staying with us while Paul and Marsha work out their marital issues and perhaps save their marriage."

Paul Harrison was your father's brother whom you knew was having issues with his wife. Only they did not have any children that you were aware of. Of course, you had not seem or heard from either of them in over five years so it was plausible. That was what you had based your cover story on. Mom and aunt Catherine were clearly running with it.

"Just great!" Interrupting your thoughts, Tim said. "Another princess cootie-head."

You turned to find Tim staring at you with a disgusted look on his face. He moved to touch your face but you saw that his hands were coated with mud and dodged him with an elegant turn, moving your arms to avoid his grasp. All the while, you were grinning at him. "It is not polite to touch a lady without her permission, cousin Tim." Sternly, you stated. "Besides, your hands are filthy."

Hannah, who was standing behind you smiled excitedly. "Joanie, you just performed all five foot and arm positions beautifully!" Happily, she yelled. "You do know ballet!"

You blushed horribly as mom and Catherine giggled. Hannah ran up to you, ignoring Tim. She in fact almost bowled him over in her haste to get to you. "Hey!" Protesting, he yelled.

"Why won't you try it?" Pouting, she demanded.

"Mommy made me learn." Pouting back you countered. "It's not me. I prefer gymnastics."

"You don't like ballet?" Surprised, Tim asked. He chuckled. "Maybe there is hope for you yet."

"Does this... boy have a mute button?" Irritated, you blurted out.

A familiar voice giggled and you saw Brooke approaching. "We wish." Smiling, she said. "I'm Brooke. Mommy told me that you'd be staying with aunt Natalie for a while. It's good to meet you, Joanie."

"Same here." Smiling, you said.

"So what turned you into such a tomboy?" Curious, Brooke asked. "Our moms insist upon a no tomboy rule in their house."

You blushed further, if that was even possible. "Daddy did not have a son so..."

"He 'boyified' you!?" Shocked, Hannah and Brooke asked in unison.

You sighed, seeing mom and Catherine's increasingly amused grins. "That was their biggest fight." Forcing a tear, you said. "Dad wanted a boy and mom wanted a girl so I sort of had to be both."

Brook frowned before a rare look of determination formed on her face. "Well, you don't have to be both here, Joanie. You can be as girly as you like!"

You heard mom and Catherine stifle more giggles only Brooke and Hannah were too occupied with you to hear them. "Yeah, we'll even help you!" She turned to Brooke. "She was just dumped here, Brooke! She did not have time to pack or anything! She couldn't even get to bring her favorite dolly!"

"She can have some of your old clothes!" Suddenly excited, Brooke declared. "I know you have some very, very pretty dresses and bright shinny shoes she can wear!"

Without another word, Brooke and Hannah took hold of one of your arms and half dragged, half carried you into the house leaving Tim standing alone and very much confused. "Am I missing something here?" Bewildered, he asked himself.

Mom shook her head, amused. "No, Tim." Smiling, she said. "I think you just met your match."

Catherine giggled then walked into the house with mom with Tim following, still feeling confused.

Later on...

They quickly got you out of your school clothes, apologizing for not doing it sooner, and into Hannah's old, and long since outgrown princess costumes, painted your nails pink, and were in the process of adding some of Hannah's costume jewellery to your neck, wrists and ears.

You sighed, wanting to say you had enough for now but you found yourself asking, "You have make up?"

Hannah followed your stare to her vanity and giggled. "Of course I do, silly. Don't you?"

You pouted, inwardly fuming. "Mom...." After a sigh, you decided it best just to roll with the punches as mom or whoever was pushing your buttons was forcing you to stay in character. "Daddy never let me touch the stuff."

Brooke pouted, a hint of annoyance in her voice. "Because he wanted a boy, even though you are a girl."

Hannah suddenly smiled. "Well, that's too bad!" She giggled. "Mom has a no tomboy rule and she is always telling me that she can't play favorites."

"That's right!" Suddenly excited, Brooke said. "Her dad can't get mad at her for following the rules of her host's household!"

Hannah and Brooke giggled excitedly together, making you worry. "What are you going to do?"

Hannah and Brooke smiled kindly at you before Hannah replied, "We are going to give you a makeover!"

"You can't do that!" Startled, you yelled. You paused then more softly said, "Daddy would be mad at me."

"What is he going to do?" Grinning, Brooke challenged. "Spank you?"

"I- I don't know." Tearing up, you replied. "He just keeps telling me that make up is not me."

"I bet he told you ballet is not you either." Serious, Hannah stated.

The stress of making yourself someone else, you began to sob silently, wanting a break from it all. You knew why you had to be in hiding but it was not easy for you. Brooke and Hannah pulled you into a warm group hug before Hannah grabbed her phone and sent a text.

-My cousin, Joanie is very sad, I need help with her.-

Who did she send the text to?

121221111313113221331221.content:
Mom was sitting, talking to Catherine when she received the text from Hannah. As she looked at it, she gave a sigh.

"What is it?" Catherine asked.

"Joanie is sad. Want to bet that our daughters have pushed Joanie too far with all the girl's stuff?" mom said.

"Probably.. You know how obsessed Hannah is with princesses and ballet, and Brooke is somewhere between that and Mel. Poor Joanie is probably in a pink leotard or princess dress right now. What do you want to say?" Catherine asked.

Mom paused for a few minutes, before she texted back to Hannah

-Don't try and force Joanie into anything. If she wants to do gymnastics and play video games, it's fine. She is going through some big changes and pressuring her won't help. Just be a friend. Mom-

After she had sent it, she shook her head. "Hannah is definitely going to come and talk to me about this" she muttered.

However, you were the one that saw mom first. "Looking good, niece" mom said, as she eyed your pink clad frame. You weren't as cheerful as her, as Hannah and Brooke had, before mom's text put a stop to it, placed you into a pink dress, pink gloves and had given you a really bad makeover."

"I've had enough, mom. If I'm going to get tortured, I'd rather be tortured by that ditzy bimbo than that princess obsessed.... cootie head" you snapped.

"Don't talk about your sisters like that" mom demanded.

"Whatever. As for you, what are you doing? You made me talk like a little girl" you demanded. You didn't know which were worse; Tim's reaction to your makeover, or Mel's and Hayley's. Both were unpalatable to you.

"I have my reasons, but I'll make it clear. I'm not here to 'torture' you, nor do I want you to stay. Of course, should you choose to stay, that is different, but I'm not after a fourth daughter. Hannah was concerned for you after your little breakdown.

"What do you know about that?" you demanded, suspecting mom was spying on you.

"Hannah was concerned and texted me" mom said. She smiled and continued, "But enough about that. Time for you bath. You have a big day tomorrow, princess."

You gave a faux cheer as you got ready for bed

1212211113131132213312211.content:
Upon entering your room after a lavender bath, you discovered several new items in your girlified room. There was a small makeup kit resting on your vanity, a ballet poster hanging on your wall next to a gymnastics poster, and a small stake of ballet books and videos on your activity table.

"What is all this junk?" Annoyed, you demanded.

Mom sighed as she closed the door. "If I am going to keep you hidden and safe from a permanent transformation into girlhood, I need a little more cooperation from you, young lady!" Hissing, she scolded. "When Hannah and Brooke look at you, they see a very lost and confused little girl whose father is trying to make act like a boy!" She paused before more calmly adding, "You made up that cute little cover story on your own, by the way."

You sighed. "Open mouth and insert foot." Glumly, you muttered.

Mom shrugged. "Live and learn." Sternly, she countered. "I warned you at the very beginning that this won't be easy for you. However, you need to try not to fight fight so much."

"What do you expect from me then." Pouting, you asked. "I don't want to like this and..."

"Stay a girl forever?" Serious, mom asked. "As long as you don't toy with magic, that will not happen. Normal girls do what Hannah and Brooke are offering you every day of the week. Is it really going to kill you to at least try to ease into your part?"

You moaned, pouting. "I guess not..."

Mom's face softened. "The makeup washes off, the ballet lessons only last about four hours, and you have already proved that you can wear dresses without freaking out."

"I just need a break every now and then to be myself." Tearing up, you said.

Mom thought for a moment then said, "How about I take you to the park for an hour each day to unwind?"

"What will I do there?" Wincing, you asked.

Mom smiled. "Read a book, fly a kite, be more yourself for a while. Can you live with that?"

Reluctantly, you nodded. "It's a start."

Mom smiled. "Good. I will tell Hannah and Brooke you will sit and watch one of their practices Monday after school."

This caught you completely off guard. "What!?"

Mom giggled. "You will only be watching." Amused, she said. "However, I bet you a sign up against double your allowance when John returns that you won't be able to resist dancing with them before class ends on Monday."

"No magic, mo, err Aunt Natalie." Frowning, you demanded.

Mom shook her head. "I won't need to." Cryptically, she said. "Is it a bet?"

121221111313113221331221123.content:
After reluctantly dawning the dress, Mel stepped forward with the pink ribbons. "You are going to look adorable in pigtails." Gushing, she said.

You frowned, annoyed. "Don't even try it!"

A tiny flame appeared in your hand, reacting to your growing frustrations. You let out a short scream, seeing it but quickly closed your hand. The flame thankfully went out and you put your hand behind your back hoping Mel did not see. Unfortunately, Mel looked at you in shock then slowly began to smile; she saw the flame in your hand. "You- You didn't see that!" Lamely, you said.

"Yes, I saw that." Smiling, Mel said. "That was a flame test. You have magic!"

"You did not see that!" Stomping one foot, you insisted. "There is no such thing as magic! Mommy and daddy told me so!"

You did not know what mom would do if she found out a flame had ignited in your hand while stuck as a little girl so you decided to try to get Mel to keep what she saw a secret. Only you were not sure how.

"My mom told me there was no such thing as magic when I was your age too." Kindly, Mel said. "When my flame first appeared, I screamed just as you did. Mom then told me the truth..."

"I'm not a freak or some monster!" Imitating one of Hannah's tantrums, you yelled. "I- I..." You began to shed real tears and honestly added, "I'm scared, okay!?"

Mel sighed and knelled down closer to your level. "I was scared too, kiddo." Gently, she said. "I know your dad wants you to act more like a boy and you are trying to please him." She paused, trying to remember her own lessons. "You need to keep in mind that emotions make magic stronger so being a tomboy will not do when you have magic."

You pouted, hearing that. "I'm such an idiot!" Ruefully, you thought. "Mom wasn't kidding when she said frustrations will bring my magic closer to the surface." Finally, you let out a sigh. "What can I do? I want to be myself not what others want me to be, no matter their reasons."

Mel giggled. "Your dad wanted a boy but he had to settle for a tomboy." Smiling, she said. "Why don't you try to be a 'pretty tomboy'?"

You paused, curious. Without thinking, you asked, "A tomboy can be pretty?"

Mel laughed. "Of course, she can, you silly!" Amused, she said. "Here, let me show you."

You winced as Mel took the two pink ribbons and tied your hair in a certain way. When she was done, she turned you to face a mirror. You gaped at the single pony tail shooting out from the back of your head then gave a slight smile. "That looks better than pigtails."

Mel giggled at your reaction. "Did you know that football players took ballet as part of their training?"

You whipped around to face Mel, annoyed. "They do not!"

"Oh yes, they do." Grinning, Mel said. "How do you think they learned to gracefully hop along the line of scrimmage so they don't clumsily fall over the line?"

You opened your mouth to answer then sighed before moaning. "I guess if a football player can stomach a few ballet lessons, it won't hurt me to try..."

Mel grinned, seeing Hannah appear at the doorway with mom behind her. "So, are you saying you will sign up for ballet?" Softly, she asked.

You moaned. "I should get my head examined!" Ruefully, you thought. Then, you said, "Yeah, I'll sign up on Monday."

"What was that, Joanie?" Teasing, Mel asked.

You sighed, irritated. Before you could stop yourself, you yelled, "Yes, I'll sign up for ballet!"

Hannah screamed in delight, startling you. She up, nearly knocking you over in a hug. "I knew you would come around, Joanie!" Happily, she chirped. "This will be so much fun!"

Mom chuckled before turning to Mel. "I'm glad someone finally got through to her." Pleased, she said. "Maybe now, she will relax and let herself be a little girl for a while."

You gave a nervous giggle then discretely threw Mel a dirty look. "Melanie is not as ditsy as she looks."

12122111131311322133122112322.content:
Mom walked into your room, closing the door behind her. She sighed, seeing you lying on your bed crying into your pillow. After casting a privacy spell so no one else will hear, she walked over and sat next to you on the bed. "I am truly sorry, John." Using your real name, she said. "I should have realized just how hard it would have been for you to act like a real little girl." She touched your shoulder. "It's too much stress for some one so young"

"I... I have magic." Sobbing, you said. "I didn't mean to let it out but..."

"Everything is going to be okay." Soothingly, mom said. "I'm going to give you a set of memories that will help you act more natural and it will include your little cover story."

Your head shot up, looking at mom with horror in your eyes but mom quickly cast a calming spell, keeping you from screaming. "What will happen to my old self?" Terrified, you whispered.

"These new memories will overlap your old ones, not replace them." Calmly, mom explained. "Once it is safe for John to return again, I will bring your old memories back to the surface."

"What will happen to the new memories?" Curious, you asked. "Will they be removed?"

Mom shook her head. "No, you will still remember your adventures as 'Joanie.', dear." Smiling, she said. "They will just be in the back of your mind and seem like nothing more than a strange dream."

You sighed, not knowing what to think but mom was not about to let you think about it. She touched your forehead with her index finger and muttered a number of strange words...

When mom was finished, she pulled her finger away and smiled. You were pouting, tears still falling from your eyes. "Melanie is a meanie!" Sobbing, you whined. "I'd look like a baby in pigtails! And she wanted to pierce my ears!"

"Mel was only teasing you when she offered to pierce your ears, Joanie." Soothingly, she said. "Also, you would not look like a baby, just irresistibly cute."

You pouted. "I don't mind getting my ears pierced, aunt Natalie." Honestly, you said. "I just rather it be done by someone who knows what they are doing." You paused then added, "No pigtails!"

Mom giggled. "You have too much stress for someone so young." Smiling, she said. "Don't worry about what your mommy or daddy might say. They are the ones fighting like infants."

You giggled at that, causing mom to smile. The new memories were working perfectly, for the moment. She smiled more as you asked, "Is it really okay if I sign up for ballet? I go back home in a few months."

"You can take all the lessons you want, Joanie." Cooing, mom replied. "Let yourself be a little girl during your visit so you can discover who you truly want to be."

You gave mom a grateful smile. "Thanks, aunt Natalie."

Mom waved her hand, dropping the privacy spell. "Why don't you tell Hannah the good news?"

You grinned before jumping off your bed and running out of the room, giggling. Mom merely shook her head, watching you acting like a true little girl. "I just hope Melanie learns as fast as Hayley did." Softly, she muttered. "I don't want John to get too used to being Joanie."
12122111131311322133122112322.title: Too much stress on someone so young.

"What did you do?" Hayley said to Mel the first moment the two girls could privately speak. That wasn't easily, as Mel was the center of attention, with her constantly talking to her guests.

"What do you mean?" Mel asked.

"You know what I meant. Joanie. She's acting more girlishly, and told us see is going to attend ballet, albeit as a spectator. To me that sounds like you put a spell on her" Hayley said.

"Wasn't me. I caught Joanie igniting a flame and I told mom. She said she was going to have a talk with a very frightened girl and for me to keep quiet about. We're totally not going to push witch stuff onto her" Mel said.

"You're reckless. Quiet meant not telling me" Hayley said, as Megan walked over.

"Hi guys. What's happening?" Megan asked cheerfully.

"Just discussing our cousin" Hayley said.

"Yeah. I noticed she seems happier. Just have just been unnerved by her move. She's a little cutie, isn't she?" Megan said.

"Yeah, but I don't think she is entirely comfortable wearing that pink dress" Hayley said with a half giggle. "excuse me. I think I should spend some time with her. It must be hard to be at a party not knowing anyone. Pity she hasn't been here long enough to make some friends of her own age" Hayley announced. She walked over to you, and motioned for you to follow. Once you were in Hayley's bedroom, she asked what happened.

"Aunt Natalie gave me a set of Joanie memories" you said.

"O-kay" Hayley said. Without warning she said in a chant-like voice, "Girlish desires will take root and sprout..."

"Don't say that!!! It sounds like a spell" you said, alarmed by Hayley's words.

Hayley started to grin. "It was or at least a fragment, but I can see what has happened. Mel caused you to panic, focusing your magic. To calm you down to prevent another magical outburst, mom gave you a Joanie persona, but has left your male side in there."

"Yep" you said girlishly.

"Okay. Which do you prefer?" Hayley said, magically producing a pair of girlish overalls. "This or your dress?"

"The overalls, but I'm not as uncomfortable wearing this as I was" you said, giving a slight twirl. Hayley giggled slightly.

"I see. Okay, I suppose I should come up with a cover. Hold still" Hayley said, as she produced a ear piercing kit. Your eyes went wide.

"I'm so glad you are coming to ballet class with me, Joanie." Gushing, Hannah said. "I just know you are going to love it once you see what we do here."

"Daddy raised me as a tomboy." Pouting, you said. "I think it's..."

You did not notice Penny, the little girl with a red bow in her hair, had sat down beside you. "Are you okay, Joanie?" Worry in her voice, Penny asked. "You're not sick, are you?"

At first, her words did not reach you; when they did, you spun around startled. Penny jumped seeing your frightful expression before becoming more worried. "You're really jumpy today, Joanie." Softly, she said. "Please talk to me. Did something happen?"

You sighed, knowing that you had to say something so you stuck to your original story. "It's kind of hard to explain." Tearing up, you said. "My family wants me out of the way for a while; they fight an awful lot."

"So you are stuck with your aunt who has a lot of different rules you are not used to." Guessing, Penny said. "I kind of know how that feels."

Penny gave you a rueful smile. "My mom and dad are divorced." Sadly, she said. "I spend six months here and six months in the next state over. Both have their own set of rules." She touched your hand, giving you a reassuring smile. "Sure, its a pain but I know that they both love me."
